DOC.HEAD: General: Mrs. Marcos, U.S. Secretly Supported Latest Coup Attempt
DOC.TEXT: A Filipino general claims former first lady Imelda Marcos and the U.S. government secretly supported a coup attempt last December that was put down with the help of American jets. Brig. Gen. Alejandro Galido made the allegations in a sworn statement released Wednesday by the Department of Justice. Galido said he was aware of plans for the Dec. 1-9 coup attempt and reported the conspiracy to Chief of Staff Gen. Renato de Villa. It was not known why the government released the statement, but it followed disclosures earlier this week that businessmen and others had supported the coup attempt. One businessman was arrested. The statement is part of a government investigation into the coup attempt, and Galido has been described by government officials quoted in newspaper reports as a government spy. There was no indication in Galido's statement why U.S. planes intervened in the coup if the United States secretly supported it. Galido said a U.S. Air Force colonel, Harold Magelo, told him in July that U.S. intelligence ``supports the overthrow'' of President Corazon Aquino. Galido said Magelo, who identified himself as a member of the Defense Intelligence Agency, promised ``to deliver ... shipments of firearms, ammunition, anti-tank missiles'' and other weapons. He also said U.S. Ambassador Nicholas Platt held a party at his home in August during which conspirators received written instructions from Brig. Gen. Edgardo Abenina, who was held at a military camp for involvement in a coup attempt in 1987. The latest attempt was launched shortly after midnight on Dec. 1, when thousands of mutineers attacked military and media facilities, seized aircraft at Villamor Air Base and staged air strikes on the presidential palace. U.S. F-4 Phantom jets from Clark Air Base flew air cover in support of government forces and prevented the mutineers from continuing their air strikes. At least 113 people were killed and more than 600 injured before rebels surrendered their last stronghold Dec. 9. Platt is in the United States on vacation. Spokeswoman Vicky Middleton said a statement would be issued later. Mrs. Aquino's spokesman, Adolfo Azcuna, said the government would not comment on Galido's statement until a presidential commission established to investigate the coup attempt submits its final report. Galido also said Mrs. Marcos supported the conspiracy and promised to pay about $475,000 to the coup plotters if she could return to the Philippines. Mrs. Marcos fled the country in 1986 after her husband, President Ferdinand Marcos, was ousted in a popular uprising. Marcos died in Hawaii in September, and Mrs. Marcos went on trial in New York City Tuesday on racketeering charges. Galido said he spoke with Mrs. Marcos several times by telephone before Marcos' death, and she urged him to press ahead with the plans so the former president could die in his homeland.

DOC.HEAD: Candlelight Vigil at Idaho Capital on Eve of Final Vote on Abortion Bill
DOC.TEXT: Abortion rights activists held a candlelight vigil late Wednesday outside the Idaho Capitol, promising to continue to fight a bill establishing the most restrictive abortion law in any state. ``This issue is not over for us,'' the Rev. James Hulett of Freedom Means Choice told more than 400 supporters on the eve of an expected final state Senate vote on the bill, which would send it to Democratic Gov. Cecil Andrus. ``We do not want government interfering in our private decisions,'' Hulett said. But while pro-choice advocates still hoped the bill would be defeated, anti-abortion activists pressed their case with Andrus, whom they see as the final link between them and the law. Both sides agreed that the bill, which would ban more than 90 percent of the 1,500 abortions performed annually in Idaho, would probably pass Thursday. ``Most people have made up their minds,'' said Kerry Uhlenkott, president of Right to Life of Idaho. ``We feel pretty confident.'' In Maryland, an anti-abortion filibuster in the state Senate entered its seventh day as both sides in the battle over an abortion bill appeared locked into positions that left little room for compromise. Idaho anti-abortion forces stepped up the pressure on Andrus to sign the bill, flooding his office with more than 2,500 calls in the past several days. The governor has declined to say what he will do when the bill reaches his desk, but earlier this week reaffirmed his opposition to abortion except in the case of rape, incest and to protect the life of the mother. Patterned on a National Right To Life model that has been rejected by other states as too restrictive, the bill makes abortion illegal except in the cases of nonstatutory rape reported within seven days, incest if the victim is under 18 years old, severe fetal deformity and a threat to the life or physical health of the mother. Some constitutional experts, including one who opposes abortion, have warned that the bill is so restrictive it will never withstand the scrutiny of the U.S. Supreme Court, costing the state hundreds of thousands of dollars to defend. That contention has been brushed aside by the bill's authors, who maintain it was carefully drafted to push the high court to the point of overturning its 1973 Roe vs. Wade decision legalizing abortion. ``We know it will be struck down'' in the lower courts, Mrs. Uhlenkott said. ``That's what we want. The Supreme Court justices have invited us to challenge Roe vs. Wade.''

DOC.HEAD: Paramount Reports `Coming to America' at Least $17 Million in Red
DOC.TEXT: The film ``Coming to America,'' the subject of a lawsuit by columnist Art Buchwald, is at least $17 million in the red, although it grossed $125 million, Paramount Pictures says. Preliminary accounting of the 1988 Eddie Murphy comedy was released Tuesday as part of Buchwald's lawsuit against the studio, which claimed the movie was based on a concept he created. A Superior Court judge ruled in January that Buchwald and partner Alain Bernheim are entitled to $250,000 plus 19 percent of the film's net profits. Under accounting by Paramount, which is appealing the decision, the film has no net profits. Buchwald says he is entitled to be paid under a contract he signed with Paramount. Paramount says similarities between Buchwald's idea and the actual film were only coincidental. Pierce O'Donnell, an attorney representing Buchwald, called Paramount's financial report misleading. ``The net profit system in Hollywood is a scam,'' he said. ``The only question is whether it's legal.'' O'Donnell could not dispute, however, that the film was still showing a deficit. According to his accounting, though, ``Coming to America'' is $11.2 million short of turning a net profit. Paramount said that as of last Dec. 31 the film has brought the studio $125 million in gross receipts, which includes film rentals, pay television deals and videocassette sales. The studio deducted $42 million in distribution fees, leaving $83 million. The studio then claimed an additional $36 million in distribution expenses, leaving $47 million. Murphy and director John Landis, who were compensated based on a percentage of the film's gross receipts, were paid $11 million combined, reducing the film's take to $36 million. From that $36 million, Paramount deducted the cost of making the film, estimated at $48 million, and interest expense of between $5 million and $6 million, placing the net loss between $17 million and $18 million. ``When some partners make profits and others are told they have an $18 million loss, something is rotten in Hollywood,'' O'Donnell said. Said Paramount attorney Chuck Diamond: ``The numbers speak for themselves. We're $17-$18 million away from breaking even.''

DOC.HEAD: Mongolian Legislature Elects New President
DOC.TEXT: The Communist-dominated legislature Wednesday elected a new president and nominated a new prime minister, key demands of pro-democracy protesters. But a government official said a draft constitutional amendment and a new election law under consideration by the legislature will contain no mention of opposition parties, and the issue was ``still in the cooking pot.'' The new leaders are relatively unknown politicians and there was no immediate comment from the nation's half-dozen opposition groups. But in the past the opposition has accused the leadership of shuffling Communist Party and government posts as a cosmetic gesture and of stalling on providing legal guarantees for free and democratic elections. The government official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the proposed constitutional ammendment will state that Mongolians may only join parties that ``correspond to the national interest and solidarity.'' Opposition activists said in preliminary talks with the government both sides had agreed that the constitution would permit a citizen ``to freely choose which party he will belong to.'' The 370-seat legislature, the Great People's Hural, began its annual session Wednesday and elected as president Punsaomaabiin Ochirbat, a minister of economic relations and supply since 1988. The government official said Ochirbat had initiated a policy over the past few years of seeking ties with countries outside the Soviet bloc. Mongolia, wedged between the Soviet Union and China, has been a Soviet satellite since 1921. Ochirbat replaces Jambyn Batmonh, 64, who resigned last week as Communist Party chief and this week as president. Opposition parties held a rally Tuesday to demand that Batmonh stay on as president. They described him as an honest man who could be trusted to lead Mongolia until direct elections were held for a new president. Ochirbat, 61, is a former teacher who spent the past two years in Czechoslovakia editing the World Marxist Review. He was not in the country when most of the large, pro-democracy demonstrations were held. He had previously served as chairman of the Trade Union Congress, but was ousted in 1982 by Mongolia's former hard-line Communist leader. The legislature also accepted the resignation of Prime Minister Dumaagiyn Sodman and nominated as his successor Sharavyn Gunjaadorg, 54, minister of agricuture.

DOC.HEAD: Taxman Goes After Children's Bank Accounts
DOC.TEXT: In highly taxed Sweden, even children with more than $160 in the bank must pay income tax starting next year. ``You are a tax subject as soon as you are born,'' senior treasury official Urban Eriksson said Tuesday, confirming a newspaper report that said children with savings accounts will have to file tax returns on their interest. Until now, most children's accounts were sheltered. But that will change when a new tax reform law takes effect in 1991. The Svenska Dagbladet newspaper said some parents have been using their children's accounts to shelter their own savings from taxes.

DOC.HEAD: Arrests, Intimidation Reported of Cuba's Human Rights Activists
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Activists say arrests and other forms of intimidation have left Cuba's human rights movement more demoralized than at any time in years. In one recent seven-day period, 11 rights activists were arrested and the homes of two others were the scene of mass protest demonstrations by government supporters. Most of those arrested had expressed support for a U.S.-led resolution on Cuba approved March 6 by the U.N. Human Rights Commission in Geneva. Official anxiety is on the increase as a result of Cuba's growing international isolation and concern that steady economic decline could quicken. The government seems intent on not allowing rights activists to cultivate possible supporters. President Fidel Castro has sworn not to emulate the reforms being carried out in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union. Schoolchildren have been taught to chant, ``Socialism or Death,'' the new national slogan that sums up Castro's determination to stick to his Marxist path. Castro has always maintained that the revolution's human rights record is second to none, pointing to advances in education, health services and employment opportunities. Cuba's children may have the highest literacy rate and lowest infant mortality rate in the Third World, Castro says. He believes a return to capitalism could wipe out these gains. Castro claims Cuban dissidents are few in number and are less interested in promoting political freedom than in creating conditions for a U.S. invasion of the island. Rights groups ridicule that suggestion. On the morning of March 5, a meeting of rights activists was held at the home of Sebastian Arcos, a movement leader. According to official claims, hundreds of outraged neighbors gathered outside to protest the meeting. Arcos' brother, Gustavo, says he's convinced the government organized the demonstration, citing a similar incident at his own home three days later when rights activists again convened. When a crowd of pro-government demonstrators formed at noon outside in protest, Gustavo Arcos found his telephone suddenly no longer worked. Although the demonstrators insisted the protest was spontaneous, Gustavo Arcos pointed to the instant deployment of television equipment and a loudspeaker _ suggesting the facilities had been prespositioned. The demonstration lasted into the evening and featured raised fists, revolutionary chants and throwing stones at Arcos' apartment. Windows were broken. The Cuban media approvingly called the demonstrations ``acts of repudiation.'' Gustavo Arcos says the government now sees itself as ``isolated and vulnerable. Their policy is to maintain constant tension.'' ``The rules of the game have changed. They are not going to permit any more dissidents,'' he said. Gustavo Arcos, a one-time Castro confidant, has spent 12 years in prison since the revolution began. He and his allies recall with nostalgia the period in 1988 when they were allowed to operate with a minimum of harassment. Two days after the demonstration outside his home, police arrested two well-known rights militants, Samuel Martinez Lara and Tania Diaz Castro, as part of a crackdown that led to the arrests of six others the same day. Martinez Lara is president of the Pro Human Rights Party and had been set free just 17 days earlier after 10 months' detention. After his re-arrest, the government took into custody three lay Catholic rights militants. The State Department view is that repression in Cuba has ``worsened significantly'' since a U.N. Human Rights delegation visited the island in September 1988. Department figures show more than 60 activists were arrested and detained since then. Cuba insists the detentions are not based on political activities. In the midst of the crackdown this month, the U.N. Human Rights Commission approved by 17-12 a U.S.-sponsored proposal calling attention to Cuba's rights situation. Castro reacted angrily to the resolution, particularly to the support shown by four former Warsaw Pact allies _ Hungary, Czechoslovakia, Poland and Bulgaria. Afterward, Castro asked, ``What's left of socialism? What can be left with that repugnant conduct?''

DOC.HEAD: The Name's the Same, but the Freaks Are Gone
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Twenty years have changed the Eden Hotel, which called itself the ``oldest and favorite shop in town serving the best Nepalese hash.'' Now it caters to clean-shaven trekkers. The ready availablility of hashish at the Eden and nearby establishments, and the bearded, long-haired Westerners who bought it, earned Jhochhen Road the nickname Freak Street. Although the hashish and flower children are gone a generation later, along with the Eden posters saying ``Let us take you higher,'' Jhochhen Road is still known as Freak Street. Nepal has outlawed the sale of drugs and the Eden now serves a credible approximation of European cuisine to Western tourists who happen by. About 150,000 visit Nepal each year. Hippies have given way to trippies, says the Insight Guide to Nepal, and there is ``rarely a whiff of illicit smoke, and not a bare breast to be seen in public.'' Many trekkers prefer Thamel, a district for budget travelers about a mile to the north, where such amenities as private baths and hot water are easier to find than on Freak Street. Times have changed, but the old ones linger in many minds. Chaitanya Lal Srestha, a doctor who uses the initials W.F. (for World Famous) before his name, remembers the visitors of the late 1960s and early 1970s. ``So many of them came to me for cures,'' he said in an interview at his clinic, a tiny, ill-ventilated alcove lined with herbs in glass bottles. ``I was famous on Freak Street because I used the ayurvedic system of medicine, which does not have any side effects, unlike the Western allopathic system.'' ``The tourists had many problems,'' he said. ``They weren't very clean, and their lives were odd. They often fell sick.'' Few tourists visit Srestha now. He spends much of his time visiting friends on Freak Street, a stooping man in his 50s who shambles from restaurants to shops, reflecting with their owners on more affluent days. Nhuchhe Narayan Manandhar, who owns a Freak Street hotel called the Sayami Lodge, said, ``I remember the groups of tourists who used to gather on the street and smoke chillums.'' Chillums are clay pipes, usually filled with hashish or marijuana. Manandhar, a dour-faced man of middle years, said he still was wary of Western tourists. ``I don't give out my rooms to a single person,'' he said. ``Stay with someone and it's OK, less chances of trouble.'' ``Some years ago, a German checked in alone and died because of too many drugs,'' he said in a mixture of Nepali and English. ``We didn't know until the next morning. I still think if there was someone with him in the room, he could have been saved.'' Rooms at the Sayami Lodge cost about $2 a night, making it among the cheapest in the city. A few minutes from Manandhar's are sights that include the old palace with its wooden lattice windows and ornate carvings, and Durbar Square, in an area of at least 50 Hindu temples. ``You can't see many freaks now,'' Manandhar said, waving toward the narrow, cobbled street crowded with low-budget travel agencies, restaurants, second-hand bookshops and stores selling mountaineering equipment. Dipendra Purush Dhakal, Nepal's director of tourism, said today's tourist spends more money and stays in Katmandu three days during a trip to Nepal that averages 12 days. That means ``most visitors go to other places,'' he said. ``The hippies didn't go anywhere outside Katmandu and didn't spend much money.'' Two reasons the hippies have disappeared are the 1972 ban on the sale of narcotics and the requirement that a Western visitor who stays in Nepal more than 30 days buy $10 worth of the local currency for each of those days. Only two shops still have address boards proclaiming Freak Street. The scores of others have reverted to the original Jhochhen, which means a ``line of houses.''

DOC.HEAD: Letters to Sartre Tarnish French Feminist's Image
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Two volumes of letters from Simone de Beauvoir to her lifetime companion, Jean-Paul Sartre, provide graphic details on the famous couple's private life, and critics say the French feminist philosopher emerges as predatory, opportunistic and macho. ``Lettres a Sartre'' (``Letters to Sartre''), published in February by Gallimard along with de Beauvoir's ``Journal de Guerre'' (``War Journal''), recount in the most minute detail the daily routine of the author of ``The Second Sex,'' the bible of feminists around the world. The letters are responses to Sartre's own letters to de Beauvoir, which were published in 1983 as ``Lettres au Castor,'' the title Sartre's favorite term of endearment for de Beauvoir _ beaver. Her correspondence was thought to have been lost until the couple's adopted daughter, Sylvie Le Bon de Beauvoir, found the letters by chance in a closet, still wrapped in their original envelopes addressed to ``Monsieur Sartre'' or ``Soldier Sartre.'' Some French critics wish the letters had stayed in the closet. ``This asphyxiating outpouring is a crime against the Castor,'' wrote Marianne Alphant in the daily Liberation. ``What do the letters teach us?'' she asks. ``That the pioneer of feminism only liked women she could dominate? That this austere muse was as moody and jealous as a simple housewife? That the novelist so thrilled with her `little inventions' was only a master recycler?'' The letters also prove, Alphant wrote, that de Beauvoir's successful autobiography, ``La Force d'Age,'' was rigged and full of falsifications. Other critics were less harsh. Josyane Savigneau of Le Monde argued that the letters show how the couple respected the ``contract of transparency'' _ complete honesty at all costs _ which became their credo in 1929 and endured until Sartre's death in 1980. In the letters, de Beauvoir details her love affairs with a male student of Sartre's and with some of her own women students, including Louise Vedrine and Nathalie Sorokine. Hoping to ``add a little spice'' to Sartre's dull life as a German prisoner of war in 1939-40, she provides graphic _ and sometimes sordid details _ about what her lovers wore, what they said, how they behaved in bed, and even how they smelled. ``In bed, Vedrine throws herself passionately in my arms, these sensual swoonings seem so terribly organic,'' de Beauvoir wrote. ``When I wake up, I feel like a fat, sated man because I avoid caresses, I think only about breakfast and about my work.'' De Beauvoir wrote that sex was a chore, yet she was fascinated with brothels, prostitutes and other forms of low life that her buttoned-up bourgeois upbringing had made taboo. At times, she comes across as downright conniving. ``If Wanda says anything about me, be sure to tell me so I can know if my charm offensive is working,'' she wrote. For Alphant, de Beauvoir's behavior towards women was ``predator and macho ... linked to an ambiguous desire to play the role of the man.'' But she was equally aggressive with men. ``Something extremely pleasant has happened to me, something I never expected _ I slept with the little Bost three days ago _ naturally I was the one to suggest it,'' she wrote to Sartre in 1938. Bost's first name was not given. ``I'm very fond of him. We spend idyllic days and passionate nights together ... (the relationship) is something precious, and strong, but superficial, too, and easy, just an agreeable fulfillment of relations that had always been pleasant.'' Nonetheless, the overriding theme in the letters is de Beauvoir's undying love and respect for Sartre. She addresses him as ``my dear little being,'' and she loves everything about him, from his ``little arm'' and ``little lip,'' to his ``little round-neck pullover sweaters'' and ``little face.'' ``When I'm with you, nothing seems so terrible as leaving you, yet faraway, the least little fear is unbearable. I love you passionately. I'm empty and unhappy without you. ... I love you with something tragic and with complete abandonment,'' she wrote. Le Bon de Beauvoir justified publishing the letters. She said the whole truth _ regardless of how shocking or unsettling _ is better than myths and part truths. ``Isn't it preferable to say everything in order to reveal the truth. And avoid, by the force of first person narrative, all the cliches, myths, lies, and allow the real person in, all its entirety to emerge,'' Le Bon de Beauvoir wrote in the preface. Readers may be surprised to learn how little de Beauvoir worried about or even thought about World War II. She was too busy rushing from one Left Bank cafe to another, meeting friends and lovers, analyzing their relationships and writing it all in letters to Sartre _ all in the name of honesty. ``From a distance, this was a grand task,'' Alphant concluded. ``Up close, it looks more like a hamster running on a wheel.''

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: It takes a lot of hard work for teen-agers to get their entries just right for the annual Rotten Sneaker Contest. ``I've run them through barbed wire, dragged them on the pavement while I was riding my bike, wore them without socks, and wore them when I was with my uncle who's a plumber'' said 14-year-old Russell McDonald, of Toronto. His sneakers were among more than 30 varieties of athletic shoes entered in the 15th annual contest Tuesday. Attention to detail is important because the judges set high standards. ``We look for the most miserable looking, broken down, horrible smelling, beat up things imaginable,'' said Dr. Herbert Lapidus, a contest judge. The judges rate the sneakers in eight categories. Lapidus said smell is the most important, then they gauge how decrepit the parts of the sneaker are _ the sole, laces, grommets, toes, heels _ and overall nastiness. It started 15 years ago in Montpelier as a small contest to promote a local athletic store. It has grown in the last three years into an international competition. Mayor Ann Cummings, a judge, said the contest was a fun break from cabin fever on a snowy first day of spring. ``A good thing about it is it doesn't require any talent,'' Cummings said. ``Everybody's got a fair chance.''

A high school biology teacher received a love bite from an amorous 175-pound male dolphin. Chuckles, the only Amazon River dolphin in captivity in North America, was in his reproductive stage when he bit the finger of zoo volunteer Nancy Sakach while apprently trying to pull her into his tank, Pittsburgh Zoo officials said. Ms. Sakach, 32, received several stitches on her finger, but did not harbor ill feelings toward the dolphin. His natural instincts had just taken over, she said. ``It was play time and I was brushing Chuckles with a sponge brush,'' she said. ``I wasn't really shocked when he bit me because you know that getting bitten is a possibility when you're dealing with dolphins in the (reproductive) stage.'' Chuckles, who's been at the zoo 22 years, has gotten into trouble with women before. He has brushed up against women in the tank as a show of affection, but the biting incident Friday marked the first time he tried to pull someone in, said Paul Leger, acting zoo director. ``We're not really sure how dolphins can tell the difference between men and women, but we think it has something to do with the ability to detect different hormones,'' he said. Ms. Sakach said all is forgiven: ``He's still my buddy and I expect to be back working with him in a couple of weeks.''

DOC.HEAD: College Scholarship Helps Recovering Drug, Alcohol Addicts
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Her struggle back from cocaine and alcohol addiction began with a disgusted look in the mirror and the realization, ``I'm sick and tired of being sick and tired.'' With the help of a college scholarship for recovering addicts, the 37-year-old has pulled herself from those depths, and in May will receive a bachelor's degree in fine arts and mass communications. ``Nobody was more ready to get sober than I was,'' said the scholarship winner who uses the pseudonym Annie. ``This is just what I needed to get back on track. Since coming back to school, I've blossomed.'' Annie is one of five recovering addicts or alcoholics who receive up to $1,000 a year to pursue a degree at the University of South Florida in Tampa or its branch campuses. In its second year, the ``anonymous scholarship'' _ so called because it assures annonymity for those involved _ was the idea of a recovering alcoholic. ``People in recovery programs like Alcoholics Anonymous are taught to pass on their sobriety _ this was the donor's way,'' said Lester Aldheizer, a development officer at the Sarasota campus. ``He began helping other recovering alcoholics finance their education on an individual basis,'' Ms. Aldheizer said in a telephone interview. ``He then came to us and asked to make it a formal scholarship program.'' Spokesmen at the New York headquarters of Alcoholics Anonymous and the National Council on Alcoholism said they were unaware of any other scholarship programs specifically for recovering alcoholics or drug addicts. Scholarship candidates must be full-time, degree-seeking students who have been sober at least two years and participate in a 12-step recovery program, such as Alcoholics Anonymous or Narcotics Anonymous. Like the anonymous benefactor, they also must be from the Sarasota-Manatee County area. Recipients have to maintain a 2.5 grade-point average and provide documentation that they are staying clean and sober. Six people got scholarships the first year, and five were renewed. The sixth did not meet the requirements, Ms. Aldheizer said, refusing to elaborate. ``Anonymity is critical to recovering people,'' she said. ``Their addiction is a very touchy subject. Even when people apply for the scholarship and are not accepted, all their documentation is destroyed.'' But it may seem that a college campus, brimming with partying young people, would be one of the worst places for a recovering addict. However, Pete Fazio, a financial aid counselor at Sarasota says it's not a problem. ``They're quite a bit older because they've already done quite a bit of living,'' said Fazio. Annie, for example, is 15 years older than most of her classmates _ and that's roughly number of years she spent addicted to cocaine and alcohol. ``You hate yourself for what you're doing to yourself and how you're living,'' she said in a telephone interview. ``I was partying, I was drinking every night and so were all the people I hung around with.'' ``It's a real ugly cycle that destroys your self-esteem. Getting sober and getting an education is all part of getting that self-esteem back.'' Annie worked as a secretary after giving up on her education after two years in a community college. The hardest part of going back to school, she said, was coping with the difference in age and feelings of inferiority. ``It can be very threatening,'' Annie said. ``Here you are an alcoholic _ you feel like a failure in life anyway. Then you start to look around and the students are all 18 and 19. It's not the way life is supposed to go.'' But she said supportive students and faculty have helped her succeed. Her grade average has hovered above 3.5 for the past two years and she has begun to speak about the dangers of substance abuse to campus groups. Her plans are to get a job and someday donate to the scholarship. ``I want to show people that it's not as hopeless as it seems,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Actor Candidate's TV Movie Draws Demand for Equal Time for Opponents
DOC.TEXT: A candidate running against former ``Waltons'' star Ralph Waite has demanded equal time because a local television station broadcast one of Waite's old movies. Johnny Pearson, Waite's opponent for the Democratic nomination in the 37th Congressional District, said he contacted KCBS-TV in Los Angeles after it broadcast ``The Secret Life of John Chapman'' from 4 a.m. to 6 a.m. Sunday. Pearson asked for two hours of air time. A spokeswoman for KCBS said the station was unaware that Waite was a candidate when it scheduled the movie several weeks ago. Jeffrey Jacobs, another Democratic candidate, said he plans to ask the station for equal time, too. Waite could not be reached for comment. A message left at his agent's office was not returned. Under federal regulations, TV stations must provide equal time to opposing candidates whenever a candidate who has qualified for the ballot appears on a broadcast outside of newscasts, interview programs, documentaries or spot coverage of news events. The most prominent actor affected by the equal time law was former President Ronald Reagan, whose movies were kept off the air during his political campaigns. The 37th District includes most of Riverside County, east of Los Angeles.

DOC.HEAD: World Trade Center Looks To Save 22 Tons of Paper Daily
DOC.TEXT: When you talk about recycling paper in the World Trade Center, you're talking about saving forests, its landlord says. Nearly 100,000 trees a year could be saved in a new recycling program for the giant office complex, according to Stephen Berger, executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which operates the center. Initially, 10,000 of the 60,000 people in its offices ``will be asked to recycle paper at their own desks,'' Berger said Tuesday. ``The program ultimately could involve every desk worker in the two 110-story towers and the five other buildings of the trade center.'' The center generates 65 tons of garbage every day, of which about 37{ tons is wastepaper, Berger said. ``If 60 percent of that wastepaper were recycled, we could recapture 22.5 tons of paper a day,'' he said. `` That's more than 10 times our current total. ``According to one estimate, it would be equivalent to a daily saving of 383 trees,'' said Berger, or more than 95,000 a year based on 250 working days. The daily savings also would include the 157,000 gallons of water and 92,000 kilowatts of electricity it takes to produce that amount of new paper and the 67 cubic yards of landfill space it would take to bury it. In the new program, each person will have a recycling bin besides a regular wastebasket and cull used stationery, copy machine paper, computer printout, computer cards, note paper and glossy paper from the rest of the trash. Each floor of the center also will have designated sites for discarding newspapers. The Port Authority said it also is replacing colored message pads and yellow legal pads with recycled and recyclable white-paper versions.

DOC.HEAD: Problems Could Delay Aid Plan for Nicaragua and Panama
DOC.TEXT: A tangle of problems awaits President Bush's proposal to send $800 million to bolster new democracies in Panama and Nicaragua and threatens to delay the measure past the president's Easter deadline. Bush met with congressional leaders Tuesday to press for quick action on the package. Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger argued on Capitol Hill that it is crucial to the survival of the new democratic governments of Panamanian President Guillermo Endara and Nicaragua's president-elect, Violeta Chamorro. ``Early success ... is going to be fundamental to whether Mr. Endara and Mrs. Chamorro are going to make it,'' Eagleburger told the Senate Appropriations subcommittee on foreign operations. Bush said the aid not only would demonstrate tangible benefits of democracy, but would turn up the heat on Cuba's Fidel Castro, the hemisphere's lone communist holdout. ``I'd like to see him shift from that highly militarized island and let democracy have a chance,'' he told lawmakers at a White House meeting. ``I think if we are helpful to Nicaragua and Panama, it will simply increase the pressure in that marvelous island of Cuba for change.'' Eagleburger sought to reassure senators by saying the $500 million for Panama is a one-shot economic infusion that won't likely be repeated, and that Nicaragua's $300 million in aid won't flow until leftist President Daniel Ortega fully turns over power to Mrs. Chamorro. But he seemed to acknowledge the tough job ahead, and several senators pointed to a thicket of potential problems that could delay the package beyond April 5, when Congress recesses for Easter. The most immediate problem is how to pay for the package. The administration is negotiating with Congress on its proposal to cut Pentagon spending to free money for the aid bill. Sen. Robert Kasten, R-Wis., said he believed those talks would be completed in the next two days. Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., the appropriations subcommittee chairman, said it was almost certain that some lawmakers would seek to cut U.S. military aid to El Salvador to signal displeasure over that government's failure to bring to justice the killers of six Jesuit priests. Nicaragua still must find a way to reintegrate the Contra rebels, who have fought the government for the past decade, into peaceful society. The U.S. government says 15,000 Contra fighters and 45,000 family members need to be repatriated, and most are in Honduras. Eagleburger acknowledged that suspicions are deep on both sides and that all the rebels are unlikely to lay down their weapons and move back by Mrs. Chamorro's April 25 inauguration. The package includes about $42 million for Contra repatriation, and anti-Contra lawmakers likely will want to debate that issue. Leahy accused the administration of having its priorities wrong, suggesting he might seek to divert some money to help bolster fledgling democracies in Eastern Europe. Nicaragua and Panama are of ``slight economic, security and foreign policy importance'' compared with Europe, he contended. Other amendments also await the bill, including a Kasten-Leahy proposal to offer $400 million in housing loan guarantees to Israel to build homes for Soviet Jews moving there under the Soviet Union's relaxed emigration policies. Eagleburger seemed to soften the administration's position on that proposal, saying it would support the idea ``on the assumption that we can obtain adequate assurances with regard to those funds'' on Israel's plans for settlements in the occupied territories. The statement was less categorical than recent statements by Bush and by Secretary of State James A. Baker III. In addition, as the first must-pass legislation to come along in this year's congressional session, the Panama-Nicaragua bill will become a popular target for pet projects of lawmakers. Dozens of members already have indicated an interest in offering amendments. ``It seems to me we have to establish the emergency nature of this ... in a stronger way,'' Kasten said. ``Right now there is not enough of an emergency nature to this total package.''

DOC.HEAD: Senate Passes Extension to State Shield Law
DOC.TEXT: The state Senate on Wednesday overwhelmingly approved an expansion of New York's Shield Law that would protect virtually any information gathered by reporters or photographers. The bill ensures that reporters' notes, unused video or audio tapes and newsroom files can't be subpoenaed unless it's proven the information is necessary to a criminal case and couldn't be obtained elsewhere. The bill, which passed the Senate 47-5 and was approved by the state Assembly two months ago, is expected to be signed by Gov. Mario Cuomo. The bill's sponsor, Republican Sen. Roy Goodman, said it would prevent the press from being hauled into court on fishing expeditions by defense attorneys. ``It will recognize, particularly in criminal cases, that the press should not be made to be an investigative arm of the government,'' Goodman said. State Sen. Emanuel Gold, a Democrat who led opposition to the proposal, said the press has as much an obligation to participate in trials as any other citizen. He likened the subpoena of notes to jury duty. ``I don't think there's a newspaper in the world that doesn't preach in favor of good citizenship,'' Gold said. ``It seems in some situations, the newspapers can't be bothered by the requirements of good citizenship.'' State law only protects information obtained by reporters in confidence. The legislation approved Wednesday puts the force of law behind a 1988 state Court of Appeals decision that found non-confidential information would have to be disclosed if it is relevant and the reporter is the only available source. The same bill failed by two votes in the final day of the 1989 legislative session. Gold, who filibustered on the legislation in the morning hours following an all-night session, complained Goodman had tried to ``shove the bill down our throats.'' ``I think there was some misinformation about what it did last year and when it got to the floor it was late and people didn't focus on it,'' Goodman said. Wednesday's 90-minute debate, which ended before 3 p.m., contained some bitter charges against the press. Gold said reporters are a ``powerful source of fear'' at the State Capitol. After opposing the bill last year, Gold said he was questioned by reporters in a ``nasty, disgusting tone'' about his position. ``I said, `are you asking me now as a reporter or a lobbyist? Because if you're asking me as a lobbyist, you don't belong on the floor right now,''' Gold said. But Goodman said the legislation was a root privilege for the press. ``Any attempt to dent this shield that we in 1970 placed legislatively around reporters ... would have a serious and chilling effect on the ability of the press to gather information,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Country music stars Emmylou Harris and Ricky Skaggs say a bill that would require warning labels on music encouraging sex, suicide or violence would have a chilling effect on songwriters. ``You might succeed in eliminating some of this trash out there ... but it also is going to have to inhibit the good stuff,'' Ms. Harris, head of the Country Music Foundation, told the state Senate Judiciary Committee Tuesday. ``I think we'd be paying a really terrible price.'' Skaggs, president of the Country Music Association, predicted the labeling would spread to books. ``If we allow this to happen in music, we can already see the door open for books,'' he said. ``If we allow this to happen, we don't realize what we're going to stop.'' The bill's sponsor, Sen. Leonard Dunavant, said the proposed fluorescent yellow warning labels would not constitute censorship, and likened them to the rating system for films. He agreed, however, to postpone action on the bill for a week to await an attorney general's opinion on its constitutionality.

Author James Michener said he may defect from Random House. The prolific novelist, who has had more than 30 books published by Random House, issued a statement Monday saying he may leave for ``some small house obedient to the old traditions.'' Michener, author of ``Hawaii'' and many other best sellers, said he had been ``devastated by the series of hammer blows my company has suffered in recent months.'' The writer cited the forced resignation of Robert Bernstein as Random House president; Bernstein's replacement with Alberto Vitale, whom Michener described as ``not a man reared in the traditions of American publishing''; and the forced resignation of Andre Schiffrin as managing director of Pantheon Books, a Random House subsidiary. Michener also expressed concern about possible layoffs at Random House. Vitale expressed dismay over Michener's remarks and said he is willing to discuss them with the writer.

No cameras. No lights. No nominees. Daniel Day-Lewis, star of ``My Left Foot,'' and Isabelle Adjani, star of ``Camille Claudel,'' were the only nominees for Academy Awards in leading roles to show up at a luncheon honoring Oscar nominees Tuesday. ``This is a pre-awards affair without winners and without losers,'' said academy President Karl Malden in greeting the 1,000 guests at the Beverly Hilton Hotel. The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences get-together had only about 60 of the 147 nominees make appearances. None of the five directors in contention for the award appeared. The supporting nominees were represented by Anjelica Huston (``Enemies, A Love Story''), Martin Landau (``Crimes and Misdemeanors'') and Dan Aykroyd (``Driving Miss Daisy''). ``I'm awe-struck,'' admitted comic Aykroyd, nominated for his first dramatic role in a film. ``I've appeared on the academy show as a presenter, but never as a nominee.'' The awards presentation will be held Monday.

Singer Michael Bolton received an honorary membership in a center for troubled youths after telling students it's never too early to start planning a career. Bolton, who recently won a Grammy Award as best male vocal for his single, ``How Am I Supposed to Live Without You,'' said Monday he would not have achieved success ``if I hadn't made the decision as a 15-year-old that this is what I want to do.'' The singer told students at the Urban Youth Center that he got into trouble as a juvenile, but ``finally came to a turning point where I decided if I'd continued in the direction I was going, I was going to go nowhere as an individual.'' ``So I decided to get serious about something I love to do,'' he said.

Tom Scholz, leader of the rock group Boston, did not breach a contract with CBS Records when the group failed to deliver a record album, a federal jury has ruled. Ending a seven-year court battle, the U.S. District Court jury also ruled Tuesday that CBS Records did not engage in a conspiracy against Scholz when it tried to stop other record companies from signing him. CBS Records sued the entire band in 1983, charging it with failing to deliver the requisite number of albums under a 1976 contract. Charges against other band members were dismissed. The band's first two albums, released in the 1970s, ``Boston'' and ``Don't Look Back,'' went platinum. CBS expected a third album by 1981. Despite promises by Scholz to CBS executives and rock magazines that the third album was imminent, no record was made. CBS suspended Scholz's royalties in 1983, then sued. Lawyers for both sides said the jury apparently believed Scholz's argument that the delay in producing the third album was rooted in the creative process. ``I feel great,'' said Scholz, the group's founder. ``(The jury) somehow picked up that I didn't care about the money.''

DOC.HEAD: Angolan President Offers Cease-Fire Plan
With PM-Baker
DOC.TEXT: Angola's President Jose Eduardo Dos Santos, getting into the peacemaking spirit in southern Africa, is offering the United States a nine-point proposal for a cease-fire and talks with U.S.-armed rebels. The plan, given to Secretary of State James A. Baker III on Tuesday as he and other dignitaries attended Namibia's independence party, has not been made public. But sources, who provided information about the document on condition they not be identified, said it called for ``direct contacts with a view to achieving a cease-fire and mechanisms of direct negotiations.'' Until now, the Soviet-backed government has insisted that a cease-fire could only occur once the UNITA rebel group accepted certain preconditions. The new proposal appears to soften the demand for preconditions. In Windhoek, Namibia, a U.S. official said Dos Santos ``appeared more inclined toward an early cease-fire than three months ago.'' But the proposal, which is loosely based on a peace plan Dos Santos outlined earlier this year, appears to have some of the same problems that caused UNITA to reject it in the past. The plan does not allow for incorporation of the organization in Angola's political life. Instead, it envisages ``the right of citizens to participate in political and social life.'' The proposal also calls for the ``recognition of the legitimacy of the government and the state'' _ a proviso that UNITA also has rejected as a precondition for talks. The rebels want the government to be determined by elections in which UNITA can participate as a group. The Angolan plan also calls for: _``The neutrality and the positive attitude of third-party governments.'' This appears to be a reference to ending arms supplies by the United States and the Soviet Union. _``Special and adequate treatment of (UNITA leader) Jonas Savimbi's case.'' Savimbi has rejected past Angolan demands that he go into exile. A cease-fire negotiated last June by Zaire's President Mobutu Sese Seko broke down last summer. The Angolan government attacked inside UNITA territory in February and fighting has been stalemated around the town of Mavinga in recent weeks. Meanwhile, Cuba warned it would retaliate against UNITA for an attack on a Cuban supply column in Angola last week. The rebels say the Cuban troops were escorting a resupply unit of the Angolan government. In a statement issued here Tuesday, the Cuban government said one soldier was killed and six were wounded in the March 17 attack. ``This new aggression against Cuban troops will not be left without punishment,'' it said. U.S. officials say Cuba is complying with an agreement to withdraw its troops from Angola by next year.

DOC.HEAD: CIA Chief: Noriega Capture Over-Emphasized by Administration
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration was wrong to place so much importance on capturing Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega after U.S. troops invaded Panama, CIA Director William Webster says. ``Actually, Noriega was not a factor from the time the first paratrooper landed in Panama,'' Webster said Tuesday night during a question-and-answer session with students at American University. Webster's remarks seem to criticize President Bush, who made the arrest of the military leader the focal point of the invasion of Panama in December. Noriega already had been indicted on federal drug trafficking charges in Florida. But Webster said Noriega ceased to be an issue once the United States invasion had begun and he effectively had been removed from power. ``I think we made a mistake in overemphasizing the importance of Noriega,'' the intelligence official said. In an Oval Office address after the invasion, Bush said: ``As president, I have no higher obligation than to safeguard the lives of American citizens. And that is why I directed our armed forces to protect the lives of American citizens in Panama and to bring General Noriega to justice in the United States.'' When Noriega evaded capture, the United States eventually put a $1 million reward on his head. In addition to wanting him out of power in Panama, the U.S. government wanted him jailed to face the drug charges. Webster said that because Noriega had experience in intelligence, keeping track of him was not easy. He changed locations and cars and had people watching the spies who were watching him, the CIA director said. Despite that, Webster said, ``we had very good intelligence about Noriega.'' But Noriega slipped through the U.S. grasp when he hurried to an appointment his trackers hadn't counted on. ``It's remarkable we had him in focus seven times on the day of the invasion, and it was only his decision to have a dalliance with a lady of the street _ we should have predicted it,'' Webster said. After a few days on the run, Noriega turned up at the Vatican embassy in Panama City, where he was sheltered for days until a deal was worked out to allow his transfer to U.S. custody. Noriega now is in a federal prison near Miami awaiting trial. Webster's remarks Tuesday are the second time in recent weeks he has publicly disagreed with others in the administration. He and Defense Secretary Dick Cheney have been carrying on a public debate over what future military threat the Soviet Union poses since the Warsaw Pact has become impotent with the removal of communist governments in Eastern Europe. Webster has argued that the threat is significantly diminished, while Cheney contends the United States still needs to maintain a strong military to meet a possible challenge from the East. On Tuesday, Webster described Cheney as a friend with whom he has breakfast once a week and said the disagreement was ``largely generated because of the budget process we are going through.''

DOC.HEAD: Painless Angina Triggered by Slow Rise in Heart Rate
DOC.TEXT: Long periods of moderate stress common in daily life can trigger potentially hazardous disruptions in the heart's blood supply, a new study shows. The research is the latest effort to understand what happens during silent ischemia _ painless moments when the heart needs more blood than its arteries can supply. As many as 3 million to 4 million Americans have these episodes without knowing it. Heart specialists are debating just what to do about them, and even whether the spells are truly dangerous. At a meeting Tuesday of the American College of Cardiologists, a Boston team presented evidence that the heart rate may gradually increase for a half-hour before the heart becomes ischemic, or deprived of oxygen-carrying blood. Twenty-one persons' heart rates were monitored by portable recording devices as they went about their daily routine. Even at their most rapid, their hearts often did not beat remarkably fast. ``It is not necessarily how strongly you turn on your cardiovascular system. It's how long,'' said Dr. Andrew Selwyn, the study's senior author from Brigham and Women's Hospital. In the study, silent ischemia occurred when the subjects' heart rates rose from an average of 74 to 95 beats per minute. But three-quarters of this increase took place over periods up to a half-hour before the ischemia. When ischemia causes pain, it is known as angina. People can take a variety of drugs to ease this condition. Some experts believe that silent ischemia is just as hazardous as the painful variety and give their patients the same medicines. The Boston study suggests such medication may not have the same effect on all kinds of silent ischemia. It found that drugs called beta blockers worked well controlling ischemia that occurred during moderate and high heart rates, but nitrates worked best at low rates. The idea that silent ischemia should be identified and treated is based in part on studies showing that people with this condition are especially prone to heart attacks and deaths. But some question whether this is true for the majority of essentially healthy people with silent ischemia. Dr. Arshed A. Quyyumi of the National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute in Bethesda, Md., contended that although silent ischemia is a danger sign in people with severe heart disease, it means little for those with mild or moderate disease. He presented data based on 20 months of follow-up research on 81 patients with mostly mild heart disease. Those with silent ischemia did just as well as people with no signs of blood shortage to their hearts. ``In the vast majority of people with coronary disease, who are at low to moderate risk, silent ischemia means nothing,'' Quyyumi said. However, he conceded that his view is not shared by most researchers studying silent ischemia. Dr. Peter F. Cohn of the State University of New York at Stony Brook, averred that the question of whether silent ischemia means anything has been answered. ``The controversy is not whether silent ischemis is important,'' Cohn said. ``It is what we should do about it.''

DOC.HEAD: Teachers Union Takes Threatening, Violent Students to Court
DOC.TEXT: A teachers' union is fighting back against students who attack or threaten their instructors, obtaining court orders to prevent hostile youths from evoking further terror in the classroom. In a school district where no student has been expelled in 25 years, Madison Teachers Inc. has obtained two injunctions prohibiting middle school students from having any contact with teachers they threatened to kill. A third injunction is pending against a pupil who kicked a teacher in the ribs. ``We don't do it unless there's a battery or threat of death,'' said John Matthews, the union's executive director. ``We've been concerned about the rapid escalation of behavior problems at middle schools and high schools in Madison in the last 2{ years.'' The union's effort has been criticized by a juvenile court judge as a wasted step in helping troublesome students, but is attracting national attention among educators who are concerned that not enough is being done to protect teachers from being shot, hit or stabbed. ``I'm fairly sympathetic. If the administration doesn't take firm and absolute action, then you'll see more teachers taking actions to protect themselves. I'd do the same,'' said state School Superintendent Herbert Grover. Matthews said the union, which represents 1,850 teachers, was forced to take matters to court because the school administration had done little to curb classroom violence and protect teachers from pupils with behavioral or drug problems. In one case that resulted in an injunction, a 14-year-old boy threatened to kill an eighth-grade science teacher after the instructor ordered the youth to the principal's office for disrupting class. Dane County Circuit Judge Robert Pekowsky granted an injunction prohibiting the boy from having any contact with the teacher, disrupting his class, or going within 100 feet of the teacher's house. The pupil could face juvenile detention for violating any part of the judge's order. The school district's current policy allows administrators to notify police when a student is involved in an assault. Pupils can be suspended for a maximum of three days for such acts. No student in the 22,000-student district has been expelled in the last 25 years, partly because the district's expulsion policy was complicated and riddled with loopholes, said Shirley Baum, assistant superintendent of secondary education. Next month, the school board will consider a revised expulsion policy ``that is not overburdened by technical procedure,'' she said. ``I don't see a particular problem with what they're doing,'' Ms. Baum said of the union. ``But I don't think it's a matter of the administration doing nothing. We're basically an education group, not a police force.'' But Milwaukee County Circuit Judge Christopher Foley, an expert on state children's law, said there are better ways to deal with violent students. ``I've never heard of this. And in all honesty, I'm not thrilled with a policy of filing harassment injunctions against students,'' he said. Foley said students who assault or threaten teachers should be taken to court, but officials should seek delinquency proceedings, which would protect the teacher while also assuring the youth receives needed services or counseling. But educators defended the Wisconsin union's actions. ``We view this as unique and it sounds like a good way to get at the problem and an orderly way of putting out the message,'' said Howard Carroll, a spokesman for the National Education Association, a Washington-based consortium of teachers' unions. Grover said the union's policy was one of several tools teachers may use in the future to protect themselves on the job. ``I think it increasingly will be one of the weapons used to bring sanity to the teaching environment,'' Grover said.

DOC.HEAD: Edgar, Phelan Win, Savage Race Cliffhanger
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 5 grafs to CALL race for Savage, UPDATE figures in congressional race. Picks up 5th graf pvs: `Reynolds had ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto Staffing
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Rep. Gus Savage defeated a Democratic challenger in his fight to keep his job after allegations of sexual misconduct, and Secretary of State Jim Edgar, a pro-choice moderate, defeated an anti-abortion conservative Tuesday to claim the Republican nomination for Illinois governor. In other races, 80-year-old Rep. Sidney Yates easily fended off a young challenger to gain the Democratic nomination for a 21st term. And attorney Richard Phelan, whose ethics investigation prompted the resignation of U.S. House Speaker Jim Wright, won a four-way Democratic primary for the powerful Cook County Board presidency. In the 2nd Congressional District, with 72 percent of the precincts reporting, Savage had 26,265 votes, or 48 percent; political newcomer Mel Reynolds had 25,444 votes, or 47 percent; and Ernest Washington, a follower of political extremist Lyndon LaRouche, had 2,926 votes, or 5 percent. The district represents parts of Chicago's heavily Democratic South Side and some suburbs, and the winner of the primary will be strongly favored in November. Reynolds had accused Savage of embarrassing constituents when he was investigated last year for sexually harassing a Peace Corps worker in Africa. Savage, seeking a sixth term, dismissed the charges as ``racist viciousness.'' In the governor's race, with 74 percent of precincts reporting, Edgar had 348,654 votes or 63 percent and Steven Baer, abortion opponent and political newcomer, had 185,113 votes or 33 percent. Dr. Robert Marshall, who ran a low-profile campaign, had 21,064 votes or 4 percent. Edgar, the near-unanimous favorite of the state GOP hierarchy, will square off in November against state Attorney General Neil Hartigan, who faced no opposition in the Democratic primary. Four-term GOP Gov. James R. Thompson is retiring. Edgar pledged that he and the rest of the Republican ticket ``will be working night and day'' to retain the governor's mansion for the GOP. ``We need your help to reach the people of Illinois and to outline our vision for the future of our great state,'' Edgar told supporters. In the Cook County Board president's race, with 75 percent of precincts reporting, Phelan led with 221,087 votes or 41 percent, followed by former state appellate judge R. Eugene Pincham at 135,607 votes or 25 percent; state Sen. Ted Lechowicz, the slated candidate of the county Democratic organization, with 129,638 votes or 24 percent; and County Clerk Stanley Kusper with 50,207 votes or 9 percent. Phelan, who poured $800,000 of his own money into a $2 million campaign, told cheering supporters at a downtown hotel, ``One thing I've learned about politics, is that it's not a parlor game. ``This has been an acrimonious and a serious campaign, but it has been tough,'' he said, adding that he and his opponents ``share many more things in common than they do differences.'' As the Democratic nominee, he becomes the odds-on favorite to win the post in November. In the 9th Congressional District, Yates had little trouble dispatching Chicago Alderman Edwin W. Eisendrath, 32. With 65 percent of precincts reporting, Yates had 34,030 votes or 70 percent to Eisendrath's 13,169 votes or 27 percent. James Newport-Chiakulas, 49, a National Education Association official, had 1,419 votes or 3 percent. Also Tuesday, New York City voters filled two vacant congressional seats in special elections. Republican City Councilwoman Susan Molinari won the seat given up by her father, Guy Molinari, who has become Staten Island borough president. And in the Bronx, state Assemblyman Jose Serrano was elected to the seat vacated by Robert Garcia after his conviction in the Wedtech influence peddling scandal.
DOC.HEAD: Pickup at dash
Bill Targets Foreign Firms That Avoid U.S. Taxes
DOC.TEXT: A new bill is targeting foreign corporations that roll up big profits on U.S. operations but pay little or no income tax to the federal government. ``When we look at our own tax code, it is abundantly clear that our own law provides better tax treatment for foreigners doing business in the United States than it does for our own citizens,'' said Rep. Robert Matsui, D-Calif., a sponsor of the bill. Under legislation introduced Tuesday, foreign companies and some foreign investors would be hit for at least $200 million a year in additional taxes. House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., another sponsor along with Rep. Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill., chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, said the actual take could be far higher. Submission of the bill came a month after the Internal Revenue Service confirmed it was investigating whether foreign companies underpaid U.S. taxes by billions of dollars in the 1980s. The bill would: _Expand the IRS' authority to investigate whether foreign companies have manipulated U.S. tax laws in dealings with their American subsidiaries and operating arms. For example, a foreign automaker could artificially inflate the price of parts coming into the United States so as to show little or no profit on the sale of the completed car. A 1989 law strengthened the hand of the IRS by requiring increased reporting and better record keeping by foreign companies, but it does not apply to past-year taxes. The bill would allow the tax agency to use the stricter rules in investigating past-year problems. _Tax the capital gains realized when a foreigner sells stock in a U.S. corporation. The tax would not apply to residents of countries with which the United States has treaties prohibiting such taxation. Individual Americans and U.S. corporations already must pay taxes on such gains. ``It is critical that we ensure that foreign-owned companies are not underpaying their taxes, thereby gaining a competitive advantage over American companies that are paying their fair share of taxes,'' Rostenkowski said at a news conference. The IRS says more than half of 36,800 foreign companies that filed tax returns in 1986 reported no taxable income. Foreign-controlled corporations reported $542 billion in receipts and $1.5 billion in net income and paid $3 billion in U.S. income taxes in 1986. Gephardt said foreign automobile manufacturers had $7.7 billion in sales and paid less than $12 million in tax. ``No wonder ... (U.S. automakers) have had a hard time competing,'' he said. The United States has been relying on foreign investors to help finance this country's budget deficit. Gephardt and Rostenkowski said they are not worried that their bill would discourage such investment. ``All we are asking people to do is pay what Americans pay to do business in this country,'' Rostenkowski said.

DOC.HEAD: Top Drug Enforcement Agent Heads for Life With the Yankees
DOC.TEXT: In Jack Lawn's youth, before he knew what cocaine was or where Colombia was _ and long before he became head of the Drug Enforcement Administration _ he was a baseball fan. ``I grew up as a Brooklyn Dodgers fan,'' said the nation's top drug cop. ``In the shadow of Ebbetts Field. I spent many wayward hours sneaking into Ebbetts Field to watch my beloved Dodgers play.'' When he retires Friday after five years as DEA administrator, he'll head back to New York. This time he'll be a Yankees fan because he'll be the Yankees' operations chief, in charge of everything but the players. Lawn's 11-year-old son is astonished that his favorite baseball team would want to hire his father. ``I love my dad, but he can't hit so good, he can't run so good and he can't throw so good,'' said Kevin. ``Why would the Yankees want him?'' It seems appropriate that Lawn would sign up with the Yankees, an organization known for tumultuous times. Lawn's tenure at the DEA began in one of its most traumatic periods, when agent Enrique ``Kiki'' Camerena was kidnapped, tortured and murdered in Mexico. A television miniseries on those events _ ``Drug Wars: The Camarena Story'' _ aired in January. In his last week on the job, the DEA office in Fort Myers, Fla., was firebombed and destroyed. Lawn leaves the DEA as public attention is focused more than ever on drugs and the federal budget for fighting narcotics is booming. When he started, the DEA's budget was about $250 million. The Bush administration is seeking about $700 million for 1991. But at the same time, cocaine and its smokeable derivative, crack, enveloped the nation. Heroin production overseas increased dramatically and domestic producers revved up manufacture of methamphetamine, known as crank or speed. Lawn says he regrets he didn't speak out more forcefully about the need for drug education and reducing demand for drugs, letting people know that to rely on law enforcement alone is to lose that war. He started saying that in 1984, when few law enforcement officials were willing to do so publicly, but he slacked off, partly because he was new to the DEA. Lawn said he also regrets he did not develop a DEA training academy for state, local and foreign narcotics officers. The academy remains on the drawing board. His major accomplishment, he said, is the DEA's increased profile with the public, Congress and the administration, including the greater funding. Lawn's claim to fame started a decade ago when, as an FBI agent, he led the investigation that solved the 1979 murder of U.S. District Court Judge John H. Wood Jr., known as ``Maximum John,'' in San Antonio. It was considered the most expensive federal investigation in history at that time. ``It was a dead case until Lawn went down there and revived it,'' said John Russell, then-spokesman for the Justice Department's criminal division. Lawn is leaving the DEA a few months before he turns 55, the mandatory retirement age for federal law enforcement agents. Although he could remain as administrator without the special agent's badge, he decided to retire. ``It was important to me to be a special agent so that when I talked to the agents, they knew they were talking to someone who shared their concerns, shared their problems, knew the reality of what it's like to be on the street, knew about the fears that families have being in the law enforcement environment,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Leaders of Revolution Ponder Overwhelming Rejection By Voters
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Six months ago, Manuela Gastmann lit a candle in church and dashed into the street to join a rally against the Communist government. She spent the next day in a prison cell. Today, she pores over the meager finances of a tiny activist group, wondering how a group of people who so adroitly won a revolution could so badly lose an election. ``We gave the people freedom,'' the 28-year-old East Berliner said Tuesday. ``They wanted money.'' East Germans voted in their first free elections on Sunday and overwhelmingly threw their support to a conservative alliance that promised quick reunification with prosperous West Germany. A three-party coalition containing many of the leaders of East Germany's peaceful revolt captured just 2.9 percent of the vote, finishing fourth and lagging behind even the reconstituted Communist Party they ousted. It will have 12 seats in the 400-member parliament. The coalition's showing was largely anticipated in recent weeks. After hard-line Communist leader Erich Honecker was forced out on Oct. 18 by massive protests, activists spoke of a ``third way'' between capitalism and communism, of governing East Germany with a new form of democratic socialism. But the cry for reunification with West Germany quickly dominated the protest movement. Michael Kukuntz, one of the founders of the most prominent revolutionary group, New Forum, said the opening of the Berlin Wall in November effectively transformed the revolt against dictatorial rule into a clamor for consumer goods. The air began rushing out of his movement he calls ``my child'' on the night the wall was opened, he said. East Germans who now had free access to West Germany migrated by the thousands daily, and those who went West only to visit brought back images of a parallel world of wealthy Germans. New Forum formed a shoestring political party with two other dissident groups, Democracy Now and the Initiative for Peace and Freedom. Kukuntz acknowledged that there were differences within New Forum over whether to embrace reunification, and that the group's position remained vague in the months before the vote. Meanwhile, the well-heeled alliance led by the Christian Democratic Union and backed by West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl promised rapid unification. It won with 48 percent of the vote. The Social Democrats, who were backed by the West German Social Democrats and favored a slower pace for unification, finished second. ``It's not a victory for the (Christian Democrats). It's not a victory for Kohl. It's a victory for the Deutsche mark,'' said Michael Bartoszek, who helped organize the New Democracy dissident group in September. ``The members of our movement were the first to fight for democracy,'' he said. Kukuntz, 39, a graphic designer, said he began dissident activity in the early 1980s. His wife was arrested for taking part in a group called Women for Peace and fired from her job. Miss Gastmann was working in a state-run export-import office when she said she was drawn into the protest movement in September. She said she took part in demonstrations at the Gethsemane Evangelical Church in East Berlin, holding candlelight protest vigils with thousands of others. She said she was among hundreds authorities arrested following an Oct. 7 rally at the church and was held for 24 hours in a small cell with 20 other women. She said she saw police beat some of those women. When the hard-line Communists fell less than two weeks later and the self-styled Communist reformers who replaced them agreed to new elections, Miss Gastmann began working as a bookkeeper with the Initiative for Peace and Freedom. ``I was very sad after the elections because the people of the (Christian Democratic Union) are not the people of the revolution,'' she said. ``I can't understand why the people of East Germany can't see that.'' While a Solidarity activist leads Poland and a former dissident is president of Czechoslovakia, the East German revolutionaries say they will continue to fill the role that is most familiar to them. ``We started as the opposition, and now we are the opposition once more,'' said Bartoszek.

DOC.HEAD: Defense Strategy Warns of Political Turbulence Ahead
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration's new national security strategy says U.S. forces are more likely to be called to fight in Third World countries than in Central Europe or against the Soviet Union. A report on the strategy sent to Congress on Tuesday warns of political turbulence ahead and cautions against moving away from the U.S. role as world peacekeeper. The report said future conflicts are more likely to break out in the Third World, which a senior White House official called ``a much more unstable place'' than Europe. Another senior official, who like the first insisted on anonymity, told reporters, ``Our mission in the world may be shifting from containment of an enemy to providing a reassurance of stability.'' ``There's no question we still have the central task of maintaining the balance of power with the Soviet Union, but we see a new era of uncertainties, new possible sources of instability, new concerns even in the European area and certainly in the Third World,'' the official said. The strategy will help guide President Bush's efforts to streamline and reshape American military forces in the post-Cold War period. ``In a new era, we foresee that our military power will remain an essential underpinning of the global balance, but less prominently and in different ways,'' the report said. ``The growing technological sophistication of Third World conflicts will place serious demands on our forces. They must be able to respond quickly and appropriately, as the application of even small amounts of power early in a crisis usually pays significant dividends.'' ``In a new era, some Third World conflicts may no longer take place against the backdrop of superpower competition. Yet many will ... continue to threaten U.S. interests,'' the report said. ``It will be increasingly difficult to slow the spread of chemical, biological and nuclear weapons _ along with long-range delivery systems. Instability in areas troubled by poverty, injustice, racial, religious or ethnic tension will continue, whether or not exploited by the Soviets,'' it said. Bush reiterated his hopes for securing three major arms control agreements this year on long-range nuclear weapons, conventional forces in Europe and chemical weapons. He said the U.S. postwar policy of containment ``of an aggressive, repressive Soviet Union ... has succeeded brilliantly.'' The annual report by the president's National Security Council said that Western rearmament and the economic boom in the 1980s helped trigger ``the systemic crisis engulfing the communist world.'' ``We have seen powerful, pent-up democratic forces unleashed all across Eastern Europe that have overturned communist dictatorships and are reversing the pattern of Soviet dominance,'' it said. ``Such fundamental political change will likely be turbulent. There may be setbacks and new sources of instability'' as the Soviet Union and the states of Eastern Europe ``advance into historically uncharted waters.'' The report said, ``Our goal is to move beyond containment, to seek the integration of the Soviet Union into the international system as a constructive partner.'' It said Central America ``remains a disruptive factor in the U.S.-Soviet relationship. We hold the Soviet Union accountable for the behavior of its clients'' in Cuba and Nicaragua.

DOC.HEAD: Wheat Growers Casting Wary Weather Eye Toward Canada
DOC.TEXT: An icy weather monster in Canada is beginning to worry U.S. winter wheat farmers, whose crop is waking up and starting to grow. There has been ``a vast improvement'' in the crop recently because of much-needed precipitation, says Agriculture Department meteorologist Raymond P. Motha. From southern Texas north through Oklahoma, Kansas and into Nebraska _ where hard, red winter wheat was planted last fall for the 1990 harvest _ the crop has responded well to the new moisture. ``The key thing right now is the possibility of cold weather as the crop comes out of dormancy,'' Motha said Tuesday. ``It's growing and kind of tender, in case we get a hard freeze.'' Motha said crop watchers are keeping tabs on ``a situation'' in Canada that could send cold weather scooting south by the weekend. ``As far as freeze danger, we've got another two or three weeks of potential freezing weather'' in the nation's breadbasket, he said. Motha's comments followed a weekly report that showed too much rain in parts of the South have hampered farm work while other areas have benefited from widespread precipitation. ``Heavy rains added to the already-surplus moisture supplies in much of the (Mississippi) Delta,'' the government's Joint Agricultural Weather Facility said in its report for March 12-18. ``Rain improved winter wheat prospects in most of the Great Plains and portions of the Pacific Northwest.'' The facility is operated by the Agriculture and Commerce departments. Weekly reports cover crop conditions but do not include production forecasts. Pastures were reported to be improving as a result of the widespread moisture. Livestock was said to be in good condition and spring lambing and calving continued in most areas. Motha said the Southeast is ``almost excessively wet'' and that many of the drought-plagued areas of the last two years have recovered. Others, however, still suffer long-term shortages of subsoil moisture. ``They've had some substantial and drought-relieving rains in the southern and central Great Plains, so that much of the hard, red wheat area of Texas, Oklahoma and Kansas are in pretty good shape moisturewise,'' he said. In the eastern Corn Belt, soil moisture is generally in pretty good shape, Motha said. But in the western Corn Belt, including Iowa, Nebraska and southern Minnesota, the long-term reserves of moisture are still below normal. Those are the deeper reserves that allow crops to survive brief periods of dry weather. When this subsoil moisture is scant, the topsoil needs frequent rain to sustain the growing plants. Motha said the long-term deficiencies still persist in Iowa, Nebraska and the Dakotas. But he said recent moisture has helped ease the situation from the last fall. In the West, there are still large and troublesome areas of drought, particularly in Southern California, he said. The weekly report said winter wheat was in generally ``good-to-excellent'' condition in Idaho and ``good-to-fair'' shape in Washington. Spring planting of small grains was under way in the Columbia Basin of Oregon. Looking at other crops, the report said: _Although rain and wet fields continued to hamper field work in the Mississippi Delta, corn planting progressed as the weather allowed. Rice planting continued in Louisiana. _Corn planting was about one-third finished in Georgia and was making progress in southern Texas, except in some rainy areas. Cotton and sorghum planting continued in the Rio Grande Valley and the Coastal Bend area. _Irrigation was under way in Florida's citrus area, with trees setting new-crop fruit.
