Peaches were in ``good-to-excellent'' condition in Georgia, and peach trees were setting fruit in Texas. _Spring-like weather prevailed over Florida's major vegetable areas and the harvest picked up steam. Vegetable growth was reported to be good in the Rio Grande Valley of Texas, with harvests continuing for carrot, cabbage, celery and lettuce crops.

DOC.HEAD: Schroeder: No Combat Harms Careers
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon policy of excluding women from combat does not keep female soldiers out of harm's way, and it denies them the chance to further their careers, Rep. Patricia Schroeder says. ``It appears that women can be the first killed, but they're not allowed to be in the front lines,'' Mrs. Schroeder, D-Colo., told the House Armed Services personnel subcommittee Tuesday. Mrs. Schroeder has proposed legislation directing the Army to conduct a four-year test to see how women would perform in combat-related units. By law, women in the Navy and Air Force are barred from serving aboard combat ships and aircraft. The Army is not covered by the law but has sculpted its own policy in line with it. Mrs. Schroeder argued that many of the non-combat jobs that women now hold put them in the line of fire on the modern-day battlefield, which relies more on high-tech weaponry than hand-to-hand combat. The congresswoman submitted her bill following the U.S. invasion of Panama last December, during which some of the 600 women who took part in the initial operation came under fire even though their jobs were not considered combat-related. But the Army's personnel chief testified that the experiment Mrs. Schroeder advocates is unnecessary. ``The fundamental issue ... is (one of) national policy. There's no ducking that _ whether women should serve in direct combat, and that's for you to decide,'' Lt. Gen. Allen K. Ono said. Ono argued other nations such as Canada have wrestled with the issue of using women in combat-related jobs, and that the United States can learn from such experience. Although Canada recently offered infantry training to 80 women, only one was able to become qualified, he said. ``The Army can't operate without its women soldiers _ but in regards to combat arms, we are able to recruit sufficient numbers of males,'' Ono said. However, Lt. Gen. Thomas A. Hickey, the Air Force's personnel chief, testified ``there probably isn't a combat job in the Air Force that women couldn't do. ``They're physically capable, they're emotionally capable. If you want us to put them there, it's up to you,'' Hickey said. Mrs. Schroeder argued that the restriction ``shuts off many routes of advancement'' for those women who want to make the military a career. Rep. Beverly Byron, D-Md., who chairs the personnel subcommittee, said she did not favor opening combat jobs to women, but is interested in making sure that women in the military have promotion opportunities in their selected fields. Front-line duty is crucial to advancing to the top ranks of the military leadership, several female military officers testified. Such a restriction ``can't help but slow the advancement of people to senior ranks,'' said Capt. Kathleen Conley, an Air Force Academy graduate who flies the Air Force's huge C-141 transport planes. ``I hope women will be flying fighter aircraft very, very soon.'' However, some military women acknowledged they are not interested in entering the combat-related fields. ``I don't want to go into the infantry. I don't think women are physically or emotionally ready to do so,'' said Army Spec. Rose M. DeBerry, a member of the 16th Military Police Battalion, who took part in the Panama invasion.

DOC.HEAD: NASA to Consider Rescuing Stranded Communications Satellite
DOC.TEXT: NASA will talk with aerospace company officials Thursday about sending astronauts to rescue a $157 million communications satellite stranded in space by a miswired Titan 3 rocket. The Intelsat 6 satellite is whirling around Earth at an altitude of 276 miles _ about 22,000 miles lower than it should be to do its job. ``The design was wrong,'' said Judy Stowell, a spokeswoman for Martin Marietta Corp., which built the rocket. ``Our analysis shows an engineering design error caused the vehicle to be wired improperly.'' As a result, after the Titan was launched on March 14, the satellite didn't separate automatically as it was supposed to. When engineers sent a separation signal, a small rocket that was to boost the satellite to its duty station stayed with the spent Titan and left the satellite marooned. A Martin Marietta spokesman was quoted by The Denver Post as saying that the Titan had been wired to launch two satellites and that the separation signal went to a location where there was none. But Ms. Stowell said Tuesday that explanation was premature and that two committees were investigating the failure. While Martin Marietta searched for the cause, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration scheduled its meeting at the Johnson Space Center in Houston with representatives of Intelsat, owner of the satellite, and Hughes Aircraft, its builder. Intelsat, a 118-nation consortium, did not insure the satellite, which was to have gone into service over the Atlantic Ocean. A spokesman, Tony Trujillo, said it was the most sophisticated communications satellite ever built, capable of carrying 120,000 telephone calls simultaneously. Intelsat was being charged $115 million for the Titan rocket and launch by Martin Marietta. The satellite cost an additional $157 million. NASA hasn't said whether it is willing to go after the satellite, as it has for five others. ``They are just going to come in and give us some information where the spacecraft is and its condition and so forth,'' said Hal Lambert, manager of integration operations at the space center. ``We are going to discuss whether it's possible to get the satellite.'' Two rescue methods have been proposed, Lambert said. In one, the space shuttle would carry a rocket stage into orbit to be bolted onto the satellite by astronauts. In the other, the satellite would be put into the shuttle cargo bay and brought back to Earth for refitting. Because it was not intended for shuttle operations, the five-ton satellite has no fitting that could be grappled by the shuttle's robot arm. That would mean a special capture device would have to be designed and built. Industry sources have little doubt the rescue can be accomplished; astronauts have saved five satellites that way, bringing three home and repairing two in orbit. The cost of such a mission, however, would be high and probably would become the deciding factor. With shuttle flights costing $250 million and up, NASA no longer will rescue satellites for $15 million, as it did in 1984 with the Palapa and Westar satellites. NASA spokesman say they don't know how much would be charged today because the agency no longer does commercial business and there is no published rate schedule. The charges, however, probably would be based on the amount of cargo space and weight involved. A Virginia company, Orbital Sciences Corp., has a device called a Transfer Orbit Stage that includes a duplicate of the rocket that was to carry the Intelsat satellite to its high orbit. Joseph Padavano, chief engineer of the device, said it would take up only one-fifth of the shuttle cargo space, but that it weighs 25,000 pounds _ more than half of the shuttle's capacity.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmakers Fault State Department Report on PLO
DOC.TEXT: Members of Congress say the State Department ignored key facts in reporting that the Palestine Liberation Organization is adhering to its commitment to renounce terrorism. ``It's close to a whitewash,'' Sen. Connie Mack, R-Fla., said Tuesday. ``It could have been a lot tougher. Mack joined Sen. Joseph Lieberman, D-Conn., and Rep. Mel Levine, D-Calif., in criticizing the State Department report, which was sent to Congress earlier this week. The report said there have been nearly 30 border and rocket attacks by Palestinian groups against Israel since PLO chairman Yasser Arafat pledged in December 1988 not to pursue terrorist tactics. At least nine of the attacks involved ``constituent groups'' of the PLO, the report said, and in three cases civilians appeared to be the target. Nonetheless, the report said: ``We have no evidence in those cases or any others that the actions were authorized and approved by the PLO Executive Committee or by Arafat personally.'' But Lieberman said the report demonstrates ``the PLO still has a long way to go before it can be considered a responsible or peaceful player on the international stage.'' The State Department also provided incomplete information, he said, and officials were ``bending over backwards not to be too critical of the PLO'' for fear of jeopardizing the Middle East peace process. Secretary of State James A. Baker III took into account proposals by the PLO, made mostly through Egypt, in trying to open negotiations between Israel and Palestinian Arabs. The effort was suspended with the collapse last week of the Israeli government. Lieberman and Mack cosponsored the legislation that requires the State Department to report to Congress every four months on whether the PLO is complying the its no-terrorism pledge. Lieberman said the report failed to report some terrorist acts and inflammatory statements made by Palestinians affiliated with the PLO. For instance, he said, Mohammad Rashid, who was involved in the bombing of a Pan American World Airways plane in 1982, has been offered legal aid by the PLO. Levine called the report ``extremely disappointing'' and said, ``It seems that the administration has selectively reviewed the evidence in order to support a preordained conclusion.'' Arafat's renunciation of terrorism, and a statement by him acknowledging Israel's existence, cleared the way for official U.S. talks with the PLO. Those talks are being conducted in Tunis by Robert Pelletreau Jr., the American ambassador to Tunisia. The report described the PLO as a loosely structured organization ``composed of disparate elements with different views.'' It said the PLO is deficient in controlling all of its groups _ especially those that oppose current PLO policy and carry out cross-border attacks against Israel. ``These deficiencies are not reasons to excuse PLO activities or to relax our vigilance,'' the report said. ``On the contrary, we have told the PLO we will hold them to their commitments, and we continue to examine all incidents on a case-by-case basis.''

DOC.HEAD: Vandalism, Drinking Mar Center for East German Newcomers
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Depression, vandalism and heavy drinking are rife in an abandoned hotel in this Rhine river city that serves as a center for East Germans who fled their country seeking a better life. Many of the half-million East Germans who've arrived over the past six months have managed to get a piece of prosperity, but others have been left behind in the rougher climate of capitalist West Germany. ``We were tempted to come here by all the nice things that were dangled out in front of us,'' said Eric Patz, a miner from Karl-Marx-Stadt who is now unemployed in Remagen. ``It was all misleading.'' ``And now that we're here, we're treated like the last piece of garbage,'' added his friend, Marion Schilling. ``I knew things would be hard here, but not this hard,'' said Ms. Schilling, who has lived in a small room at this center with her boyfriend and 7-year-old daughter since December. ``I don't get enough money to buy the basic things my daughter needs, like new shoes.'' Life may get tougher for the resettlers. On Tuesday, West Germany announced it would cut many of the special privileges enjoyed by the immigrants. The changes, to take place July 1, would eliminate guarantees of a place to stay, ``starting-out money'' and low-interest loans for new arrivals. The changes are part of an effort to stop the influx of East Germans, which has strained housing and job markets. ``At the beginning, in September, it was really euphoric here,'' said Daniel Selle, who directs the center in Remagen, which is 15 miles south of Bonn. ``The people who began coming later have a lot of problems that they brought with them from the East. They have trouble holding jobs, or they drink. ``Many of them, too, had illusions about what life in the West would be like,'' he said in an interview Tuesday. The influx intensified dramatically after Hungary opened its borders to East Germans in September and thousands poured into West Germany. It continued even after the toppling of East Germany's Communist government in October. West Germany is pushing for quick unification in hopes the East Germans will decide to stay home, especially now that voters there elected their own government Sunday. The Remagen center, financed by Rhineland-Palatinate state and operated by the Red Cross, houses 76 people. The wallpaper is peeling from the rooms and winding hallways but they are generally in good shape. The center has three communal kitchens and several private ones, and residents can sift through piles of donated clothes to pluck out a wardrobe. However, brand-new refrigerators in one communal kitchen stand empty because people were stealing food from each other; an intended playroom for children was turned by residents into a garbage dump; and animosity abounds between East Germans and the many ethnic Germans from the Soviet Union and other East bloc countries who also live in the center. Reports of fighting and heavy drinking have come from centers throughout the country in the past few weeks. Selle, an easygoing man with round wire-rimmed glasses and a long ponytail, characterizes his work at the center as frustrating. ``People here aren't willing to act as a community, there is no solidarity,'' he said. ``And every Monday I have a whole list of things to get repaired which were destroyed over the weekend.'' However, not all immigrants at the center are embittered. Bernd Hobusch says he and his family were grateful to have had a place to stay after their arrival. ``We had so many things to take care of, getting our papers in order and looking for work,'' said Hobusch, a 39-year-old construction worker from the East German city of Dessau. ``Living here at least relieved us of one problem.'' Hobusch and his family will be moving out of the center next week. He, his wife and four children have been living in one room there since December. ``I've had a job since January, but I had to earn enough to pay a security deposit on an apartment,'' Hobusch said. ``It was really hard to find an apartment with four children. Landlords here don't like kids.'' Hobusch complained about the attitude of many other East Germans at the center. ``A lot of them just collect money from the state and sit around all day drinking,'' he said. ``They live here for months and don't even look for jobs.''

DOC.HEAD: Jury Selection Begins In List Trial
DOC.NOTE: Eds: L'E. in graf 2 is cq
DOC.TEXT: A judge excused 59 people from jury duty in the trial of John E. List, a 63-year-old accountant accused of killing his mother, wife and three children at their home 18 years ago. Superior Court Judge L'E. Wertheimer refused to release seven people from a pool of more than 220 potential jurors as jury selection began Tuesday. Jury selection was to continue today, and Wertheimer hopes to have the panel chosen by Friday. Opening statements are set for March 30. Those dismissed Tuesday cited reasons ranging from religious prohibitions, health ailments, demanding jobs, claustrophobia and other hardships. Others cited intense news coverage of the case and said they might be biased in judging whether List massacred his family at their 19-room mansion in suburban Westfield in November 1971. ``I remember when it first happened,'' said a man in his early 30s who runs a boot and shoe factory. ``I've tried to read as much as I can about it.'' List is charged with five counts of first-degree murder and faces life in prison. Prospective jurors were told the trial might last seven to 10 days. Some of those dismissed said they had seen the ``America's Most Wanted'' television show that included a plaster bust of how List might look 17 years after the slaying. He was arrested on a tip last June in a Richmond, Va. suburb. List told authorities he was Robert P. Clark, and his second wife, Delores, said her husband was a victim of mistaken identity. But investigators identified him through fingerprints from his Army record. The FBI and prosecutors maintain that List assumed a new identity after the slayings, working as an accountant in Colorado and Virginia. He remarried in 1983 and was known to neighbors as a quiet, church-going man who taught Sunday school. On Dec. 7, 1971, police found the bodies of List's wife and children lined up on a ballroom floor, and his mother stuffed in an upstairs closet. The children had been shot one by one as they came home from school. Authorities said the victims had been dead for about a month.

DOC.HEAD: Polish Patriot's Remains May Finally be Sent Home
With PM-US-Poland
DOC.TEXT: The federal government is moving to fulfill Franklin D. Roosevelt's promise to send home the remains of Polish patriot and preeminent pianist Ignace Jan Paderewski ``when Poland is free.'' The conditions could not be met over five decades of Nazi occupation and communist dictatorship _ and there still are concerns to be overcome. But with Poland quickly moving to full independence and democratic rule, U.S. and Polish officials now are looking to June 1991, the 50th anniversary of the pianist's death in New York City, as the appropriate date to return his remains. On Thursday, Tadeusz Mazowiecki, the first non-communist prime minister of Poland in 40 years, will visit Paderewski's temporary resting place in a crypt at Arlington National Cemetery. But U.S. officials say they have no indication that Mazowiecki will demand the immediate return of the remains of a man who is one of Poland's foremost heroes and became the Polish republic's first premier. ``It's the general consensus in the Polish community both here and in Poland that it would be best on the 50th anniversary of his death, June 29, 1991,'' said a State Department official. ``The trends are very favorable and final decisions will be made in the fall as to the exact arrangements,'' said the official, who spoke on the condition he not be identified. ``There are going to be major changes in the Polish government between now and then,'' the official said. ``There is a high probability for a new Constitution and new senior officers who are not communists. ``We have waited because we wanted to make sure the steps that needed to be taken were accomplished properly and that the Paderewski family, the Catholic Church and the Polish-American community were all in agreement that Poland was once again whole and free,'' he said. At his death at age 80, Paderewski was the most famous pianist in the world. But he also used his concerts to raise money for Polish refugees after World War I and served as the first premier of the Republic of Poland in 1919 and 1920. He became president of the parliament of the Polish government in exile, in London, after Nazi troops stormed across the Polish frontier in 1939. He still was working for Poland at the time of his death. On July 5, 1941, several days after his death, Paderewski's body was placed at President Roosevelt's order in a crypt at the base of the monument raised to those killed when the battleship Maine exploded in Havana harbor in 1898, a spark that helped ignite the Spanish-American war. Paderewski's zinc coffin lies inside a large cypress box inside the crypt near the base of the Maine's flag staff. In 1962, when it was apparent Paderewski's temporary sojourn would be lengthy, President John F. Kennedy reaffirmed Roosevelt's promise that the body would be returned only when Poland was free. A bronze plaque, placed shortly thereafter, reads: ``Ignace Jan Paderewski, Polish Statesman and Musician. His Remains Rest Temporarily Within The USS Maine Memorial.''

DOC.HEAD: Abortionists Shun AIDS-Infected Women, Survey Finds
DOC.TEXT: An informal survey of New York City abortion providers suggests that women who reveal they are infected with the AIDS virus may quickly find their appointments canceled. Two-thirds of the abortion clinics and physicians surveyed by the city's human rights commission canceled an appointment after the caller said she was infected with the human immunodeficiency virus, or HIV, which causes AIDS. ``Revealing your HIV status to a health care person is not safe,'' Katherine Franke, a commission lawyer who led the study, said Tuesday. ``Most people don't tell. That's the way they get abortions,'' she said. The commission began looking into the matter after receiving several reports from women who claimed they had been denied abortion services because they were HIV-positive. Physicians and representatives with AIDS organizations and abortion groups said they were unaware of any other study that has documented the problem in other parts of the country, although they had heard anecdotal reports. Dr. Lewis Koplik, an Albuquerque, N.M., obstetrician-gynecologist who heads the National Abortion Federation's medical advisory committee, said he has an ``undocumented gut feeling'' that the New York experience may be occurring elsewhere. ``If you have one woman who has HIV infection or AIDS and can't get service, that's a real problem. It's just something that should not happen,'' he said. Los Angeles obstetrician-gynecologist David Grimes, chairman of Planned Parenthood's medical advisory committee, said he does not believe the problem is widespread, although it may be more apparent on the East Coast where more women are infected with HIV. He did say he often sees patients referred by other physicians who feel inadequately prepared to treat HIV-infected women. Women who are HIV-positive but have no symptoms of AIDS and no other diseases are generally at no greater risk than non-HIV women for abortion, Grimes said. But he said women whose immune systems are compromised, whether by AIDS or some other disease, are more appropriately treated in a hospital. In the survey, conducted from November 1988 through February 1989, callers from the New York City human rights commission made appointments with 30 abortion clinics and physicians that advertised in the Yellow Pages. Twenty canceled the appointment after the caller said she was infected with HIV but had no symptoms of AIDS. Twelve of the 20 said they did not have adequate infection control, while others said abortion on an HIV-infected woman was too complicated a procedure for them to handle and referred the caller to a hospital. Many of the responses ``were very hostile,'' Ms. Franke said. ``Some just hung up or said, `We can't treat your kind.''' For women refused services or referred to a crowded public hospital, the result may be delay in getting an abortion, which increases chances of complications, Ms. Franke said. The chances that a woman will pass the AIDS virus to her baby are estimated at between 20 percent and 50 percent. Franke said that while the human rights commission would be prepared to file suit against clinics that refuse to serve women with HIV, it would rather see the problem addressed through education of physicians and other health professionals. Public health officials believe that about 1 million people in the United States are infected with the AIDS virus. More than 11,000 of the 121,645 cases of AIDS in U.S. adults reported since June 1, 1981 have been women.

DOC.HEAD: State Drug Officials Seek Tripling of Federal Support
DOC.NOTE: EDS: The original noon EST embargo on this material has been broken. The story may be used immediately
DOC.TEXT: State alcohol and drug abuse directors are calling for the federal government to nearly triple the $1.2 billion it now spends for treatment programs for alcoholics and addicts. ``There is an urgent need to make additional treatment services available to all persons who need them, especially adolescents, pregnant women and IV (intravenous) and cocaine drug users,'' said John Gustafson, president of the National Association of State Alcohol and Drug Abuse Directors. The estimated total costs of alcohol and drug abuse exceed $200 billion, but the Bush administration spends only about one-half of 1 percent of that amount on treatment, the group said in a report Tuesday. Block grants, the states' main source of federal funds for treatment programs and mental health services, total $1.2 billion this year. The association said that figure should be boosted by at least $2 billion. Federal spending for treatment ``is at least partially based upon a suspicion that treatment programs for substance abusers are of dubious value,'' the report said. However, the association said its analysis of more than 15 years of research found that substance abuse treatment increases employment, decreases crime, increases productivity and reduces health costs. One study by the University of California at Los Angeles estimated that for every dollar spent for treatment services, $11.54 in social costs is saved. ``There are no great unsolved mysteries to drug and alcohol treatment. ... The real mystery is why we spend so little treating dependency and so much paying for its effects'' _ crime, violence, illness, the breakup of families, poverty and death, Gustafson said. For comparison, he estimated it costs $50,000 to keep an inmate in prison for a year and $100,000 to care for an AIDS patient for a year, while outpatient drug treatment costs about $3,000 per patient. The government's National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism estimated that 18 million adults abuse alcohol, and that 10 million of those are alcoholics. The report said 41 states and the District of Columbia reported that a total of 1.4 million people _ 123,525 of them under 18 _ receive alcohol and drug treatment each year. Those states estimated that 10.6 million others are in need of such treatment. The report said that 66,766 people in 44 states are on waiting lists for treatment; about half have been waiting for at least a month.

DOC.HEAD: Cardinal Says Church Shouldn't `Cut Off' Abortion Rights Supporters
DOC.TEXT: Roman Catholic Cardinal Joseph Bernardin says the church should not discipline Catholic public officials just because they do not oppose abortion. He said all public officials, Catholics and otherwise, should be held accountable for their positions. ``It is important, however, that we continue to engage them and not cut them off,'' said Bernardin, one of the church's most prominent speakers on abortion and other ``pro-life'' issues. His comments Tuesday night at Georgetown University came four months after a Catholic California assemblywoman was banned from receiving communion because of her public stance in favor of abortion rights. Lucy Killea won election to the California Senate after the widely publicized action taken by Bishop Leo T. Maher in response to her television ads focusing on abortion. Bernardin noted that the National Conference of Catholic Bishops voted last November for a resolution declaring: ``No Catholic can responsibly take a `pro-choice' stand when the `choice' in question involves the taking of innocent life.'' ``In accord with the bishops' statement, I am firmly committed to the position that public officials who recognize the evil of abortion have a responsibility to limit its extent, to work for its prevention and to protect unborn life,'' said the cardinal, a former head of the bishops' Pro-Life Committee. He said the church has a clear right to involve itself in public policy controversies such as abortion. However, he said, ``I believe that the church can be most effective in the public debate on abortion through moral persuasion, not punitive measures.'' Bernardin did not mention the California case by name _ nor other recent politician-church leader disputes such as the one involving New York Gov. Mario Cuomo and a bishop who suggested Cuomo risked going to hell because of his stance on abortion.

DOC.HEAD: Group Decries Stores Putting Sugar Cereals at Kids-Eye Level
DOC.TEXT: A consumer group says supermarket displays that put sugar-laden cereals at kids-eye level are attracting children with ``candy ads masquerading as cereal.'' Such displays add to the problems of getting children to eat more nutritious foods, Center for Science in the Public Interest said Tuesday. Victoria Leonard said the center surveyed supermarket cereal displays and found child-oriented cereals in colorful packages generally lower than the more nutritious cereals marketed for adults. ``That makes it more likely to catch the attention of a child walking by,'' said Leonard. ``Children are being bombarded by candy ads that are masquerading as cereal.'' CSPI volunteers last November looked at the location of cereals displayed in 27 stores in the Boston, San Francisco, Chicago, Baltimore and Washington, D.C. metropolitan areas. Leonard said the center has written the stores asking that they change the displays and elevate the children's cereals. ``Children are attracted by the brand names and flashy packaging and then plead with their parents to buy them,'' she said. ``We want parents to make the choice.'' CSPI is a nonprofit, 200,000-member organization founded in 1971 to promote improved health policy.
DOC.HEAD: Maryland Banker Revises Lawsuit Against CIA
DOC.TEXT: A former official of a Baltimore bank says he has filed a revised lawsuit seeking $4 million from the bank, the CIA and other federal officials for allegedly ruining his life after he balked at handling arms transactions for a CIA front. Robert Maxwell charges that he was threatened, forced to resign and suffered a nervous breakdown after he questioned the legality of certain dealings relating to an account held by the now-defunct Associated Traders Corp. at the First National Bank of Maryland, in Baltimore. Maxwell left the bank in late 1985, taking with him several documents which, he told a news conference Tuesday, linked Associated Traders with at least $23 million in covert arms shipments to Central America, Angola and Afghanistan. Published accounts by columnist Jack Anderson and others, dating to 1986, have identified Associated Traders, dissolved in the wake of that publicity, as a CIA front. According to Maxwell's suit, bank officials confirmed to him that it was.
DOC.HEAD: Interior Secretary Orders Increased Protection For Burial Grounds
DOC.TEXT: Interior Department officials are under instructions to develop better protections for treatment of sacred objects and human remains on federal lands. Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan said Tuesday he told Interior bureau heads the new policies should be based on four areas of special emphasis: _Public education and participation. _Cooperation in fighting archaeological looters. _More interagency information exchange. _Increased site inventories and collections curation. ``This is a subject of much concern to many Americans and especially to American Indians,'' said Lujan. ``Unfortunately, for many years Indian graves were often desecrated and the human remains and objects within them treated disrespectfully.''

DOC.HEAD: Scientist: Long-Lost Relative of Humans and Apes Found in Remote Forest
LaserPhoto NY26, LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: A field biologist who trudged through a soggy, leech-infested forest in search of a long-lost relative of humans and apes returned with malaria, blood poisoning and the first photographs of an animal no scientist had ever seen alive. ``For a week, I couldn't move,'' Bernhard Meier of Ruhr University in Bochum, West Germany, said in a telephone interview Tuesday. But he recovered, and his sighting of the hairy-eared dwarf lemur in Madagascar has been described as one of the most important rediscoveries of a mammal in the last decade. ``I went three times to that forest to find that animal, although I already knew it was there,'' he said. An old man in a nearby village had told him about it. To get to the forest, near Mananara in northern Madagascar, an island country off the east coast of Africa, ``you need to hike three days, long and strong,'' Meier said. ``Nothing is dry after a few kilometers because you need to cross many big rivers and creeks'' containing leeches. ``The leeches are not dangerous. Most people say, `Oh, leeches, I don't want these plum-sized, ugly, satisfied leeches on me.' ... But the mosquitoes are dangerous. They transmit malaria.'' Five preserved specimens, the first collected 115 years ago, are held in museums. But until Meier's discovery, researchers had no idea whether the creature still existed. The first complete description of the animal, known to scientists as Allocebus trichotis, will be published shortly in Folia Primatologica, a scientific journal. Meier made the discovery last April, but it is only now being reported. The rediscovery of the lemur (pronounced LEE-mur) is important because it is the only surviving species of an entire genus of lemurs that have disappeared, said Russell Mittermeier, president of Conservation International in Washington, D.C., and a primate specialist. ``If you lose a species, there are close relatives around,'' he said. ``If you lose a genus, that's worse.'' The discovery of the hairy-eared dwarf lemur is ``one of the two most important rediscoveries of mammals in a decade,'' Mittermeier said. The other was the rediscovery of the soft-spined porcupine in Brazil in 1986, he said. The lemur is brown and shaped like a mouse, with a body 5 inches long and a 7-inch, furry tail. It weighs no more than 3{ ounces. ``Allocebus is the smallest primate species in existence, except during the dry season when the mouse lemur is not fat and is smaller,'' Meier said. The lemurs of Madagascar are scientifically important because they are a group of primates that evolved in isolation during the millions of years that the other primates _ monkeys, apes and humans _ were evolving elsewhere. ``In effect, Madagascar is a giant experiment in alternative evolution,'' the New Scientist, an English journal, has said. Meier has an enviable record as a lemur hunter. Within the last few years he discovered and described a lemur new to science, the golden bamboo lemur, in collaboration with Patricia Wright of Duke University in North Carolina. He also rediscovered the greater bamboo lemur, which biologists feared had become extinct. Meier emphasized that the importance of the discovery also lies in the attention it focuses on preserving the forest where the lemur dwells. About 57,000 acres of the forest have been designated as a biosphere reserve by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization. That part of the forest is protected, but a surrounding area of forest about 10 times that size is under increasing pressure from a burgeoning local population, Meier said. ``It is one of the last patches of virgin, lowland rain forest, with huge trees you can't imagine, 50 meters (about 160 feet) tall,'' Meier said. ``This forest is a very special ecosystem and can't be substituted by importation of other things.''

DOC.HEAD: Namibia at-a-Glance
With PM-Namibia, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a brief look at Namibia, which became independent from South Africa today:

GEOGRAPHY _ The 318,252 square-mile country is mostly desert, with scattered deposits of valuable minerals. It is bounded by the Atlantic Ocean, South Africa, Zambia, Botswana and Angola. Its only deep-water port, Walvis Bay, stays part of South Africa after independence.

HISTORY _ South Africa has ruled Namibia since capturing the territory of South-West Africa from Germany in 1915. The South-West Africa Peoples Organization (SWAPO) began guerrilla attacks in 1966, after South Africa rejected a U.N. resolution demanding it relinquish control of the territory. An estimated 20,000 people, mostly SWAPO guerrillas, died in the fighting, which ended in April 1989. U.N. Resolution 435, adopted in 1978, established the independence process. It was not implemented until April 1, 1989, after the United States and the Soviet Union brokered an agreement calling for South African and Cuban troop withdrawals from neighboring Angola, where SWAPO bases were located. SWAPO won the most votes in November 1989 elections, but had to compromise with other parties in writing a Western-style, democratic constitution.

POPULATION _ The 1981 census recorded a population of 1.3 million, but the return of 40,000 exiles and the growth rate of 2.7 percent a year makes the figure out-of-date. The population is predominantly black, divided among seven major ethnic divisions, plus Bushmen, mixed-race groups, and 75,000 whites.

ECONOMY _ SWAPO was strongly committed to socialism while in exile but, since winning the November election, has spoken more often of working with the mining, farming and fishing industries to create jobs, educate and improve living conditions for the impoverished black majority. South African aid, coupled with the white-controlled industries, has made Namibia one of the few African countries to achieve an annual per capita income of $1,000. But the country's wealth is concentrated in the hands of the whites, who make up 6 percent of the population, and South Africa is ending its aid.
