DOC.HEAD: `Gunsmoke' Outdraws `Phantom'
With LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Marshal Matt Dillon on CBS outdrew NBC's ``Phantom'' and helped the network claim second place in the overall ratings. A ``Cheers'' episode about St. Patrick's Day bar jokes took first place in the A.C. Nielsen ratings, released Tuesday, for the week ended March 18. ``America's Funniest Home Videos'' on ABC was second and ``Roseanne,'' also ABC, was third. ``Gunsmoke: The Last Apache,'' starring James Arness as the durable lawman, was No. 7 in the ratings, tied with ABC's ``The Wonder Years.'' The program's Sunday night rival, the first half of the two-part NBC miniseries ``The Phantom of the Opera,'' was 40th, tied with ``Amen'' and ``Dear John.'' For the week, NBC finished first with an average rating of 13.8, its 22nd consecutive week of winning the ratings. CBS was in second place with 11.7, edging out ABC, which finished with 11.5. Each ratings point represents 921,000 homes. It was the second time in three weeks that CBS finished No. 2. ``The Simpsons,'' Fox network's cartoon family, finished 11th in the ratings with a 17.5 and won against the first half-hour of a new episode of CBS's ``Murder, She Wrote.'' It was the highest ranking ever for a regularly scheduled Fox show. Here are the Top 10 shows, their networks and ratings: ``Cheers,'' NBC, 22.1; ``America's Funniest Home Videos,'' ABC, 22.0; ``Roseanne,'' ABC, 21.9; ``The Cosby Show,'' NBC, 21.8; ``60 Minutes,'' CBS, 20.4; ``A Different World,'' NBC, 20.3; ``CBS Sunday Movie _ Gunsmoke: The Last Apache,'' CBS, 19.7; (tied with) ``The Wonder Years,'' ABC, 19.7; ``Who's the Boss,'' ABC, 18.1; ``In the Heat of the Night,'' NBC, 17.9. ABC's ``World News Tonight'' was first in the news show average ratings for the 10th week in a row, with 10.6, followed by ``NBC Nightly News'' with 9.2 and the ``CBS Evening News'' with 9.1. Jane Pauley's NBC News special, ``Changes,'' was ranked a respectable 32nd, tied with ``Hunter'' for a 13.2 rating. A repeat of ``The Karen Carpenter Story,'' CBS' much-advertised effort to counter the Pauley show, was in 50th place with ``Anything But Love'' and a 10.8 rating. Although Marshal Dillon did well, another longtime TV stalwart _ ``Kojak'' _on ABC came in 75th for the Saturday night ``ABC Mystery Movie.'' ``Why, Charlie Brown, Why,'' a CBS special with the ``Peanuts'' gang dealing with serious illness, was 65th.

DOC.HEAD: Guerrilla Leader Exiled For Decades is Namibia's First President
With PM-Nambia, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Sam Nujoma, a high school dropout and former railway steward who fled his country 30 years ago after his arrest for political activity, returned in triumph to become its first president. He says he launched a war for independent Namibia with four guns. His South-West Africa People's Organization never controlled any territory during the 23-year guerrilla war against South African rule, despite the loss of 20,000 lives. Nujoma, 60, considered a shrewd, instinctive politician, traveled the world winning support for his cause, and maintained control despite challenges to his leadership. Nujoma, who has a full white beard and a perpetual smile, was generally portrayed by South African authorities as a Marxist terrorist while in exile. But since his return home Sept. 14, even his political opponents have praised Nujoma's moderation and efforts at reconciliation, including agreement on a Western-style democratic constitution, and the appointment of white businessmen and opposition party members to his Cabinet. Many Namibians credit Nujoma's leadership for the smooth transition to independence after the deep divisions caused by the war and South Africa's policies of dividing the country into ethnically based regional governments, with separate education and health care for each race. Nujoma is generally easygoing but can be sensitive about his lack of formal schooling. He is a compelling speaker when he has a prepared text but rambles in disjointed sentences during interviews. ``Others got their education while I led the struggle,'' Nujoma once said. He had been devoted to politics since his 20s, and after being fired from his job as a railway steward for trade union activities, he helped found the Ovamboland People's Organization in the 1950s. It was based in Ovambo, the most populous, northern part of the territory, and was the forerunner to SWAPO, which has been criticized for filling its leadership posts with members of Nujomo's Ovambo tribe. He was arrested following a political protest in 1959, and fled the territory shortly after his release. In exile, he helped establish SWAPO and was named president in 1960. When South Africa refused to head a 1966 U.N. resolution ending its mandate over the former German colony of South-West Africa, Nujoma launched SWAPO's guerrilla campaign. ``We started the armed struggle with only two sub-machine guns and two pistols,'' Nujoma said last year. ``I got them from Algeria, plus some rounds of ammunition.'' SWAPO was never able to claim military victory, but Nujoma won wide political support during his travels to communist and Third World countries. The United Nations declared SWAPO the ``sole and authentic representative of the Namibian people'' although the territory has dozens of political parties. Critics say Nujoma was able to maintain his grip on power during the years of exile through a ruthless security apparatus that detained, tortured and killed dissidents and suspected spies at SWAPO's camps in Angola. The organization has acknowledged that abuses took place, but said some were justified during time of war. Nujoma led SWAPO to victory with 57 percent of the vote in November's elections for a constitutional assembly, but the U.N. independence regulations forced the party to compromise with opponents in establishing a form of government that limits Nujoma to two five-year terms as president.

DOC.HEAD: Cities Swimming in Trash Seek Out Innovative Recycling Help
DOC.NOTE: Eds: wTe Corp. is cq.
DOC.TEXT: A Massachusetts company is making money out of garbage through new recycling methods for cities swimming in the refuse of a throwaway society. Public landfills are clogged with paper, glass, aluminum and plastic, and less than 10 percent of 160 million tons of garbage produced yearly in the United States is recycled, according to David Spencer, president and founder of wTe Corp. in Bedford. His company develops methods for processing waste to recover ferrous metal and other substances. The company also runs trash-to-energy plants under contract with cities, and joined with such companies as Dow Chemical Co. to develop plastics recycling technology. At a research station at the University of California at Berkeley, wTe hauls in barrels of trash to experiment with ways to separate components for recycling and energy conversion. Spencer, 44, believes recycling and recovery, which is the process of extracting certain components of trash, will become increasingly important as cities run out of land to bury refuse, long the cheapest and easiest disposal method. ``Everything we manufacture in this country finds its way into the waste stream. ... It all winds up on a trash truck,'' Spencer said in a recent interview. ``To look at the increase in garbage, just look at the GNP.'' Spencer acknowledged that recovery and recycling operations are costly for cash-strapped municipalities, which must weigh such expenses as housing for the elderly against recycling programs. It often may be less expensive in the short run to bury garbage in a landfill, but in the long run ``yesterday's landfill is today's superfund site,'' he said. Spencer, who has degrees in metallurgy and materials science, is a Philadelphia native who, after attending the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in Cambridge, founded Waste Energy Technology Corp. in 1981. The name was changed to wTe in 1987. Now a $20 million, privately held company with 220 employees, wTe's operations include a waste-to-energy plant and recycling facility in Akron, Ohio, waste-recovery projects in Dade County, Fla., and Columbus, Ohio, and, through a subsidiary, a polystyrene recycling project in Brooklyn, N.Y. In Bedford, the company runs the city's curbside recycling program. Columbus has wTe under contract to use a magnetic process to extract ferrous metal from the city's waste stream before waste is burned in the city's incinerator. That makes the burning process less abrasive and wearing on city equipment. It also reduces the toxic level in and the amount of ash left over, said Tim Barr, deputy director of Columbus public utilities. Ray Kapper, Akron director of public services, said wTe was brought in to run the city's waste-to-energy plant after problems with hazardous waste and an explosion in which three people died. Such plants burn waste to produce steam and other forms of energy. Under contract with Amoco Corp., wTe developed a process for the McDonald's Corp. chain to recycle polystyrene containers tossed away with half-eaten hamburgers and paper. The extracted material is turned into trays and other products for Rubbermaid Inc. Recycling methods can be environmentally benign. For example, discarded tires, long an urban eyesore, can be burned safely to create energy, Spencer says. The 300,000 to 500,000 tires discarded in Akron annually are shredded and fed into the waste-to-energy plant during winter, when people traditionally throw out less trash but energy needs are greater, he said. Spencer said his interest in recycling comes from a lifelong hatred of seeing anything go to waste. ``My mother used to get the squeak out of the pig, as they say,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Exxon Captain Says He Might Not Have Imbibed As Hazelwood Did
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Trial Resumes at 12:30 p.m. EST.
DOC.TEXT: An Exxon tanker captain who once sailed with Joseph Hazelwood gave him high marks for seamanship, but said he might not have imbibed as Hazelwood did before boarding the ill-fated Exxon Valdez. Ivan Mihajlovic, captain of the Exxon San Francisco who testified Wednesday in Hazelwood's defense, said he found no fault with the former skipper's navigation or with his decision to leave the bridge while his tanker transited Prince William Sound. On cross-examination, Assistant District Attorney Brent Cole gave the witness a prosecution scenario in which Hazelwood had five drinks during seven hours ashore in Valdez on March 24, the day his ship sailed and ran aground. ``Do you have an opinion whether that is proper conduct for an Exxon master?'' asked Cole. ``That's probably something I wouldn't do,'' said Mihajlovic. Defense attorney Michael Chalos objected because of a dispute in testimony as to how much Hazelwood actually drank. But Superior Court Judge Karl Johnstone said Cole was entitled to ask the question. Chalos then asked the witness: ``You said your own personal preference wouldn't be to drink ashore. Does the fact someone else would (drink) make it improper?'' ``No,'' responded Mihajlovic. Mihajlovic was among the final witnesses in the defense case which is expected to conclude by week's end. Hazelwood, 43, of Huntington N.Y., is the only Exxon Valdez crew member charged in the nation's worst oil spill. The tanker gashed its hull on Bligh Reef, spewing almost 11 million gallons of Alaska crude that devastated fisheries, wildlife and the pristine shores of the sound. The former skipper is charged with one felony, criminal mischief, and three misdemeanors, reckless endangerment, operating a vessel while intoxicated and negligent discharge of oil. He faces up to 7\ years in prison and $61,000 in fines if convicted. The prosecution maintains that Hazelwood was reckless in leaving the bridge of his tanker in control of a third mate during a transit they claim was hazardous. But Mijalovic said he doesn't consider the sound hazardous and noted he has left the bridge of his own vessel in that area. He said a captain is not required to be on the bridge for that transit. He said such a regulation only exists for the Panama Canal. He also corroborated a defense claim that ships regularly navigate the sound without licensed pilots on board. He cited a 1986 letter from the Alaska Maritime Agency that advised captains the pilotage requirement was waived as long a vessel had two miles of visibility. Hazelwood has a pilotage endorsement for Prince William Sound, but his third mate, Gregory Cousins, had not taken the required exam for endorsement. Witnesses have said the endorsement shows that an officer is familiar with navigational markers and potential hazards in the area. ``One captain told me it was like getting pilotage for the Pacific Ocean,'' Mihajlovic. ``He was joking around that it (the sound) was so open in comparison to the East Coast.''

DOC.HEAD: Shelter Volunteers Spend Wedding Night at Party for Homeless
With PM-Census-Homeless Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Brent and Jennifer Holtfretter wouldn't let a wedding interfere with their work at a shelter for the homeless _ even their own. They got married Tuesday afternoon and then spent part of their honeymoon night working at St. Paul's Community Center. The shelter threw a party Tuesday night to attract homeless people during the U.S. Census Bureau's first count of the homeless across the country. The couple have been working at the shelter for about seven years. ``We spend more time down here than just about any place else. We love these people. They don't have any place to go, and we'll do anything to help,'' said Mrs. Holtfretter. ``We'll get to the honeymoon, but probably much later tonight,'' Holtfretter said.

DOC.HEAD: Bass Brothers Win Battle of Millionaires
With PM-Illinois Primary, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Bass Brothers of Texas won a battle of millionaires when voters rejected a referendum that would have required a huge hog farm to build a $10 million facility to treat manure. Weld County residents voted 14,706 to 6,334 to defeat a referendum on the issue, county officials said. National Farms Inc., owned by the brothers from Fort Worth, Texas, opened the massive hog-processing operation 20 miles east of Greeley last year. When it reaches full capacity, the facility will process 300,000 hogs a year and will be one of the largest hog plants in the nation. ``Our reaction is that it was what we expected,'' said Bill Haw, president of National Farms. ``We built the most environmentally sound livestock facility in the world. The people in Weld County obviously recognized that.'' Advocates of the treatment plant claimed nitrogen from the pig manure is leaching into groundwater and may reach the nearby South Platte River. The most prominent backer of the ballot issue was Denver oil and railroad magnate Philip Anschutz, who owns a 32,000-acre private hunting preserve downstream from the hog plant on the South Platte in northeastern Colorado. Anschutz paid nearly $40,000 to underwrite the efforts of a citizens' group, Protect Our Water, which was the chief advocate for passage. The ballot proposal asked whether ``all swine production facilities in the county designed to hold more than 25,000 animals'' must provide secondary sewage treatment. National Farms is the only facility of that size in Weld County. Haw claimed Anschutz was trying to get even with National Farms because the company bought land that Anschutz wanted for expansion of his preserve. ``It (the vote) was a vendetta by Philip Anschutz,'' Haw said. ``It didn't take.'' Anschutz disagreed. ``The issue with us has always been making certain that public health and environmental protection are maintained as the massive hog farm increases its operations,'' he said in a statement. He said he would continue to monitor the situation. Haw said it would have cost National Farms about $10 million to build the secondary sewage treatment plant the ballot issue would have required. National Farms currently flushes manure from its indoor hog-raising pens several times daily. The waste is collected and then sprayed onto grazing land used by cattle. Haw contended National Farms' irrigation system is sufficient treatment and that growing vegetation will consume the nitrogen from the hog wastes. Other Weld County cattle feedlot operators feared passage of the ballot issue could hurt the county's economy in the long run. ``We think it's serious not only for business, it's serious for the whole economic climate of Weld County,'' said Richard L. Monfort, president of ConAgra Red Meat Cos. of Greeley.

DOC.HEAD: Molinari, Serrano Win Special Elections
With PM-Illinois Primary, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Voters in special elections broadened New York's congressional delegation to include a veteran Hispanic lawmaker and a young Republican woman who's taking her father's seat. Susan Molinari, a 31-year-old Republican City Council member, easily prevailed Tuesday to fill the post vacated by her father, Guy Molinari, who resigned to become Staten Island borough president. She had 60 percent of the vote. Democratic Assemblyman Jose Serrano won even more easily to replace Robert Garcia, a Democrat who quit his South Bronx seat after his conviction in the Wedtech influence-peddling scandal. Serrano, 46, had 92 percent against lackluster opposition. He will be the only Puerto Rico native serving as a full voting member of Congress. Molinari, whose district includes Staten Island and a sliver of Brooklyn, will be the youngest member of Congress. ``I'm just thrilled and very honored by what has taken place tonight,'' said Molinari, who took a congratulatory telephone call from President Bush. She called voters in her district _ where Democrats predominate but often cross party lines _ ``probably the most sophisticated in the city.'' Serrano, who rose from poverty to political prominence, celebrated with Mayor David Dinkins and supporters in a Bronx restaurant. Noting the day's foul weather, he exulted: ``Here we are _ a little bit damp and a lotta bit happy.'' The Hispanic leader had 26,719 votes, or 92 percent, and Republican Simeon Golar had 2,027 votes, or 8 percent, with all precincts in. Turnout, traditionally low in the district, was about 14 percent of the registered voters. Molinari had 45,682 votes, or 60 percent, and Democrat Robert J. Gigante had 25,916 votes, or 34 percent, with all precincts reporting. Two minor party candidates shared the rest. Turnout was about 31 percent. Serrano moved to the Bronx with his family when he was 7 and worked as a bank teller, among other jobs, before winning his Assembly seat in 1974. He rose to be Education Committee chairman, earning a reputation as an earnest and thorough legislator. Jose Roberto Martinez, director of the Puerto Rican federal affairs office in Washington, said he expected Serrano to take a lead in representing Puerto Rican concerns. ``Absolutely, it will be helpful,'' he said. For his part, Serrano noted that his congressional district is one of the nation's poorest and said he plans to speak often with schoolchildren, encouraging them to improve their lives. ``Representing this district is more than being a congressman,'' he said in an interview. ``It's like being a big brother, a social worker, a friend to people who need someone to talk to them and to encourage them to go on.'' Molinari won by dint of her own success in the City Council as well as her father's popularity. Elected to the council by a 161-vote margin in 1985, she won re-election last year in a landslide. Her father, who held the seat since 1980, was co-chairman of Bush's campaign in New York in 1988, and his contacts should help her establish a presence in Congress. At the same time, Molinari has cited her independence from her father and from the Bush administration on matters such as legalized abortion, which she supports. In the campaign she stressed environmental issues, a prime concern in Staten Island.

DOC.HEAD: Some South Africans Question Why Thousands Died in Namibian War
With PM-Namibia, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: As Namibians danced in the streets celebrating independence after 75 years of South African rule, many whites in this country were feeling betrayed and bitter. ``It seems as if the battle over the years was in vain,'' said Johnny Johnson, editor of The Citizen, a newspaper traditionally supportive of the South African government but critical of its handling of Namibia. ``At one time, South-West Africa was regarded virtually as a fifth province of South Africa,'' Johnson wrote in an editorial. He noted that hundreds of ``South Africans lost their lives in its defense. The border became synonymous with patriotism, and duty, and love of one's own country.'' ``The border'' he wrote of is the one Namibia shares with Angola _ 500 miles from the northernmost tip of South Africa _ where South African troops had fought Namibian guerrillas and their allies, Angolan government troops. Many South Africans had come to feel Namibia, also known as South-West Africa, was part of their country. The South-West Africa People's Organization (SWAPO) began a war of urban bombings in 1966, when South Africa rejected a U.N. resolution calling on it to grant Namibia independence. SWAPO established bases in Angola to the north after that country won independence from Portugal in 1975. But the arrival of 50,000 Cuban troops to help the new Marxist Angolan government in its civil war with U.S.-backed guerrillas gave South Africa a reason to delay Namibian independence, and an excuse to enter Angola on the side of the anti-Marxist rebels. Pretoria said it would never allow Namibia to become independent with the chance that Cuban troops would use the territory to reach the borders of South Africa. On the eve of Namibia's independence, President F.W. de Klerk told his nation that it had always been the government's intention to grant independence. ``Today is the culmination of a process which we have started a long time ago,'' he said. ``We've been working for creation of a climate which would allow Namibians to decide for themselves what they want to do.'' What some South Africans could not accept is that the majority of Namibians chose SWAPO and its leader, Sam Nujoma, whom the South African government had characterized for decades as part of the ``total Communist onslaught.'' ``The day SWAPO takes power the Communist flag of Moscow will fly over Windhoek,'' Defense Minister Magnus Malan once said. But it was a rainbow-colored flag representing a multiracial government under a Western-style democratic constitution that was raised over the Namibian capital just after midnight today. And it was the South African president, not Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who was a keynote speaker at the independence festivities. Letters to newspapers have complained for weeks about the $1.9 million contribution the South African government donated to the celebration. Some said it was the price of de Klerk's ticket. It was something the government ``should not have done, if only in respect for those who died in the war,'' Johnson's editorial said. Members of the opposition Conservative Party planned a memorial service this evening for ``young South African men who have died fighting communist forces in South-West Africa and Angola.'' Fred Rundle, one of the memorial service organizers asked: ``What does Mr. F.W. de Klerk and the National Party say to the parents of the over 1,200 young men killed during the war? If the government had decided to give over to the communists, why did they fight the war in the first place?'' The tens of thousands of black Namibians and Angolans on both sides who died in the fighting were never counted. But when the deaths of white soldiers intensified in 1988 as Cuban jet bombers struck farther south, the Dutch Reformed Church, the most influential in the nation, asked: What were the strategic interests of the country that required its sons to die in Angola? The question, an editorial in the church's newspaper, set off a storm, with The Citizen suggesting it gave comfort to the enemy by merely raising the issue. Within three months, however, South African troops were out of Angola. By the end of the year, the agreement had been signed to withdraw from Namibia. ``The sudden switch from war to diplomacy, from conflict to peace, came too suddenly for most South Africans to grasp the fact that the sacrifices had, at worst, been in vain and, at best, had gained time,'' The Citizen said.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuanians Flee Soviet Military In Showdown With Moscow
DOC.TEXT: Algis Bernatavicis broke ranks with the Red Army and joined hundreds of other Lithuanians who deserted after their Baltic republic declared itself independent. ``They accused us of being saboteurs,'' he said Tuesday, one day after walking out on his unit near Moscow. ``They called us Germans and Nazis.'' ``There is no turning back now,'' said his friend, 19-year-old Valdas Grigalunas, who had just left his post with the Northern Fleet. For the hundreds of Lithuanian youths who have fled the Soviet military in the 10 days since their small republic declared itself sovereign, there indeed seems to be no turning back. The new Lithuanian government is backing the youths' decisons to return home and trying to negotiate their security, said Deputy Prime Minister Kazimieras Motieka. But the Soviet military has said it will use force to ship the deserters back to their units _ and presumably military justice _ if the conflict is not resolved by Saturday. The showdown is among the increasing tensions between Lithuania and Moscow. On Tuesday night, police were spot checking the passports of young men boarding the train from Moscow to Lithuania, apparently looking for deserters. Bernatavicis and Grigalunas were interviewed as they debated signing up for a new Lithuanian volunteer force, which officials said would be used as customs and frontier guards. Grigalunas was still officially on leave, but said he was not likely to leave his homeland to return to a harsh life in the Soviet armed forces, which Lithuanians consider an army of occupation. Fifty years ago, Lithuania and fellow Baltic republics Latvia and Estonia were forcibly annexed by the Soviet Union. All three have been complaining since their drive for independence began two years ago that their draftees were being harassed, tortured or killed by soldiers and officers offended by their desire for freedom. In one celebrated case, a young Baltic conscript machine-gunned eight soldiers and claimed it was self-defense against a gang rape. Bernatavicis said insults forced him and 13 other Lithuanians from his unit to desert. He said it was not difficult; he simply changed into civilian clothes and went home. Lithuanian officials said they intend to set up border and customs forces to show the world's governments that Lithuania controls its territory and should be formally recognized as independent. So far, no foreign country has officially recognized Lithuania as independent and Moscow has warned it will not tolerate a change in customs enforcement at the border. The Soviet Union has tens and perhaps hundreds of thousands of troops stationed in Lithuania, whose Baltic port of Klaipeda is extremely valuable to the Soviet navy. Signs in the capital of Vilnius said the Sajudis People's Front, the nationalist movement that dominates the Lithuanian government, was handling registration of men between ages of 19 and 40 who were ready to serve voluntarily in defense of the state. Both men and women responded, crowding the tiny office to fill in applications stating their military experience and availability on short notice. ``I just want to do some good for free Lithuania,'' said a woman about 30 years old. Many of the volunteers are former Soviet soldiers who ``say they consider themselves Lithuanan and want to serve in the Lithuanian army'' said Ludwiga Pociuniene, who was taking applications in another office at the Parliament building. She dug out one letter written by a soldier from Kanous, who said he fled his army unit in Moscow after being beaten senseless and hospitalized. He was later refused care for severe headaches. The youth said his officer told him, ``Lithuanians must hang themselves.'' Pociuniene said the Lithuanian police were under great pressure from Moscow to arrest the deserters, but the new Lithuanian Parliament has asked them not to obey the Kremlin command. In February, even before independence, Lithuania's Parliament ordered state prosecutors to prevent the transfer and filing of charges against Lithuanian soldiers who had to escape unbearable conditions in the Soviet army, according to the Lithuanian Review newspaper.

DOC.HEAD: GOP Moderate Wins in Gubernatorial Race; Savage, Yates Overcome Challengers
LaserPhoto CX6, CX7
DOC.TEXT: A defiant Rep. Gus Savage lashed out at ``the white racist press'' after a narrow victory in Illinois' primary, and GOP Secretary of State Jim Edgar subdued a conservative insurgency to win his party's nomination for governor and set up a fall battle over taxes. Tuesday's voting also brought victories for millionaire attorney Richard J. Phelan in a four-way Democratic primary for the powerful post of Cook County Board president, and for 80-year-old Rep. Sidney Yates, who defeated a 32-year-old Chicago alderman to win renomination to a 21st term. Savage, who faced the toughest primary of his 10-year congressional career after allegations of sexual misconduct involving a Peace Corps worker, defeated Mel Reynolds, 38, who had called the incumbent ``totally ineffective.'' ``The power ... truly is with the people,'' Savage told supporters in declaring victory. ``Our opponent was those whites who control all of the people's television airwaves'' and major newspapers. Savage, who called the race a warm-up for Chicago's 1991 mayoral race, also said, ``I believe that we shall beat (Chicago Mayor) Richard Daley and the Democratic machine and the white racist press in 1991.'' With 95 percent of precincts reporting, Savage had 39,602 votes, or 51 percent; Reynolds had 33,472 votes, or 43 percent, and Ernest Washington Jr., a follower of political extremist Lyndon LaRouche, had 4,187 or 5 percent. In the GOP gubernatorial primary, Edgar, a pro-choice moderate, outdistanced conservative political organizer Steven Baer by nearly 2-1 after an ideologically charged race that drew attention from President Bush and national Republican leaders. With 98 percent of precincts reporting statewide, Edgar had 475,493 votes, or 63 percent, to Baer's 254,092 votes, or 33 percent. A third candidate, Dr. Robert Marshall, trailed with 28,250 votes, or 4 percent. Baer, an anti-abortion, anti-tax activist, had mounted a two-pronged attack on Edgar's pro-choice stance and his call for extension of a temporary 20 percent state income tax increase enacted last year. Edgar's victory sets up a fall contest with Attorney General Neil Hartigan, who was unopposed in the Democratic primary. Four-term Republican Gov. James R. Thompson is retiring. Both Edgar and Hartigan are pro-choice, but Hartigan has taken a wait-and-see stance on extension of the income tax increase. Phelan, who led the U.S. House ethics committee investigation that forced House Speaker Jim Wright into retirement, vowed to clean up Cook County government after his Democratic primary victory. ``Today the people of Cook County voted for a change, and tonight I guarantee you change is on the way,'' Phelan, the son of a Democratic precinct captain, told cheering supporters at a downtown hotel. With 97 percent of precincts reporting, Phelan led with 274,673 votes, or 38 percent, followed by black former state appellate Judge R. Eugene Pincham, 225,757 votes, or 31 percent; state Sen. Ted Lechowicz, the slated candidate of the county Democratic organization with 154,616 votes, or 22 percent; and County Clerk Stanley Kusper, 62,123 votes, or 9 percent. Though Kusper and Lechowicz acknowledged defeat, Pincham refused to concede the election. ``We believe that victory is still here,'' Pincham told a crowd of supporters Tuesday night. ``We're not going to say anything until we get the count in the morning.'' Yates, a veteran of four decades in Congress who represents a district along Chicago's North Shore and in some north suburbs, fended off a spirited primary challenge from freshman Alderman Edwin Eisendrath, who said the district needed new blood. With 99 percent of the precincts reporting, Yates had 53,091 votes or 70 percent; Eisendrath had 20,536 votes or 27 percent; and National Education Association official James Newport-Chiakulas came in third with 2,261 votes, or 3 percent. Yates, who had complained about what he said was Eisendrath's emphasis on age as an issue in the race, said he hadn't enjoyed the contest. ``I think it was one of the most expensive and one of the most negative races in which I've participated,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: State Government To Lift Ban On Eating Kangaroo Steaks
DOC.TEXT: The kangaroo may soon become common cuisine in the country's most populous state now that New South Wales plans to make it legal to dine on Australia's national symbol. ``Quite clearly this is a food product which is very much going to waste and there does seem to be a certain demand for it among restaurateurs and among people who like game meat,'' said Ian Armstrong, the state's agriculture minister. The New South Wales Parliament is considering a bill to legalize kangaroo consumption and Armstrong predicted it would pass during the current legislative session. The state of South Australia and the Northern Territory already allow kangaroo cuisine. Animal welfare groups oppose New South Wales' plans and promised today to picket restaurants or butchers selling kangaroo meat. ``The kangaroo is our national emblem and ... it should not be exploited for monetary value,'' said Christine Townsend of the group Animal Liberation. ``We really think people would be disgusted by eating kangaroo.'' She said it had not been proven that kangaroos were a pest to farmers. She contended that sheep do as much damage to the countryside as kangaroo. Farmers say kangaroos harm their grazing lands and fencing, causing millions of dollars worth of damage. Armstrong said the kangaroo population has grown too large. The National Parks and Wildlife Service estimates that Australia has about 20 million kangaroos. The agency says more than 3 million are killed annually, mainly for their skins and to be used as pet food. The state of New South Wales has about 7 million kangaroos, of which 800,000 will be killed this year, said a spokesman for the wildlife service. Armstrong said butchers who specialize in game meats had expressed interest in the product. He said there also would be a market for exports to Europe. He said his department was considering legalizing the consumption of meat from the Ostrich-like emu bird, but he assured reporters that koala bears and wombats would never become legal menu entrees. Armstrong dismissed fears by conservationists that kangaroo meat was unsafe and said every butchered portion would be inspected. Ms. Townsend, the Animal Liberation spokeswoman, said the country's animal welfare groups would work together to produce leaflets opposing the move, contact restaurant and catering associations, and protest outside any restaurant or butcher that started selling the meat.

DOC.HEAD: Suburban Voters Resoundingly Reject Junkyard Sculptures
With PM-Illinois Primary, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The critics have spoken. By more than 2-to-1, voters Tuesday called for scrapping ``Spindle,'' a 50-foot-tall steel shish kebab spearing eight automobiles, and ``Bil-Bored,'' a sculpture made of household appliances and concrete. In an advisory referendum, folks in this west Chicago suburb said they wanted the junkyard art removed by the owner of the shopping plaza where it is displayed. Before the vote, mall owner David Bermant said he would abide by the voters' wishes in this city of about 53,000. ``I've just about had it with Berwyn. I mean, I'm really discouraged about Berwyn. Don't they have any sense of aesthetics in Berwyn?'' Bermant said. ``I gave them these wonderful works of art and what do I get? Public meetings. Insults. Hate mail.'' ``Spindle'' was rejected, 5,512 to 2,450, in Tuesday's election. The notion of scrapping the 9-year-old ``Bil-Bored'' was greeted with even greater enthusiasm. A total of 6,379 voters want to junk it, and just 1,662 were willing to let it stay. Bermant said he's placed similar works in the 20 shopping plazas he owns around the country, without any problems. Local critics were unmoved. ```Bil-Bored' looks like a big pork chop filled with garbage ... and `Spindle' is just more junk up our gazoos,'' said state Sen. Judy Baar Topinka. Bermant had wanted the issue to come to a vote next fall, after local residents had become more familiar with ``Spindle,'' in place only a few months. ``You need 10 years to gain an understanding of art like this,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: No-Questions-Asked Reward Offered in Museum Heist
DOC.TEXT: Two international auction houses agreed to underwrite a $1 million reward _ no questions asked _ in the theft of a dozen uninsured art treasures from the Gardner Museum. ``Our firm has never done this before, but there has never been such a catastrophic art theft,'' said Diana D. Brooks, president of the Sotheby's auction house. ``This is the most serious theft in our memory. This is a very sad day for the art world,'' she said from New York. The reward in Sunday's heist was offered Tuesday, when the museum remained closed to the public as investigators bustled inside. Sotheby's and Christie's auction houses are underwriting the reward by using their own money and by soliciting funds from art supporters worldwide, museum Director Anne Hawley said. Hawley indicated Tuesday the reward might even be paid to the thieves if the art was safely recovered. Eleven paintings and drawings by Rembrandt, Degas and Vermeer and other old masters were among the works stolen. The loss was estimated in the hundreds of millions of dollars. Investigators focused on what may have been recent, similar efforts to break into the Gardner and the Museum of Fine Arts. About two weeks before Sunday's theft, at least three people participated in an apparently staged disturbance outside the museum, investigators said. A man pounded on the door, the same one the thieves used Sunday, and begged to be let in to escape two attackers, investigators said. When a museum guard refused, the man got into a car with his two supposed attackers and drove off. On Jan. 15, two men who appeared to be police officers tried to enter the Museum of Fine Arts when it was closed for the Martin Luther King Jr. holiday, said William McAuliffe, the museum's chief of security. ``We're checking to see if they were police,'' he said. The Gardner's art collection, gathered and donated for a museum by the late Isabella Stewart Gardner, was only insured for restoration and conservation, not for theft. The cost of theft insurance would be more than the museum's annual $2.8 million operating budget. Besides, Mrs. Gardner's will, which was written in 1920, prohibited any additions or alterations to the collection. Authorities told the museum that the reward would help recover the stolen art. ``The FBI is very certain this will aid in the investigation considerably,'' Hawley said.

DOC.HEAD: Reebok Pulls Television Commercials Amid Consumer Complaints
DOC.TEXT: Officials of Reebok International Ltd., responding to parents' complaints nationwide, have pulled a television commercial which some said could give youngsters a dangerous taste for adventure. The TV spots of 30 and 60 seconds, which made their debut Saturday, featured two men leaping in slow motion from a bridge with an elastic cord tied to their sneakers. The jumper wearing Reeboks bounces back while the other man _ clad in a pair of Nikes _ continues the free fall. ``The Pump from Reebok _ it fits a little better than your ordinary athletic shoe,'' concludes the commercial that has appeared on the CBS, TBS, and Fox networks. Bernadette Mansur, vice president of marketing for the Stoughton-based athletic company, said Tuesday calls had come in from around the country from parents concerned that their children would try emulating the jump. ``We have heard from consumers and we pay special attention to that,'' she said. ``We made a decision and have directed our agency to pull the ad ... for review.'' The company also heard from network officials, some of whom were troubled by the disclaimer: ``Extremely dangerous. Don't try this.'' The message appears briefly at the bottom of the television screen. ``Bungee cord jumping is considered a daredevil sport,'' ABC spokeswoman Janice Gretemeyer said from New York. ``We're concerned about the safety issue and we have asked (Reebok) to make the disclaimer larger.'' Bungee jumping originated in the South Pacific Islands as a test of manhood. Boys were required to leap from bamboo towers with vines attacked to their ankles. Mansur said the company was examining ways to resurrect the commercial, which could include making the warning bolder and scheduling the spot only after 10 p.m. She said a decision would be announced within several days. The flap comes within weeks of Reebok's announcement that it would split with its advertising agency, the New York firm Chiat-Day-Mojo. Company officials have examined bids from at least four agencies vying for the high-profile, $40 million account. The athletic company has been battling for first place with Nike, which had $1.19 billion in U.S. sales last year compared with $1.15 billion for Reebok.

DOC.HEAD: More Money For Defense, Subsidies; Budget Deficit Continues
DOC.TEXT: China today acnowledged severe economic problems but included in its 1990 budget steep spending increases for defense, education and subsidies for inefficient state-run enterprises. ``The present financial situation remains grave, with many contradictions and great difficulties cropping up in national finance,'' Finance Minister Wang Bingqian told the national legislature. The Communist nation's economic downturn, following 18 months of austerity measures, has reduced revenues and complicated efforts to meet demands to balance the budget, he said. ``What is more, in some localities and work units financial procedures became chaotic, supervision and management became lax, budgetary control was loosened and tax evasion, illegal retention of profits, diversion of funds and similar breaches of financial laws and discipline became quite common,'' he said. He told the 2,700 delegates to the annual National People's Congress that China would register a deficit of $1.89 billion, down slightly from $2 billion in 1989. If tabulated by Western accounting methods, in which domestic and foreign borrowing are regarded as part of the deficit, the imbalance would be $9 billion, an increase of more than $1 billion. Wang put state revenues for 1990 at $68.86 billion, up 10.9 percent, and spending at $70.75 billion, up 10.3 percent. While most departments were being told to cut spending and practice frugality again this year, the resurgent military _ with more political clout following its role in putting down pro-democracy demonstrations in June _ was awarded a sizable increase. National defense was budgeted $6.16 billion, an increase of 15.2 percent over 1989. Western military analysts say real spending is far greater if peripheral costs are counted. Spending on education in a nation with a 20 percent illiteracy rate was increased 9.8 percent to $7.5 billion. Nearly one-third of the state budget, $22.6 billion, will go to subsidies for money-losing enterprises and price rises, ``a great drain on the state treasury,'' Wang said. The state in 1990 will need $14 billion to support money-losing state businesses, up from $12.77 billion last year. Wang said the state, which last year required most workers and factories to buy bonds to help finance public debt, has budgeted $2.6 billion to pay back individuals, up $2 billion. However, amortization of bonds held by enterprises, public institutions and banks will be postponed, he said. Wang said the government will try to increase revenues by raising business tax rates and improving collection of individual earnings taxes. He said Beijing will also ``moderately increase'' the revenues local authorities must turn over to the state, and reduce subsidies to some localities. In another speech to the congress, State Planning Commission chief Zou Jiahua said China needed more central controls over the economy, saying the state will set more mandatory targets this year for basic materials in short supply and exert more controls over distribution of goods and capital investment.

DOC.HEAD: Deng Resigns From Last State Post
DOC.TEXT: Senior leader Deng Xiaoping today officially left his last government post, the chairmanship of the state Central Military Commission. The expected move followed the 85-year-old Deng's retirement in November from the Central Military Commission of the ruling Communist Party, a body with largely the same composition and function as the government commission. That was his last party position. Deng, who came to power in the late 1970s and began market-oriented economic reforms that have changed the face of China, is still regarded as the nation's most powerful man. He played an instrumental role in the revival of ideological orthodoxy following the suppression of the pro-democracy movement in June. Although he now holds no party or government posts, he is believed to still have the final say on major decisions and plays a key role in maintaining the outward impression of harmony among Beijing's various leadership factions. Deng has sought to set an example for other aging revolutionaries by stepping down from public office and encouraging the promotion of younger leaders. He resigned from the Politburo Standing Committee, the party's top decision-making body, in late 1987. However, he and other more conservative octogenarians have not relinquished their behind-the-scenes authority. Deng was not present at today's session of the National People's Congress, which accepted his resignation, and did not attend Tuesday's opening of the annual meeting. The congress acted on a letter from the party Central Committee saying that Deng had resigned from the party military commission and proposing that he also be allowed to give up the chairmanship of the state body. The letter noted that party General Secretary Jiang Zemin had been appointed to succeed Deng as chairman of the party military commission. Jiang, Deng's chosen successor after the fall of party chief Zhao Ziyang in June, is also expected to be appointed head of the state military commission, a body responsible for defense policies. However, the congress did not immediately act on naming a new head to the state body.

DOC.HEAD: Clear Skies Cover Much of Nation; Snow, Rain Taper off in Northeast
DOC.TEXT: Snow and rain tapered off today in the Northeast, while clear skies helped swollen rivers recede in the South. Record highs were set in the West for Tuesday, the first day of spring. Temperatures rose to 90 in Los Angeles and 92 in Tucson, Ariz. Temperatures early today were in the 60s and 70s in parts of the lower Rockies, Pacific Coast and Great Plains. Snow and freezing rain fell over much of New England and eastern New York Tuesday. Vermont got the heaviest snow in the region Tuesday. The Killington Ski Area reported 22 inches of snow and expected more by early today. The Catskills were expected to get from 5 to 8 inches of snow today; Philadelphia received a dusting. Freezing temperatures spread early today across inland portions of the Carolinas, the Maryland Panhandle, northern Virginia and much of Georgia. Frost and freezing temperatures also reached across much of Alabama and Mississippi. More than 1,500 people were evacuated Tuesday as the Choctawhatchee River rose in Florida. An additional 500 people were evacuated from other river basins. In Selma, the Alabama River rose more than 12 feet above flood stage. And in Georgia, the Oconee River at Dublin was expected to crest today at 27 feet, 6 feet above flood stage. Tuesday's high for the nation was 95 degrees at Borrego Springs and Palm Springs, Calif., and at Yuma, Ariz. DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up, Gold Lower
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rose against most major foreign currencies in early European trading today, while the British pound plummeted on the heels of Tuesday's budget. Gold prices were sharply lower, falling by as much as $9 an ounce, the lowest level since late last year. The Bank of England reportedly intervened to stop the pound's slide, which began minutes after foreign exchange markets opened in London. Currency dealers said Chancellor of the Exchequer John Major's first budget, delivered to Parliament on Tuesday, was too soft on inflation and increased pressure for another rise in interest rates. ``It is not a happy outlook,'' said Tim Potter, a senior dealer at Goldman Sachs International in London. The dollar gained support from several international events, dealers said, including concerns about Soviet troop movements along the Lithuanian border and fears that the cost of German unification will be far greater than expected. The dollar was also perked up by Tuesday's release of a relatively good U.S. trade report for January, traders said. ``The political and fundamental base for the dollar is very good right now,'' said Jens-Uwe Fischer, senior trader at Manufacturers Hanover in Frankfurt. Markets were closed in Tokyo for Spring Equinox Day, a national holiday. In London, the dollar was quoted at 154.25 Japanese yen, compared with 153.65 at Tuesday's close in Tokyo. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Tuesday: _ 1.7025 West German marks, up from 1.6965 _ 1.5199 Swiss francs, up from 1.5157 _ 5.7477 French francs, up from 5.7340 _ 1.9207 Dutch guilders, up from 1.9107 _ 1,256.75 Italian lire, up from 1,253.50 _ 1.1783 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1792 In London, the dollar strengthened against the British pound, and was quoted at $1.5950, compared with $1.6105 late Tuesday. Bullion dealers said the rising dollar was helping to fuel gold sales, although many linked the metal's weakness to disinterest in buying. Gold was down $8.10 a troy ounce in London and $9.25 in Zurich. The metal in London at a bid price of $393.70, down from $398 bid late Tuesday. At midmorning, the city's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended price of $389.90. In Zurich, the bid price was $390, down from $399.25 late Tuesday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell $6.25 to close at a bid $394.51. Silver fell in London to a bid price of $5.05 a troy ounce, from Tuesday's $5.09.

DOC.HEAD: Jewish Leaders To Meet in Berlin on German Reunification
DOC.TEXT: The Berlin villa where the Nazi leadership met to implement the ``final solution'' against Europe's Jewish population will be the site of a World Jewish Congress conference on German reunification. The New York-based organization announced Tuesday that the meeting is scheduled for May 8, the 45th anniversary of V-E Day. ``The world is expecting a Jewish statement on reunification,'' said Edgar Bronfman, the president of the World Jewish Congress. ``I think that the place where they decided on the `final solution' is the right place to have such a meeting, and the anniversary of the victory in Europe seems to be the right day.'' Some 100 members of the World Jewish Congress from about 70 countries will attend the conference at the villa in Wannsee, Berlin, where on Jan. 20, 1942, high German government and party officials adopted a plan to exterminate the Jews. ``Jews have a right to state a moral position on German reunification and we will make a moral statement. And part of that moral statement is to see that it (the Holocaust) doesn't happen again,'' Bronfman said. In the long run, he said, a united Germany can be ``a very positive thing'' for Europe, but certain precautions must be taken to prevent a repeat of history. For example, Germany's borders ``must be sealed in cement,'' and the country should not be allowed nuclear weapons, he said. Bronfman said he does not fear a resurgence of anti-Semitism once the two Germanys are united. In fact, he said, reunification might cause a decline in anti-Jewish feelings. ``Now that reunification is about to be a fact, they won't be blaming the Jews'' for a divided Germany, Bronfman explained. The conference will convene May 6 and a formal declaration on German reunification will be issued May 8. It will be the first meeting ever held on German soil by the World Jewish Congress, which was founded in 1936 in response to Hitler's threats against Jews.

DOC.HEAD: In Small City, Counting the Homeless One at a Time
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf, `The Census ..., with 3 grafs to UPDATE with this morning's search; pick up 8th graf, `I think ...
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Census-Homeless Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: One by one, nine recovering drug addicts living in a clapboard, barrio church left a religious service to be counted among the homeless. They were nervous about personal questions, but eager to be included in the U.S. Census effort because they so often feel forgotten. ``I think they should know how many people we have,'' said 18-year-old Julie, who asked that her last name not be revealed. Late Tuesday and early today, eight pairs of census-takers fanned out across this west Texas oil and cow town, adding up the unfortunate. The homeless may be more visible in major cities than in towns like San Angelo (population: 90,000), but those who work with the indigent here say they are eager to show that small communities have a problem, too. ``People don't believe it when you tell them there are in excess of 100 street people in San Angelo,'' said Lloyd Thompson, manager of a Salvation Army family shelter. The census duos visited 37 shelters, motels and churches in the San Angelo area Tuesday. This morning, they checked under bridges crossing the Concho River, street corners and city parks as part of the Census count of the homeless in towns as small as 50,000 people. After nearly two hours of searching the streets before sunrise, 10 census workers reported finding only deer, cottontail rabbits, a lawn chair and a water heater laying on its side under a bridge. They said they believed most of the homeless spent the night indoors because of cool temperatures. ``I think there's quite a few homeless here,'' said Judi Chappa, a homeless advocate in San Angelo. ``It's not like New York City, but for a country town, we have a surprising number. That's just the way it is everywhere.'' Police officers and sheriff's deputies offered tips on where homeless gather, and some of the homeless who heard about the count called the Census Bureau to assist in the search, Ms. Chappa said. Jill Dice, a 19-year-old census-taker, said she was scared and nervous as she began questioning recovering addicts at the two-story Victory Temple, a church where a drug rehabilitation center is run. ``I didn't really know how they'd approach what we were doing, but everyone was very cooperative,'' said Ms. Dice, who earns $5 an hour and a 50-cent hourly night differential for the homeless count. Another center resident, 24-year-old Robin, answered questions on the long census form after she was given reassurances of confidentiality. ``I really thought it was a violation of my privacy,'' she said. ``They asked if I was single, divorced or married and what my income was. I don't know what that information is used for, but I think it's a little personal.''

DOC.HEAD: 10-Year-Old Killed in Occupied West Bank, Toll of Children 143
DOC.TEXT: A 10-year-old Palestinian boy was killed by Israeli troops in the occupied West Bank town of Tulkarem, raising to 143 the number of Arab youngsters reported slain in the uprising against Israeli rule. The army and Arab witnesses gave conflicting accounts today of the death of Shukri Barakat, who was hit in the head with a rubber bullet Tuesday evening. The death came a day after former President Jimmy Carter accused Israel of violating the human rights of Palestinians in the occupied territories, citing imprisonment without trial and the shooting deaths of children. Carter, who ended his three-day visit Tuesday, accused Israeli troops of ``excessive use of firearms'' in dealing with the 27-month-old Palestinian uprising. He added: ``A lot of these are little children who have been killed, and these things are very disturbing to me and to the rest of the world.'' According to the Israeli Information Center for Human Rights in the Occupied Territories, the latest death raised to 143 the number of children aged 16 and under killed by Israelis since the uprising began in December 1987. Forty-two have been 12 years and younger, the center said. It listed three Israeli children who died in a firebomb attack on a bus as among the 43 Israeli victims of the uprising. Confronted with past criticism over the deaths of Palestinian children, Israeli military officials have charged that uprising activists put youngsters at risk by placing them at the front of protests. Shukri, a grade school student, was hit in the head by a rubber bullet that shattered his skull, doctors at Ramallah Hospital said. The army said in a statement that stones were thrown at soldiers on patrol and they fired rubber bullets to disperse the youths. ``The troops hit one of the youths, and he was later reported to have died,'' the army said. Relatives told Arab reporters, however, that the boy was standing in the doorway of his home when he was hit with a bullet apparently fired from a nearby rooftop army post. They said they saw no stones thrown. The incident was being investigated by military police, the army spokesman's office said. Tuesday's death was the second reported from a rubber bullet in three days. On Sunday, a 50-year-old Palestinian died after he was hit in the head by a rubber bullet as he drove his horse cart through the Al Amari refugee camp in the West Bank. Palestinians doctors said the bullet was fired at close range. The army says that rubber bullets generally are not lethal. They are frequently used by troops to disperse demonstrators. The child's death raised to 667 the number of Palestinians killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians in the uprising against Israeli rule in the territories Israel seized in the 1967 Middle East war. An additional 198 Palestinians have been killed by fellow Arabs, most on suspicion of collaboration with Israeli authorities. Carter met with Israeli human rights activists during his visit, and attorney Avigdor Feldman told the former president that the high fatality figures seemed to reflect problems with the army's firing regulations. Feldman said: ``Given this toll, and because such a large proportion of the casualties are children who cannot be accused of actually endangering the lives of army troops, one of three conclusions can be reached: either the regulations for opening fire are inappropriate, the regulations are not implemented or those who contravene them are not brought to trial.''

DOC.HEAD: Governor Defends Abortion Statute, Opponent Arraigned
Retransmitting to fix category code.
DOC.TEXT: An opponent of the most restrictive U.S. abortion statute was arraigned in the law's first court test as Gov. Joseph F. Ada today stood behind his signing of the legislation. ``I still believe that a fetus is a human being. And, therefore, as human beings, they have rights _ civil rights,'' Ada said. Ada signed the measure into law Monday. It was unanimously passed March 8 by the U.S. territory's Legislature. The law prohibits abortions except when a pregnancy endangers the life of the mother. It makes it a third-degree felony to perform an abortion or aid in the procedure, a misdemeanor for a woman to solicit or have an abortion and a misdemeanor for a person to solicit a woman to have an abortion. Less than 48 hours after Ada signed the bill, attorney Janet Benshoof, director of the American Civil Liberties Union's Reproductive Freedom Project in New York, was arraigned in Superior Court on a misdemeanor charge of solicitation to commit abortion. She pleaded innocent before Judge Peter C. Siguenza, who released Benshoof on her own recognizance and said a trial date would be scheduled April 2. She said she will continue to organize opponents of the law in hopes of persuading voters to overturn the measure in a November referendum. Benshoof, who traveled here in an unsuccessful attempt to talk Ada out of signing the measure, called the law ``a sick statute'' and ``an invasion of the bedroom.'' ``I can understand and appreciate that,'' Ada said of her comments. ``People have opinions to make and I respect their opinions. It's a democratic country we're in.'' Before the Legislature approved the measure, Attorney General Elizabeth Barrett-Anderson called it unconstitutional. Asked why he signed the legislation over such an objection, Ada said: ``I have to make that decision myself ... And the only body that actually resolves that issue is the court.'' Barrett-Anderson said today law enforcement officials would not enforce the section of the statute forbidding abortions until a court ruling on its constitutionalilty. However, she said that if an abortion is performed and Guam's law is upheld in court, the individuals involved will face criminal charges if the statue of limitations of three years has yet to run out. Barrett-Anderson said authorities would continue to enforce the law's restriction on soliciting a woman to have an abortion. The law sets a referendum during the Nov. 6 general election for residents of this Pacific Ocean island about 1,500 miles east of the Philippines to decide whether to keep the law.

DOC.HEAD: Africa's Last Colony Free At Last
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to UPDATE with parade, parliament sworn in. Picks up 11th pvs, `Forty-one of...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WDH1
DOC.TEXT: The world's newest nation celebrated its birth today with parties, tribal dancing and parades, and ex-guerrilla leaders were sworn in as ministers of the new government. About 25,000 Namibians cheered wildly at a sports stadium as the South African flag was lowered in Africa's last colony just after midnight, replaced by the red, green and blue banner of newly independent Namibia. Tens of thousands lined the main street of Windhoek, the capital, for a three-mile parade. ``Africa's last colony is from this hour liberated,'' President Sam Nujoma said in his inaugural address after U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar swore in the former guerrilla leader. Nujoma led the 23-year fight to end rule by neighboring South Africa. As a fireworks display lit up the sky, Namibians began impromptu parties throughout the capital of Windhoek and car horns blared through the night. ``This is beautiful. We are all thrilled. We have waited so long for this day,'' said Olga Basson as she watched gold and red fireworks ripping through the night sky. President F.W. de Klerk of South Africa, who held his hand across his heart as he watched his nation's flag being lowered, called for an end to violence in southern Africa. ``I stand here tonight as an advocate for peace. The season for violence has passed for Namibia and the whole of southern Africa,'' de Klerk said. ``It is above all a moment for hope. Hope that the future of this vast and beautiful land will bring peace.'' As thousands watched the parade, middle-aged black women from the Herero tribe, wearing colorful ankle-length Victorian dresses and two-pointed headdresses, marched in front of white teen-age baton twirlers. Floats depicted the country's ethnic diversity, including the primitive Bushmen, and modern bands rode flatbed trucks to the stadium. Many young blacks cheered loudly when Palestine Liberation Organization chief Yasser Arafat, his car blocked by the parade, stepped out and walked a few paces along the side of the parade before slipping into a hotel. Later, the National Assembly was sworn in, and it adopted a coat of arms with the Namibian motto: ``Unity, Liberty, Justice.'' Forty-one of the 72 members belong to the South-West Africa People's Organization, the guerrilla movement that fought South African rule then captured U.N.-supervised elections in November. Seven parties, ranging from black Marxists to right-wing whites, are represented in the assembly, which wrote a democratic, Western-style constitution that has earned praise both inside the country and from abroad. De Klerk has pledged to end South Africa's apartheid system of racial segregation and the date chosen for the ceremony was rich in symbolic meaning for his country. It marked the 30th anniversary of the ``Sharpeville Massacre,'' when 69 unarmed demonstrators were shot and killed in South Africa while protesting racial segregation laws in a black township south of Johannesburg. Sharpeville was the turning point for the African National Congress, which broke with decades of nonviolent protest to fight against South Africa's white-run government. ``The day was chosen as a sign of solidarity not only for the people of Namibia, but also with the people of South Africa,'' said Hifikepunye Pohamba, home affairs minister in the new government. South African black nationalist leader Nelson Mandela drew a fervent burst of applause when he entered the stadium. Others attending included Secretary of State James A. Baker III, Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze and the leaders at least 12 African nations. They used the occasion for behind-the-scenes consultations throughout the day, with the United States, the Soviet Union and others holding meetings. The huge, arid territory of 1.3 million people on Africa's southwest coast was a German colony until it was captured by South Africa during World War I. Some whites expressed concern about the new black government, but said they wanted to support the new nation. South Africa agreed in December 1988 to grant independence to Namibia under a regional peace treaty that also calls for Cuba to withdraw its 50,000 soldiers from Angola by mid-1991. South Africa retains control of Walvis Bay, Nambia's only deep sea port, which was a British colony before Germany occupied Namibia. South Africa says the port is part of its territory, but Namibia is demanding it be incorporated into its boundaries.

DOC.HEAD: Appeals Court: Government Can't Bar Clinics from Suggesting Abortion
DOC.TEXT: An organization of family planning clinics hailed as a victory for poor women an appeals court ruling striking down a federal regulation on discussion of abortion. But a different appeals court upheld the regulation, which may send the matter to the U.S. Supreme Court. The 1st U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals said the regulation that bans government-funded family planning clinics discussing abortion with clients is an unconstitutional attempt to limit freedom of speech. ``Poor women deserve to hear and to learn everything that more economically advantaged women hear and learn,'' said Scott Swirling, executive director of the National Family Planning and Reproductive Health Association. The association was a plaintiff in the case, decided in a 4-1 decision released Monday. ``The speech involves informing a woman about the existence of a health- and privacy-related activity in which she has a constitutional right to engage,'' the appeals court said. State Attorney General James Shannon said the ruling was particularly significant because it comes after the U.S. Supreme Court ruling last summer that gave states further authority to set restrictions on abortion. ``What the court has said here is that on constitutional grounds ... these regulations are impermissible,'' Shannon said. He said he expects the matter may go to the Supreme Court because the 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals has ruled differently on the same issue. The court noted that in the 2nd Circuit opinion ``the majority states that the regulations are neutral because they prohibit any discussion about abortion.'' But the 1st Circuit majority rejected that interpretation. ``It is naive to assert that not talking about abortion to a pregnant woman when discussing her options is value-neutral ... By discussing only what is best for the unborn child, the counselor has already made the woman's choice.'' Lucy Eddinger, a spokeswoman for the Office of Population Affairs in the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, which is responsible for administering the regulation, said the agency had not had a chance to review the opinion. Mike W. Robinson, a spokesman for the U.S. Justice Department, which argued the case for the federal government, said no decision had been made on an appeal. In other abortion-related developments: _ Pro-choice forces in Boise, Idaho, were to continue their uphill battle today against anti-abortion advocates claiming they have the votes for final passage of the most restrictive law against abortion in any state. _ Tempers flared Tuesday night in Annapolis, Md., in a weeklong state Senate filibuster by anti-abortion senators when pro-choice senators tried for the first time to break the filibuster.

DOC.HEAD: Squabbling Factions Come to Agreement on Leadership
DOC.TEXT: In a grueling, 12-hour overnight negotiating session, Socialist Party leaders today achieved what eluded them at last week's four-day national congress _ an agreement on who will run the party. The outcome, allowing Pierre Mauroy to retain the powerful post of first secretary, ended former Premier Laurent Fabius' challenge for the job and control of the party apparatus. What remained to be seen was if the political wounds could heal after months of infighting, a failed congress last weekend at Rennes, and a wrenching compromise. ``Ah, if only we had been able to do at Rennes what has just been done in Paris,'' said Mauroy after agreement was reached at 5 a.m. ``I showed a spirt of compromise,'' said Fabius, once France's youngest premier, the protege of President Francois Mitterrand. ``The Rennes electro-shock affected everybody,'' said Fabius. ``Everybody gave a little. Unity prevailed.'' Under the agreement, Fabius will place one of his supporters in the No. 2 party post, and three others will have leadership positions. Mauroy, who was allied with Education Minister Lionel Jospin, also a former first secretary, will have four supporters in the leadership. Three remaining posts will go to a smaller faction led by Premier Michel Rocard, one will go to that of Defense Minister Jean-Pierre Chevenement, and one to Jean Poperen, minister for relations with Parliament. These decisions were to be confirmed later today by a meeting of the Socialists' board of directors. Many words and much ink were expended in recent weeks on the idea of a ``synthesis'' of party platforms supported by the various factions in the party. In reality, policy differences were minimal. The issue was control of the party and what that control might mean to future presidential candidates. Mauroy announced that agreement had been reached on the text of the platform, outlining the party's orientation for the next three years, but no details were provided. ``One doesn't know what it means to be a Socialist in 1990,'' said Julien Dray, author of one of the minority manifestos circulated in Rennes. ``You have the impression that the Socialists are just happy managing the income from growth.'' Poperen also was cautious in his assessment of the compromise, saying that ``all of the difficulties have not been overcome.'' The party clearly suffered from the spectacle at Rennes, which dismayed Socialists everywhere and amused supporters of conservative parties, who have their own problems with unity. Mauroy, who served as Mitterrand's first premier, will have his hands full trying to make the agreement work and putting a new face on a party tarnished by the recent squabbling. Fortunately for the new leadership, it has three years before the next scheduled national elections and five years before France votes for a new president.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Stay Away From Work To Protest 1960 Massacre
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 graf to UPDATE with higher estimates of strike participation, memorial service in Soweto. Pickup 4th pvs, `A police...'
DOC.HEAD: By BARRY RENFREW
Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: Tens of thousands of blacks went on strike today and crowds stoned vehicles and built barricades to mark the 30th anniversary of the ``Sharpeville Massacre,'' in which police killed 69 blacks. Thousands of blacks took part in a ``stay away'' protest in Johannesburg, Durban, Pietermaritzburg, East London and other cities and towns nationwide to mourn those killed during a 1960 march that protested racial segregation laws in Sharpeville, a town outside Johannesburg. The government-run South African Broadcasting Corp. reported that from 20 percent to 70 percent of black workers stayed away from work in many areas. Press reports said participation was higher in some areas, with up to 99 percent of the workforce on strike in parts of Durban. But there was no way to estimate how many people were taking part overall. In a memorial service in the black township of Soweto, an anti-apartheid leader demanded the government end violence. ``Let it not be said we are a violent people ... we are a very tolerant people and if you think about the oppression we have suffered, it goes beyond human endurance,'' said Cassim Salojee, vice president of the anti-apartheid United Democratic Front. A police report today said five men were stabbed to death and their bodies burned in black factional fighting during the past 24 hours, but the deaths did not appear linked to the strike. The 1960 massacre, condemned internationally, was a turning point for the African National Congress, which broke with decades of nonviolent protest to fight South Africa's white-run government. Crowds of youths stoned cars and buses in some parts of Durban and other cities to stop people who wanted to work. Protesters put up barricades to block off some black townships and closed streets with rows of burning tires. Black schoolchildren in some areas attacked schools to enforce the strike and police said a crowd of students set fire to a school in Umlazi in Natal. Police in the eastern province of Natal warned motorists to stay away from some areas because protesters were stoning and burning vehicles. A mob seized a truck and cars and blocked a main road near Pietermaritzburg, they said. Most protests were peaceful, with people organizing marches and meetings. Crowds marched in black townships chanting anti-apartheid slogans and dancing. In Durban, local journalists estimated up to 99 percent of black workers were staying away from work in parts of the east coast city. Virtually no buses were running in black areas and crowds stoned trains in some areas to try and stop service, they said. The streets of central Johannesburg were quiet, with little traffic and few pedestrians in many areas. Thousands of black workers who tried to reach work from outlying towns were stranded after bus drivers refused to work. Some factories and shops in the southeastern industrial cities of East London and Port Elizabeth were forced to close when workers failed to show up. Some businesses closed and gave workers a paid holiday in a show of support. The new nation of Namibia elected to become independent from South African control today to mark the Sharpeville anniversary and show support for South African blacks. ``The day was chosen as a sign of solidarity not only for the people of Namibia, but also with the people of South Africa,'' said Hifikepunye Pohamba, new home affairs minister in the neighboring nation.

DOC.HEAD: Government Rejects Coke's Application For Plant
DOC.TEXT: Coca Cola lost its bid to return to India today when the government turned down an application that would have allowed the soft drink maker to compete with domestic producers. Even a spokesman for Coke's top competitor, Pepsi-Cola, criticized the move as a return to economic nationalism by India, which in recent years had encouraged foreign investment. Commerce Secretary S.P. Shukla said Coke's application to build a $3 million plant in an export zone had been rejected. ``The reasons for our move will be explained in a letter to the applicant,'' he said. A spokeswoman for the Ministry of Commerce said ``protection of India's domestic market played a major factor in the decision.'' A request by PepsiCo. Inc. for an additional plant probably would also be rejected, she added, speaking on condition of not being identified in keeping with government practice. Coke left India in 1977 when it refused to give the government details of its secret syrup formula. An Indian company, calling itself Campa Cola, adopted Coke's logo but not the taste of ``the real thing.'' The Coca Cola Co. applied two years ago to manufacture its syrup in an export processing zone. Under the proposal, only 25 percent of its output would have been sold in India to local bottlers. As an added incentive, Coke offered to invest in a joint venture in southern India to export tea concentrate to Japan. Coke's goal was to break into India's $350 million soft drink market which is now controlled by three domestic soda companies. Industry analysts say there is room for growth in that market. The average Indian consumes only three bottles of soft drink a year, compared to 13 in neighboring Pakistan, 38 in Thailand and 550 in the United States. Murad Baig, a spokesman for Coca-Cola, accused the government of giving in to domestic soda barons and of trying to protect ``a lazy industry.'' ``It is backward-looking and doesn't help India,'' he said. ``We just sacrificed hundreds and hundreds of jobs.'' Coke's revised proposal mirrored a successful bid by PepsiCo Inc., which in 1988 won the right to sell Pepsi in India in exchange for investing in a $15 million agricultural joint venture in Punjab state. Pepsi will begin selling its drink, called Pepsi Era, this summer and has already begun marketing potato chips under the Hostess brand name and its cheese-flavored Cheetos snacks. Pepsi's plan was approved under the administration of then-Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, who opened India to foreign investment. But India's new government, led by Prime Minister V.P. Singh, will ``most probably'' reject PepsiCo's second proposal to set up shop in an export zone, the Ministry of Commerce spokeswoman said. Rajiv Desai, a spokesman for PepsiCo. in India, said the decision to ban Pepsi's top competitor, Coke, ``smacked of economic nationalism. This government is chasing ghosts of the past whereas all over the world everyone else is looking ahead.'' For decades since independence from Britain in 1947, India limited the operation of foreign companies and imposed huge tariffs on imports to protect its domestic industries. Under Gandhi's administration India opened up to foreign business. The clunky Ambassador car faced new competition on India's roads by the sporty Maruti compact, a joint venture with the Japanese company, Suzuki. Ironically, Singh, as finance minister under Gandhi, was the mastermind of much of India's new openness to foreign investment. But his economic policies appear to have changed since he took the top government office. Several of Singh's Cabinet appointments, including George Fernandes, minister of railways, and Madhu Dandadate, minister of finance, are old-school socialists and oppose expansion of foreign investment in India.
