The Ministry of Commerce spokeswoman said she had no idea when the government would decide on another hotly debated foreign investment proposal, by the DuPont Co., for a $140 million U.S. joint venture to make nylon.

DOC.HEAD: Homeless Give Mixed Opinions on Census
With AM-Census-Homeless Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Unemployed factory worker Robert Allen won't have to see the U.S. Census Bureau's figures to learn about homelessness in America. He says he's proof there is a problem. Allen, 28, was among the people approached by census workers Tuesday night at the Cherry Street Mission during the first nationwide survey of homeless people. He walked away when they tried to ask him questions. ``We need jobs, not surveys,'' said Allen, who has been on the streets for three months. ``Why should I take part? What are they going to use the numbers for, anyway? To tell us there ain't no homeless problem? Hell, I'm a living example that there is a problem.'' Two census workers went into the lobby of the mission, where about 10 people were staying Tuesday night. The mission is in an area of topless bars, prostitutes and crack houses. Some of the residents lay on wooden benches; others stood watching a small black-and-white television. The workers went to each person in the shelter, asking them if they wanted to participate. ``Do you need help filling out this form?'' Kathleen Shively, a census worker, asked Jim Grainer, who was lying on a bench. Grainer rose and answered her questions slowly. He said he had been homeless for several years. One person jumped up and tried to attack Ms. Shively, but a guard jumped between the two. Although some people backed away from census workers, others willingly answered the questions. At St. Paul's Community Center, Becky Jenks sat at a table and ate a slice of pizza. She said she lost her home 1{ years ago after she had a stroke and was no longer able to work. ``I don't know if (the census) will help. All I know is that I'm here tonight, so why not give them the information? It can't hurt,'' Ms. Jenks said. The shelter threw a party to encourage the homeless to come in off the streets to be counted. Shelter workers served pizza and soft drinks as most of the 70 patrons sat around a 25-inch color television. Homeless advocacy groups across Ohio cooperated with the Census Bureau but contended the survey was doomed to undercount the homeless. The Ohio Coalition for the Homeless estimated 140,000 men, women and children in Ohio were homeless in 1988, an increase of 18 percent over 1987. The Census Bureau never intended the survey to be an exact count of the homeless, said Jerry Blocker, a spokesman for the regional Census Bureau office in Detroit. ``It's going to give us some ideas about the homeless problem, but we know it's impossible to count every single homeless person. That's not what this survey is about,'' Blocker said.

DOC.HEAD: Popular President Must Now Respond to Pro-Democracy Demands
With PM-Taiwan
DOC.TEXT: President Lee Teng-hui has risen from obscurity to become a widely popular leader since succeeding the Chiang Kai-shek family dynasty. But he now faces intense pressure to bring more democracy to Taiwan. Much of his two-year tenure as president has been marked by cautious policies designed to strike a balance between the conservative old guard of the ruling Nationalist Party and an increasingly restless population clamoring for more freedoms. ``A president acts like the head of a family,'' Lee recently said. ``All members' interests must be taken care of to keep the family happy and harmonious.'' But newspapers recently have drawn a different picture of the 67-year-old leader, saying he rarely consults party elders on important policy decisions. He also displayed independence when he chose his top personal aide as his vice presidential candidate, shunning demands by many old guard politicians that his running mate be the sole surviving son of Chiang Kai-shek. The move led to speculation that Lee was primarily interested in consolidating his own power. ``Some people say Lee could turn himself into another emperor if he is given too much power,'' said Nationalist lawmaker Huang Chu-wen. ``But I don't think he has any intention to do it, nor will the society allow it.'' Many Taiwanese hope that Lee, elected as president for six more years today, will become less cautious and move to dismantle the existing political system that ensures the electoral college and legislature are controlled by old guard Nationalists. Those elderly politicians were elected on mainland China before the Nationalist government fled to Taiwan after losing a civil war to Communist forces. They were frozen in office to support the party's claim that it remains the legitimate government of all China. Public pressure for general elections has increased sharply, particularly after some deputies proposed increasing the assembly's powers and the salaries of its members. A student sit-in at a downtown Taipei park began Friday with 200 participants, but their ranks had swelled today to 2,000. Many said they would stage a one-day hunger strike to promote democratic change. ``He has to grasp this momentum for democratic reform very quickly,'' said Chuang Suo-hang, a fellow at the Institute for National Policy Research. Although concern about the nation's political future has caused Lee's popularity to drop somewhat from his earlier approval ratings of more than 80 percent, he still can count on widespread support and good will. Part of his popularity stems from his being the first native Taiwanese to lead the government and the ruling party, formed 95 years ago on the Chinese mainland by Sun Yat-sen. He has frequently toured the island to visit farmers, soldiers and other groups to build up personal support. Lee was elevated from vice president to head of government in January 1988 when President Chiang Ching-kuo, the son of Chiang Kai-shek, died and ended four decades of family rule on Taiwan. In the last year of his life, Chiang Ching-kuo ended martial law and a ban on opposition political parties in a political liberalization program that Lee says he will continue. Because he is a native Taiwanese, Lee is viewed warily by many old guard Nationalist conservatives who still dream of returning victoriously to rule the Chinese mainland. Lee has carefully reiterated the Nationalist claim to represent all China, but he also has pursued a more pragmatic policy to increase unofficial contacts with the Chinese mainland. He has yet to allow direct trade as demanded by many businessmen.

DOC.HEAD: Texas GOP Gubernatorial Hopeful Says He's Hesitant to Battle Female Foe
DOC.TEXT: Republican Clayton Williams says he would feel uncomfortable facing Ann Richards in the Texas governor's race because she is a woman. The GOP gubernatorial nominee said Tuesday that he had no problem with a woman seeking the governor's office, but added he would be more cautious running against her. Williams' discussion of the gender issue overshadowed a highly touted lunch at the White House with President Bush, who pledged to campaign actively for Williams, a millionaire oilman and rancher. ``I'd be less comfortable, I think, campaigning against a woman,'' said Williams. Ms. Richards faces state Attorney General Jim Mattox in an April 10 runoff for the Democratic nomination. ``Even cowboys get the blues,'' said Ms. Richards in Austin. ``The inevitable is not always comfortable,'' the state treasurer said. ``I don't want to be his mother. I want to be governor of Texas.'' Williams was in Washington for what he called a ``listening and learning'' visit. Last week, he clobbered three opponents to win the GOP nomination to replace retiring Republican Gov. Bill Clements. During a luncheon at a Mexican restaurant for Washington-based reporters for Texas media organizations, Williams made his comments about running against a woman. He said he did not care whether Ms. Richards or Mattox won the Democratic nod. ``We'll take either one of them on,'' said Williams. ``They both have strengths and weaknesses.'' But he took the statement, which he has made earlier, a step further, adding that ``I wouldn't be as comfortable in battling with a woman. I don't have that comfort factor because I've never done that. ``I don't have a problem there, but neither do I have experience,'' said Williams, who has never held political office. Asked to explain his comments, he said, ``The worlds from which I came was the male world.''

DOC.HEAD: Trumps Use Columnist's Fax Machine to Exchange Barbs
DOC.TEXT: The warring Trumps, Donald and Ivana, traded barbs again in their high-profile divorce battle, this time via a gossip columnist's facsimile machine. The millionaire developer faxed a message to the Daily News' Liz Smith complaining that she has shown favoritism toward his wife in her coverage of the split. The letter, according to today's News, read: ``Dear Liz: ``Why don't you stop saying that Ivana is fighting to protect herself and `her' children. (1) The children are `our' children, and no one loves them more than I do; (2) The children are totally protected by me and do not need Ivana's protection exclusively. ``You have carried the episode too far and should be ashamed of yourself as a professional.'' Smith, who first broke the story of the Trumps' estrangement last month, said Trump's message was also faxed to Ivana Trump's attorneys, who responded: ``Donald Trump has a peculiar way of protecting his children when he insists on enforcing an ante-nuptial agreement that would (1) end the continuity of his children's lives by making them move out of their home in the Trump Tower into exile in the country away from their friends and schoolmates; (2) make his children live on 10 percent of what they are presently living on; (3) try to force an agreement where he would have to drop dead _ he is 43 _ before they would get any of his multimillion-dollar empire.'' The Trumps have three children, ages 12, 8, and 6.

DOC.HEAD: Census Takers Find Shelter Door Shut to Them
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 4th graf, bgng, Although the... to UPDATE with overnight low temperature
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Census-Homeless Rdp Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Census Bureau's effort to get an accurate count of the number of homeless people living in the District of Columbia has gone well according to officials, but the process will have to be carried over because of cold weather. Spokeswoman Pauline Lichtman-Panzer said today that low temperatures made it difficult for federal enumerators to locate a lot of homeless people who should be counted and that the count would resume Wednesday. ``We really didn't expect that the temperatures would be so low,'' she said. ``Our enumerators said that caused many more persons to seek refuge in city or private shelters. We'll be back on the streets (Wednesday) and will hopefully get better numbers.'' Although the National Weather Service said temperatures were only four degrees below the normal 38 degree reading overnight, it was far below the sunny, 80-degree-plus afternoons the area had last week. Lichtman-Panzer said that the canvassers were welcomed at most shelter locations they visited during the survey period, but that wasn't the case at the Capitol Hill shelter operated by the Community for Creative Non-Violence, whose leader, Mitch Snyder, refused to let census takers inside. Snyder, who recently fasted for nine days in protest of proposed reductions in the city government's homeless-aid budget, denounced the federal effort Tuesday night. ``Homeless people are very resourceful,'' he said. ``They have to be to survive on the streets. I doubt that the census takers will be going down every alley in the city, looking into every shanty and crawl space. These people should be allowed to have their dignity and not be disturbed in the middle of the night to accommodate government grandstanding.'' Snyder met the census takers outside of the shelter operated by the Community for Creative Non-Violence and turned over approximately 80 census forms that he said had been completed. He had previously announced that no enumerators would be allowed in the building. ``We need to create more shelter space and more affordable housing to get these people off the streets,'' Snyder said. ``All the Census Bureau is doing is putting on a show for the media by sending these teams of counters out on the streets.'' ``You can't use this census with any degree of legitimacy,'' he said. ``Politicians can use these figures to say anything that they want them to _ mainly that the problem of homelessness isn't as bad as the American people have been made to believe because there's no way that you can legitimately count how many homeless people that are in this city or in this country.'' Valerie Lobban, a district office manager with the Census Bureau, said Snyder's actions were not representative of the receptions that census counters had received at other Washington shelters. She said the process had reportedly been going without difficulty. The District of Columbia government estimates there are 7,500 homeless people in the nation's capital, up more than 50 percent from 1982 levels. Wylie Williams, the district's deputy mayor for economic development, said the count was important because ``only when we know how many homeless there are can improvements be made in the delivery of services.''

DOC.HEAD: Report: Iran Working To Free One Hostage
DOC.TEXT: A senior Iranian official has said his government is working for the release of a hostage held in Lebanon, The New York Times reported today. The official, an ally of President Hashemi Rafsanjani who asked not to be identified, said in a European capital last weekend that the Iranian government was operating with the ``full expectation that the United States, in particular, will show an equal amount of good will,'' the Times reported. The statement implied that actions by the United States like releasing frozen Iranian assets would help continue the process, said the Times. The official did not name the hostage targeted for possible release or specify his nationality. There are eight Americans among the 18 Westerners believed held hostage in Lebanon. The longest held, Terry A. Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, began his sixth year in captivity last week. Iranian officials including a deputy foreign minister have said recently that all the hostages may be released this year. But other senior Iranian figures, including former interior Minister Ali Akbar Mohtashemi, have called for the continued imprisonment of foreign hostages in Lebanon. The senior Iranian official insisted that the importance of militant opponents of the release of hostages was ``being greatly exaggerated abroad.'' On Tuesday, Iranian radio reported that a majority of Parliament issued a statement late Monday calling on the Foreign Ministry to distance itself from the hostage issue as a Lebanese internal affair. The official said that in his view, the United States has wasted time talking to ``unimportant people'' about the hostages, including middlemen and businessmen who pretend to have special ties to the Iranian government. He said talks should be conducted with responsible Iranian officials in the context of normalizing ties and not just getting hostages out.

DOC.HEAD: Troops Sent To Transylvanian City Shaken By Ethnic Violence
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 7th graf, `Since the...' with 2 grafs to ADD background on Iron Guard. Pickup 8th graf `A government...'
DOC.TEXT: Romanians and ethnic Hungarians took to the streets of a northwestern city again today, and the army sent reinforcements to quell ethnic violence that has left at least six people dead. Troops cordoned off the town after armed ethnic Romanians on Tuesday night poured in from neighboring villages and battled ethnic Hungarians, who were protesting an attack a day earlier on their political association headquarters. Also today, a government fact-finding panel went to Tirgu Mures, a Transylvanian city 250 miles northwest of Bucharest. Vice President Cazimir Ionescu said leaflets distributed by the fascist Iron Guard had caused the fighting by falsely claiming that the Hungarian minority centered in Transylvania is seeking political autonomy. ``They scared the Romanians with the idea that the Hungarians want to take over Transylvania, and they are telling the Hungarians that some requests they have made (to the government) will not be granted,'' he said in an interview. ``It's a movement that wants to create panic, but we don't know exactly what it wants,'' the vice president said. Since the December revolution toppled Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, Romania has been inundated with propaganda signed by the Iron Guard calling on Romania to expel ethnic Hungarians and other ethnic minorities. The grassroots, fascist organization was powerful in Romania during the late 1930s and early 1940s. During the Ceausescu regime, Iron Guard and other non-Communist groups were repressed. This morning more than 2,000 ethnic Hungarians gathered in Tirgu Mures' central Square of Roses, witnesses said. Groups of Romanians were gathering on the outskirts of the city and heading for the square, the witnesses said. A government commission of inquiry flew to Tirgu Mures this morning, and additional troop reinforcements were sent in from neighboring areas to try to quell the violence that government radio said left six dead and 300 injured. One witness in the city of 250,000, Ioan Pol, said some ethnic Hungarians threw firebombs during the fighting Tuesday. He said he heard what appeared to be gunfire, but its origin was unknown. Among those hospitalized was Kevin Harvey, a British photographer working for The Associated Press, who was beaten and clubbed. The ruling Council of National Unity, which is dominated by former Communists, met in special session today to decide on additional measures to defuse the tension. The provisional government appealed for calm. Neighboring Hungary asked for immediate U.N. mediation to restore order in the region, the Hungarian state news agency MTI reported. The fighting, the most widespread ethnic violence in Romania in decades, began Saturday when a crowd attacked a Tirgu Mures pharmacy that posted a Hungarian-language sign, Hungarian news media reported. The clashes have their roots in traditional historical rivalries in the region, fueled by ethnic Hungarian demands since December for greater cultural and political autonomy, including the use of Hungarian street signs, Hungarian-language television, schools and other social institutions. In the Hungarian capital of Budapest, about 50,000 people rallied Tuesday in support of the estimated 1.7 million ethnic Hungarians in Romania, who were long suppressed by Ceausescu. ``Ceausescu is dead, but it seems that some want to keep his spirit alive,'' Istvan Csurka, a leader of the nationalist Hungarian Democratic Front, told the torch-bearing crowd. In the Romanian city of Iasi near the Soviet border republic of Moldavia, demonstrators also took to the streets to protest the ethnic clashes. Ceausescu, ousted and executed in a popular revolution in December, was replaced by a provisional government pledging democratic reform, but ethnic Hungarians say his discriminationatory policies have continued. Hungary asked for immediate U.N. mediation to restore order in the region, MTI reported. Romania's leadership repeatedly broadcast a warning Tuesday that ``any kind of extremist, nationalist or chauvinistic actions, irrespective of who they come from, are of the nature to destabilize the national and international situation of Romania.'' ``We insist that you go back to your homes in peace,'' said the communique, signed by leaders of the ruling Council of National Unity. Tirgu Mures is considered a cradle of ethnic Hungarian culture in Transylvania, which was ruled by Hungarians for centuries before being granted to Romania under a 1920 treaty. Most of Romania's ethnic Hungarians live in Transylvania. Under Ceausescu, ethnic culture and minority rights were largely suppressed in a drive to impose a single national identity in this country of 23 million people.

DOC.HEAD: Injured Migrant Workers May Sue Employers After Receiving Benefits
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court ruled today that migrant farm workers injured on the job may sue their employers in federal court after receiving worker-compensation benefits. By a 9-0 vote in a Florida case, the justices said states do not have the power to ban such suits. Justice Thurgood Marshall, writing for the court, rejected the U.S. Labor Department's interpretation of a federal law designed to protect the seasonal workers. The law, the Migrant and Seasonal Agricultural Worker Protection Act, provides ``aggrieved farmworkers with direct recourse to federal court where their rights under the statute are violated,'' Marshall said. The Labor Department is not empowered ``to regulate the scope of the judicial power vested by the statute.'' The court upheld a lower court victory for 10 Florida farmhands who were hurt in 1985 while being transported in a van by their employer, the Adams Fruit Co. Each collected worker-compensation benefits from Adams under Florida law and then sued the company in federal court, alleging the van was unsafe. The company said Florida's worker-compensation law made it the exclusive legal remedy for such injuries and a federal judge agreed. But the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals overruled the judge and reinstated the workers' suit. That ruling conflicted with a decision by the 4th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals which said a farm worker injured when sprayed by pesticides could not sue. In resolving the conflict today, Marshall said the federal law's enforcement provisions ``in no way intimate that the availability'' of the right to sue in federal court ``is affected by state workers' compensation law.'' State officials from California, Texas and Massachusetts urged the high court to rule in favor of the migrant workers. The case is Adams Fruit vs. Barrett, 88-2035.

DOC.HEAD: Hungary Cancels Flights Carrying Jews to Israel
DOC.TEXT: The Hungarian state airline Malev today suspened flights of Soviet Jews to Israel because of a threat last week by a Moslem extremist group in Lebanon, the state news agency MTI reported. ``Malev has informed MTI that because of the threats .... it has suspended the transportation of Soviet emigrants to Israel because it does not wish to jeopardize the safety of passengers and aircraft,'' the news agency said. The threat issued Thursday in Lebanon by Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine warned all airlines against carrying Soviet Jews to Israel. ``All airports facilitating the transport as well as airlines, their jetliners and offices, will be direct targets for us,'' said Jihad, which holds some of the eight American hostages. ``This is a warning and a threat.'' Many Arab governments have opposed the emigration of Soviet Jews to Israel, saying that many of them may be settled in the occupied territories, strengthening Israel's hold on the disputed lands. Earlier today, MTI said that security had been tightened to unprecedented levels at Budapest's Ferihegy airport following the threat. Budapest is a transit point for many Soviet Jews traveling from Moscow since there are no direct flights from the Soviet Union to Israel. In the warning, Islamic Jihad gave the airlines a week-long grace period before they would be considered targets of their attacks. Col. Geza Kantor, deputy head of department at national police headquarters, said the threat was being taken seriously and that Hungarian police, border guards, and Malev's security guards were cooperating.

DOC.HEAD: Counters Prowl Mean Streets and Hideaways to Tally Homeless
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with gunshot in Brooklyn, robbery in Florida, quote from census director, picking up 4th graf, `It shows ...; INSERTS 2 grafs after 10th graf, `In St. Paul ..., with details of gunshot and robbery; SUBS grafs 14-15, `In New York ..., with 2 grafs to UPDATE with census officials denying undercount; edits throughout to tighten. Pick up 16th graf, `In Manchester ...
DOC.HEAD: LaserColor FX3, LaserPhoto DX2
DOC.TEXT: A government trying to shed light on how many of its citizens live in the shadows wrapped up an unprecedented 14-hour survey today to count the homeless. Free meals, blankets and parties helped lure the homeless to government workers carrying clipboards and flashlights. But the counters, some of them homeless themselves, also encountered gunfire in Brooklyn, a spring snow in Vermont, robbers in Florida, and the protests of critics and elusive targets everywhere. And many of the homeless fell, once again, between the cracks. Although results of the homeless census won't be known for months, the Census Bureau declared it a success. ``Nationally, the operation went very smoothly,'' Census Director Barbara Everitt Bryant said at a morning news conference in New York. Ms. Bryant noted that there were a few spots, including Cleveland and Washington, D.C., where the census workers didn't finish and would return tonight. Around the nation, some homeless people took comfort in the very fact of being counted. ``It shows that they're starting to recognize us as humans and not the scum of the earth,'' said Chester Broadwell, 21, a resident of the Waystation shelter in Burlington, Vt. But in Toledo, Ohio, 28-year-old Robert Allen snubbed U.S. Census officials. ``What are they going to use the numbers for anyway? To tell us there ain't no homeless problem? Hell, I'm a living example that there is a problem,'' Allen said. ``We need jobs, not surveys.'' A total of 15,000 enumerators _ the federal term for headcounters _ were dispatched to seek the name, age, sex, race and marital status of a segment of society that considers itself forgotten. The $2.7 million effort, the most ambitious ever undertaken to count the homeless, focused on every city of 50,000 or more residents. The tally will be added to the conventional census that begins April 1 as part of the constitutional mandate to count citizens every 10 years. The homeless were sought out at shelters, missions, flophouses, cheap hotels, bus depots, subway cars, underpasses, bridges, railroad trestles, bank machine chambers, park benches, trash bins and abandoned buildings. In St. Paul, Minn., census workers waited outside limestone caves along the Mississippi River. Once the domain of bootleggers, they now are frequented by the homeless. In New York City, enumerators in Brooklyn ran for cover early today when a gunshot came from a building they were approaching, according to Fernando Armstrong, assistant regional census manager. No one was injured, and Armstrong said it wasn't clear that the shot was aimed at the census-takers. In Fort Lauderdale, Fla., two census takers were robbed at a homeless shelter by a man who followed them after being interviewed, Census Bureau spokesman Ken Baldowski said. The workers were not injured and they pledged to continue their work, he said. No count was made public, and the nationwide survey did little to settle the debate over the size of the homeless population, now estimated at a low of 250,000 to a high of more than 3 million. Before the count, which targeted 22,000 shelters and street sites nationwide, Ms. Bryant said, ``We'll get the vast majority. There are no believable numbers of homeless in America. This is going to get an order of the magnitude of the problem.'' Still, many homeless people clearly went uncounted. In New York City, eight enumerators and a supervisor spent slightly more than an hour at the Port Authority Bus Terminal, where hundreds of homeless stay. But they appeared to spend much of their time milling about a newstand on the terminal's ground level rather than on the upper levels where many homeless people sleep in stairwells, on bus platforms and in hallways. Regional Director Sheila Grimm denied that the counters had avoided the upper levels. She said the nature of the homeless at the Port Authority demanded that the enumerators merely make a sweep through the terminal rather than interview individuals. In Manchester, N.H., census workers overlooked a man sleeping on the steps of City Hall _ it was outside the specified survey area. And in northern California, census workers skipped spots in the Santa Cruz mountains where, in two incidents two years ago, shots were fired at census representatives doing preparatory work for the 1990 census. Activists who consider homelessness a national disgrace fear an undercount that will justify government cuts in services. Counters were turned away from the 1,400-bed shelter in Washington, D.C., operated by the Community for Creative Non-Violence. ``These people should be allowed to have their dignity and not be disturbed in the middle of the night to accommodate government grandstanding,'' said activist Mitch Snyder. David Hayden also rebuffed counters at his Justice House Community in Roanoke, Va. He earlier had burned census forms to protest what he claimed was a bogus count. But other shelters sought to get the highest tally possible. ``We ought to do everything we can to get as many names on the list as possible,'' said Ruth Beshalske, director of the St. Paul's Community Shelter in Toledo, Ohio, site of a party for the homeless. In Sacramento, Calif., one group gave away 1,000 blankets at a Salvation Army center, where the city contributed to a free ham dinner. ``That's how much we think it is in the city's interest to get an accurate count,'' said Arnie Godmintz, a coordinator from the Sacramento Housing and Redevelopment Agency. The Union Gospel Mission in St. Paul, Minn., waived the $1.25 price for a meal and drew a crowd of about 250 to 300 people, double the normal showing. Counters faced all manner of obstacles in the nightlong tally, not the least of which was 22 inches of springtime snow in parts of Vermont that interrupted the tally. At New York's Grand Central Terminal, census counters tried to interview those who were lucid while recording what they could observe about the sex, age and race of those who were sleeping or hostile. ``Don't smile at me,'' snarled one woman. ``I have a right to remain silent,'' said a man nearby. A pair of feet sticking out of a cardboard box and the outline of a person under a blanket on a dark train platform were recorded simply as two more bodies. In San Francisco, one man at a shelter guffawed when he was asked a standard census question: ``Are you a person away from your usual home for a short time, such as on a vacation or a business trip?'' Census officials say the count will help determine such things as congressional and state representation and how much taxpayers' dollars are doled out for homeless programs.

DOC.HEAD: Lord Victor Rothschild Dies at 79
DOC.TEXT: Lord Victor Rothschild, millionaire banker and former British intelligence agent, has died in London, his wife said today. He was 79. Lady Rothschild said in a statement that her husband died Tuesday. She did not disclose the cause of death or other details. His secretary refused to say whether Rothschild had been ill or if he had died at home. Rothschild was born on Oct. 31, 1910, into the 200-year-old family descended from Jewish-German coin collectors who founded a banking dynasty. He succeeded his uncle as the 4th Baron Rothschild in 1937. He took his seat in the House of Lords, the unelected upper chamber of Parliament, as a member of the Labor Party. In 1986, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher cleared Rothschild of accusations he was a Soviet spy. Mrs. Thatcher said there was no evidence he was the so-called Fifth Man in the infamous spy ring of Guy Burgess, Kim Philby, Donald Maclean and Anthony Blunt. Rothschild had been a senior officer in MI5, Britain's domestic intelligence agency. He was friends in his university days at Cambridge with some students who later betrayed Britain, including Blunt. An orthodox Jew, he was awarded an honorary degree from Tel Aviv University for ``the advancement of science, education and the economy of Israel'' in 1971. It was followed in 1975 by an honorary degree from Jerusalem's Hebrew University. Rothschild was regarded as an intellectual and, although he shunned publicity, he was an avid party-goer. Britain awarded him the George Medal for bravery in World War II for defusing German bombs. He also received the American Legion of Merit for his wartime efforts. Lady Rothschild's statement said a private funeral will be held but did not disclose details. She said there would be a memorial service later. Besides his wife, the former Tessa Mayor, Rothschild is survived by their son James and their two daughters, Emma and Victoria. He also is survived by three children from his first marriage, a son Jacob and two daughters, Sarah and Miranda.

DOC.HEAD: Bush to Visit Atlanta, Cincinnati, Indianapolis and Detroit
DOC.TEXT: President Bush will travel to Atlanta, Cincinnati, Indianapolis and Detroit on April 2 and 3, the White House announced today. At his first stop, in Atlanta, Bush will address the 68th annual convention of the National Association of Broadcasters, said presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. In Cincinnati, Bush will tour General Electric's aircraft engine plant and attend a fund-raising dinner for Ohio Republican gubernatorial nominee George Voinovich. He will stay there for the night. On April 3, he will participate in a tree-planting program, ``Trees for Tomorrow,'' and attend a fund-raising luncheon for Republican Sen. Dan Coats. In Detroit, Bush will attend a fund-raising dinner for the Michigan state Republican party.

DOC.HEAD: Peres Meets with Religious Parties to Form New Government
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 12 graf, `Peres was...' with 1 graf that party has 5 members, ADDS two grafs after 13th, ``The agreement...' to ADD details on talks with second religious party. Pickup 14th graf, `Shamir's 15-month-old...' ^By ALLYN FISHER
DOC.TEXT: Labor Party leader Shimon Peres today held talks with key religious parties aimed at building a new governing coalition to replace the right-wing Likud bloc's caretaker government. In another development, the director of the Government Press Office disputed a State Department report that the Palestine Liberation Organization was adhering to its pledge to renounce terrorism. Peres' moves followed his designation by President Chaim Herzog on Tuesday to build a government to replace the Likud-Labor coaltion Cabinet toppled in a Parliament vote of no confidence Thursday. The decision by Herzog brought renewed calls in Likud to oust caretaker Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir as party leader since his party could be excluded from the government for the first time in 13 years, Israeli newspapers said. Peres said he telephoned Shamir today and asked him to meet to discuss forming a new joint coalition. Shamir refused, Peres said on Army radio. ``Mr. Shamir's response was that they have a decision not to join a Labor-led government and so he saw no need'' to meet, Peres said. Industry Minister Moshe Nissim of the Likud bloc said a Labor-led government would cause ``severe political damage to Israel.'' Shamir met today with six other Likud leaders to map out a strategy for blocking Peres' coalition-building, the radio said. If Likud can muster 60 votes in the 120-member Parliament they can prevent the 66-year-old Peres from becoming prime minister. Peres has six weeks to build a coalition and if he fails, Likud could be named to try. But political analysts believed the momentum was in Peres' hands and that he could outmaneuver Likud if he acted quickly. Israeli news reports said Peres hoped to present a new Cabinet to Parliament for a customary vote of approval by next week. Peres was optimistic after a two-hour meeting with the five-member Agudat Israel party. He said on the radio that an ``agreement was emerging,'' with the pivotal ultra-Orthodox party. The agreement was based on Labor promises to provide funds for religious seminaries and housing in exchange for a freeze in ultra-Orthodox demands for controversial religious legislation, Peres said. Together with Agudat, the left, and Arab parties, Labor would have 60 votes for a government, meaning that it would still need to win over at least one of three other religious parties. Labor leaders viewed their best chance as an alliance with the ultra-Orthodox Shas, or ``Sephardic Torah Guardians,'' which holds five seats in Parliament. Shamir's 15-month-old coalition collapsed on a no-confidence motion after Shamir refused to accept a U.S. plan for starting an Israeli-Palestinian dialogue. Peres has already pledged that as premier he will accept the compromise proposals by Secretary of State James A. Baker III. Regarding the State Department report on the PLO, the director of the Government Press Office, Yossi Olmert, said it ``is not relevant to reality.'' ``The PLO continues to be deeply involved in terrorist activity against Israel, both in Israel proper and in the occupied territories,'' he said in a statement. At the same time, the army chief of staff, Lt. Gen. Dan Shomron, was quoted as saying there was no proof that PLO chief Yasser Arafat's mainstream faction, Fatah, was carrying out attacks against Israel. The State Department report listed nearly 30 border and rocket attacks by Palestinian groups against Israel since Arafat renounced terrorism in December 1988. But it added: ``We have no evidence in those cases or any others that the actions were authorized and approved by the PLO Executive Committee or by Arafat personally.'' Israel has maintained that the PLO is a ``terrorist organization'' and has urged the United States to end its dialogue with the PLO. A government report provided by Olmert said that in 1989, there were 12 attacks by Fatah within Israel; 15 attempts at cross-border attacks; and two firings of rockets at farming settlements.

DOC.HEAD: Prospective Jurors Remember Imelda's Shoes As Trial Begins
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to UPDATE with Manila papers publishing letter, Mrs. Marcos arriving in court today, juror questioning. Picks up 10th graf, `Supporters greeted...'.
DOC.TEXT: Prospective jurors in the fraud trial of Imelda Marcos said they did not know very much about the former Philippines first lady _ except that she owned more than 1,000 pairs of shoes. ``I heard about the shoes, she bought a lot of shoes, and that's about it,'' said David Gong, a 26-year-old graduate student who was among 10 people who passed the first test on Tuesday as jury selection began in U.S. District Court. In Manila, newspapers published the text of a letter sent by Mrs. Marcos to President Bush, offering to turn over her fortune to a five-member international panel, which would distribute the funds to the Filipino people. In the letter, released by the Philippine government, Mrs. Marcos claimed she was innocent and that the trial was an attempt to ``extort money and property from me.'' Mrs. Marcos' attorney, Gerry Spence, said Mrs. Marcos wrote to offer Bush help in finding funds allegedly stolen from the Manila government, on condition the money be used for Philippine charities, and that Bush help to arrange for her husband's body to be sent home from Hawaii, where he died last Sept. 28. Spence said she had not received an answer. In Washington, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Bush had received a letter from Mrs. Marcos. Fitzwater would not elaborate, saying only that the president could not respond for legal reasons pertaining to the trial. Judge John F. Keenan today resumed his screening of 150 prospective jurors after excusing 10 and tentatively accepting 10 others on the first day. Mrs. Marcos, met at the courthouse by a few reporters and photographers, had no comment other than a brief ``good morning.'' Mrs. Marcos, 60, is accused of participating in the illegal transfer of more than $160 million from the Philippines treasury to buy Manhattan real estate, and of defrauding banking institutions of another $165 million to finance the deals. Also on trial is Saudi financier Adnan Khashoggi, accused of helping Mrs. Marcos and her late husband, Philippines President Ferdinand E. Marcos, conceal their ownership of the real estate. Marcos was named in the October 1988 indictment, but died Sept. 28 in exile in Hawaii. Mrs. Marcos, wearing a black dress and a mournful expression, told the mob of reporters who met her Tuesday that she was unhappy over facing trial here. ``I should be tried in my own country, the Republic of the Philippines, not in a foreign country,'' she said. Supporters greeted Mrs. Marcos with signs reading ``Marcos is Innocent'' and ``Justice for Imelda.'' Other signs showed pictures of the Marcoses with ex-presidents Nixon, Carter and Reagan. Arriving separately with his lawyers, Khashoggi told reporters he felt the United States had ``betrayed'' Mrs. Marcos, but was ``too big to be embarrassed'' by any revelations from the trial. Asked where he might prefer to be, the Saudi who was once called the world's richest man replied, ``I would rather be in Mecca, fasting.'' Mrs. Marcos could face a maximum of 50 years in prison and a $1 million fine if convicted on all counts of racketeering, racketeering conspiracy, mail fraud and obstruction of justice. Khashoggi, 54, is charged with obstruction of justice and mail fraud, which carry a maximum sentence upon conviction of 10 years in prison and a $500,000 fine. Both defendants have pleaded innocent. Those prospective jurors not dismissed for such reasons as work obligations or personal bias were told to return to court next Tuesday when the final panel is to be chosen. The trial is expected to last three to four months. Asked what they knew of Mrs. Marcos, several prospective jurors said they had heard about the many pairs of shoes she left behind when she and her husband fled the Phillipines in early 1986 and went into exile in Hawaii. Critics of the Marcoses, including the government of President Corazon Aquino, have cited the shoes as symbolizing the excesses of an opulent lifestyle of leaders in a country plagued by widespread poverty. Samuel Cerezo, a 51-year-old transit official, was asked whether the shoes would prejudice him against Mrs. Marcos. ``No, my daughter also has a lot of shoes,'' he replied.

DOC.HEAD: Floods Keep About 1,500 From Homes in Florida Panhandle
LaserPhoto XMAR1
DOC.TEXT: Flood waters flowed over the Florida panhandle today, keeping about 1,500 people from their homes, and the swollen Alabama River spread into a miles-wide, coffee-colored lake curving around Selma. The Choctawhatchee River crested at Caryville overnight at 21 feet, or 9 feet above flood stage. But the river was continuing to rise about 20 miles downstream near Ebro, said Ginger Vance, a spokeswoman for the Washington County Civil Defense office. It will be at least Thursday before most evacuees can start returning to their homes and begin cleaning up, said county Adminstrator Roger Hagan. Caryville is a small farming town about 100 miles west of Tallahassee. Most of the people forced from their homes were staying with friends or relatives or camping out, said Sharon Fowler, a state Department of Health and Rehabilitative Services worker. She said only about 20 people spent the night at a shelter in Bonifay. ``A lot of people are camping out out in the woods, in the hills, wherever they can get,'' she said. ``They want to stay close to their property.'' The flood waters surged into the Florida panhandle from Alabama and Georgia after heavy rain doused those states last week. At least 11 people died in flood-related accidents in Alabama. Alabama rivers swollen by torrential rain were dropping over much of the state today, with drops of more than 7 feet by the Alabama River at Catoma Creek near Montgomery and 9 feet by the Pea River at the hamlet of Elba. A broken levee at Elba forced about 2,000 residents to flee as flood waters turned the town into a lake over the weekend. Few people have been able to return to their homes because power and phone service remained out. City officials planned to tour the ravaged downtown area today. Engineers with Army Corps of Engineers said Tuesday that the levee had no structural flaws; it just wasn't high enough for the flood. Hundreds lined up in Elba on Tuesday for diphtheria and tetanus booster shots to avoid any outbreak of diseases associated with flood waters or contaminated drinking water. There was no levee to protect low-lying areas in Selma, where caskets rose from the ground in a flooded cemetery and up to 500 people fled their homes Tuesday when the Alabama River rose more than 12 feet above flood stage. About 65 homeless people bedded down for the night in a school gymnasium. ``We were about under water,'' said Richard Colman, who was rescued from his home by helicopter. ``The water just kept on rising and it caught us.'' Selma's central business district sits safely on a bluff above the Alabama River, but raging flood waters poured into poor neighborhoods on the east side of town and the opposite side of the river. A half-dozen caskets popped from the inundated ground at Elmwood Cemetery on Monday. ``I think what happened is that most of the graves were pretty recent and the water came up before the dirt had settled down good and the pressure just brought them up,'' said Jonas Lewis, the cemetery's caretaker. In Geneva, Ala., emergency workers stopped up a break in the levee that was flowing like an open fire hydrant near the courthouse Tuesday afternoon. Flooding along several rivers elsewhere in the Florida panhandle drove at least 500 people from their homes, but about 300 returned Tuesday along the Blackwater River. At least 1,000 people were forced out in Washington County, most of them leaving their homes in Caryville on the banks of the Choctawhatchee and nearby rural areas Monday after county commissioners ordered a mandatory evacuation. A voluntary evacuation extending about 20 miles downstream to Ebro was requested Tuesday. That affected at least 500 people, but Washington County Commissioner John Cook of Vernon estimated about half of those residents decided to remain in their homes.

DOC.HEAD: Singer Gloria Estefan Injured in Bus-Truck Accident
LaserPhoto WX11, XPOC3
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout with doctor saying Miss Estefan will need surgery, paralysis still a danger, Bush calling singer, different spellings for her injured son, CORRECTS spelling of town to Scarborough sted Scarboro. TRIMS to tighten. ADDS byline.
DOC.TEXT: Doctors said today that singer Gloria Estefan would need surgery for a broken vertebra she suffered when a truck ran into her band's bus on a snow-covered mountain highway. Miss Estefan, lead singer of the Latin-pop band Miami Sound Machine, has a ``partial neurologic deficit'' that is causing numbness in her feet, Dr. Harry Schmaltz said at a news conference at Community Medical Center. Schmaltz, an orthopedic surgeon at the hospital, said she needs surgery to stabilize the spine and prevent further injury, but that the family wants a specialist to perform the operation. He said there still was some danger of paralysis, and that she would need about three to six months' recuperation in which she would have to wear a constraining device to prevent further injury. Estefan expressed frustration to doctors at missing concerts and concern about her 9-year-old son, who broke his collarbone in the crash. Police gave the boy's name as Nayib but the hospital spelled it Nayad. He was released Tuesday, along with Miss Estefan's husband, Emilio Estefan Jr., who suffered head and hand injuries. Among the well-wishers who called the hospital were President Bush and Dick Clark of ``American Bandstand'' fame. White House Press Secretary Marlin Fitzwater said Bush called the 32-year-old singer this morning to wish her well and tell her how much had enjoyed her visit at the White House on Monday to discuss her anti-drug work. Miss Estefan is a longtime Bush supporter who performed at one of his inaugural events in Washington in 1989. Also hospitalized was the singer's personal assistant, Barbara Arencibia, 25, who suffered a back injury. The group was headed to Syracuse, N.Y., for a Tuesday night concert. The accident occurred about noon on westbound Interstate 380 near Tobyhanna in the Pocono Mountains in eastern Pennsylvania. The Estefans' driver, Ron Jones, said he had stopped on the highway when a tractor-trailer jackknifed in the snow and a truck and bus stopped behind it. Jones said the bus was pushed into the truck when another truck rammed it from behind. Miss Estefan was asleep on a couch and was thrown to the floor. Trooper Joseph Kearney said the truck driver ``came up on them and ... was unable to stop and he should have been.'' The truck driver, identified as Heraldo E. Samuels of Scarborough, Ontario, was cited for driving at an unsafe speed. He was treated and released. Miss Estefan was nominated in February for best pop vocal performance by a female for the single ``Don't Wanna Lose You'' in the Grammy awards. Her new album, ``Cuts Both Ways,'' a collection of dance songs and ballads, was 26th on the Cashbox magazine pop chart last week. The Cuban-born Miss Estefan and Miami Sound Machine have attracted listeners worldwide with the sounds of salsa, samba and conga for more than a decade. Their hits include ``Rhythm Is Gonna Get You'' and ``Anything for You.'' The band was recently renamed Gloria Estefan and the Miami Sound Machine.

DOC.HEAD: States May Not Bar Witnesses from Ever Making Public Grand Jury Testimony
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf, The court, to CORRECT 16 to 15; also subs penultimate graf to correspond.
DOC.TEXT: States may not prohibit grand jury witnesses from ever revealing their own testimony, the Supreme Court ruled unanimously today. The court said a Florida law providing such a prohibition, similar to laws in 15 other states, violated free-speech rights. The decision, upholding a federal appeals court ruling, is a defeat for Florida officials who tried to block a former newspaper reporter from disclosing details of his appearance before a grand jury four years ago. ``The interests advanced by the portion of the Florida statute struck down are not sufficient to overcome (the reporter's) First Amendment right to make a truthful statement of information he acquired on his own,'' Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist wrote for the court. He added: ``The ban extends not merely to the life of the grand jury but into the indefinite future. The potential for abause of the Florida prohibition, through its employment as a device to silence those who know of unlawful conduct or irregularities on the part of public officials, is apparent.'' Today's decision does not affect state laws barring grand jury witnesses from disclosing their testimony while the investigation is in progress. Jane Kirtley of the Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press said the decision will help journalists who want to interview people who testified before grand juries once an investigation ends. ``The court recognized that this kind of statute is an overwhelming restraint that could not withstand constitutional scrutiny,'' Ms. Kirtley said. Michael Smith, a former reporter for the Charlotte Herald-News in Charlotte County, Fla., wants to publish a news story and possibly a book about a 1986 grand jury investigation into allegations of corruption in the county sheriff's department and the county state attorney's office. The grand jury probe ended in 1986, and no indictments were handed down. Smith challenged the Florida grand jury secrecy law because he feared he could be prosecuted for revealing his testimony before the secret panel. A federal judge upheld the law and threw out Smith's suit. But the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruled for Smith, sparking Florida's appeal to the Supreme Court. In his opinion for the court, Rehnquist cited past decisions that say states may not punish publication of lawfully obtained, truthful information ``absent a need to further a state interest of the highest order.'' No such need exists in this case, he said. Rehnquist acknowledged that the invalidated law could help prevent investigation targets who later stand trial from trying to influence grand jury witnesses. But he said, ``With present day criminal procedure generally requiring the disclosure of witnesses on the part of the state, the names of these witnesses will be available to the accused sometime before trial in any event.'' The chief justice also noted that Florida ``provides substantial criminal penalties for both perjury and tampering with witnesses.'' The justices were told that the 15 states with laws similar to Florida's are Alabama, Arizona, Indiana, Kentucky, Louisiana, Michigan, Mississippi, Missouri, Nevada, North Carolina, North Dakota, South Dakota, Texas, Utah and Washington. The case is Butterworth vs. Smith, 88-1993.

DOC.HEAD: Riverboat Gambling Bill Signed into Law
DOC.TEXT: Riverboat gambling will be allowed in Missisippi beginning April 1 under a bill signed into law by Gov. Ray Mabus. Proponents have touted the measure as a way to boost tourism in communities along the Mississippi River. Mabus signed the bill Tuesday. Riverboat gambling already has been approved in Illinois and Iowa, but the Illinois law doesn't take effect until January 1991, and the Iowa statute not until April 1991. In Mississippi, boats at least 150 feet long and capable of carrying a minimum 250 passengers would be allowed to open casinos on the waterway. The state would license the boats, which could open their casinos while moving or docked. ``The important aspect of the legislation is that it would let those communities along the Mississippi River have the right to vote on whether they would like to have casino-type gambling in their area,'' said the governor's spokesman, Kevin Vandebroek. Residents of Mississippi counties with ports on the river could force a referendum and voters could forbid the boats from docking in their counties. The Mississippi River forms the state's western line. Some operators already have expressed an interest in bringing gambling boats to the river. ``We've been meeting with people that have shown some preliminary interest in bringing a boat into this area,'' said Jimmy Heidel, executive vice president of the Vicksburg-Warren Chamber of Commerce. Cruise ships can already open their casinos while in the waters of the Mississippi Sound, off the state's southern coast. Mississippi lawmakers are trying to resolve differences in a bill that would reduce the minimum size of those vessels.

Here are excerpts from recent editorials in newspapers throughout the country. March 17 Grants Pass (Ore.) Daily Courier on ``earth-friendly'' products: Companies should try hard work instead of hype in trying to cash in on the growing trend among consumers to buy so-called ``earth-friendly'' items. Industry must research new ways to produce and use biodegradable materials in packaging and to reuse materials that aren't biodegradable, such as glass. They also need to phase out products that damage the environment, such as hairsprays containing chemicals that destroy the earth's protective ozone layer. Unfortunately, all many companies are doing these days is slapping labels with misleading or outright false claims on their products, rather than looking for ways to honestly help environmentally conscious shoppers. Plastic trash bags suddenly turn into ``degradable'' bags, and a can of aerosol hair spray becomes ``ozone friendly,'' even though it contains chemicals that cause smog and air pollution. ... Regulators need to force manufacturers to verify their claims, just as they did when firms claimed to have cures for baldness. This time the goal is much more important than growing hair, though. It's obvious from the government's half-hearted attempts at cleaning up the environment that any real progress will have to come from grassroots movements. People will have to change their lifestyles and demand that politicians and companies change their ways, too.

March 18 Akron (Ohio) Beacon Journal on the Postal Service: Talk about bad timing. Just as the U.S. Postal Service is asking for a 19 percent rate increase, the Government Accounting Office comes along and details some outrageous costs the service ran up at conferences for postal executives. The Postal Service, which is projected to lose $1.6 billion this year, spent up to $10 million on conferences last year, the GAO reported. At one conference in Scottsdale, Ariz., officials were treated to $99 dinners and ran up a bar tab of $12,718 _ all paid for by the Postal Service. ... The Postal Service generally doesn't deserve the scorn heaped on it, and there is even an argument for some rate increase. But when those in charge of the service squander the money they have, they can't expect to be seen as credible when they ask for more.

March 18 The Herald-Dispatch, Huntington, W.Va., on Pentagon spending: Last month, the General Accounting Office found that the Air Force kept such poor financial records it was almost impossible to audit many accounts. Now comes the news the Pentagon has a $43 billion _ yes, that's right, $43 BILLION _ slush fund it can spend as it wishes, without congressional approval. The slush fund was brought to light by Rep. John D. Dingell, D-Mich., who correctly has called for a corresponding $43 billion cut in the Defense Department set aside accounts making up the slush fund. Dingell says the $43 billion, accumulated over a period of several years, was laundered through the U.S. Treasury. The net result: Congress could kill a weapons program and find out years later that it was still being funded from the slush fund. There's simply no excuse for this careless, sloppy backdoor handling of taxpayers' money.

March 19 San Antonio Express-News on subsidies to the National Rifle Association: Not many people are aware that the Defense Department indirectly subsidizes the National Rifle Association, or NRA. The multimillion-dollar handout is drawing the attention it deserves as the Pentagon adjusts to a shrinking share of the federal budget. The subsidy comes from the Army's Division of Civilian Marksmanship, or DCM, which was established in 1903 to improve the shooting skills among men of military age. The program received $4.6 million in fiscal 1990; the Bush budget for fiscal 1991 asks for $5.6 million. ... Only about 200 marksmen were recruited last year for the military as a result of DCM's efforts. That works out to about $23,000 per recruit, which the House Armed Services Committee calls ``a very expensive recruiting tool.'' (U.S. Rep. Fortney) Stark, D-Calif., isn't the first to question the value of the program. Ex-President Jimmy Carter tried to do away with it, and a federal judge once suggested that the ``symbolic relationship between the Army and the NRA'' might be unhealthy since the NRA attempts to influence the government on controversial issues, such as gun control. Thousands of small items could be cut from the budget without impairing U.S. interests; the Army's NRA-oriented marksmanship program is one of them.

DOC.HEAD: Diary Entries Don't Have to Be Turned Over, Judge Says
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs; edits thruout to tighten; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: Former President Reagan does not have to produce some three dozen diary entries requested by John Poindexter for his Iran-Contra trial, a federal judge ruled today. U.S. District Court Judge Harold Greene said that production of the diary entries ``is not essential to the achievement of justice in this case.'' The judge's ruling came as Reagan's videotaped testimony was being shown at Poindexter's trial on five felony charges of conspiracy, making false statements and obstructing Congress. Greene earlier had directed Reagan to turn over the diary entries to his former national security adviser, but the ex-president challenged the judge's order by invoking executive privilege. The Bush administration joined Reagan's assertion of the privilege. ``The claims of executive privilege filed on behalf of the former president and of the incumbent president are sufficient'' to defeat Poindexter's request, said Greene. Greene granted Reagan's motion to quash Poindexter's subpoena for the diary entries, which relate to both the Iran initiative and Contra resupply operation. The judge said ``There is absolutely no basis in law for a holding that'' Poindexter is entitled to the diary entries in addition to Reagan's videotaped testimony. Poindexter's lawyers say he needs the diaries because Reagan was unable in his videotaped testimony to recall many details of the Iran-Contra affair. For example, the former president said he could not remember when he learned of a November 1985 shipment of Hawk missiles to Iran. ``Mr. Reagan did testify under oath at great length about many specific activities in his administration _ an event that is unprecedented in American history,'' said Greene. The judge said Reagan's testimony, plus written answers he gave several years ago in the Iran-Contra affair, provided Poindexter ``with ample assistance for the conduct of his defense.'' Poindexter's lawyers say the diaries may refer to facts that Reagan now says he cannot recall. But ``if the concept of executive privilege is to retain any meaning, it will surely shield personal presidential papers from production ... on so flimsy a basis,'' said Greene. In Greene's courtroom, meanwhile, jurors began watching Reagan's videotaped testimony taken Feb. 16-17 in Los Angeles for the Poindexter trial. The jurors were instructed to treat his testimony like that of any other witness. Greene said testimony from Reagan should not be judged by a different standard. ``You apply the same test,'' he told the jurors. ``You ... give the same care and same weight'' to Reagan's videotaped testimony ``as you would if he were here'' in person, Greene told the jury of seven women and five men. Poindexter's lawyers were presenting the Reagan tape in a bid to offset evidence presented by Iran-Contra prosecutors, who brought their case to a close Tuesday. ``Would you please state your full name and spell your last name for the record?'' a clerk asked on the videotape. ``Ronald Reagan, R-e-a-g-a-n,'' the former president responded. In 7{ days of testimony, prosecution witnesses told the jury the former national security adviser destroyed a presidential document and sent false letters to Congress about covert aid to the Contra rebels in Nicaragua. The jury was watching Reagan's testimony on a television monitor placed in front of the jury box. Transcripts were released the week after Reagan testified and the tapes were shown in the federal courthouse in Washington, D.C. Copies of the tapes were being released to the news media today. Reagan's videotape was to be shown in its entirety, concluding at midday Thursday, Greene told the jury. On Tuesday, Greene denied a defense motion of acquittal, saying there is evidence suggesting Poindexter adopted false information ``designed to obstruct Congress.'' Reagan made a number of statements favorable to Poindexter. He said he was convinced that his aides' activities on behalf of the Contras ``were all being done within the law.'' He also said ``I don't think any false statements were made'' by Poindexter in connection with the Iran-Contra affair. The former president said ``I am in complete support'' with allegedly false letters Poindexter sent to Congress about assisting the Contras. The letters said the administration was in compliance with ``both the spirit and letter of the law'' restricting aid to the rebels. But they also embraced year-earlier denials by then-national security adviser Robert McFarlane that White House aide Oliver North was raising funds for the Contras and aiding them militarily. While Reagan said he never gave Poindexter authority to destroy records or obstruct Congress, he did suggest it might have been all right to withhold information and destroy documents to protect national security in the U.S. arms initiative with Iran. Reagan suggested that any leaks of sensitive information from Congress might jeopardize the lives of U.S. hostages held in Lebanon. Under cross-examination, the former president said he ``never had any inkling'' his aides were guiding the Contras' strategy ``in any way.'' And he said he never authorized his aides to break the law.

DOC.HEAD: Anti-U.S. Protest By Marcos Supporters
With PM-Marcos Trial
DOC.TEXT: About 1,500 supporters of the late Ferdinand Marcos today spat on and burned an American flag and an effigy of Uncle Sam outside the U.S. Embassy to protest the New York trial of his widow, Imelda. Protesters held placards demanding ``Justice for Imelda'' and ``We love the Marcos family'' during the generally peaceful demonstration. The protest came one day after jury selection began in the racketeering trial of the 60-year-old Mrs. Marcos in U.S. District Court in Manhattan. About 50 members of the left-wing League of Filipino Students who wanted to hold a separate anti-U.S. bases demonstration threw homemade bombs at police when they were prevented from getting near the embassy. One of the bombs hit the roof of the entrance to the embassy but caused no injuries. No injuries were reported to police or students. The students, who had marched from a nearby park, lobbed more bombs at the police who tried to chase them. Two members of the group were arrested. The melee briefly disrupted the demonstration of the Marcos supporters, who also tried to flee the scene thinking the police were dispersing them. They returned to continue the rally. ``We are here in support of our first lady,'' speaker Luz Domingo told the crowd. ``We are here to protest American intervention and the injustice done to her.'' Another speaker, attorney Romeo Cayetano, said the trial of Mrs. Marcos on foreign soil was an affront to Philippine sovereignty and showed the Manila government ``has no honor.'' Manila newspapers published the text of a letter sent by Mrs. Marcos to President Bush offering to turn over her fortune to a five-member international panel, which would distribute the funds to the Filipino people. In the letter, released by the Philippine government, Mrs. Marcos claimed she was innocent and that the trial was an attempt to ``extort money and property from me.'' In Washington, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Bush received a letter from Mrs. Marcos. Fitzwater would not elaborate, saying only that the president could not respond for legal reasons pertaining to the trial. Mrs. Marcos is accused of taking part in the illegal transfer of more than $160 million from the Philippine treasury to buy Manhattan real estate. The indictment also alleges she defrauded banking institutions of $165 million to pay for the properties. She could be imprisoned for 50 years and fined $1 million if convicted of all charges. Jury selection continued today. Mrs. Marcos is being tried with Saudi financier Adnan Khashoggi, who is accused of helping the Marcoses hide their ownership of the real estate. Marcos, the ousted Philippines president who was the central figure in the October 1988 indictment, died Sept. 28 in exile in Hawaii. He fled there after being toppled in the civilian-military uprising that propelled Corazon Aquino to power four years ago. Meanwhile, Press Secretary Tomas Gomez said Mrs. Aquino had no comment on the trial and Mrs. Marcos' letter to Bush. ``The president has more important things to do than monitor (the trial),'' Gomez said. Gomez said the letter was ``irrelevant'' to Mrs. Marcos' court case.

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: of them.
DOC.TEXT: March 15 The Westerly (R.I.) Sun on the Soviet presidency: Mikhail Gorbachev has been elected president of the Soviet Union. In the context of what's been going on in and around the Soviet Union, Gorbachev's victory, over no one, is rather anticlimactic. ... Five years from now things will be different _ very different. A popular vote of the Soviet people will decide the presidency. And more and more it appears a safe bet that the Soviet people of 1995 will be millions fewer than they are today. How many millions fewer? That depends on _ among others _ people who would rather be known as Latvians, Lithuanians, Estonians and Moldavians.

March 20 The Albuquerque (N.M.) Tribune on the East German elections: Once again, an electorate has sensibly defied predictions: The conservatives' big plurality in East Germany's first free election ... simplifies the process of German reunification _ where a socialist victory, widely expected, would have bogged it down in ambiguities. The socialists are strong enough, however, to moderate the breakneck pace of reunification and interject some caution into the process. Despite their strong showing, the conservatives lack the two-thirds majority needed to change the constitution and precipitate reunification. Their invitation to the Social Democrats to enter a grand coalition was quickly rejected. As a result, whatever government emerges from (the) election must lead the people of East Germany through their historic transition without the luxury of bipartisan backing. In opposition, the Social Democrats will retain at least some of the influence they sought over the pace and content of coming negotiations. Ultimately, the best social glue of all is economic rebirth _ brought closer by the voters' embrace of unification.

March 19 The Clarion-Ledger, Jackson, Miss., on Nicaragua: Some impatient Americans stand astounded. Almost a month after Nicaragua's election the issue of armed Contra guerrillas and a hostile Sandinista army hasn't been settled. No wiser words could be spoken on this situation than, `Patience, patience.'' All in the United States who clamor for a virtually instantaneous transition from divided, poor and wartorn to united, peaceful and prosperous, need a brief history lesson. Nicaraguans have fought among themselves, with help from many outside friends, for the last 10 years. Before the Sandinista revolution and the Contra counter-revolution, the Nicaraguan people had hardly a moment's peace in this country. The election Feb. 25 was a remarkable first step, but only a first step, in the long process of democratization. Violeta Chamorro and Daniel Ortega have acted civilly, even graciously, toward each other, but that doesn't remove the bitterness lingering from a decade of bloody civil war. Suspicions run deep, and distrust is founded on years of deceit practiced by both sides. The Bush administration, to its credit, has not made unrealistic predictions about the transition of power. It has stroked both sides of the political spectrum in diplomatic overtures. The president, unlike President Reagan, appears to realize the peace within Nicaragua must be hammered out within Nicaragua. It cannot be dictated from Washington, or any other foreign capital.

March 14 The News-Leader, Springfield, Mo., on food labeling: Maybe it's time for an old-fashioned food fight. That's about all there is to a nutty proposal by the Department of Health and Human Services encouraging the states to pass food labeling laws. That job clearly belongs to the federal government, not with the states. Unfortunately, alternatives to mandatory food labeling are working in far too many cases. The Center for Science in the Public Interest reported recently that four of the largest fast food chains have quit offering on-the-spot information about their menus, violating a 1986 agreement to provide ingredients and nutritional information nationwide. Americans should be up in arms. More than 65 million of us _ one in three _ is on a diet right now. More than one in four is overweight.

DOC.TEXT: March 16 Winston-Salem (N.C.) Journal on hostage-taking: Today marks the fifth anniversary of the kidnapping of Terry Anderson. He was a professional bystander _ an Associated Press reporter in Lebanon _ who had the misfortune to become the story himself when snatched by Shiite Moslems in that ruined land. Presently, seven other Americans are also being held along with at least that many additional Western hostages. ... The continued captivity of these victims is an insane act whose only conceivable value is to keep the hostage-takers on the world's agenda. Perhaps they subscribe to the adage that all publicity is good publicity, but they are wrong. Instead, the continuing captivity is a constant reminder that we live in an often vicious and irrational world where Western values are hardly universally shared.

March 18 Los Angeles Daily News on product safety: The Federal Trade Commission, in announcing an investigation into the environmental claims being made these days on behalf of more and more products, has selected a difficult target in its longstanding campaign against false advertising. (The task) ... promises to be tricky because deceptive environmental claims in some instances may be responses to unfounded or exaggerated concerns that may be traced to fearmongers. ... Witness some of the alarming but ill-founded things that have been said in the past year or so. There was the panic about Alar on apples _ a risk that turned out to be practically nonexistent. Lately, the fear peddlers are having a field day with malathion spraying, which most scientists do not consider a threat to health, though the few dissenters get a disproportionate share of attention. And the talk of global warming goes on and on amid mounting evidence that the atmosphere really isn't heating up significantly. ... The FTC has an obligation to protect consumers from hucksters who use phony environmental claims to hawk their merchandise. However, it would be helpful if those consumers looked more critically at claims made by the activists and others who have agendas, if not products, to sell in the marketplace of ideas.

March 21 Philadelphia Daily News on Phoenix as 1993 Super Bowl site: In Arizona, the question of a holiday honoring Martin Luther King divides even the certifiably loony Republican Party majority. Accordingly, many organizations refuse to convene in Arizona until that state decides to honor a great man. The National Football League is not one of them. Its 1993 Super Bowl is scheduled for Phoenix. It was more important to pump cash to one of the league's most inept owners than to stand on principle. Except for Norman Braman, owner of the (Philadelphia) Eagles. He stands alone in opposing the site and vowing to work toward rescinding the offer if Arizona does not act. Sometimes standing alone is the only place for a principled man.

March 20 Milwaukee Sentinel on the delayed baseball season: A one-week delay in the start of the 1990 major-league baseball season probably will drive the schedule makers crazy and maybe bring back the doubleheader if there aren't enough open dates to make up for the late start. The late start, due to a dispute between players and owners, also reduced the length of spring training. This might be seen as heresy by those who promote the so-called Cactus and Grapefruit Leagues as something to warm up the fans as well as the players, but maybe spring training should always be three weeks long. The truth be told, the games played at the training sites are boring contests that count for nothing. The experts will argue that conditioning is the real purpose of spring training. That's true. But why does it seem that every camp closes with the manager counting the wounded? ... All this, of course, ignores the economic importance of spring training to states where the camps are located. But the owners and players ignored that, too, and there has been no mention of reparations for the losses Florida and Arizona will suffer because of the prolonged negotiations. The retirees and other baseball devotees who live in those states should switch their allegiances to minor-league teams and the new senior league made up of retired players who can't get enough of baseball. These are guys who really come to play.
DOC.HEAD: End Editorial Rdp
United States Lifts Economic Sanctions Against Namibia
With PM-Namibia, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The United States lifted economic sanctions against Namibia today, the same day the African state became independent from South Africa, the Treasury Department announced. The sanctions had been imposed against South Africa because of its anti-apartheid racial policies and extended to Namibia because it was administered by the South African government. ``In view of Namibia's independence, and the Department of State's determination that Namibia will no longer be administered by South Africa, the Treasury Department has amended the regulations to lift sanctions from Namibia'' effective at 12:01 a.m. EST,'' the department said in a statement. The sanctions had prohibited loans and new investments and barred imports of certain goods from Namibia. The sanctions remain against South Africa.

DOC.HEAD: Jewish Film Festival to Proceed As Planned
DOC.TEXT: City officials today agreed to provide theater space in downtown Moscow for a Jewish film festival after U.S. diplomats demanded that the show be allowed to go ahead as planned, a festival organizer said. The weeklong festival of 30 films will open on schedule Saturday night, using two of the three large theaters officials had promised, Janice Plotkin, co-director of the San Francisco-based Jewish Film Festival organization. ``They took away one theater, but we're very pleased with the results,'' she said, adding that a smaller theater is to be provided instead. ``It's been a hair-raising experience.'' Moscow officials had said they could not provide space in large theaters in the center of the Soviet capital, and organizers had been faced with the prospect of moving the festival to small theaters on the outskirts of the city, Ms. Plotkin said. City officials did not explain why they could not provide the larger theaters, but the festival never was in danger of cancellation, she said. Well-known national legislators, the U.S. Embassy, and Soviet filmmakers intervened in the dispute over theater space, and the organizers were notified by city officials today that the festival could go ahead, she said. There was no immediate comment from U.S. or Soviet officials.

DOC.HEAD: Wildlife Expert Sees Little Progress in Guarding Against Spill Damage
DOC.TEXT: Nearly a year after the Exxon Valdez disaster, little has been done to protect wildlife from another such oil spill, an expert who directed the rehabilitation of sea otters after the Alaska spill said Wednesday. ``Basically there are no facilities in existence today anywhere in North America nor any ongoing organization to respond to another oil spill,'' Randall W. Davis said in an interview. Davis, co-director of International Wildlife Research of San Diego, Calif., is completing a report on the rescue program after the Alaska spill last March 24 that includes recommendations for oil spill contingency planning in Alaska and California. The Valdez spewed almost 11 million gallons of crude oil into the sea when it ran aground in Prince William Sound, soaking 1,100 miles of scenic coastland.
