Searchers found 34,400 dead birds and believe at least 1,000 sea otters and countless other animals died in the nation's worst oil spill. ``We are only a little bit further ahead than we were a year ago in that we have a little bit better understanding of how to do it, but so far there has been very little advance preparation,'' Davis said. ``In order to respond quickly, that is within one day, we need a rehabilitaion facility,'' he said. ``We probably need a number of them in areas that are considered high risk.'' Davis said these areas should include Valdez, the southern terminal of the Alaska oil pipeline, and probably a site on the California coast and others in other parts of the country. ``The special needs of marine mammals make a facility much more difficult to build,'' he said. ``Birds are a little bit easier to treat. Marine mammals require generally more sophisticated facilities and it is difficult to build them right at the time of the spill.'' ``Our response in Alaska was not as effective as it could have been because we were trying to build those specialized facilities while we were treating animals,'' said Davis. ``That makes it very, very difficult.'' International Wildlife Research has drawn up plans for a combined rehabilitation and research facility that Davis said could be built either in California or Alaska for about $5 million. He said the rehabilitation portion alone could probably be built for $1.5 million. Davis was in Washington for a news conference at which the Izaak Walton League of America presented a conservation award to The Procter & Gamble Company for its support of animal rescue efforts. The company donated manpower, a computer and Dawn dishwashing detergent to the Alaska effort. It also is underwriting production and distribution of ``Mission: Rescue,'' a video about the cleanup that is being offered at no charge for showings at zoos, aquariums and nature centers. Davis oversaw the rehabilitation of 230 sea otters in the months following the Alaska spill. He was joined at the news conference by Jay Holcolmb, director of International Bird Rescue Research of Berkeley, Calif., who headed activities that saved some 1,600 birds after the Valdez spill. ``By using computer technology, we were able to record and save crucial technical data collected over a six-month period on the care of thousands of birds,'' he said. ``This information proved its worth in our work in rescue efforts following the recent spills in San Francisco and Huntington Beach, Calif.''

DOC.HEAD: Oscar-Winning Film Director Maurice Cloche Dies
DOC.TEXT: Film director Maurice Cloche, best known for his Oscar-winning movie ``Monsieur Vincent,'' died at his home in Bordeaux after a long illness, the French media reported Wednesday. He was 82. ``Monsieur Vincent,'' a moving dramatization of the life of St. Vincent de Paul and starring Pierre Fresnay, won the Academy Award in 1947 for best foreign film. It also was honored as the best film in France that year. Cloche died Tuesday after battling Parkinson's Disease in recent years. Cloche's career spanned more than a half-century and included spy thrillers as well as films with religious and social themes. His best known films include a ``La Cage aux Oiseaux,'' (The Bird Cage); ``Le Docteur Laennec,'' the story of the inventor of the stethoscope; ``Ne de Pere Inconnu,'' (Father Unknown); and ``La Cage aux Filles'' (The Girl Cage). In 1940, Cloche founded a film society for young talent. It later became France's leading film school, the Institute of Advanced Film Studies.

DOC.HEAD: Helms Asks Investigation of Endowment for the Arts
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Jesse Helms said today he has asked congressional investigators to determine whether the National Endowment for the Arts is funding pornographic art. Helms ``is deeply concerned about the NEA's apparent indifference to enforcing the congressional ban on funding obscene art,'' the North Carolina Republican senator's office said in a statement. Helms and other conservatives pushed a law through Congress last year that bans federal funding of art that ``may be considered obscene'' by the endowment chairman. The law expressly forbids spending tax money on ``depictions of sadomasochism, homoeroticism, the sexual exploitation of children or individuals engaged in sex acts'' and materials that lack serious artistic value. Artists complained that the restrictions inhibited creativity and free expression. In a letter to Charles Bowsher, comptroller general of the General Accounting Office, Helms said Endowment Chairman John Frohnmayer may be sincere in saying no NEA funds are being used to support obscene art. ``But the evidence to the contrary is so compelling that it is imperative that there be an objective investigation by an agency independent of the NEA,'' Helms wrote. His letter was accompanied by several examples. He said that in January, the endowment gave $20,000 fellowships to three acknowledged lesbian writers. Helms said the Washington Blade, a gay newspaper, reported that the authors are well-known for the homoerotic content of some of their works. Another example cited by Helms was the ``Degenerate With a Capital D'' exhibition at the Black and White in Color Gallery in New York, which included a work titled ``Alchemy Cabinet,'' featuring a vial containing the remains of an aborted baby. ``A flyer for the show boasted that `we will show the art no matter what laws are passed, threats are made or restrictions placed,''' Helms said. Helms also charged that the endowment, an independent federal agency, is asking grant recipients not to give the endowment credit when it funds obscene works. ``On several occasions, I have come across material stating that funding was provided by the NEA only to have the NEA deny such funding,'' he said. ``The NEA apparently takes no action against those who use its name without authorization.'' ``This is new,'' Virginia Falck, an NEA spokeswoman said in a telephone interview from Washington when told of the Helms letter. ``We don't have an official response. ``This has been going on for over a year,'' Ms. Falck said. ``Some of the things that we've been accused of by him and other congressmen we have funded and some we haven't.'' Ms. Falck said Frohnmayer could not be reached immediately for comment. Frohnmayer was scheduled to speak today at a congressional hearing on a measure to extend NEA funding five years when it expires Sept. 30.

DOC.HEAD: Suspected Collaborator Slain; Child Dies of Rubber Bullet Wound
DOC.TEXT: Masked Arabs shot to death a Palestinian man Wednesday who was suspected of collaborating with Israel, and a Palestinian schoolboy died after being shot by Israeli soldiers. The death of 10-year-old Shukri Barakat raised to 143 the number of Palestinian children who have died in the uprising against Israeli rule of the occupied lands. He was hit in the head by a rubber bullet Tuesday evening in the West Bank town of Tulkarem. New clashes broke out Wednesday between soldiers and Palestinian youths. In the West Bank town of Qalqilya, troops clashed with stone-throwing high school students. The students were marking the 22nd anniversary of a battle in the Jordanian town of Karameh. The March 1968 battle is viewed by Palestinians as a victory over Israel. Arab reports said parents surrounded one of the schools to try to prevent soldiers from entering and making arrests. They said at least seven Palestinians were slightly wounded with rubber bullets and rocks. Doctors at the U.N. hospital in Qalqilya said more than 50 Palestinians were treated for tear gas inhalation, and four were admitted with beating injuries. An army spokesman confirmed the incident but said he knew of only one person treated for a rubber bullet injury and one person given first aid for gas fumes. The alleged collaborator, Ahmad Khalil Musabeh, was shot in the head by masked assailants in the market at Khan Yunis, in the Gaza Strip. He was the 199th Palestinian to be killed by fellow Arabs since the uprising began in December 1987. Most of the victims have been accused of collaborating with Israel. There were conflicting reports, meanwhile, on the circumstances surrounding the 10-year-old boy's death. The army said in a statement that youths hurled stones at soldiers on patrol and that the troops fired rubber bullets to disperse the youths. ``The troops hit one of the youths, and he was later reported to have died,'' the army said. But relatives told Arab reporters the child was standing in the doorway of his home when he was hit with a bullet apparently fired from a nearby army post. They said they saw no stones thrown. Military police were investigating the incident. On Tuesday, former President Jimmy Carter accused Israel of violating the human rights of Palestinians in the occupied territories and cited in particular the deaths of children. According to the Israeli Information Center for Human Rights in the Occupied Territories, 143 Palestinian children aged 16 and under have been killed by Israelis in the uprising. A total of 42 have been 12 years and younger, the center said. Confronted with past criticism over the deaths of children, Israeli military officials have charged that uprising activists put youngsters at risk by placing them at the front of protests. The army also says that rubber bullets, used frequently to disperse demonstrators, are not lethal generally. A total of 667 Palestinians, including children, have been killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians since the uprising began.

DOC.HEAD: Two Burmese Students Given Six Years Each For Hijacking
DOC.TEXT: Two Burmese students were sentenced by a Thai court on Wednesday to six years in jail each for hijacking a jetliner to press for political concessions from their authoritarian government. Ye Yint and Ye Thi Ha last October diverted a Burmese jetliner, with more than 80 people aboard, to Thailand. They threatened to blow up the plane unless their demands were met but later surrendered peacefully to Thai authorities. They demanded the release of political prisoners, the lifting of martial law, and other changes from the military junta that has ruled Burma since a September 1988 coup. During the coup, soldiers killed hundreds of students and other pro-democracy demonstrators.

DOC.HEAD: More Lung Cancer Surgery Looms for Flying Wallendas Acrobat
DOC.TEXT: Trapeze star Angel Wallenda spent her 22nd birthday consulting with doctors about removing cancerous sections of her lungs. Mrs. Wallenda was at the City of Hope National Medical Center on Tuesday afternoon, where surgeons will decide when to start removing tumor-ravaged segments of her lungs. ``The tests weren't complete,'' said her husband, Steven. In 1988, the Flying Wallendas acrobat had surgery that reduced her lungs to about half their capacity. The previous year, her right leg was amputated below the knee due to bone cancer. The doctors want to save enough of her lungs to allow her to breathe on her own, he said. ``They're kind of worried because if I wait any longer they won't be able to do it at all,'' Mrs. Wallenda said. ``If they take out too much I won't have any left to breathe.'' Mrs. Wallenda had previously been told the best she can hope for is to live connected to an oxygen tank. After the bone cancer surgery, Mrs. Wallenda was fitted with an artificial lower leg and continued performing with her husband, whose family has been in the acrobatics business since the 1600s. Carrying on the tradition is the couple's 3-year-old, Steven Wallenda II, who first performed publicly on the trapeze at 11 months. The most famous of the Flying Wallendas, Karl the Great, died after a 1978 fall during a performance in Puerto Rico. The couple met in New York nearly five years ago. She was working in an ice cream shop at a suburban mall where he was performing. She later attended one of his acts and when he asked for a volunteer from the audience, she came forward.

DOC.HEAD: Police Say Four Kidnappings Occur Every Day in Colombia
DOC.TEXT: An average of four people were kidnapped each day in Colombia during the first 2{ months of 1990, a police report said Wednesday. The rate was double that of the same period last year. Leftist guerrillas and common criminals seeking ransoms were behind most of the 326 kidnappings from Jan. 1 to March 16, according to the report by the country's investigative police. The document did not say how many of the people had been released. Last week, the report said, eight people were kidnapped, five of them by common criminals and three by National Liberation Army guerrillas. The rebels finance part of their activities with ransoms.

DOC.SECOND: Few Passengers Make Use of Clue to Airline Tardiness
DOC.TEXT: Airline passengers hate delays, yet few seem to realize they could improve their odds of arriving on time if they heeded one simple clue. Just for the asking, travelers can learn any flight's recent record for tardiness. An example: If you were thinking of taking USAir Flight 896 from Philadelphia to Boston at 5:55 p.m. you could know your chances of arriving late are better than 80 percent. ``Late'' is defined as more than 15 minutes behind schedule. The clue lies in the flight's code that appears in airline and travel agent computers. The code for the USAir flight, for example, has a ``1'' as the last digit. That means that for the past month the flight has arrived on time between 10 and 20 percent of the time. A ``2'' at the end of a flight's computer code would mean the flight lands on time between 20 and 30 percent of the time, and so on up to the 90 to 100 percent range. A rating of less than 30 percent gets ``chronically late'' honors in the Department of Transportation's monthly ``Air Travel Consumer Report.'' So what does a traveler do if the flight has a low score? A passenger flying from Philadelphia to Boston could take Delta 648 at 4:50 p.m. with a 60 to 70 percent chance of arriving on time, or USAir 424 ten minutes later, which has a 40 to 50 percent chance. But how often do customers ask for this information? ``No one ever has,'' said Yolande Frommer, referring to customers at her Washington, D.C., travel agency. They'll ask the type of aircraft, how many seats are in a row, where the exits are and what movie is playing, she said, but they don't think to ask the chances of the plane arriving on time, even though it often is a major concern. Many people simply aren't aware that the information is available. Phil Davidoff, president-elect of the American Association of Travel Agents, said that although few travelers use the data, some agents notified customers when the on-time rating is below 50 percent. ``It's clearly down the line in factors that will affect a decision,'' about which flight to take, Davidoff said. The data comes from the airlines themselves. They are required by law to report it to the government each month. Delays due to mechanical problems are not counted in the ratings because the government thinks that including them might encourage airlines to rush repairs in order to keep up their on-time rating. Chris Witkowski of the Ralph Nader-founded Aviation Consumer Action Project said the ratings are an important tool for wise travelers. He dismisses the idea that expanding the ratings to include delays due to mechanical breakdowns might jeopardize safety. ``If there is a chance of that happening, it calls for stricter government inspections,'' Witkowski said. Some other consumer groups disagree. Richard Livingston of the Airline Passengers Association of North America, a consumer and safety advocacy group, said he thinks the government should pay more attention to the relative safety and security of flights instead of collecting data which might not be used by passengers. ``They tend to focus too much on delays,'' he said. In addition to the flight data, the report tells which of the 30 biggest airports have the most on-time arrivals at each hour of the day. The latest report covering January said all flights were on time in the 9 a.m. hour at New York's John F. Kennedy, the 6 a.m. hour at Orlando, Fla., and the 7 a.m. hour at Kansas City. These were the only cases of 100 percent on-time arrivals in January. The worst records were at JFK in the 5 p.m. period, at Charlotte, N.C., in the 10 p.m. slot and at New York's LaGuardia between 6 and 9 p.m. In each of those cases, more than 40 percent of flights were late. Hoyt Decker, who heads the Transportation Department's consumer division, said airlines have shown a keen interest in the consumer reports. ``It most assuredly does influence performance,'' he said. Decker acknowledged that the average traveler's first concerns are the price of the ticket and the time the flight leaves, but he said travel agents should be passing along the information about flights and airports as part of their services. ``If people aren't using it, they should,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: No Broken Hearts in This Cardiac Unit
DOC.TEXT: A heart attack didn't change Russell Marlowe's desire to marry Kathleen Ann France; only the date and place of the wedding. They got married in a hospital's cardiac unit. The couple exchanged vows at Westmoreland Hospital. Marlowe, 52, suffered the heart attack last week as he was driving on the Pennsylvania Turnpike near New Stanton. ``Last Friday, I didn't know whether I was going to make it or not,'' he said after Tuesday's ceremony. ``Today we're married.'' The wedding had been scheduled for April 7 in Akron, Ohio, where both live. ``In just a week our lives changed from good to bad, then from bad to good,'' said the bride, also 52. ``As long as we have each other, we'll be fine.''

DOC.HEAD: Kohl Predicts Unified Germany by 1992
DOC.TEXT: Chancellor Helmut Kohl on Wednesday predicted full German unification by the end of 1992. France's president told him the merger should lead to closer integration for all of Europe. ``With the start of the big European market on Dec. 31, 1992, we will also see a united Germany,'' Kohl said in the southern city of Constance. He spoke to reporters after a two-day summit with Spanish Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez. Kohl was referring to the European Economic Community's plans to create a barrier-free internal market by that date. ``We want a speedy development, but not a hectic one,'' said Kohl. Kohl expressed hope that an East German government will be formed soon and that talks about the planned economic union between the two German states can resume. He planned to meet later with leaders of the victorious Alliance for Germany, a grouping of three parties that won the most votes in Sunday's election in East Germany. It did not achieve a majority, however, and must form a coalition government. Kohl's chief spokesman, Hans Klein, said President Francois Mitterrand of France had sent a telegram congratulating the chancellor for the victory of his East German political allies. They received massive campaign support from Kohl. Like Kohl's Christian Democratic Union, the alliance supports fast reunification and a market economy, along with traditional Christian values. According to Klein, Mitterrand also told Kohl that German unity must be part of the larger process of overcoming the divisions of Europe. ``German unity in the unity of the (European Economic) Community, which in turn is a stage to European unity, is the path which we have jointly mapped out and which is the one we now have to pursue,'' Klein quoted the letter as saying. Some Europeans are concerned that a united Germany will be an overbearing economic power, and France is seeking to link the united Germany firmly with the West. On Friday, Kohl is slated to fly to Brussels for talks with EEC officials about the possible effects of a common German currency on the EEC's own European Monetary System. Under the common currency idea, the powerful West German mark would become East Germany's currency as well. Rudolf Seiters, Kohl's chief of staff, said West Germany hopes to have the currency plan in place by July 1. Also Wednesday, West Germany's opposition Social Democratic Party said it opposes NATO membership for a united Germany unless the Western alliance abandons its strategy of nuclear deterrence. The demand was made in a 12-point disarmament program unveiled by the leftist Social Democrats. It states that NATO would have to undergo ``fundamental changes'' if it were to include a united Germany as a member. The party's counterpart in East Germany finished in second place in the election. It favors a more gradual approach to reunification than the alliance and turned down an offer to take part in a coalition government.

DOC.HEAD: Sikh Separatist Violence Kills 15
DOC.TEXT: Clashes involving Sikh separatists fighting for an independent nation left at least 15 people dead Wednesday in Punjab state, including six policemen, news reports said. The officers died during three separate gunbattles with Sikh militants, United News of India said. The other victims were two Sikhs killed by security forces, and seven people slain by Sikh militants, the news agency said. There has been a rise in violence linked to Sikh extremists this week. On Sunday night, 26 people were killed in clashes. Sikhs are a religious minority in Hindu-dominated India, but they are a majority in the rich farming state of Punjab. The Sikhs claim they suffer discrimination by the Hindu-dominated government and are fighting for their own nation in Punjab.

DOC.HEAD: Study Bolsters Argument That Greenhouse Warming Has Begun
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For release at 6 p.m. EST, time set by source
DOC.TEXT: Global warming during the past century could not have come solely from a long-term influence of the oceans, according to a study that supports the idea that the greenhouse effect has begun to warm the Earth. A computer simulation suggests that the oceans can account for only about three-fifths of the warming recorded in the last 100 years. The researchers cautioned that the result does not prove greenhouse warming played a role. Other scientists agreed, but split on how strongly it bolsters the idea that greenhouse warming has begun. The greenhouse effect refers to a warming caused by a buildup in the atmosphere of certain gases, such as carbon dioxide, chiefly from human activity. Scientists are concerned that it eventually could alter climates and rainfall patterns and lead to coastal flooding from raised ocean levels. But they disagree about whether the greenhouse effect has yet produced any detectable impact. The Earth has warmed by about nine-tenths of a degree Fahrenheit during the past century. A major problem in demonstrating a role for the greenhouse effect is that scientists do not know how much of the warming comes from long-term natural variability, said Gerald Meehl of the National Center for Atmospheric Research in Boulder, Colo. The oceans, which slowly absorb and release huge amounts of heat, are probably the most likely source of this long-term influence, he said. The new study of the oceans' influence is presented in Thursday's issue of the British journal Nature by T.M.L. Wigley and S.C.B. Raper of the University of East Anglia in Norwich, England. Their simulation found that over intervals of up to 100 years, the oceans might produce a trend of up to about half a degree Fahrenheit. That means the ocean influence could not have produced the observed global warming by itself, the researchers wrote. Yet, ``we still cannot claim to have unequivocally detected the greenhouse effect,'' they said. Researcher Robert Cess said the study cannot really rule out the idea that the oceans did produce the global warming. The simulation was too simplified to produce a firm conclusion, said Cess, an atmospheric sciences professor at the State University of New York at Stony Brook. But researcher Stephen Schneider of atmospheric research center, who called himself 80 percent certain that greenhouse warming has begun, said the result adds to his belief. ``It's not proof yet,'' he said. ``It's another step along the way.'' Scientists will need 10 to 20 more years of observations to be sure if they are seeing a greenhouse warming, he said.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Lawyer: Top Co-Defendant of Noriega Has Agreed to Plead Guilty
DOC.TEXT: Luis del Cid, a key co-defendant of Manuel Noriega, has agreed to plead guilty to a drug conspiracy count, his attorney said today. Final details of the plea bargain are still being worked out, but should go before a federal judge soon, said del Cid's defense lawyer Samuel Burstyn. ``There is an agreement in principle,'' Burstyn said. ``It's in the process of being reduced to writing.'' Del Cid, a lieutenant colonel in Panama's military at the time of his capture during the U.S. invasion of that country, is accused in a February 1988 indictment of accepting $200,000 in cocaine-trafficking profits from a drug pilot. The indictment says the money was delivered by the government's chief prosecution witness, Floyd Carlton Caceres, at the headquarters of the Panamanian Defense Forces in Panama City in December 1983. It allegedly was intended for Noriega, the Panamanian general deposed as dictator after the Dec. 20 invasion. Noriega is in federal prison on charges of accepting $4.6 million in bribes to allow Colombia's Medellin drug cartel to use Panama as a way station for U.S.-bound cocaine. The conspiracy count could bring del Cid up to 10 years in federal prison, Burstyn said, and there is no sentence limit written into the agreement. But he said he did not expect his client to serve more than 2{ years when the plea bargain is approved. Under the charges included in the indictment, del Cid could have served up to 70 years in prison, according to the U.S. attorney's office. Diane Cossin, spokeswoman for the U.S. attorney's office, said she could not confirm or deny a possible deal with del Cid. ``Any comment about a plea agreement would be premature until it's filed with the court and accepted by the court,'' she said. Burstyn refused to say today whether del Cid will testify against his former boss under the agreement. But previously he noted that once a defendant has pleaded guilty, he must honor a subpoena from the prosecution and cannot invoke his Fifth Amendment right to refuse to testify. If the agreement is approved, del Cid will be the second of the six defendants in custody to enter a guilty plea. Drug pilot Eduardo Pardo already has pleaded guilty to flying drug profits from Fort Lauderdale to Panama. Also in custody is accused Colombian cocaine trafficker William Saldarriaga. Free on bond are another alleged drug pilot, Daniel Miranda, and an accused minor trafficker, Brian Alden Davidow.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Asks Mandela to Drop Demand for Nationalization of Industry
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with further comment from Baker, Mandela
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III today urged nationalist leader Nelson Mandela to reconsider his call for nationalization of financial institutions and industries in South Africa, a U.S. official said. The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Baker ``was pleased with the way Mandela received that.'' The source declined to elaborate. The official also said that Baker assured Mandela during his meeting with the African National Congress leader that sanctions imposed on South Africa by the U.S. Congress would be continued by the Bush administration. After the meeting, Baker and Mandela commended each other's efforts to bring peace to southern Africa. Also today, the United States lifted santions against Namibia, a day after the country achieved independence from South Africa. ``There were differences,'' said Mandela, a leader of the ANC, which is fighting to end white-minority rule in South Africa. ``But I would like you to concentrate on the friendship that exists between the ANC and the government, the Congress and the people of the United States.'' Mandela and other ANC leaders have argued that in order to correct the huge economic disparity between blacks and whites in South Africa key industries must be nationalized once whites share political power with blacks. Mandela, among world leaders attending Namibia's independence celebrations, said one of the disagreements was Baker's plan to meet President F. W. de Klerk during a South African visit this week. Mandela says it sends an inaccurate message that the South African government has made meaningful changes. The ANC leader said he is looking forward to meeting with President Bush in Washington, but no date has been set. Baker told reporters after the meeting with Mandela that the ANC had ``gone out of their way to make arrangements for us to see their colleagues in South Africa.'' Baker said of Mandela: ``I think his courageousness is something that the world has taken note of and ... has sustained many even in the U.S. that apartheid must be abolished.'' Baker, in greeting Mandela, said the U.S.-brokered negotiations that led to independence for Namibia were an example of how superpower cooperation could benefit the world. ``I fully agree,'' Mandela replied. Mandela also praised Bush and and Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev when he complimented world leaders for easing international conflicts. ``One of the things we deeply appreciate are the efforts made by the world powers to relax world tensions,'' said Mandela. ``I think that we are turning a new chapter and for that we are grateful to President Reagan, President Gorbachev, and of course to President Bush,'' Mandela said. Mandela's comments on Reagan and Bush, however, did not specifically extend to American policy toward South Africa. ANC leaders have said they can communicate better with the Bush administration, although they still disagree with some of its policies toward the South African government. The African National Congress, the main black group fighting minority white rule in South Africa, has long condemned Reagan's policy of ``constructive engagement'' toward South Africa, which involved continued ties in order to exert influence, and opposition to economic sanctions.

DOC.HEAD: Nigeria and United States Sign Drug-Fighting Pact
DOC.TEXT: The United States and Nigeria signed a pact Wednesday to join forces to fight drug abuse and trafficking. Justice Minister Bola Ajibola and U.S. Ambassador Lannon Walker signed an agreement to establish a joint task force on narcotics to ``wage war against illicit production, trafficking and abuse of narcotic drugs and other controlled substances.'' The Nigerian government also agreed to strengthen security on flights to the United States to conform with guidelines of U.S. Customs.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Meets With Polish Prime Minister
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 5 grafs new, new quotes, another round of meetings scheduled; editing throughout to shorten.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush assured Polish Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki today that the United States supports the right of the Polish people to live ``secure within their present borders.'' Bush's statement, delivered at a colorful White House welcoming ceremony, was intended to calm Polish fears that the reunification of Germany might lead to German claims on territory ceded to Poland after World War II. ``In any decisions affecting the fate of Poland, Poland must have a voice,'' Bush said to ringing applause. Agreement has been reached that Polish representatives will be present at meetings of the so-called two-plus-four nations when the issue of Polands's Western borders are discussed. The conference consists of East and West Germany, the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union. Bush invited Mazowiecki back to the White House for an unscheduled round of talks on Thursday. ``We see a new Europe in which the security of all European states _ and their fundamental right to exist secure within their present borders _ is totally assured,'' Bush said at arrival ceremonies on the South Lawn of the White House. ``America wants to see Poland succeed,'' Bush said. ``We want to welcome Poland as a full partner in the community of nations. We want to see your people enjoy the fruits of free enterprise.'' Opening a meeting in which Polish fears of a reunified and strong Germany are expected to be the dominant theme, Bush told Poland's first non-communist prime minister since World War II that the United States will remain a power in Europe and that the NATO alliance will remain strong and united. ``We have come from a country that wants to and can play a significant role in the new emerging order in Europe,'' Mazowiecki said in reply. ``We're coming here to talk about the future _ the future of Polish-American political cooperation in the face of momentous changes and ... economic cooperation so vital in our move to free enterprise.'' However, Mazowiecki said there are strains in the partnership. ``The present acceleration of history is one in which the partnership is being put to a test,'' he said, adding that the two nations would pass the test because of their common interests and U.S. goodwill. Later, in a ceremony in the White House Rose Garden, Bush and Mazowiecki signed a treaty designed to promote business and economic relations between the two countries and to attract significant U.S. investment. ``We can take this treaty to the U.S. investment community and say, `this is why you should invest in Poland','' Bush said. Mazowiecki said: ``The treaty is very important because it offers prospects for American business and companies to become engaged in the Polish environment.'' The prime minister said investors will encounter problems in their initial involvement in Poland, problems such as a faltering and unreliable telephone system. ``But I would like to tell your people they should not be discouraged,'' he said. ``We will welcome the courageous people who will come and help move us through this happy year of problems.'' Mazowiecki bowed to the American flag as he and Bush reviewed the military color guard standing at attention on the lawn. A child wearing colorful Polish national dress gave the prime minister red and white carnations, the colors of the Polish flag. Bush declined to respond when asked during a photo session if he objects to the continued presence of Soviet troops in Poland. Earlier, White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said the United States hoped it would not be necessary to have those troops in Poland. ``The presence of Soviet troops is something that is a little surprising to us,'' he said. ``We frankly don't think that will be necessary in the long run.'' Poland, unlike its East European neighbors, has said it wants Soviet troops to remain, apparently because of concern over the prospect of a reunited and strong German state. Mazowiecki, asked at the White House if he wants a written guarantee on his country's western borders with Germany, replied: ``We'll be talking about this.'' He told reporters before leaving Warsaw that Poland wants the United States to support its demand for a signed treaty guaranteeing its western border before reunification. Any treaty will have to be worked out between the two German states and Poland, said a U.S. official, who briefed reporters on condition of anonymity. The United States does not think it appropriate to become involved in exactly how and when that is done, the official said. The unification meetings involve East and West Germany and representatives of the United States, Britain, the Soviet Union and France, the four victors in World War II who retain authority in both German nations.

DOC.HEAD: United States Lifts Anti-Apartheid Sanctions Against Namibia
With AM-Namibia Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush ended sanctions against the new nation of Namibia on Wednesday and promised to give the former South African colony full access to the American market. ``With the end of South Africa's administration, all U.S. sanctions against Namibia are being lifted,'' Bush said. ``We welcome Namibia as a full trading partner and are taking steps to ensure that it is given access to the American market,'' he said. The Treasury Department said lifting the sanctions would allow new loans and investments in Namibia and remove the prohibition against imports of certain goods from Namibia. The sanctions had been imposed against South Africa because of its anti-apartheid racial policies and extended to Namibia because it was administered by the South African government. The sanctions remain against South Africa. Namibia, the last colony in Africa, spent the past 75 years under the rule of South Africa. ``The independence of Namibia today marks the end of colonialism in Africa, and a proud beginning for the world's newest country,'' the president said. He said the United States has already established full diplomatic relations with the new Republic of Namibia and will exchange ambassadors as quickly as possible. ``Americans can take pride in the role the United States played in making this transition to independence possible,'' Bush said. ``Brought about in large measure by vigorous American diplomacy, the 1988 Brazzaville Protocol and the New York Accords cleared the way to Namibian indepence and the withdrawal of all Cuban troops from Angola,'' he said. Bush said he sent Secretary of State James A. Baker III to the independence ceremonies in Windhoek ``as a sign of the respect and esteen in which we hold the world's newest democracy.'' He said Baker ``carries the good wishes of all Americans to President Sam Nujoma and the Namibian people. We are especially gratified that Namibia's Constituent Assembly has produced a constitution that is among the most democratic in Africa, and which provides an excellent basis to ensure national harmony and development.'' ``From this promising beginning we look forward to a warm and productive relationship with Namibia,'' said Bush. President Nujoma was the leader of the South West African People's Organization, which led the war against South Africa's rule. Elections last November provided SWAPO with a parliamentary majority. Nujoma has discarded SWAPO's ideological rhetoric, embraced a free-market economy and appointed non-political experts as his finance, agriculture and planning ministers.

DOC.HEAD: Soldier Killed After Being Struck by Helicopter Blade
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Wagstaffe cq
DOC.TEXT: An Army pilot standing by an observation helicopter was struck and killed by the rotor blades, officials said Wednesday. The accident, which occurred Tuesday afternoon and involved an OH-58 Kiowa helicopter, killed 1st Lt. Billy C. Perry Jr., 29, of Fort Campbell, Ky., said Maj. John Wagstaffe, an Army spokesman. The accident was under investigation. Fort Irwin, located in the Mojave Desert, is a major training center for Army units brought in from around the nation.

DOC.HEAD: Defense Industry Experts Say Research Should Continue
DOC.TEXT: The government could lose its competitive edge if it does not continue its research in defense technology despite diminishing military budgets, industry experts told Congress Wednesday. ``The worst that could happen is if we're caught with a major technological surprise,'' Norman R. Augustine, chairman and chief executive officer of Martin Marietta Corp., and a former Pentagon official, told a House panel. Augustine and two other defense industry specialists told the Armed Services defense policy panel that the United States should create a proven weapon and then consider saving the product. However, they said, the work must include testing as well as research and development. Donald A. Hicks, chairman of Hicks & Associates Inc., noted that if the government had stopped at research and development of the next generation air-to-air missile, commonly known as AMRAAM, the Pentagon never would have learned of some of the problems found during the operational tests. ``We should go all the way to putting the item in inventory, into the troops hands, then shut down the production line and put the proven data package on the shelf,'' Augustine said. The experts also stressed the importance of moving ahead with the next generation of weapons, aircraft and submarines only if development reflects a significant improvement from the current systems. Hicks, a proponent of stealth technology, said the United States has a real advantage in developing the radar-evading characteristics, best known on the B-2 bomber. ``We should get it into the inventory and get as much as we can,'' Hicks said of the aircraft that is the center of controversy because of its costly price tag of $530 million a copy.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Gorbachev Orders Lithuanians to Turn in Guns
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today ordered citizens of the breakaway Lithuanian republic to hand over their weapons to Soviet authorities, Soviet media reported. A directive from Gorbachev read on the evening television program ``Vremya'' said the Soviet Interior Ministry should confiscate guns from anyone who refuse to turn them in during the next seven days. The order from Gorbachev was sure to heighten the tension between Moscow and Lithuania, which declared independence on March 11. Gorbachev as well as the Soviet Congress has declared the move illegal. Lithuanians have begun signing up for voluntary defense service, and some Lithuanians serving in the Soviet armed forces have deserted. Gorbachev also ordered Soviet border guards to strengthen Lithuania's foreign border and prevent what it called illegal acts along the border. The Soviet Foreign Ministry also was ordered to clamp tighter controls on granting foreigners the right to travel to the republic. Lithuania is one of three Baltic republics annexed by the Soviet Union after the Hitler-Stalin pact of 1940, under which the Kremlin assumed control.

DOC.HEAD: After East Germans, Hungarians Prepare for Free Elections
DOC.TEXT: A stern figure, forefinger raised in admonition, glowers down at motorists heading into Budapest from the west and urges them to vote for ``Freedom and Property.'' At the southern train station, second-graders gleefully point to another poster displaying the back of a bull-necked Soviet officer. The Russian caption reads, ``Comrades, It's All Over.'' Another placard shows Leonid Brezhnev and Erich Honecker, the former hard-line East German leader, eyes closed and lip-to-lip in the classic kiss Warsaw Pact leaders used to give each other. Below, a pair of young lovers kiss playfully, and a slogan asks voters: ``Which Would You Pick?'' Elections for the 394-seat parliament are less than a week away, and the 29 political parties jockeying for a say in the next Hungarian government are sparing no effort to win the hearts and minds of the electorate. With Hungary among the Soviet bloc countries furthest on the road to reform, many campaign themes deal with independence from the Soviets _ a Red Army pullout began March 12 _ and a return to political pluralism and a market economy. The campaign ends March 23, two days before Hungarians vote. In the days remaining, the parties given the greatest chance of winning _ the Hungarian Democratic Forum, the Independent Smallholders, the League of Free Democrats, and the Socialists _ are focusing on the undecided voters. There are many of those, and it appears Sunday's vote will be only a preliminary test of party popularity. None is expected to win a majority, forcing a runff to decide a winner. A Gallup Poll published March 12 said 21 percent of the 1,000 people queried would vote for the Democratic Forum. The party has campaigned on a nationalistic platform interlaced with Christian Democratic values, a European-wide movement that emphasizes traditional Christian values in everyday life. Its staunch anti-Communist views are obvious in its campaign posters, which include the bull-necked Soviet officer at the train station. The party's president, Jozsef Antall, is the stern man on the poster above the highway. The Free Democrats, who consider themselves liberals and seek creation of a West European-style society, had 20.3 percent support in the poll. The Independent Smallholders, supported by 15.7 percent of the respondents, came in third. The party has presented itself as the main rural party, with center-right leanings. In last place was the governing Socialist Party _ the main remnant of the Communist party that ruled more than four decades. It had support of 8 percent of the respondents. The Socialist Party has pledged a full commitment to democracy, but Hungarians apparently are finding it difficult to trust a party born of the Communists, who ruled the country alone for more than four decades. Reformers gained the upper hand in the Communist Party last year, leading to the party's dissolution last year. The Socialists then declared themselves successors to the Communists. Talks with opposition groups led to the elections. They will be the second free elections in the Soviet bloc. But voters have pointed out in interviews recently that parallels should not be drawn between their vote and that in East Germany on March 18. More than 40 percent of the East Germans cast ballots for the Christian Democrats, who campaigned on a platform of quick reunification with West Germany and had support from West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl. ``We don't have a West Germany here to influence the voters,'' said Zoltan Fodor, a 35-year-old computer specialist in Budapest. ``We also don't have the theme of reunification.'' A woman sunning herself on a bench near a wall of election posters agreed that the proximity of West Germany to East Germany played an important role in the elections. ``They always had Western-style democratic values in view,'' said the woman, who identified herself only as Piroska. She was referring to the fact that most East Germans had access to the other Germany's television programs, even in the dark years of totalitarianism at home. ``We, in contrast, have been more isolated in some respects, although our democratic strivings began years ago,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Congressman Wants Base-Closing Money Spent for Job Training
DOC.TEXT: A California congressman, faced with the closing of military facilities in his district, introduced a bill Wednesday requiring that some Pentagon funds for base closings be used for job retraining. Rep. Robert Matsui, D-Calif., said at a news conference his legislation would require that at least 10 percent of the money earmarked for shutting down military bases be directed to job training in the affected communities. The legislation would ensure civilian military workers ``are not abandoned as we head into a future promising peace instead of conflict,'' Matsui said. The money would help give displaced workers job retraining, relocation and education assistance, counseling and job referral. Mather Air Force Base, which is located in Matsui's Sacramento district, is scheduled to close beginning in 1991. The closing will affect about 1,000 civilian employees. The facility was on the list of 86 domestic bases the Commission on Base Realignment and Closure recommended closing in December 1988. Former Defense Secretary Frank Carlucci and Congress accepted the commission's conclusions. Earlier this year, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney proposed closing or scaling back more than 72 domestic facilities and 14 overseas installations. Among those mentioned for closing is Sacramento Army Depot, which employs about 3,500 civilian workers and is also located in Matsui's district. Congress still must approve Cheney's list of candidates for closure.

DOC.HEAD: Museum Announces Acquisition of Van Gogh's `Irises'
DOC.TEXT: The J. Paul Getty Museum announced today it has purchased its greatest 19th century painting, the masterpiece ``Irises'' by Dutch artist Vincent van Gogh, for an undisclosed sum. Painted in 1889, ``Irises'' was sold to the museum by Alan Bond, the financially troubled Australian entrepreneur who paid a record $53.9 million for the work at a 1987 auction. In keeping with its policy of not discussing details of private acquisitions, the museum will not be disclosing the price of the work, the Getty said in a statement. The painting already is on display in the museum's second-floor galleries, where other 19th century paintings are displayed, including works by Pierre-Auguste Renoir, Edouard Manet and Edvard Munch. ``The chance to acquire the painting was a great moment in the history of the museum and the trust,'' said Harold M. Williams, president and chief executive officer of the J. Paul Getty Trust. Getty, the late oil baron endowed the museum with $2.1 billion, making it the world's richest art institution. The painting, characteristic of van Gogh's bold style, represents a patch of garden in a French asylum at Saint-Remy de Provence, where the troubled artist committed himself following a mental breakdown in Arles. ``This is among the most original and dynamic of all van Gogh's compositions, in which the spearlike, slashing representation of the flowers is echoed by the vibrancy of color,'' said George Goldner, the Getty's curator of paintings and drawings. ``At the same time it is a picture of great poetry, as expressed in the one white iris on the left side which, in its isolation, has a special poignancy.'' The private transaction was arranged by Sotheby's New York auction house, which had loaned Bond $27 million to buy ``Irises,'' using the painting itself as collateral. The unusual deal was widely criticized for inflating prices in the international art market. Since Bond's financial empire began crumbling under the weight of more than $5 billion in debt, there has been considerable curiosity about the fate of ``Irises'' among art curators, dealers and collectors. In a statement released by Sotheby's, Bond was quoted as saying, ``I am very pleased with this sale, particularly because this great masterpiece will be on exhibition at such a pre-eminent museum.''

DOC.HEAD: Deficit Continues, But Chinese Military to Get More Money
DOC.TEXT: China's military, schools and insolvent state-run enterprises will get more money this year, but other sectors will have to cut back as the nation faces another year in the red, the finance minister said Wednesday. Wang Bingqian said in a report to the National People's Congress that ``the present financial situation remains grave, with many contradictions and great difficulties cropping up in national finance.'' Also Wednesday, the legislature's 2,700 delegates accepted the resignation of senior leader Deng Xiaoping from his last government post _ chairman of the state Central Military Commission. Deng, 85, retired in November from his last Communist Party post, which was as head of the party's Central Military Commission. His resignation from the state body was expected, and party chief Jiang Zemin is expected to be named his successor. Although Deng now holds no official posts, he is believed to still have final authority on major issues. Wang detailed China's financial problems of the past year and warned that this year would be no better. ``The condition of the state budget for this year is grim because during this period of economic improvement and rectification, economic growth is slowing down,'' he said. Wang said an austerity program instituted in 1988 had slowed down China's economy, reducing revenues and complicating efforts to meet state demands for a balanced budget. This year's deficit will be $1.89 billion, down slightly from last year's $2 billion, Wang said. If domestic and foreign borrowing were regarded as part of the deficit, as they are in the West, this year's imbalance would be $9 billion, up more than $1 billion from last year. Wang said state revenues for 1990 are expected to go up nearly 11 percent to $68.86 billion, while spending is expected to grow by just over 10 percent to $70.75 billion. The government will try to increase revenues by raising business tax rates and improving collection of individual earnings taxes, he told the legislature. The revenues that local governments must turn over to the state will be ``moderately increased,'' and subsidies to some regions will be reduced, Wang said. The military will get a hefty 15.2 percent increase in its budget. National defense was allotted $6.16 billion, although Western military analysts say real spending is far greater if peripheral costs are included. Defense spending was held down during the 1980s as China concentrated on economic development, but the military was expected to get more this year because of its greater political clout after putting down last year's pro-democracy movement. Education got a 9.8 percent boost. Nearly one-third of the state budget, or $22.6 billion, will be spent on subsidies for money-losing enterprises and price rises. Wang called it ``a great drain on the state treasury.'' The state has allocated $2 billion to pay back individuals who last year were required to buy bonds to help finance public debt. Repayment to enterprises, public institutions and banks has been postponed, he said.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Precede: VILNIUS
Gorbachev Orders Lithuanians To Surrender Arms; Vilnius Protests Maneuvers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 8 grafs to UPDATE with Gorbachev ordering Lithuanians to turn in their weapons. Pickup 4th graf `In Moscow...'
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today ordered Lithuanians to turn in their weapons, a day after the Baltic republic's breakaway government demanded an end to Soviet military maneuvers. The Soviet Interior Ministry should confiscate guns from anyone who refuse to hand them in after a week, said Gorbachev's directive read on the evening television program ``Vremya.'' Lithuania declared independence March 11, a move condemned by Gorbachev and the Soviet Congress, and Lithuanians have begun signing up for voluntary defense service. The official news agency Tass said the decree aims ``to protect the rights of Soviet citizens and Soviet soverignty in Lithuania.'' The decree ordered the KGB to ``step up security on the Soviet border on Lithuanian territory and halt all illegitimate actions violating federal legislation on frontiers.'' The Soviet Foreign Ministry also was ordered to clamp tighter controls on granting foreigners the right to travel to the republic. In a telegram Tuesday night, Lithuanian Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene complained about unannounced Soviet military moves, which Lithuanians consider an attempt to intimidate them into backing down on their declaration of independence. ``The people of Lithuania are deeply disturbed about the actions of the Soviet armed forces: the intense mobilization of armored vehicles and tanks, the intensified flights of military air force planes, and unauthorized sorties into Lithuanian territory by paratroopers involved in intelligence activities,'' she said in the cable from Vilnius. In Moscow, a bill establishing tough requirements for secession passed its first legislative hurdle. The Supreme Soviet's Council of the Union, one of two chambers, gave the bill preliminary approval and sent it to the other chamber. Deputies said the secession procedure, which requires a republic-wide referendum and a transition period of up to five years, would have to be observed by Lithuania, even though it has already declared its independence. But Lithuanian deputy Vaidotas Antanaitis, who attended the session as an observer, disagreed. ``The bill doesn't apply to us; we've already left,'' he said during a break in the proceedings. The bill gained approval in a 175-15 vote after deputies argued that to delay its passage might lead more republics to copy Lithuania's March 11 declaration of independence. Mrs. Prunskiene said Lithuania's Parliament had not been notified in advance of the maneuvers, which began over the weekend, nor on the status of the Soviet army in Lithuania. The Lithuanians want Soviet troops to leave. ``Representatives from U.S.S.R. ministries and agencies arrive in Lithuania and act without contacting the government of Lithuania,'' she complained in the telegram, which was addressed to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and other senior Soviet officials. Mrs. Prunskiene called on the Kremlin to discuss the presence of troops and other issues: ``The government is convinced that there is a sound basis for coming to mutually beneficial understanding and for discussing issues of common interest in a calm and rational manner.'' The Soviet Congress of People's Deputies on Thursday declared Lithuania's March 11 declaration of independence illegal and invalid but did not say what steps would be taken to try to prevent secession. Gorbachev has said he would not use force and Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze, speaking Tuesday in Namibia, reiterated that position: ``We are against the use of force in any region, and particularly against the use of force domestically.'' Lithuanian Deputy Prime Minister Kazimieras Motieka said Tuesday that Soviet military airfields in the republic ``have an excessive number of helicopters and perhaps also military units.'' Lithuania has eight Soviet military bases and tens of thousands of troops, according to emigre sources. The Lithuanians insist on negotiating independence and say they intend to respect Soviet interests. Lithuania's Parliament today began debate in the capital of Vilnius on defining the structure of its new government, specifically on trimming the number of its ministries. There was no sign today of Soviet troop movements. Officials also said there were no signs of an economic blockade that many Lithuanians have anticipated in retaliation for the declaration of independence. ``We are still receiving gas and oil,'' Lithuania's two most critical imports from the Soviet Union, said Mrs. Prunskiene, an economist who was elected prime minister on Saturday. In a stern warning to Lithuania on Monday, the Kremlin ordered its ministries to ensure that no Moscow-run enterprises or agencies were turned over to Lithuania. It also said it would not tolerate a Lithuanian attempt to take over control of its boders, but the Lithuanians moved ahead with plans to take charge of the frontiers and youths volunteered to help. Signs in Vilnius said the Sajudis grass-roots nationalist movement was handling the registration of men between ages of 19 and 40 who were ready to serve in defense of the region. Both men and women were responding to the call and crowded the tiny office in the Parliament building to fill out the forms. Lithuanian officials said they intend to set up border and customs forces to show the world's governments that Lithuania controls its territory and should be formally recognized as independent. So far, no foreign country has officially recognized Lithuania as independent. Mrs. Prunskiene said the government hoped to have installed withing 10 days 37 border posts in locations on the Soviet and Polish frontiers that are not occupied by Soviet forces.

DOC.HEAD: Honduran Cargo Plane Crashes
DOC.TEXT: A Honduran cargo plane crashed into a mountain near Tegucigalpa in bad weather on Wednesday, killing its three crew members, officials said. ``The plane was totally disintegrated,'' said Capt. Francisco Perez Aguilar, chief of civil aeronautics operations. The Tan-Sahsa airline Electra turboprop, carrying medical supplies and tractor parts, was en route from Miami to Tegucigalpa. It crashed at 9:06 a.m. on Cerro de Hule, five miles south of the capital, officials said. The pilot, co-pilot and flight engineer, the only people on board, died in the crash, Perez Aguilar said. The mountain was obscured by rain and wind Wednesday. The Tegucigalpa airport is situated in a valley surrounded by mountains that are frequently hidden by bad weather. Cerro de Hule is where a Tan-Sahsa 727 passenger jet crashed Oct. 21, 1989. That crash killed 131 of the 146 people on board.

DOC.HEAD: Independence Architect Says Namibia Independence Is Hope for Africa
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUB 3rd graf, `Crocker spent...' to restore dropped word. Pickup 4th, `These included...
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Namibia, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The architect of the U.S.-brokered negotiations that led to Namibian independence said Wednesday the success of the talks shows there is hope for peace in all of southern Africa. ``It is really the first time since the early 1960s that southern Africa has a chance for peace,'' said Chester Crocker, the former U.S. assistant secretary of state for African affairs. He was speaking on the first full day of independence for Namibia, which since 1915 had been a territory of South Africa. Crocker spent eight years negotiating independence for Namibia and had to work out a series of complicated deals to bring it about. These included persuading Angola's Marxist government to send home 50,000 Cuban troops, who were helping it battle anti-Marxist guerrillas and South African fighters. The Angolans also agreed to close bases of the African National Congress, the nationalist group fighting South Africa's government. Crocker was criticized by many African governments for linking a Cuban withdrawal from Angola to Namibian independence. ``It never made any sense without it,'' he responded in an interview. ``You had three wars going on and they're all inter-linked, and there's nothing in it for South Africa if there is no Cuban withdrawal. Angola and Namibia are intimately connected by history. It was a natural approach.'' ``We were pushing two rocks up two hills simulteaneously, not one rock up one hill,'' said Crocker, now a professor at Georgetown University. The negotiations often broke down just as it appeared a deal was near. In 1984, the United States set up an office that was to become its embassy in Namibia. Two U.S. officials assigned to the office, Dennis Keogh, and Army Lt. Col. Kenneth Crabtree, were killed by a bomb at Oshakati, in the northern war zone. The office was closed when it became apparent independence was in the distance. Crocker kept pushing, and a U.S. Embassy was opened here against Wednesday by Secretary of State James A. Baker III. A plaque honoring the two slain men is in the foyer. Asked why the sides ultimately reached an agreement, Crocker said Angola's attempt at a decisive military offensive in 1987 ``was a total fiasco.'' South Africa agreed to terms ``because this for them was a very substantial accomplishment for their own diplomacy as they saw it. Castro would say the same from his perspective,'' he said of the Cuban leader. ``But look what the South Africans got. They're leaving Namibia on their own terms. They're getting rid of the ANC presence in Angola. They're getting rid of the only foreign troops in southern Africa, the Cubans,'' Crocker said. ``It's a great sense of accomplishment and reward ... to see it work and to see this country about to take off, to see the region turning a page,'' he said. ``This is an achievement for U.S. diplomacy. People talk about U.S.-Soviet diplomacy and it did play a role. But frankly it was our concept and it was our effort, and they joined it when it really began to take off.'' The civil war is still going on in Angola, and a civil war also rages in Mozambique, along with political violence in South Africa. But Crocker said that through the success of the Namibian agreement, ``People have seen negotiations work and that sort of demonstration can be very powerful.'' On the subject of South African apartheid, Crocker said those who attribute recent reforms in South Africa to American sanctions, or to his policies, ``denigrate the struggle of black and white South Africans to promote change. The struggle has always been inside. That's where the power is.'' He said legalization of labor unions, and their subsequent pressures against apartheid were far more important than sanctions imposed by the United States.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Singer Janet Jackson says she won't use a black leopard in her act because fans have expressed concern about its welfare. Miss Jackson said through her publicist on Tuesday that she removed the leopard from her act in New York, where she performed last week. Some audience members worried the animal could be harmed being carted from location to location on Miss Jackson's current worldwide tour. ``While the illusion with the cat was appreciated by most of the audience, if it caused even a few people to worry about the safety of the cat it's not worth it,'' Miss Jackson said in a statement. ``I love animals and would never do any harm, or allow anyone to do any harm to one,'' said Miss Jackson, whose brother Michael Jackson has a menagerie of exotic animals at his California ranch. ``I would rather do without the cat.''

Lily Tomlin, who donated proceeds from a recent comedy performance to an innovative day-care center for homeless children, attended the center's dedication ceremonies. A room in the Wayside Christian Mission's day-care center was named the Lily Tomlin Arts and Drama Room. Ms. Tomlin's opening night performance in Louisville of ``The Search for Signs of Intelligent Life in the Universe'' raised $3,000 to $5,000 for the center, said Executive Director Timothy Moseley. The center will serve about 25 children within two weeks and eventually up to 49 a week, Moseley said. It will enable parents applying for jobs, looking for apartments, visiting the doctor or running errands to leave their children with day-care workers instead of taking them along, he said. Ms. Tomlin, whose parents were born in western Kentucky, spent about two hours touring the homeless shelter and the day-care center Tuesday.

Roy Acuff will be away from the Grand Ole Opry stage for two to three weeks because of minor eye surgery, a spokeswoman said Wednesday. Acuff, 86, had outpatient surgery Monday on his right eye to prevent his glaucoma from getting worse, said Opry spokeswoman Debbie Logue. She said the singer would wear an eye patch for a while. Acuff, dubbed the King of Country Music, has performed at the Opry since 1938.

Webb Pierce, a country music singer popular in the '50s and '60s, was recovering Wednesday from abdominal surgery, a hospital spokeswoman said. Pierce had extensive surgery Friday and ``is now recovering well,'' said Anna Austin, a spokeswoman at Southern Hills Medical Center. She said he was moved from an intensive care unit to a regular room Tuesday. Further details about the surgery were not released. Pierce, 63, has been semiretired for several years. He is best known for his hit record ``In the Jailhouse Now.''

Former U.S. Attorney Rudolph Giuliani, who lost his bid last year to be mayor, will be a commentator on the syndicated ``Inside Edition'' series, a spokeswoman for the show said Wednesday. The weeknight show ``is the best daily investigative news program on the air,'' Giuliani said in a statement. Giuliani, who is married to local TV anchorwoman Donna Hanover, will make his debut on the weeknight show Thursday. He will return periodically, said the spokeswoman, Marcy Baron. Guiliani, a Republican, was defeated by Democrat David Dinkins.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: versions of the following items are moving on sports wires
DOC.TEXT: Nadia Comaneci, the Romanian gymnast who fled from her homeland last fall, is living with friends in Montreal and looking for work as a gym teacher, a newspaper reported Wednesday. The 14-year-old darling of the 1976 Olympic Games has been romantically linked to a married Romanian who helped her escape, but she insisted in an interview with Montreal La Presse that she was never involved with him. The man, Constantin Panait, who had been working in Florida as a roofer, now lives in Cleveland with his wife and four children, she said. ``I'm starting with nothing,'' Comaneci said. ``I have to establish a career. I have a boyfriend in Romania but he's far away. I don't have a car. The only thing I can afford to buy is a pair of roller skates.'' When she came to Montreal last month, there were rumors that Comaneci would be offered a job with the Olympics Installations Board, a provincial agency that operates the Olympic Stadium and adjacent facilities. But no agreement has been reached. Comaneci, who was the first gymnast to obtain a perfect score of 10 and won three gold medals at the 1976 Games in Montreal, left Tuesday for Rome to tape a TV show, La Presse said.

East German ice skating star Katarina Witt says burglars broke into her country home and made off with ``valuable jewelry,'' the state-run ADN news agency reported Wednesday. Police are investigating the break-in, which occurred last week at Witt's bungalow in Eberswalde county, northeast of Berlin, ADN said. It gave no further details. Witt, a two-time Olympic gold medalist, enjoyed great privileges under East Germany's former hard-line communist leadership, as did other top sports figures. She currently performs in a commercial Western ice revue.

DOC.HEAD: In Homeless Count, Neighbors Know Best
LaserPhoto staffing
DOC.TEXT: For the seven months he lived in Tompkins Square Park, Louis Hrusovsky could count the days since his last satisfying meal, the hours spent idle, the moments until police would roust him. Early Wednesday, Hrusovsky returned to Tompkins Square and put that abject arithmatic to good use. He counted the homeless. ``This area will be one of the most thorough counts in the city,'' he said. ``I lived in this park for seven months, until three weeks ago. I can give you the name of everyone in the park.'' Hrusovsky and his fellow enumerators _ a cheery, determined group _ tried to do just that. They were a bright spot in the first national effort to count America's unsheltered. From the start, critics had said that the census, conducted Tuesday night and Wednesday morning, would overlook many of the nation's homeless, including an estimated 70,000 to 90,000 in New York City. City officials and advocates for the homeless repeated the charges on Wednesday. Not only did the counter miss the nooks and crannies where many homeless sleep _ subway tunnels and back alleys, they also failed to visit several shelters. At the Port Authority Bus Terminal, home to hundreds of homeless, reporters watched as some counters milled around a newsstand. It seemed as if they were ignoring the terminal's upper levels, where many people sleep in hallways, bus platforms and stairwells. Barbara Everitt Bryant, the U.S. Census Bureau director, insisted that the terminal was blanketed, and said any shelters that were missed would be checked on Wednesday night. Anyway, Census officials said they were looking for a ``snapshot'' of the homeless, not precise numbers. Among the skeptics was a man who identified himself as Sharif. He said he had been living in Tompkins Square Park, a scruffy plot of green on Manhattan's Lower East Side, for the past four months. ``The Census Bureau doesn't have the heart or audacity to go to where people crash,'' he said before the census takers arrived. He pointed out nooks of the park, abandoned buildings and vacant lots where he said sleeping homeless would go uncounted. Sharif was wrong. At about 2:30 a.m., Hrusovsky and 11 other enumerators arrived at the park. Methodically, carefully, they counted everyone. Some of the census takers had been homeless, some had not. All were from the neighborhood, and knew it well. ``Since 1952, my family has never been in the census,'' said Blanca Moore. ``I chose to work in my neighborhood, and I am hopeful that all these people can be counted.'' After counting the sleeping forms dotting the park, 11 enumerators wended their way through the lettered streets that are known as Alphabet City; a decayed section of vacant lots, abandoned buildings occupied by squatters and gentrified apartment houses. First stop, at 3 a.m., was a fenced-in lot on Avenue B. Paul Eskridge tested the chained gate and peered in at three makeshift tents, ringed by old appliances and grocery carts stacked with cans to be returned for deposit. ``This is private domain, so we'll have to guess. Three tents, two people in each, to be conservative, so six in all,'' he said, filling out the forms. As the group made its way down Ninth Street, Eskridge darted across the street and snagged a man who said he was homeless. ``What kind of hour is this to be out? You guys are the kooks!'' said the homeless man. He politely answered the questions. At the next corner, the group eyed three young men standing on the corner. ``I know those three. They're drug dealers,'' said one enumerator. ``OK, then avoid them,'' said another. On a side street off Avenue D, the group stepped into a rubble-strewn lot where three shacks stood patched together from tar paper and wood scraps. ``Don't wake anyone up,'' one woman whispered, as a man emerged from a lean-to. ``Hi!'' Susie Garcia called out to him. ``We're from the Census Bureau.'' A few minutes of explanation and the group left with the count: nine males, six females, all adults. One counter mentioned he saw a child in one shack. ``They're saying there were no kids because they're afraid we'll send a social worker out there,'' said another counter. Despite the chilly drizzle, counters introduced themselves to everyone they passed. ``I'm doing it for the money,'' admitted Garcia, who received $9.50 an hour. ``But I live right in this neighborhood, and I hope it makes a difference. Besides, this isn't a job _ it's an adventure.'' Shortly before 4 a.m., a car pulled up and rolled down a window. ``Hey! Isn't it too late to take a census?'' Several counters replied in unison: ``It's never too late for a census!''

DOC.HEAD: Nujoma Stresses Economic Reform as Namibia Celebrates Independence
LaserPhotos WDK1,WDK5,WDH15
DOC.TEXT: Namibia celebrated its first day of independence Wednesday with a joyful multi-racial parade, and President Sam Nujoma stressed the need for economic development if the country is to achieve democratic ideals. ``We have inherited a lopsided economy ... Two-thirds of our people are very poor,'' and 30 percent are unemployed, Nujoma told an overflow crowd of more than 30,000 Namibians and hundreds of foreign dignitaries. All-night parties and tribal dancing followed the lowering of the South African flag at the sports stadium just after midnight. Namibians cheered as the red, green and blue banner of their newly independent country was raised in its place, marking the end of 75 years of South African rule. The 72-member National Assembly elected in November was sworn in, and thousands lined the streets again just after dawn as a 3-mile-long parade made its way to the stadium where Nujoma spoke. Forty-one of the legislators belong to Nujoma's South-West Africa People's Organization, the guerrilla movement that waged a 23-year war against South African rule and then captured the most votes in November's balloting. Black women from the Herero tribe, wearing colorful ankle-length Victorian dresses and headdresses, marched in front of white teen-agers twirling batons down Kaiser Street, which will be renamed Independence Avenue. The floats depicted the country's ethnic diversity. Primitive Bushmen and modern bands were carried along on the back of flatbed trucks to the stadium. The speeches were followed by singing and dancing that lasted into the night. Many young blacks cheered loudly when Palestine Liberation Organization leader Yasser Arafat, his car blocked by the parade, stepped out and walked a few steps along the route before slipping into a hotel. Between the festivities and state dinners, dozens of foreign leaders took the oportunity to discuss issues. South African President F.W. de Klerk met with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze. It was the first meeting between a South African president and a member of the Soviet government since relations were broken 34 years ago over South Africa's system of racial segregation. De Klerk also met Yugoslavian President Janez Drnovsek and Swedish Foreign Minister Sten Andersson. South African Foreign Minister Pik Botha described the contacts as ``South Africa's return to international acceptability.'' Shevardnadze and Secretary of State James A. Baker III met Angolan President Eduardo dos Santos. They discussed a possible cease-fire in the Angolan civil war, where the United States and the Soviet Union back opposing sides. To coincide with independence, the United States lifted economic sanctions against Namibia. The sanctions were imposed against South Africa to protest apartheid, but they extended to Namibia while it was under South Africa's control. The two superpower ministers also had separate meetings with Nelson Mandela, the deputy president of the African National Congress. Nujoma's focus on economics before an audience of international decision-makers was seen as an indication of the country's need for an infusion of money to balance its budget and meet the expectations that independence has created for so many black citizens. Unemployment is disproportionately suffered by the black majority and was exacerbated by the return last year of more than 40,000 exiles. Business and industry are concentrated in the hands of whites, who make up just 6 percent of the population. Nujoma, an avowed socialist during his 30 years in exile, made no reference to that ideology during his speech, but he repeatedly mentioned the necessity of private capital and investment to strengthen the Namibian economy. Namibia has an annual per capita income of about $1,000 a year, one of the highest in Africa. But this is partly based on South African aid, which is ending. The semi-desert country has good infrastructure and profitable mining, fishing and agriculture industries, controlled by whites. The country of more than 1.3 million people faces a $191 million deficit this year on a budget of a little more than $766 million. South Africa captured Namibia from the Germans in 1915 and agreed to give up its control last year as part of a complicated deal also involving Angola and Cuba. In return for independence, Cuba withdrew troops backing the Angolan government against guerrillas and South African fighters. Namibia had also been known as South-West Africa. Chester Crocker, the former U.S. assistant secretary of state for African affairs who worked out the deal, said Wednesday its success showed there is hope for peace in all of southern Africa. Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak spoke as chairman of the Organization of African Unity, and like Nujoma he focused on the economy. ``Political freedom cannot be sustained without economic development,'' said Nujoma. He said the lessening of tensions between East and West is a positive global development and said he hoped the rich countries of the world will not now build a ``new iron curtain'' between north and south that would lead to ``the marginalization of Africa.''

DOC.HEAD: INS Reports Surge in Apprehensions Over Last 10 Months
DOC.TEXT: Illegal immigration along the southwestern border has surged in recent months, reversing a three-year downturn that began when the federal government told employers they could not hire undocumented workers. According to figures from the Immigration and Naturalization Service, apprehensions of illegal aliens along the Southwest border were up in each of the last 10 months, compared with the same month a year ago. INS spokesman Verne Jervis said the rise in apprehensions _ considered to be the best indicator of illegal immigration _ began in May 1989 and continued through February. According to the INS figures, apprehensions of illegal aliens were up 29.9 percent over the last 10 months, compared with the same period a year ago.
