Apprehensions totaled 801,937 over the period, compared with 617,317 from May 1988 through February 1989. Some months recorded surges of nearly 60 percent, while in other months the increases dropped below 20 percent. The last three months have been among the highest, with apprehensions rising 57.3 percent in February from a year earlier, by 39.6 percent in January 1990 from the previous January, and by 58.3 in December 1989 over the same month in 1988. Although the trend in apprehensions continued downward through the fiscal year that ended last Sept. 30, the first six months of this fiscal year have seen an increase in apprehensions of 37 percent over the same period a year ago. Apprehensions had begun dropping sharply in fiscal 1987, a year after Congress passed and President Reagan signed the Immigration Control and Reform Act of 1986. The law made employers subject to civil and criminal sanctions for hiring undocumented workers. Jervis said the recent rise in illegal immigration may be due to the availablity of fradulent documents, which undocumented workers use to obtain work, or simply to the ``desperation'' of some Mexicans seeking work in the United States. Jervis said the Bush administration's budget for the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1 seeks an increase in money for the Border Patrol to $289.2 million from the current $262.6 million. The administration wants to raise the number of border guards from 4,852 to 4,942.

DOC.HEAD: House Panel Seeks to Restrict Domestic Assault Rifles
DOC.TEXT: A House panel voted Wednesday to restrict the sale and possession of U.S.-made assault rifles and require a minimum 10-year sentence for a person carrying such a weapon while committing a crime. President Bush last year banned import of the semi-automatic rifles. The bill approved by the House Judiciary subcommittee on crime would require the administration to extend the ban to domestic-made versions which the president determines have no sporting purpose. Subcommittee Chairman Bill Hughes, D-N.J., said it makes no sense to ban imports and not the American assault weapons that account for two-thirds of those in circulation. ``There's no question but that assault weapons are being used with increased frequency by drug dealers, criminals and mental incompetents to carry out acts of violence,'' Hughes said. The term assault weapons refers to semiautomatic versions of automatic rifles originally developed for military use. The bill would not affect the ownership or transfer of existing weapons and it would not apply to handguns. The 10-year minimum penalty would apply when an assault weapon is used or carried during a violent crime or drug crime. The bill next goes to the full House Judiciary Committee.

DOC.HEAD: The Lambada: It's Hot, Hot, Hot
DOC.TEXT: The miniskirted woman straddles her partner's thigh, and they begin a rhythmic bump and grind. It's dancing: the lambada to be exact, a sexy two-step promoters are hoping will be the craze of the '90s. ``This is taking dancing to new heights,'' an enthusiastic Charles P. Moore says after his first lambada lesson at the Palladium nightclub, where every Friday night is Lambada Night. ``It's like sex of the human body with the artistic value of art being applied to dance. I love it!'' Promoters are hyping the Brazilian dance as the dirtiest of dirty dances. An ad for one of two new lambada movies, ``The Forbidden Dance'' says: ``Lambada ... If it got any hotter, it wouldn't be dancing!'' ``It's a very sensual dance, that's for sure,'' said Sophia Morris, a dance instructor at the Palladium. The first step to lambada success appears to be losing one's inhibitions. Lessons begin with the women straddling their partners thighs. ``Just move your hips. Especially you ladies! One-two! One-two!'' shouted instructor Sergio Barbosa, his hips swaying sensually from side to side. Decades old, the dance originated in Brazil's northern Bahia. It resembles other Latin dances _ only it's done closer, a lot closer. Lambada reached a fever pitch last summer in France and arrived in the United States late last year. Publicity surrounding the dance has produced a spate of quickie Lambada movies, including ``The Forbidden Dance,'' and ``Lambada.'' And moviegoers will soon be treated to: ``Naked Lambada,'' ``Blame it on the Lambada,'' and ``Lambada: The Seduction.'' The publicity appears to be paying off. Outside the Palladium, before the doors open at 11 p.m., tourists from Canada, Wisconsin and Florida wait in line with local lambada-devotees. Hoping to cash in on the craze, the Palladium offers free lambada lessons, a floor show and a lambada dance contest. ``We thought it would be very ethnic but its become very mainstream very quickly,'' said Steve Gold, the Palladium's executive director. ``People were ready for something new. There hasn't been anything new out there since the Hustle.'' Looking at the dance floor, Brandon Morris of Milwaukee likes what he sees. ``I like the music and I like the dance. It's erotic,'' said Morris, who showed up without a partner. ``If I can find someone to dance with me, I want to try it. But first, I want to find out how to do it.'' To those who say the dance is obscene and nothing more than a simulated sex act, Tom Romeo says nonsense. ``You're moving so fast, you don't have time to think about sex,'' he said. His sister, Dina, says it's just plain fun. ``If it was such a dirty dance,'' she added, ``I wouldn't do it with my brother.''

DOC.HEAD: UNITA Rebels Claim Bombarding Southern Government Positions
With AM-Namibia, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Angolan rebels claimed Wednesday they were bombarding two major garrisons in southern Angola and had pinned down troops of the Marxist government. A brief military statement released in Lisbon and signed by the rebels' military information chief, Col. Zacarias Mundombe, said the strategic Mavinga airstrip and Cuito Cuanavale came under ``intense bombardment.'' It gave no details of casualties or damage but said the shelling prevented government soldiers at Mavinga from leaving their positions. In separate attacks in the northern province of Uige, the statement said rebels killed 23 government soldiers, destroyed Soviet-built military vehicles and captured various weapons. Fighting in Angola's 15-year-old civil war has intensified since the government launched a major offensive against the UNITA rebels in their southern heartland in December. Clashes have been especially bitter around Mavinga, 700 miles southeast of the capital, Luanda. The U.S.-backed UNITA _ the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola _ has been waging a war since 1975 to force the Soviet-aided government into a power-sharing agreement.

DOC.HEAD: Seven Injured When Thousands Gather to See British Band
DOC.TEXT: A crush of thousands of fans seeking autographs from members of the British band Depeche Modes left several people with minor injuries. At least five people were treated and released at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center, said emergency room receptionist Lisa Perez. Police Capt. Keith Bushey said his injured count was seven. About 400 fans were expected at the Tuesday night signing at the Wherehouse record store, but 3,000 showed up, said Police Sgt. Emilio Perez. Nearly 100 officers in riot gear quelled the crowd, which spilled over into La Cienega Boulevard, a major thoroughfare. People began shoving and throwing rocks and bottles, said Bushey. ``People were getting stepped on and one girl fainted,'' said Art Cortez, 16, who was in the crowd. ``It was like a riot.'' Police cordoned off streets for about two hours and made no arrests, Bushey said. Members of the band _ Alan Wilder, David Gahan, Martin Gore and Andy Fletcher _ were expected to sign autographs from 9:30 p.m. to midnight but were whisked away in a limousine by 10:15 p.m. The group, currently on the charts with their single, ``Personal Jesus,'' was promoting their new album, ``Violator.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Welcomes Resumed Food Deliveries in Ethiopia
DOC.TEXT: The State Department on Wednesday welcomed the resumption of food delivery to rebel-held territory in northern Ethiopia, but said only a small fraction of starving people are being reached. Eleven trucks carrying 120 tons of U.S. donated food crossed Tuesday from government-held territory to an area controlled by the Tigrean People's Liberation Front, said State Department deputy spokesman Richard Boucher. A second convoy is expected to travel Thursday. ``We welcome the movement of this test convoy made possible by informal agreement among the warring parties in Ethiopia,'' Boucher said. ``The government of Ethiopia, its relief organization, numerous private voluntary agencies and the concerned rebel groups each, in their way, deserve credit.'' Boucher said that 4 million to 5 million Ethiopians face starvation, but that only a small fraction of them will be reached whatever the success of the new operation. ``There is an urgent necessity of opening other relief corridors and for the warring parties to give top priority to feeding the hungry,'' he said. Boucher called for the reopening of the Red Sea port of Massawa to food shipments and said internationally supervised food distributions should be made from there into Eritrea, the country's northernmost province. According to U.N. estimates, more than 1 million people are threatened with starvation in Eritrea alone. ``Agreements must be reached for airlifts into affected areas as needed, whether controlled by the government or by insurgents,'' Boucher said. The relief effort is the first since Eritrean rebels launched an offensive in early February and overran the port of Massawa.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Deplores Romanian Violence, Lauds Government Response
DOC.TEXT: The State Department appealed to Romanians on Wednesday to reject extremist groups and end recent ethnic violence that has claimed lives in the northwestern part of the country. But spokesman Richard Boucher said the United States is heartened by Romanian President Ion Iliescu's to restore order and ``promote an atmosphere of social calm and national reconciliation during this explosive period.'' ``Romanian citizens of all ethnic backgrounds should remember their recent monumental sacrifices in ousting the brutal Ceaucescu dictatorship in the hope of establishing a democracy based on respect for human rights and tolerance of political and cultural diversity,'' Boucher said. Romanians overthrew communist dictator Nicolai Ceaucescu last December, executing him and his wife in the violent revolt. The government sent troops to the Transylvanian city of Tirgu Mures Wednesday to quell violence against ethnic Hungarians that had left least six people dead. Romanians poured into the city to battle ethnic Hungarians who were protesting an attack Tuesday on their political association headquarters. Boucher said there were reports as many as 300 people were injured. ``We appeal to all Romanians to reject extremist groups which are using the new permissive environment to resuscitate destructive ethnic animosities,'' he said. ``The United States deplores the provocations, intimidations and violence perpetrated by all parties to the current conflict,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Homosexual Fights Army Over ROTC Commission
LaserPhoto NXJ1
DOC.TEXT: In the eyes of the Army's Reserve Officer Training Corps, James M. Holobaugh went from being a model cadet to a reject by uttering three words: ``I am gay.'' Now, with the same kind of determination that made him a top ROTC performer, Holobaugh is fighting the Army's ban on homosexuals and and to receive the commission he earned. Holobaugh, 24, was once held in such esteem by the Army that he was chosen to appear in an ROTC recruitment ad. He was due to receive his Army commission at Washington University in St. Louis last May, a year before graduation. But after informing his superiors a month earlier that he had come to the realization he was gay, no commission was forthcoming. The Pentagon regards homosexuals as unsuitable for military service. The U.S. Supreme Court recently dealt opponents of that policy a blow by refusing to hear two appeals of the Pentagon policy. The Army's professor of military science at Washington University in January recommended after a hearing that Holobaugh be denied his commission and be required to repay his four-year scholarship, worth $25,000. A final decision is to be made by the commanding general of the Army Cadet Command at Fort Monroe, Va., an ROTC spokesman said. ``I was kind of surprised about the scholarship,'' Holobaugh, an easy-going man with a ready smile, said in an interview Monday. ``If I had flunked out of school I could understand. But this was not for something I made a choice about. I just am.'' Holobaugh is finishing his engineering studies at the University of New Haven but will get his degree from Washington in May before taking a job in New York City. Advised that years of lawsuits have been unsuccessful in changing the armed forces' policy on homosexuals, Holobaugh decided last month that going public with his ordeal might be a more effective way to put pressure on the military. The decision was not an easy one. ``I just told my father the first week of February that I was gay and then bam, I'm on television. It was hard for him,'' Holobaugh said. He said he has received letters of support from all over the country and planned to begin taking his case to college groups Wednesday night, at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. On Thursday, he was scheduled to speak at Harvard Law School. ``I feel now for the rest of my life there will be something I'll be fighting for,'' he said. If schools begin kicking ROTC off campus because of the Defense Department's ban of homosexuals, the military might be swayed to change its policies in order to protect a program that each year turns out more than 70 percent of the Army's junior officers, Holobaugh said. Holobaugh took part in just about all of ROTC's extracurricular activities and earned seven A's and one B in his military classes, first at the University of Missouri at Rolla, where he spent 2{ years, and then at Washington University. ``A lot of people badmouth the Army when you're in. It's like the thing to do. But I knew I had chosen the right thing. ``I thought it was a great opportunity to serve my country, to get a lot of good experience as an officer and to finance my education,'' he said, adding that the Army would have to sue him if it wants to collect any of the scholarship money. Holobaugh said he went through the process of accepting he was gay in late 1988 and early 1989. He went to a captain for advice in April 1989 because he was deeply afraid he could be court-martialed if they found out he was gay after he was already in the Army. The captain advised him to tell the truth and request he be denied his commission. He followed the recommendations, even though he said he wanted the commission. Later, after talking with a private attorney, he informed the Army he wanted to fulfill his service obligations. ``Now that I look back on it I'm really glad I said something because I can't imagine going four years on active duty or eight in the reserves and trying to keep this secret,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Republic Driving for Independence Postpones Elections
DOC.TEXT: The republic of Georgia postponed elections scheduled Sunday to introduce a multiparty system and give opposition parties time to organize their campaigns against the ruling Communists. The republic's ruling Supreme Soviet parliament decided late Tuesday to postpone the elections. A spokesman for the opposition People's Front, Valerian Khukhunasvili, said the decision was made after intense negotiations between the Communist Party chief and the head of the People's Front. The official Soviet news agency Tass said the elections would be held in October or November and that current legislators would continue in their offices until then. The Georgian Supreme Soviet also abolished an article in the republic's constitution granting the Communist Party a monopoly on political power, Tass said. The move echoed the national legislature's vote last week to end the unchallenged role of the Communist Party. The amended Georgian constitution gives all political parties and public organizations the right ``to take part in working out the policies of the government, in managing government and public affairs.'' The People's Front was instrumental in pressing for the change and has spearheaded the republic's fight for independence. On March 9, the Georgian parliament condemned what it said was the republic's forced annexation by the Soviet Union in the 1920s and demanded negotiations on restoring independence. Two days later, the Baltic republic of Lithuania declared itself independent, which the Soviet government refuses to accept. Pro-independence groups have scored significant victories in local elections this year in Lithuania and the two other Baltic republics, Estonia and Latvia. Pro-independence parties in Georgia, including the People's Front, have been pushing for secession for more than a year. The parties have used mass demonstrations to press for independence. On April 9, 1989, Soviet soldiers moved against a crowd of peaceful demonstrators in the republic's capital of Tbilisi, killing 19. A patrol later shot another person for violating curfew.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Accuses Burmese Authorities of Rights Abuses
DOC.TEXT: The State Department accused the Burmese government Wednesday of engaging in ``arbitrary interference'' in the lives of many Burmese citizens by forcibly removing them from their homes. Deputy spokesman Richard Boucher said Burmese military authorities have relocated, often on short notice, residents of some Burmese cities, particularly Rangoon, to new areas outside those locations. ``In many cases, the new housing areas are ill-prepared, lacking sanitary and other facilities, and are isolated by distance and lack of regular transport,'' he said. ``While some of those being forcibly relocated appear to be squatters, we understand that many are legitimate owners of houses and property.'' There have been reports of deaths as a result of the relocations. Most appear to have taken place in areas where there has been strong anti-government sentiment, he said. ``Whatever the motives for the relocations, they appear to have been carried out without due regard for the interest, safety and rights of those involved,'' Boucher said. ``We call upon the Burmese military regime to respect the fundamental and legitimate civil rights of the Burmese people, including refraining from arbitrary interference in their lives and property.''

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Neighborly Census, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Some sights and sounds from the nation's first homeless census:

Willie Smith and Sharon Johnson, two people among the thousands of homeless in San Francisco, were glad to cooperate when U.S. Census Bureau workers came calling with their questions. ``We're all humans, and this count makes us feel like we've all got a little respect as human beings,'' the 37-year-old Smith said Tuesday night at the Pierce-Arrow Episcopal Community Services shelter in the city's Tenderloin district. Smith, homeless in San Francisco for two years, sat in front of a poster of former presidents Nixon, Ford and Carter in the crowded shelter as he and others answered questions about their age, race, marital status and ethnic origin. ``Why sure,'' answered Johnson, resident of another Episcopal shelter, when asked if she wanted to take part in the survey. ``I exist, don't I? I'm part of the population of this country.''

At Baloney Joe's shelter in Portland, Ore., George Whitney filled out the forms, but he was not impressed by the census. ``It's just the people in their ivory tower drinking their mint juleps and counting noses,'' he said. ``Nobody can help the homeless because nobody understands the problem.'' The city of Portland agreed to pay 30 homeless people $20 apiece to guide Census workers to homeless camps. The Census Bureau identified 150 sites, most of them shelters and hotels, plus about 70 homeless camps or other street locations that were taken from a list compiled by the city.

Occasional light rain fell in Sioux Falls, S.D., as Census workers patroled downtown streets. After crowds walked and drove away following the 2 a.m. closing time for bars, the streets were deserted except for just a few pedestrians and cars. Census counters Jill Baldwin and Dennis LaBore stood on a corner checking passing pedestrians. ``We haven't run into any problems. It's been real quiet,'' Baldwin said. ``There's not many people out.''

Because it was a chilly night in Miami _ about 55 degrees _ many of the homeless gathered in doorways. Some downtown built small fires. In one stretch of abandoned buildings, more than 50 homeless people slept on the sidewalk. A car filled with ``enumerators,'' as the Census counters are called, rode slowly past. In the innercity Overtown section, the site of three riots during the 1980s, a three-person Census team encountered little hostility among the homeless. ``Some of them knew all about the census. One lady we counted said she worked as a census taker 10 years ago,'' said Gregory Williams. Williams also counted a homeless man who keeps his possessions hidden in a tree. Like many enumerators in Miami, all members of the Overtown team removed their jewelry and did not carry valuable items. ``Sure we were a little scared, but just don't let them see the fear in your eyes,'' said Olivia Hawkins.

In Lawton, Okla., John Wolfenbarger let Census workers run extension cords into his Shady Sam's Pawn Shop to run microwave ovens that supplied the homeless with fresh hot dogs all night. Wolfenbarger donated the hot dogs. ``I've always had a place to lay down, but I have feelings for those people,'' Wolfenbarger said. ``They're no different from anybody else.''

Every night for the past 18 years, the world ignored Richard Bryant. Tuesday night, everyone wanted to know his name, age, race, sex and marital status. While 15,000 U.S. Census counters fanned out across the United States to count the homeless, Bryant sat in a shelter in Charleston, W.Va., smoking cigarettes and watching television with a 39-year-old Arkansas drifter, a jobless North Carolina man and a dozen other homeless men. ``I've learned to live with the fact that I'm one of the chosen outcasts,'' he said in a coarse, morning-after rumble. Bryant, who has been homeless since 1972, said he is a Korean War veteran and a master carpenter. He smokes marijuana and drinks, but ascribes his plight to a society that won't accept non-conformity. Like others in the shelter, he was approached earlier in the evening by the census takers. He laughs when asked about it. ``I truly believe the government is like everyone else. They have good intentions but no direction. It's like everything the government does. It gets so involved and so complicated that very little good comes out of it.'' He is asked about his future. ``Is it going to be better? I don't know. If I make it to tomorrow, great. If I don't make it, even better, I'm delivered from this.''

Shortly after dawn, three Census workers in San Diego County, Calif., walked into a canyon where about 100 migrant workers live in shacks made of plywood, sheet metal and heavy plastic. The Census workers were there to interview the men before most of them left in search of daily jobs. But some of the migrants said the census takers passed them by. ``They just walked right past us. They didn't ask us anything,'' said a migrant worker who declined to give his name. ``There were two of them, and they met another one on top of the hill and walked over it. We haven't seen them since.'' Michael J. Weiler, assistant regional Census manager, said in a telephone interview that he would look into the migrant census takers' actions. ``There could have been several things that came up. They're not supposed to wake people up,'' he said. When asked why census takers would walk past people, he said, ``I'll just have to look into that.''

At 2:30 a.m., two men trudged along the railroad tracks running along the Vermont shore of Lake Champlain. They tried to keep warm in the face of whipping winds and driving snow. One of them had neither boots nor gloves. With a wind of 14 mph, the wind chill was about 9 degrees. ``This is not a night for anybody to be outside,'' said Bill Timbers, one of the two. An observer might have mistaken them for homeless, but Timbers and Paul Dufresne were, in fact, census takers on a futile search for the homeless. The pair walked through streets, peered into trash dumps, rummaged through boxes and plastic crates, shined their flashlights into doorways and alleys _ and came up empty. The homeless, apparently, were staying out of the cold. The counters said they didn't mind. ``The one thing I am glad about is that we didn't count anybody out here tonight,'' Dufresne said.

DOC.HEAD: Bright & Brief
DOC.TEXT: John E. Body's name is mud at The Citizens Bank in Weston. The farmer's account of $1,335.29 was closed after he left a trail of mud on a newly fitted carpet _ twice in one week. ``On both occasions, Mr. Body tracked in mud or some other substance onto the bank's carpet with his deep, cleated boots,'' Lewis C. Pellegrin, the bank's chief executive officer, said in a March 6 letter to the farmer. ``This appears to have been done either maliciously or in a totally thoughtless manner,'' Pellegrin wrote. ``Several man-hours were required to clean the carpet because of Mr. Body's thoughtless actions.'' The bank cannot afford to clean its carpet every time Body drops by, Pellegrin complained. So if Body returns and tracks the carpet again, the bank will prosecute him for willful destruction of property, he wrote. Body, in a letter to the Weston Democrat newspaper, argued that he hadn't been warned and would have used the bank's outdoor facilities. In raising chickens, ducks and goats, ``invariably ... I am working in the mud since we have had such a wet year past,'' he wrote. Other banks in the town that ``care more about people than the carpet on the floor'' had offered their services, he wrote. ``So thank you `Pell.' I feel great doing my banking elsewhere, where the little guy with the dirty shoes is appreciated.''

Pupils at Birch Elementary School, rebelling against the health-food dogma of their elders, are lobbying for the return of chocolate milk to the cafeteria. ``I tried to tell them they had to find some brown cows, but they wouldn't believe me,'' said Bill Ragland, a teacher and student council adviser. But chocolate milk, barred by a nutrition task force at Boulder Valley schools five years ago, is no joking matter for the students. Some already bring their own chocolate milk to school or stir cocoa powder in the school's white-milk cartons. Pupils want chocolate milk offered once a week, but Barb Berry, ``the lunch lady'' at Birch, says she cannot violate the ban by the Boulder-based school board. Jesse Berger, 11, raised the issue with the student council last fall, and two-thirds of the 450 pupils have added their signatures in support. The Boulder Valley school board was to discuss the request Wednesday, but a decision wasn't expected until next month at the earliest.

One story recounts a millionaires' reunion, another tells of a man who burned his overalls when he was told he had won $14 million. But this is not your everday supermarket tabloid. It's Jackpot _ a 2-million-circulation quarterly put out by the Illinois State Lottery. The eight-page tabloid tells everything you care to know about the state's gambling games, using slick color graphs, cartoons, feature-length stories, briefs and photographs galore of lottery players, winners and employees. It is distributed free to grocery stores, gas stations and other lottery agents where tickets are sold. Jackpot is intended ``to give the lottery a vehicle to address the public on the games,'' Editor Mary Johnston-Clark said Tuesday. ``And on how to play the games. And to let them know that people win the games all the time.'' ``At the beginning, a $5 million jackpot was big,'' she said, but ``now, unless it's $20 million, or $30 million or $40 million, they (the media) don't bat an eye.'' The fall 1989 issue carried a story about last year's seventh annual Illinois State Lottery Millionaires' Reunion. ``I enjoy the reunions because I get to meet other people and find out what they do with their money,'' one guest, Irene Straka, was quoted as saying. The latest issue highlighted some of the year's most quotable winners. ``I burned my overalls,'' said commercial painter Sam LaPorta when asked his reaction to winning $14.4 million. ``I started screaming and kicking the bathroom door, shouting, `We're millionaires.' Then I called my boss up and said `Moose, find somebody else.'''

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev's Text on Lithuania Decree
DOC.TEXT: Here is the text of Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's decree banning firearms sales in Lithuania and ordering residents to turn in their guns. The text, transmitted in Russian by the official news agency Tass, was translated by The Associated Press.

The U.S.S.R. president's decree on Extra Measures to Protect the Rights of Soviet Citizens and the Sovereignty of the U.S.S.R. on the territory of the Lithuanian S.S.R. Contrary to the resolution adopted by Congress of People's Deputies of March 15, the Lithuanian Parliament and government continue passing bills violating the rights of the Soviet citizens and the sovereignity of the Soviet Union. In connection with this I decree: 1) The U.S.S.R. Council of Ministers, the executive bodies and local councils of Lithuanian S.S.R., the law-enforcement organs are to ensure the observance of the federal Constitution and laws, and protect the rights and legitimate interests of the Soviet citizens living or staying in Lithuanian S.S.R. 2) KGB border forces are to take essential measures to tighten up security on the Soviet border in Lithuanian S.S.R., to halt all unlawful actions violating Soviet border legislation. 3) The federal government's resolution No. 646 of July 23, 1975, on the acquisition, accounting and keeping of hunting rifles is to be temporarily suspended, and the sale of hunting weapons is to be banned for the same period in the republic. Citizens living in Lithuanian S.S.R. are within the next seven days to hand in all their weapons to the law-enforcement bodies for temporary keeping. The U.S.S.R. Interior Ministry is to seize such weapons in cases of refusal to turn them in. The Defense Ministry is to receive from law-enforcement organs the weapons seized from citizens and ensure their safekeeping. 4) The Foreign Ministry and the Interior Ministry are to tighten control over issuance of entrance visas to foreigners and over the permission for foreigners to visit the Lithuanian S.S.R. The Interior Ministry and the U.S.S.R. Procurator's Office are to take all essential measures to suppress violations by foreigners staying in Lithuanian S.S.R. of the regulations concerning the stay of foreign nationals all the way to their deportation in keeping with the U.S.S.R. law on the legal status of foreign nationals in the U.S.S.R. 5) The decree becomes effective immediately after signing.

DOC.HEAD: Rep. Savage Survives Tough Opposition in Illinois Primary
DOC.TEXT: Rep. Gus Savage survived a sexual harassment scandal and a strong challenge to win the Democrat primary, but his opponent said the five-term congressman's strength may be ebbing. With 95 percent of precincts reporting in the mostly black district, Savage had 39,602 votes or 51 percent and Mel Reynolds, who like Savage is black, had 33,472 votes or 43 percent. A follower of extremist Lyndon LaRouche had 5 percent. ``Here's a 10-year incumbent barely getting over 50 percent of the vote against someone who's never held elective office,'' said Reynolds, 38, a former Rhodes scholar whom detractors labeled an outsider backed mostly by whites. ``There's no doubt about it,'' Savage's political strength is weakening, said Reynolds, who received just 14 percent of the vote when he ran against Savage in 1988. Other victors in Tuesday's election included Secretary of State Jim Edgar, whose campaign for the GOP gubernatorial nomination over an abortion foe drew support from the White House. He faces Attorney General Neil Hartigan, who was unopposed in the Democratic primary. Four-term Republican Gov. James R. Thompson is retiring. Attorney Richard Phelan, who led the U.S. House ethics committee probe that forced out Speaker Jim Wright last year, won his first try at political office in a tough four-way Democratic race for Cook County Board president. And age was the dominant issue as 80-year-old U.S. Rep. Sidney Yates won renomination to a 21st term by defeating a 32-year-old Chicago alderman in the Democratic primary. In special elections in New York City, Democratic Assemblyman Jose Serrano easily defeated his opponent to become the first Puerto Rican native serving as a full voting member of Congress, and Republican Susan Molinari won handily to claim the congressional seat her father gave up to become Staten Island borough president. In Chicago, Nathaniel Clay, editor of Metro Press, a black-oriented weekly newspaper, said Savage has been hurt by a finding by the House ethics committee that the congressman had made improper sexual advances to a Peace Corps worker during a trip last year to Zaire. But Clay noted that Savage, 64, has never gotten much over 50 percent of the vote, ``but that's what's amazing, he keeps getting elected, just barely.'' Clay said Savage's support comes mostly from poor blacks in the district, which covers the city's South Side and some suburbs. ``He plays on their emotions. Many of those people feel locked out, left behind,'' and Savage wins them over with campaigns based on bigotry, hate and attacks on what he calls ``white racists,'' Clay said. In his victory speech Tuesday night, Savage said his win is indicative of the power of the people. ``Our opponent was those whites who control all of the people's television airwaves'' and major newspapers, Savage said. Political analyst Don Rose, a frequent ally of Savage, says it will take someone who can match Savage's credentials as a longtime black activist to beat him. ``He was one of two or three major players who created the black independent political movement in Chicago,'' Rose said. Savage is considered a shoo-in in November over GOP candidate William Hespel, a state worker who defeated two candidates. In New York, Serrano, 46, will fill the vacancy left by Robert Garcia, a Democrat who quit his South Bronx seat after his conviction in the Wedtech influence-peddling scandal. Serrano pulled in 93 percent of the vote. Molinari, 31, a City Council member, will become the youngest member of Congress when sworn in. She won with 59 percent of the vote. Her father is Guy Molinari, who had held the seat since 1980 and was co-chairman of President Bush's campaign in New York in 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Rejects Tougher Smog Control Requirement
DOC.TEXT: The Senate today narrowly defeated an attempt to toughen controls on urban smog as part of a compromise clean air bill. It was the third major defeat for environmentalists seeking to strengthen the nation's main air pollution law. The vote was 53 to 46. Opponents of the smog-control measure, including Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, argued the overall bill under consideration already is a big improvement over current federal law and that stronger provisions could block passage this year. Sen. John Kerry, D-Mass., a key sponsor of the proposal, argued the amendment was needed to assure clean air in many of the cities that today suffer from the worst smog problems. The amendment would have preserved the federal government's authority to impose an air pollution reduction plan if states and local officials fail to act. It also would eliminate exemptions for some industrial polluters and broaden the smog-controlling curbs to include smaller polluters. The vote was the third major setback for environmentalists in the clean air debate. By a 52-46 vote Tuesday night, the Senate defeated a proposal to require tougher tailpipe-emission controls on automobiles, greater use of clean fuels by fleet operators and production of 1 million cars capable of burning alternative fuels. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, called the defeated amendment a ``prescription for deadlock'' on the clean air bill. ``Do we want 13 more years of speeches or do we want a bill? Do we want to make statements or do we want to make law?'' Mitchell said. Still unresolved was a proposal to give federal aid to coal miners who would lose their jobs as a result of the clean air measure _ a plan described by Senate leaders as a ``deal breaker.'' Sen. Robert C. Byrd, D-W.Va., is seeking $700 million in aid for the miners over four years if they lose their jobs because of tougher acid rain controls at coal-burning powerplants in the Midwest. The White House contends the assistance is too expensive. Sen. Timothy Wirth, D-Colo., said Tuesday that Byrd ``appears to have a majority of the votes'' for his proposal. However, an aide to Mitchell said it was uncertain whether the amendment would pass if it came to a vote. White House officials and Senate leaders were trying to work out a compromise with Byrd. Byrd for more than a decade has fought additional controls on sulfur dioxide from utility plants because such curbs would threaten the jobs of thousands of coal miners, including many in West Virginia where high-sulfur coal predominates. The clean air bill would set tough new pollution controls on industry and automobiles to reduce urban smog, cut toxic chemical emissions from industry and require electric utilities to reduce sulfur dioxide emissions by 10 million tons by the end of the decade. The auto pollution control amendment was sponsored by Wirth and Sen. Pete Wilson, R-Calif. Wirth argued his amendment was needed because autos ``are the biggest source of pollution in our cities.'' But senators backing the compromise bill insisted that passage of the tougher controls would threaten the legislation. ``It will bust the deal'' with the White House, said Sen. Max Baucus, D-Mont. The vote on the Wirth amendment revealed some of the maneuvering on the bill. Sen. Steven Symms, R-Idaho, was among some senators who voted for the tougher controls after arguing vigorously against the legislation for weeks. Senate sources suggested that Symms and other senators hoped to cripple the compromise bill by adding an amendment the White House would not accept. Environmentalists, meanwhile, said that while a number of votes are expected on other amendments intended to strengthen the clean air bill, the tougher auto pollution curbs were a top priority. Daniel Weiss of the Sierra Club accused the administration of ``ramming down the throats of the Senate'' a bill that does not go far enough to control urban smog. The vote was ``a good deal for General Motors and a terrible deal for the general public,'' said Gene Karpinski of the U.S. Public Interest Research Group. The automakers strongly opposed the tougher pollution controls, saying they would be required to manufacture alternative-fuel cars that customers might not want to buy. The measure also would require automakers to meet new tailpipe standards by the year 2003, although they say the technology to accomplish that does not exist.

DOC.HEAD: Lawyer: Top Co-Defendant Has Agreed to Plead Guilty
DOC.TEXT: A co-defendant prosecutors say could tie Manuel Noriega directly to drug payoffs has agreed in principle to plead guilty to a drug conspiracy count, his attorney said Wednesday. Luis del Cid, 46, was a lieutenant colonel in the Panamanian military and a top aide to Noriega when the two were captured during the U.S. invasion in December. Del Cid ``acted as a liason and money courier between drug traffickers and Manuel Antonio Noriega,'' the U.S. attorney's office has said. His defense attorney, Samuel Burstyn, said he negotiated with the government almost from the time of del Cid's capture, but only recently settled on a plea bargain. Final details of the deal should go before a federal judge soon, Burstyn said. ``There is an agreement in principle,'' Burstyn said. ``It's in the process of being reduced to writing.'' A spokeswoman for the U.S. attorney's office, Diane Cossin, said she could not confirm the deal. ``We do not deal in speculation, and have not announced the plea agreement,'' she said. ``We don't discuss business until it is completed.'' Burstyn refused to say if del Cid will take the stand against Noriega, but such understandings are normal in most plea agreements. And previously, Burstyn has said that a guilty plea would permit the prosecution to subpoena his client, and would prevent del Cid from using the Fifth Amendment to avoid testifying. Noriega's attorney Steven Kollin did not immediately return phone calls from The Associated Press. When the possibility of a del Cid deal was first reported last month, Kollin said his client would be unhurt ``as long as del Cid tells the truth.'' Burstyn said one of the key sticking points in the negotiations was del Cid's probable prison term. Under the indictment, del Cid faced a possible 70 years in prison, and after his capture, he rejected an initial prosecution offer of 40 years in return for a guilty plea. Under the agreement finally reached, he would face a maximum 10 years in prison on the single conspiracy count, but is unlikely to serve that long, Burstyn said. ``There's no time limit in the agreement, but I believe he'll serve no more than 2{ years,'' the attorney said. Del Cid is accused in a February 1988 indictment of accepting $200,000 in cocaine-trafficking profits from drug pilot Floyd Carlton Caceres, now the prosecution's chief witness. Carlton and Noriega had agreed to the price during a December 1983 meeting, the indictment alleges. Later that month, Carlton delivered the money intended for Noriega to del Cid at the headquarters of the Panamanian Defense Forces in Panama City. The pilot continued to deal with Noriega, and prosecutors have said that shows the money was indeed passed on to the Panamanian leader. The defense previously has disputed some prosecution claims that del Cid was a key aide to Noriega, forcing the U.S. attorney's office to acknowledge he was not head of Panamanian intelligence, as they first claimed. But prosecutors in turn showed a picture of del Cid and Noriega at a meeting with Cuban leader Fidel Castro _ a meeting the indictment says was intended to mediate a dispute between the Panamanian leader and the Medellin drug cartel that paid him $4.6 million and bribes. If the plea bargain is approved, del Cid will be the second of the six defendants in custody to plead guilty. Drug pilot Eduardo Pardo has already pleaded guilty to flying $800,000 in cocaine profits from Fort Lauderdale to Panama in May 1983 and is awaiting sentencing. Also in custody is accused Colombian cocaine trafficker William Saldarriaga. Free on bond are another pilot, Daniel Miranda, and an accused minor trafficker, Brian Alden Davidow. All three have pleaded innocent.

DOC.HEAD: Marcos Supporters Demand `Justice for Imelda'
DOC.TEXT: About 1,500 people carrying signs demanding ``Justice for Imelda'' spat on and burned an American flag outside the U.S. Embassy on Wednesday, protesting the trial of Ferdinand Marcos's widow. ``We are here in support of our first lady,'' Luz Domingo told the crowd. ``We are here to protest American intervention and the injustice done to her.'' Another speaker, attorney Romeo Cayetano, said the trial of Mrs. Marcos on foreign soil was an affront to Philippine sovereignty and showed the Manila government ``has no honor.'' Jury selection began Tuesday in the racketeering trial of the 60-year-old Mrs. Marcos in U.S. District Court in Manhattan. Nearby the demonstration, about 50 members of the left-wing League of Filipino Students protesting U.S. military bases threw homemade bombs at police when they were prevented from getting close to the embassy compound. One of the bombs hit the roof of the entrance to the embassy but caused no injuries. No injuries were reported to police or students. The students, who had marched from a nearby park, tossed additional bombs at police who tried to chase them. Two members of the group were arrested. The melee briefly disrupted the demonstration of the Marcos supporters, who also tried to flee the scene thinking the police were dispersing them. They later returned to continue the rally. Mrs. Marcos is accused of taking part in the illegal transfer of more than $160 million from the Philippine treasury to buy Manhattan real estate. The indictment also alleges she defrauded banking institutions of $165 million to pay for the properties. She could be imprisoned for 50 years and fined $1 million if convicted of all charges. Manila newspapers printed a letter from Mrs. Marcos to President Bush on Wednesday in which she offered to hand over her wealth to a five-member international board, which would distribute the money to the Filipino people. In the letter, released by the Philippine government, Mrs. Marcos claimed she was innocent and that the trial was an attempt to ``extort money and property from me.'' White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Bush received a letter from Mrs. Marcos but he gave no details of its contents, saying the president could not respond for legal reasons. Mrs. Marcos is being tried with Saudi financier Adnan Khashoggi, who is accused of helping the Marcoses hide their ownership of the real estate. Marcos, the ousted Philippines president who was the central figure in the October 1988 indictment, died Sept. 28 in exile in Hawaii. He fled there after being toppled in the civilian-military uprising that propelled Corazon Aquino to power four years ago.

DOC.HEAD: Deficit Near Gramm-Rudman Target 7 Months Early
DOC.TEXT: The federal budget deficit totaled $97.52 billion for the first five months of fiscal year 1990, just $2.48 billion less than the Gramm-Rudman deficit target for the entire year, the government said Wednesday. The Treasury Department said the deficit last month was $36.42 billion, 30.1 percent above the $27.87 billion imbalance in February 1989. Receipts totaled $65.17 billion in February, up 5.3 percent from the same month last year. But expenditures amounted to $101.58 billion, a 13.2 percent increase over February 1989. ``The revenues weren't so bad, but the expenditures were way up,'' said economist Michael K. Evans, head of a Washington forecasting firm. ``Essentially, expenditures have not been under control all year long.'' ``It was the significant acceleration in federal spending in February that allowed the deficit to widen here,'' agreed William V. Sullivan Jr., director of money market research at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in New York. The February deficit followed a $9.42 billion surplus in January, the first for the fiscal year that started Oct. 1. Evans and Sullivan noted that the Gramm-Rudman target for fiscal 1990 has all but been abandoned, with Evans suggesting the actual imbalance for the year will total $160 billion to $165 billion. ``Unless there's a miracle, we'll come in ahead of last year, which was $152 billion,'' Evans said. ``That means we have got to look for an improvement of almost $90 billion in the budget in fiscal year 1991 to meet the Gramm-Rudman target of $64 billion,'' Sullivan added. ``That's a virtual impossibility.'' The 1990 deficit through February was 5.3 percent above that for the first five months of fiscal 1989. Receipts were up 5.6 percent to $393.48 billion for the period, while outlays were up 5.5 percent to $490.99 billion. As usual, the biggest spending categories in February were for the military, Social Security and other programs in the Department of Health and Human Services and interest on the national debt. Military spending totaled $24.26 billion in February and $116.78 billion so far this year. It is projected to total $286.79 billion for the entire fiscal year. Social Security payments amounted to $20.51 billion for the month and $99.04 billion for the year so far. They are expected to total $244.59 billion for the year. Other HHS programs, including Medicare and Medicaid, totaled $15.54 billion for February and $75.25 billion so far. They are projected to cost $191.17 billion for the year. Interest on the national debt totaled $17.32 billion during February and $111.73 billion so far this year. It is expected to total 254.85 billion for the year.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecution vs. Defense in Hazelwood Trial
With AM-Hazelwood Trial
DOC.TEXT: After six weeks of testimony, the case of former Exxon Valdez captain Joseph Hazelwood has gone to the jury. The Exxon Valdez rammed Bligh Reef in Alaska's Prince William Sound on March 24, 1989, spilling almost 11 million gallons of Alaska crude oil and devastating fisheries and wildlife. Hazelwood is charged with criminal mischief, reckless endangerment, operating a vessel while intoxicated, and negligent discharge of oil in the grounding. If convicted, he could receive 7\ years in prison and $61,000 in fines. The prosecution contends Hazelwood was drunk and reckless while in charge of the Exxon Valdez and risked his ship and crew before and after the grounding. The defense counters that his judgment was not impaired, he showed no signs of inebriation and he gave prudent commands to protect the safety of ship and crew. Here are some key points raised by the two sides in Hazelwood's trial:
DOC.HEAD: WAS HAZELWOOD RECKLESS?
DOC.TEXT:
PROSECUTION: Hazelwood was reckless in leaving the bridge in control of the third mate during a hazardous transit. DEFENSE: It is part of the captain's job to delegate responsibility. Another captain testified that he does not consider Prince William Sound hazardous, he had left the bridge of his vessel in the same area and there is no regulation requiring the captain to be on the bridge during the transit.
PROSECUTION: The third mate left in charge of the bridge had no license to pilot the ship within Prince William Sound. Hazelwood was the only one aboard who had such a license. DEFENSE: Another captain testified he didn't have a pilot's license for Prince William Sound and believed there was no requirement for a pilot to be aboard a ship transiting that area. He cited a letter from the Alaska Maritime Agency, advising captains in 1986 of a change in pilotage requirements.
PROSECUTION: Chief mate James Kunkel testified he warned Hazelwood that helmsman Robert Kagan ``needed practice in steering'' and required ``special supervision'' in even the simplest tasks. DEFENSE: Kunkel also said Kagan was capable of executing a ``simple'' 10-degree right rudder turn, the missed turn that would have steered the tanker away from the reef. Another witness said the order was so simple it could have been executed by a 5-year-old.
PROSECUTION: Hazelwood told the third mate, Gregory Cousins, to divert the tanker from normal shipping lanes to avoid ice, but never gave specific steering directions. As a result Cousins wound up racing between the chart room and the radar screen trying to work out the proper maneuver and had no time to keep an eye on Kagan. DEFENSE: Hazelwood left clear instruction for the ice-avoidance maneuver and if the instructions had been followed, the Valdez would have cleared Bligh Reef. When Hazelwood asked Cousins if he felt ``comfortable'' with what he had to do, Cousins replied in the affirmative.
PROSECUTION: Hazelwood risked the lives of crew members by not ringing a general alarm and letting them sleep through the disaster. DEFENSE: Kunkel said they discussed abandoning ship but feared there would be panic and that putting the crew in oil-polluted water in the middle of the night was riskier. He said Hazelwood gave orders to wake the crew by going from cabin to cabin.
PROSECUTION: Hazelwood risked the crew and ship when he recklessly tried to extricate the grounded tanker off Bligh Reef by frantically revving the engines and maneuvering the rudder without having sufficient information to determine the vessel's stability. Hazelwood told the Coast Guard he was trying to get off the reef. DEFENSE: Hazelwood's maneuvers after the grounding were professional attempts to stabilize the ship. He was not trying to move or extricate it. The point became all but moot when the judge ruled the ship was incapable of moving anywhere and could not have sunk as prosecution witnesses claimed.
DOC.HEAD: WAS HAZELWOOD DRUNK?
DOC.TEXT:
PROSECUTION: Hazelwood had five drinks and spent perhaps seven hours in a bar drinking before sailing. DEFENSE: Hazelwood had two or three drinks and spent only three hours in the bar.
PROSECUTION: Three witnesses, two of them Coast Coast investigators, said they smelled alcohol on Hazelwood's breath. Crew members saw Hazelwood drinking in Valdez that day before they sailed. DEFENSE: Crew members testified that Hazelwood negotiated a precarious gangplank to the ship without a misstep and appeared sober as he gave orders. Defense suggested Hazelwood drank a low-alcohol brew while on the ship, accounting for the alcohol smell.
PROSECUTION: An expert using a method called ``retrograde extrapolation'' concluded that Hazelwood's level of intoxication at the time of the shipwreck was .14 percent, based on blood and urine tests taken 10{ hours afterward. At the time of the test Hazelwood had a blood alcohol level of .061 percent. The legal limit for driving a car in Alaska is .10 percent. DEFENSE: The retroactive test is only useful for periods of 2-3 hours after an incident, and if Hazelwood drank anything after the accident, the results of such an extrapolation would be invalid. Their experts called the calculations ``nonsense.''
PROSECUTION: One could hear that Hazelwood was drunk by the rate and pitch of his voice on a tape made by the Coast Guard when the ship went aground. DEFENSE: A tape-recording expert said the tape was a poor copy that did not accurately reflect Hazelwood's voice. The witness also said that while slurred speech might be an indication of drunkenness, changes in the rate of speech or pitch were not.

DOC.HEAD: London's Favorite Clock to be Silenced for Repairs
DOC.TEXT: Big Ben, which didn't miss its hourly bell once during World War II bombings, will be silenced temporarily for repairs. Although the clock will continue to run uninterrupted, the hourly bell will be stopped for 12 weeks, and the quarter-hourly ``Westminster'' chimes for two days, Government Minister Christopher Chope said Wednesday. A mechanism needs replacing because of age, said Chope, the minister responsible for the Property Services Agency that looks after the clock. The faulty mechanism, the hammer arm that strikes the hour, will have to be removed so a replica can be made, the agency said. Chope said work will begin March 26. Big Ben has been keeping time since 1859. It is stopped twice a year when Britain goes on and off daylight savings time. In October, it stopped for three hours due to a mechanical fault. In 1976 a piece of metal broke off the clockworks, forcing the hourly bell to be silenced for 22 days and the chimes for several months. The keepers of the clock said get-well cards addressed to Big Ben arrived from all over the world. The name Big Ben actually applies only to the 13{-ton bell, but it has become the nickname for the entire clock. The BBC normally carries live chimes from Big Ben before its 10 p.m. and midnight newscasts on domestic radio. It said it will use a different time signal during the repair period.

DOC.HEAD: Millionaire Banker Lord Rothschild Dead at 79
DOC.TEXT: Lord Rothschild, the millionaire banker and decorated World War II intelligence agent, has died in London, his wife said in a statement Wednesday. He was 79. Lady Rothschild said her husband died Tuesday. She did not reveal the cause of death or give any other details. Rothschild's secretary refused to say whether he had been ill or where he died. Lord Rothschild was born Nathaniel Mayer Victor Rothschild on Oct. 31, 1910, into the famous family of German-Jewish coin collectors who founded a banking dynasty. Lord Rothschild was the head of the English wing of the family. Baron Guy de Rothschild is head of the French branch. After studying sciences, English and French at Cambridge, he went on to become a professor in the Zoology Department and was recognized as one of the world's leading experts on spermatozoa. He succeeded his uncle as the 3rd Baron Rothschild in 1937, taking his seat in the House of Lords, the unelected upper chamber of Parliament, as a member of the Labor Party. In the early 1970s, he served as an adviser to Conservative Prime Minister Edward Heath. During World War II, Rothschild served as a senior officer with MI5, the British counter-espionage service. Britain awarded Rothschild the George Medal for bravery in World War II for defusing German bombs. He also received the American Legion of Merit for his wartime efforts. In 1986, Rothschild sent a letter to The Daily Telegraph urging MI5 to state publicly that it had ``unequivocal evidence'' disproving rumors that he was the ``fifth man'' in the infamous Soviet spy ring formed by Guy Burgess, Kim Philby, Donald Maclean and Anthony Blunt. Rothschild in his student days at Cambridge University was a member of the elite debating society known as The Apostles, as were Burgess and Blunt. Rothschild and Blunt, who became art adviser to Queen Elizabeth II, remained friends in adult life. In his letter, Rothschild said there had been innuendos since 1981 that he was the ``fifth man.'' British press reports said the unequivocal evidence Rothschild referred to was a secret 1962 meeting in London when he finally nailed Philby as a Soviet agent. Philby, a former British intelligence officer, was then a Beirut-based journalist. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said the government had no evidence that Rothschild was ever a Soviet agent. The Rothschild family has a reputation for generosity, especially toward Israel. An orthodox Jew, Lord Rothschild was awarded an honorary degree from Tel Aviv University in 1971 for ``the advancement of science, education and the economy of Israel.'' It was followed in 1975 by an honorary degree from Jerusalem's Hebrew University. He was also an accomplished cricket player, golfer, jazz pianist, writer and businessman. Lady Rothschild's statement said a private funeral will be held, but did not say when or where. She said there would be a memorial service later. Besides his wife, the former Tessa Mayor, Lord Rothschild is survived by their son James and their two daughters Emma and Victoria. He is also survived by a son, Jacob, and two daughters, Sarah and Miranda, from his first marriage which ended in 1945. Jacob, a trustee of the National Gallery, is the heir to the peerage, becoming the 4th Baron Rothschild.

DOC.HEAD: What The Jury Did Not Hear
With AM-Hazelwood Trial
DOC.TEXT: Some information was withheld from the jury deciding the fate of Joseph Hazelwood, who is charged with operating a vessel while intoxicated and other offenses in connection with last year's catastrophic Alaska oil spill. The jurors were not told, for example, that Hazelwood has a history of drunken driving convictions and participated in an alcohol rehabilitation program. This was held to be inadmissible evidence. In addition, because Hazelwood is being tried under state law, the jury did not hear that his blood alcohol level of .061, taken 10{ hours after the accident, exceeded the .04 percent limit set by the Coast Guard for operation of a commercial vessel.

DOC.HEAD: Many Newly Elected Lawmakers Apparently Helped Secret Police
DOC.TEXT: Many of the newly elected East German lawmakers may have collaborated with the former secret police, and all deputies should be closely investigated before taking their seats in Parliament, officials said Wednesday. Bishop Gottfried Forck urged all East German parties to conduct such investigations by next week, before parliament's first session. Werner Fischer, charged by the outgoing government with supervising the secret police's dismantling, said there were growing indications many secret police informers were among the newly elected lawmakers. East Germany held its first free election for the new 400-member parliament on Sunday. ``The indications have reached such a dimension that they cannot be ignored,'' Fischer told The Associated Press. Forck said he met West German President Richard von Weizsaecker in West Berlin on Wednesday to discuss the revelations. Both Forck and Weizsaecker's office said the talks were confidential and refused to discuss details. Fischer said indications that agents of the secret of the police, known as Stasi, might have infiltrated East German political parties were evident before Sunday's vote. But he said his office decided not to make them public to avoid disrupting the balloting. After the peaceful popular revolt that toppled the hard-line Communist leadership in October, the interim government began dismantling the hated secret police. Stasi had 85,000 agents and tens of thousands of informers. The secret police force was a major part of the Communist apparatus that controlled all walks of life for 40 years, and many people were intimidated into becoming its helpers. Rainer Eppelmann, chairman of one of the three parties in the alliance that won Sunday, said as many as 40 of the newly elected lawmakers might have been secret police agents. In an interview with West Germany's mass-circulation newspaper Bild, Eppelmann alleged that four elected deputies from Erfurt had been secret police agents. Eppelmann became leader of Democratic Awakening party last week, after the group's former chairman, Wolfgang Schnur, admitted he had been a long-time secret police informer. Eppelmann said he was convinced that former Stasi collaborators are sitting in other political parties as well. Forck said church officials, prosecutors and representatives of political parties should be present when the secret police files are opened. Forck said it would be up to the parties to decide if deputies found to have been secret police informers should give up their seats. He said the results of the probe should be kept confidential. Fischer said there were ``clear indications'' that some former secret police agents were now being employed by West German intelligence, but Forck said these were only rumors. Lutz Stavenhagen, the Bonn government intelligence services coordinator, denied that West German intelligence was taking over former Stasi agents. ``It is a clear policy of West German intelligence not to employ former Stasi agents,'' he said. Ralf Bachmann, deputy spokesman for the outgoing government in East Berlin, said the decision whether to make secret police files public should be left to the new parliament. Helmut Lueck, spokesman for the Christian Democrats, the conservative winner of Sunday's election, called for a church commission to probe the new deputies for any links to the former secret police.

DOC.HEAD: Homeless Census Fails to Still Old Debate
With AM-Neighborly Census, Bjt
LaserPhoto MP4
DOC.TEXT: After sending 15,000 workers into camps and caves, streets and shelters, the Census Bureau declared success Wednesday in its first-ever tally of the nation's homeless. But critics found fresh ammunition to charge that the special census failed to do its job. Census workers, many of them homeless themselves, endured gunfire, robbery, insults and foul weather to count the number of Americans with no fixed address. Past guesses have ranged from 250,000 to 3 million. The results won't be announced until late 1991, and the debate over the census will continue until then and beyond. It was framed again Wednesday by two men on opposite sides of the country. ``It's just the people in their ivory tower drinking their mint juleps and counting noses,'' said George Whitney, a resident of Baloney Joe's shelter in Portland, Ore. ``Nobody can help the homeless because nobody understands the problem. In New York, Dwayne Mays stood up for the census, in which he participated both as a counter and as one of the counted. He, too, is homeless. ``Hopefully, it will let people realize there is a whole population of homeless people that is not dehumanized, still maintains self-respect and self-esteem, that is living in conditions that are abhorrent,'' Mays said. ``We're here, and we are counted now.'' Not all the homeless were counted, though, even by the Census Bureau's assessment. In some cases, homeless people avoided the census takers; in others, they were apparently overlooked. In Manchester, N.H., census takers failed to count a man who was sleeping on the steps of City Hall _ he was outside their survey area. In San Diego County, Calif., a group of farmworkers in a migrant camp said a team of Census ``enumerators'' walked past them without stopping to count. In New York City, reporters watched Census workers mill around a newsstand on the ground floor of the Port Authority bus terminal, apparently avoiding the upper floors where hundreds of homeless sleep. Census officials insisted they had canvassed the entire station. The Census Bureau spent $2.7 million on the homeless count, which it carried out between 6 p.m. Tuesday and 8 a.m. Wednesday in every city with a population over 50,000. In several cities, Census workers said homeless people had vanished from their usual spots, apparently to avoid the government. ``That tells us something,'' said Don Weese, manager of the Census Bureau office in Tulsa, Okla. ``It tells us there's a large segment of that homeless population that simply does not want to be recognized, known or encountered at all.'' Still, the officials defended their effort and said it would provide a valuable ``snapshot'' of the state of the homeless. The issue is politically important because federal money goes to cities and states on the basis of population. Urban leaders have been fuming for a decade, saying the Census Bureau ignored most of the homeless in the 1980 census. ``Shelter and Street Night appears to have been a success,'' Census Bureau Director Barbara Bryant said. ``I believe our efforts have given us a good start on achieving our goal of a full and fair census of the American people.'' Ms. Bryant conceded that Census workers had missed some shelters and other homeless hangouts, and would have to try again Wednesday night in a handful of cities. They included Washington, New York, Philadelphia and Cleveland. Critics found nothing in the tally to change their view. ``You can't use this census with any degree of legitimacy,'' said Mitch Snyder, an advocate for the homeless in Washington. ``Politicians can use these figures to say anything that they want ... because there's no way that you can legitimately count how many homeless people that are in this city or in this country.'' For the most part, the census was carried out as planned. There were some frightening moments, however. In New York City, a group of Census workers scattered when a gunshot was fired from a building they were approaching in Brooklyn. They weren't injured, and Census officials said it wasn't clear whether they were the targets. In Oklahoma City, police turned back two Census workers who unwittingly stumbled onto a stakeout. ``They were just told the bad guys are loose, and it wasn't pursuant to what those two were doing, and to take a hike,'' said John Prince, a local Census official. In Fort Lauderdale, Fla., two Census workers were robbed at knifepoint by a man in a homeless shelter. Neither was injured. The mishaps underscored the unenviable nature of the task. Ms. Bryant, the Census director, said she hoped the first homeless census also would be the last. ``I hope that the numbers we got last night and the characteristics of the people we found will provide the information that program planners need to solve this problem,'' she said. ``Our goal is not to be out there in the year 2000.''

DOC.HEAD: Court Says Grand Jury Testimony Needn't be Secret Forever
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 4 grafs reaction after 13th graf pvs, He testified
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court said Wednesday that states may not require people who appear before a grand jury to keep their testimony a secret forever. The court ruled unanimously that such a Florida law, similar to those in 15 other states, violated free-speech rights. The invalidated Florida law barred grand jury witnesses from disclosing their testimony even after the investigation ended. The justices were told that Alabama, Arizona, Indiana, Kentucky, Louisiana, Michigan, Mississippi, Missouri, Nevada, North Carolina, North Dakota, South Dakota, Texas, Utah and Washington have similarly restrictive laws. The federal government and most states impose no disclosure restrictions on grand jury witnesses, apparently not even while an investigation is in progress. But the new decision does not affect state laws that bar people from disclosing their grand jury testimony while the secret panel's investigation is active. Grand juries are presented evidence by prosecutors who seek to have charges filed against criminal suspects. It is up to the grand jury to decide whether charges should be filed and its proceedings are conducted in secret to spare the reputations of presumably innocent people. ``The interests advanced by the portion of the Florida statute struck down are not sufficient to overcome (a witness') First Amendment right to make a truthful statement of information'' lawfully obtained, Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist wrote for the court. ``The ban extends not merely to the life of the grand jury but into the indefinite future,'' he said. Jane Kirtley of the Reporters Committee for the Freedom of the Press said the decision will help journalists who want to interview grand jury witnesses. ``The court recognized that this kind of statute is an overwhelming restraint that could not withstand constitutional scrutiny,'' she said. Michael Smith, a former reporter for the Charlotte Herald-News in Charlotte County, Fla., wants to write a news story and possibly a book about a 1986 grand jury investigation into allegations of corruption in the county sheriff's department and the local state attorney's office. He testified before that grand jury, which ended its investigation in 1986 and issued no indictments. Smith, now a National Guard sergeant at Fort Indiantown Gap in Annville, Pa., was called by the county grand jury to testify about stories he had written about the alleged corruption. ``The grand jury itself is kind of an inquisition process,'' he said Wednesday. ``If witnesses aren't allowed to say what they did or heard in there, then you not only have an inquisition but an inquisition operating in the dark.'' George Waas, the assistant attorney general who handled the case, said the decision will clear up any confusion about the validity of such open-ended secrecy laws. ``Our opinion is that it's an issue that needed to be clarified, and now it has been,'' he said. Smith challenged the Florida secrecy law because he feared he could be prosecuted for revealing his grand jury testimony. A federal judge threw out Smith's suit, but the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruled for Smith. Wednesday's decision upheld the appeals court ruling. In a separate decision, the justices ruled unanimously in another Florida case that migrant farm workers injured on the job may sue their employers in federal court even after receiving worker compensation benefits.

DOC.HEAD: Public Citizen Sues Pfizer Subsidiary
DOC.TEXT: An advocacy group said it filed a lawsuit Wednesday against the maker of an allegedly defective heart valve that has been implanted in the chests of more than 80,000 people. Public Citizen asked the court to order Shiley Inc. and its parent company, Pfizer Inc., to notify all those who have had the valve implanted about alleged defects and possible life-threatening consequences if it fails. The suit also asked that the companies pay for psychological counseling and medical consultation to advise these people of the risks and benefits of having the valve removed, the symptoms of valve failure and emergency steps to be taken if those symptoms occur. The group, founded by consumer activist Ralph Nader, filed the lawsuit in Los Angeles County Superior Court. Shiley's principal offices are in California. Pfizer, based in New York, said the suit is ``completely without merit'' and will ``frighten cardiac patients unnecessarily and ultimately do much more harm than good.'' Pfizer said the valves ``have saved the lives of tens of thousands of patients. All but a small fraction of 1 percent of these valves continue to function properly.'' The device is called the Bjork-Shiley Concavo-Convex heart valve, also known as the Shiley valve. It was implanted in more than 80,000 people, including about 40,000 in the United States. The Food and Drug Administration approved the valve in April 1979, but after reports of malfunctions, Shiley removed it from the market in November 1986. The company has reported to the FDA nearly 400 failures of the valve, 248 of which resulted in death. The valve consists of a disc inside a metal ring covered by a Teflon sewing ring that is sutured to the heart to hold the valve in place. The disc, pivoting on two thin metal struts, opens to allow blood to flow through, and then closes. The malfunctions have involved fractures of the struts. When a fracture occurs, the disc escapes from the ring, allowing an uncontrollable blood flow through the heart. The lawsuit alleged that Pfizer and Shiley were aware of problems with the valve but engaged ``in a course of conduct ... designed to prevent the true facts regarding the risks created by the implantation of the defective valves from being known and to shield themselves from legal liability through deliberate concealment of material facts.'' Pfizer said in a statement it notified all physicians who have implanted the valves ``of the very small fracture risk'' and advised them to educate and monitor their patients. ``We believe this is the proper and most effective way to communicate with patients about such a sensitive medical issue,'' the company said. It added that the FDA has endorsed this method of communication. But Public Citizen said that surgeons who implant the valves ``do not orinarily follow their patients for more than a few weeks after surgery.'' The lawsuit also alleged that Pfizer's letters ``failed to contain accurate and complete information'' about the risks posed by the valves.

DOC.HEAD: Precede ROME
Food Convoy Passes Safely Through War Zone
DOC.NOTE: EDS: New thruout to UPDATE with food convoy passing through war zone. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A convoy of trucks unloaded at least 110 tons of food for famine victims Wednesday after safely passing through war-torn northern Ethiopia. The 11 trucks arrived Tuesday night in Kobo in the Wollo province after leaving the provincial capital of Dessie at dawn on a 75-mile journey over mountainous roads through contested territory. The convoy was the first relief effort since early February, when a rebel offensive closed a Red Sea port being used to unload supplies. The State Department on Wednesday welcomed the resumption of food delivery to rebel-held territory but said only a small fraction of starving people are being reached. Sponsors of the convoy hope to feed about one million people in the provinces of Wollo, Tigre and southern Eritrea until next December, when the harvest is due. The United Nations estimates that more than 4 million people in northern Ethiopia are in danger of starvation caused by drought and war. ``We are excited. We think the whole trip was a success,'' said Hamed Bahget, deputy director of Catholic relief services in Ethiopia's capital, Addis Ababa. ``There was no hitch.'' The trip was completed without a formal cease-fire between the government and the Tigre People's Liberation Front, which has controlled much of Wollo province since late last year. Both sides have promised safety for the convoys, operated by a consortium of Ethiopian church groups with money and food donations mostly from the United States and Western Europe. Privately, relief workers say the promise of safe passage could be revoked at any time because of either error or suspicion that the convoys are being used to smuggle war material. The Tigreans have been fighting since 1975 to oust President Mengistu Haile Mariam and establish a government similar to Albania, the last orthodox Communist government in Eastern Europe. The trucks are scheduled to return to Dressie on Thursday, when a second convoy will leave for another town in Wollo or Tigre. The church groups hope to extend their distribution network from Wollo and Tigre into southern Eritrea. Eritrea, the country's northernmost province, is largely controlled by another, larger rebel group, the Secessionist Eritrea People's Liberation Front. The United Nations says more than one million people are threatened with starvation in Eritrea alone. The Ethiopian government and Tigre rebels on Wednesday began a third round of preliminary talks aimed at ending their 15-year-old conflict. The Italian Foreign Ministry, an observer at the meetings, said the talks centered on the composition of the delegations, the agenda for full-fledged negotiations and ways to end the fighting. The government delegation was headed by Deputy Prime Minister Ashagre Ygletu. Meles Zenawi, president of the Tigre People's Liberation Front, led the rebel delegation. Earlier talks were held in Rome on Nov. 4-11 and Dec. 12-19. The current session is aimed at achieving full-scale peace negotiations to be presided over by Italy and Kenya.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Official Rejects More Treatment Aid
DOC.TEXT: A Bush administration official said Wednesday that more federal money should not be pumped in to expand drug and alcohol abuse treatment programs until existing resources are targeted more effectively. Dr. Beny Primm, who heads the Office of Treatment Improvement in the Department of Health and Human Services, said his office is trying to determine how much treatment is now available and how many people want it before figuring whether more money is needed. ``Many of the (treatment) slots go unoccupied,'' he said, while people in other areas can wait for months to enter programs. Primm appeared at a news conference with officials of the National Association of State Alcohol and Drug Abuse Directors, which released a report calling for the federal government to nearly triple the $1.3 billion it now sends to the states for treatment programs. Primm said he agrees with the association's view that treatment of alcohol and drug abuse is effective, but he said the existing public treatment network must be coordinated better to distribute more efficiently available resources. ``If a needs assessment indicates a great need for treatment to be expanded and there are handles on what is now provided, then we are willing to make those recommendations,'' he said. John Gustafson, president of the association, said, ``Dr. Primm and I clearly disagree.''
