The group estimates that more than 10 million people in the United States need alcohol and other drug treatment, and that 44 states and the District of Columbia have waiting lists totaling 66,766 people. Primm, however, said he did not know what those figures were based on. Primm said cities need a central referral unit that can match treatment openings with those seeking treatment. Also needed are new techniques to assess needs and demand, ``a massive effort'' to show that treatment works and efforts to attract high-quality workers and to make treatment more acceptable in the community, he said. Primm also said he was concerned that several cities in the Northeast had not yet asked to receive the funds they were awarded under a $100 million, two-year program designed to make more treatment available in areas that have long waiting lists for their publicly funded programs. The cities had specified that they had waiting lists of more than 500 people, he said. ``I don't know what the reason is,'' he said. ``Something is the matter, and it's not the federal government.'' The program can fund 21,535 treatment slots, but cities have requested funds for only about 19,000 placements, he said. He declined to identify the cities, saying it would premature since he did not yet know why they haven't tapped the funds.

DOC.HEAD: Space Agency to Review Space Walk Requirements
DOC.TEXT: NASA, reacting to criticism about the number of astronaut space walks that will be needed to maintain the proposed space station, said Wednesday it will review its requirements and report the results to Congress. NASA said that on Friday it will review the status of an ongoing study of the space-walk requirements. The announcement made no reference to two articles in the New York Times this week that prompted the review. On Monday, the Times reported that an internal NASA investigation showed 2,200 hours of space walks would be required each year, 5{ times as long as all U.S. space walks to date. It said the study found the station could not be built as designed because its parts would begin to break down before the station was completed in the late 1990s. On Wednesday, the newspaper quoted Dr. William Fisher, a co-leader of a NASA investigative panel, as challenging his bosses for saying the findings were ``a worst case scenario.'' Fisher, an astronaut, said his team had been done a disservice by implication its efforts were ``somehow not credible simply because the results are unpopular.'' Fisher said ``our ongoing investigation may well show the problem to be even greater than our preliminary figures would indicate.'' NASA said Richard H. Truly, the agency's administrator, will conduct Friday's review. Others taking part, in addition to Fisher, will include Charles Price, the other co-leader; William Lenoir, who heads NASA's space flight program; Richard Kohrs, director of the space station program, and officials from the Johnson Space Center.

DOC.HEAD: Water Agency Wants Mandatory Conservation in Southern California
With LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: With California's drought entering its fourth year, the largest water agency supplying Southern California wants mandatory conservation rules banning driveway washing, daytime lawn watering and car washing. ``Even if we had rain of biblical proportions, we couldn't get back to normal this year,'' Bob Gomperz, spokesman for the Metropolitan Water District, said Wednesday. The district imports water into the desert-like region by aqueducts from the Colorado River and Northern California, and sells it wholesale to 27 smaller water districts. The agency supplies more than 500 billion gallons yearly to the 13 million residents of a six-county area containing 300 communities from Ventura County to the Mexico border. The area includes Los Angeles and San Diego. California's rainy season is just about over, mountain snowpack levels are running at less than 63 percent of normal and river runoff is 35 percent of normal, the state's Cooperative Snow Survey reports. ``Most of the season is over already. The thing is cast now. It's grim,'' said the survey's Jack Pardee. Runoff in the Sierra Nevada range fell to 63 percent of normal in 1987, 60 percent of normal in 1988 and 64 percent last year. So far in 1990, the runoff has been 63 percent. The region also has lost some of the water it took from the Colorado River water, as Arizona has begun using more of its entitlement from the heavily allocated river. The projected reduction was about 300,000 acre-feet, or approximately the amount used by 700,000 households annually. ``There is a possibility that (Southern California) could experience shortages ... even with normal precipitation for the rest of the year,'' said district general manager Carl Boronkay. ``If (the shortage) is as serious as I think it is, then it's time we all got serious'' and began mandatory programs to cut usage, Boronkay said. If communities begin water-saving measures immediately, most of the region could avoid being forced to take such drastic steps as have been taken in Santa Barbara, northwest of Los Angeles, where watering lawns is now illegal. Statewide, several communities have resorted to rationing. Monterey County on the central coast is holding consumers to 80 percent of their past consumption rate. Santa Clara County, southeast of San Francisco, has rationed water at 75 percent of normal. The Central Valley Water Project has cut the flow of water up to 50 percent. And El Dorado County, including part of the Sierra Nevada east of Sacramento, has banned new water connections. The Metropolitan Water District estimates that supplies could fall short of demand by up to 12 percent in the coming year. The agency also warned that mandatory water rationing may be necessary if there isn't some improvement next year. Conservation measures it wants to impose include banning hosing down driveways, watering lawns during daylight, washing cars and serving water in restaurants without a customer request. But the Los Angeles Department of Water and Power, which gets about half its water from the district, doesn't feel those measures will be enough to alleviate shortages. It also gets water from wells. ``We're on the borderline of mandatory rationing,'' said DWP engineer Dennis Williams. ``The city of Los Angeles could very well have mandatory rationing.'' The city already has a mandatory conservation law like the one requested by the water district. It's been on the books since the drought of 1977 and could be activated by the City Council at any time.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Endorses International Waste Pact
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration has endorsed an international agreement to control the export and disposal of hazardous waste, the White House said Wednesday. The United Nations' Basel Convention on controlling cross-border shipments of hazardous waste prohibits such shipments unless the exporting country does not have the technical capability or adequate facilities to dispose of it. It also allows export for recycling. The convention covers household and infectious wastes and municipal incinerator residue, as well as hazardous waste. An anaylst for Natural Resources Defense Council, an environmental group, called the convention a ``modest first step'' toward ending dumping of waste from industrial countries on Third World countries. ``We believe that trade must end. Anything short of a treaty to end all trade is unacceptable,'' said Jane Bloom, senior attorney for NRDC. The United States has a separate agreement covering exports of U.S. hazardous waste to Mexico and Canada. President Bush said a year ago that hazardous waste would be exported from the United States only to countries that agreed to handle it in an environmentally safe manner. Bush will send Congress legislation to implement both that policy and the Basel accord. The 1989 Basel Convention, signed by 46 countries, was the first of its kind calling for keeping cross-border hazardous waste shipments to a minimum. The Senate must ratify the treaty, which bars waste exports to Antarctica, for Bush's endorsement to become policy. The policy intends to cut down on using African and other Third World countries as dumping grounds. Environmental groups, however, have complained that it legalizes the international waste trade and that it was weakened to please industrialized countries. The Basel agreement says waste exports are to be barred if there is reason to believe the importing country will not manage them in an environmentally sound manner. Countries through which waste shipments pass must be notified and give written consent. The agreement says that a country can export such waste if it does not have the technical capacity, facilities or sites to dispose of it in an environmentally sound and efficient manner, the White House said.

DOC.HEAD: Group Finds Rivers Threatened by Dams, Diversions, the Air Force
DOC.TEXT: Oregon's Klamath River is the most endangered river in the nation because of a proposed power project that threatens ``one of the nation's oustanding whitewater recreational rivers,'' an environmental group said Wednesday. The diversion of the Klamath to generate power would also threaten several endangered species and sacred Native American sites, American Rivers said in a report ranking on the nation's 10 most endangered rivers. The non-profit group, which works to protect river shorelines and block construction of some dams, followed the Klamath with Colorado's South Platte River, which was ranked as the most endangered in 1988 and 1989. The Penobscot River in Maine and the American River in California were next on the list. The others were: the Bruneau and Jarbidge Rivers, Idaho; the Alsek and Tatshenshini Rivers, Alaska and Canada; Passaic River, New Jersey; Cahaba River, Alabama; Jemez River, New Mexico; and James River, Missouri. ``We are noticing more diversity of threat and greater geographic distribution of the threats,'' said Kevin Coyle, acting president of American Rivers. He said Western rivers have dominated the list in the past. ``Now we have a river in the Southwest, one in New Jersey, Maine, Missouri. It is the first time a river has ever been listed from Alaska,'' he said. Coyle said the threat against Colorado's South Platte has eased somewhat because the Environmental Protection Agency is moving to veto a wetlands permit needed for construction of the Two Forks Dam. But he said the river is still near the top of the endangered list because ``we don't believe the South Platte is a finished issue by any means.'' In Idaho, Coyle said the group is concerned about Air Force plans to turn about a million acres along the Bruneau and Jarbidge rivers into a bombing range. ``The Air Force proposes to use this spectacular wilderness area for low-level supersonic bombing, including live ordnance air-to-ground missiles,'' the report said. The Alsek and Tatshenshini Rivers are threatened by mining, the report said, and the Passaic is endangered by plans to eliminate flooding by building a ``flood tunnel'' to bypass some areas. ``On the Jemez in New Mexico, they want to do pumice mining to make stonewashed blue jeans,'' he said. ``Each of the threats is very different.'' The ``clear, clean waters'' of the James River, near Springfield, Mo., are threatened by a proposed water supply dam which American Rivers said is of questionable necessity. Coyle said the hydropower diversion on the Klamath ``threatens one of the nation's outstanding whitewater recreational rivers.'' His group is working with others to add the Klamath to the National Wild and Scenic Rivers System and protect it from construction. Federal regulators are to decide this year whether to license the proposed power project on the Klamath and the Bureau of Land Management will decide whether to include 19-mile stretch in the scenic rivers system, he said. ``The river segment contains rare year-round whitewater rafting in the southern Oregon, northern California area. Also threatened are several federally threatened fish species,'' a blue-ribbon trout fishery and habitat for peregrine falcons,'' the study said. ``In addition, there is concern that some sacred sites of the Klamath and Shasta tribes would be destroyed or open to vandalism,'' it said.

DOC.HEAD: Reebok, Leonard Donate Money to Education Center
DOC.TEXT: An anti-apartheid group received $625,000 in donations Wednesday to help develop a research and education institute on Africa and the Caribbean. Paul Fireman, chairman of Reebok International Ltd., announced a three-year, $375,000 grant, while boxer Sugar Ray Leonard agreed to contribute $250,000 to TransAfrica Forum. TransAfrica is a think-tank and the parent organization of the forum, an educational resource that analyzes U.S. foreign policy as it affects Africa and the Caribbean. TransAfrica Director Randall Robinson said the center would begin operating in Washington in about two years. Educational programs that teach African history and culture will be geared toward young people, scholars, policy-makers and the general public, he said. The centerpiece of the new facility will be the William H. Gray III Foreign Policy Library and Research Center. Gray, a Philadelphia Democrat, is the majority whip in the House. Fireman said the contribution, the largest to date, is part of Reebok's ``longstanding commitment to human rights across the world.'' Leonard is a member of the Forum's ``Capital Campaign.'' ``We are creating a unique facility that will do more than enable scholars and policy-makers to expand their knowledge about Africa and the Caribbean,'' Robinson said. ``It will also teach African-American schoolchildren to explore their African heritage and identity.'' Robinson said contributions would be accepted from any corporation willing to divest all interests in South Africa. Fireman said Reebok's revenue totaled $1.822 billion in 1989. He said ``a vicious rumor'' was circulating within the black community that Reebok is a South Africa company. That, he said, has been ``a tremendous deficiency'' to domestic sales. ``Reebok refuses to do business in South Africa because we have made a commitment to help advance the cause of human rights throughout the world,'' Fireman said. The Stoughton, Mass., company terminated one distributor relationship in South Africa in 1986, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Strikes Mar Sharpeville Massacre's 30th Anniversary; 2 Dead, 50 Hurt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 11th graf `The largest' to CORRECT spelling to Langa, sted Lanka. Picks up 12th `African National...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Namibia, Bjt
LaserPhoto JOH1
DOC.TEXT: Blacks put up barricades and stoned cars Wednesday to enforce a nationwide strike marking the 30th anniversary of the Sharpeville massacre. Police said at two people were killed and about 50 injured. Tens of thousands of black workers stayed home from work and school and attended rallies in black townships in honor of the 69 blacks killed by police during a 1960 demonstration at Sharpeville, a black township outside Johannesburg. The Sharpeville shootings were a turning point for the African National Congress, which broke with decades of non-violent protest to fight South Africa's white-run government. During the past decade, a national strike has been called each year to commemorate the dead, and many employers now give their workers the day off. In Glencoe, a town in Natal province, police said officers killed one youth when they fired rubber bullets and tear gas at a crowd attacking policemen who were dismantling a barricade. Police said that at Umlazi, south of Durban, a black man fired shots at attackers who had thrown gasoline bombs at his house and stoned his car. One man was killed and one wounded by the shots, police said. Fighting between black political groups in Natal province has claimed more than 3,000 lives since 1987. Umlazi, where thousands of people streamed to the stadium for a rally, was one of the most violent areas of the country. Throughout the day, crowds erected barricades with tree stumps, barrels and burned-out vehicles, then threw stones or gasoline bombs at officers who came to tear down the barricades. Police said 49 people were injured when officers fired birdshot, rubber bullets and tear gas to disperse crowds putting up blockades, intimidating people on their to work, or attacking police vehicles with stones and gunfire. Thousands of blacks _ either heeding the call to stay away or unable to travel due to the shutdown of public transportation _ were absent from work and school in Johannesburg, Durban, Pietermaritzburg, East London, Uitenhage, Cape Town and other towns across South Africa. There was no way to estimate how many people took part in the strike. The largest rally was reported at Uitenhage, in eastern Cape province. Journalists said 100,000 people gathered there to commemorate blacks killed in the township of Langa during a Sharpeville anniversary protest five years ago. African National Congress leader Raymond Mhlaba and other officials put up a tombstone in a Langa cemetery and tossed flowers over it for those killed in 1985. The exact death toll has never been confirmed. Estimates range from 29 to 43. The shutdown of black transportation effectively enforced the boycott. The state-run South African Broadcasting Corporation reported that between 20 percent and 80 percent of black workers stayed away from work in many areas. Press reports said the strike was more widely observed in some areas, with up to 99 percent of the work force on strike in parts of Durban. The harbor on the Indian Ocean was at a standstill, with ship departures delayed by a 98 percent absentee rate. Virtually no buses were running in black areas and crowds stoned trains some places to try to stop service, local journalists said. The streets of central Johannesburg were quiet, with little traffic and few pedestrians. Thousands of black workers who tried to reach work from outlying towns were stranded.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Refuses to Subpoena Reagan Diary; Jury Begin Watching Videotape
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 14-20, beginning `The jury ...' with 12 grafs to UPDATE with afternoon Reagan testimony
DOC.TEXT: The judge in John Poindexter's Iran-Contra trial reversed himself Wednesday, saying that former President Reagan does not have to produce diary entries sought by his one-time national security adviser. U.S. District Court Judge Harold Greene issued the ruling as the jury began watching eight hours of videotaped testimony by Reagan. Greene had ordered Reagan to turn over the diary, but said after reading the three dozen entries sought by Poindexter that the material was not ``essential to the achievement of justice in this case.'' Poindexter said he needed the excerpts because Reagan, in his taped testimony, ``professed a total inability to recall'' the diversion of Iran arms sale proceeds to the Nicaraguan Contras and a 1985 Hawk missile shipment. Defense lawyers also said Reagan was unable to recall Poindexter's activities on behalf of the Contras. Poindexter is charged with five felony charges of conspiracy, making false statements and obstructing Congress in connection with the Iran-Contra affair. ``Mr. Reagan did testify under oath at great length about many specific activities in his administration _ an event that is unprecedented in American history,'' Greene said in a 14-page ruling. He granted Reagan's motion to quash Poindexter's subpoena for the entries, which relate to both the Iran initiative and Contra resupply operation, saying they ``offer no new insights about these events.'' Reagan, later joined by the Bush administration, fought the subpoena by invoking executive privilege. ``If the concept of executive privilege is to retain any meaning, it will surely shield personal presidential papers from production ... on so flimsy a basis,'' Greene said. ``The inability of a witness to recall ... does not automatically entitle a party ... to rummage through ... personal papers, including his personal diary,'' he said. Prosecution witnesses have testified during the 7{ days of the trial that Poindexter destroyed a presidential document and sent false letters to Congress about covert aid to the Contras. Reagan's videotaped testimony taken Feb. 16-17 was shown in Greene's courtroom on television monitors, including one positioned in front of the jury. The jury spent all day Wednesday watching the videotape and was to finish the process Thursday morning. The jurors watched intently as Iran-Contra prosecutor Dan Webb questioned Reagan in rapid-fire fashion. ``Did you ... give authority to John Poindexter to make any false ... statements?'' Webb asked. ``No,'' Reagan replied. ``And I don't think any false statements were made.'' ``Did you ever ... give authority to John Poindexter to destroy ... records?'' Webb asked. ``No,'' responded the former president. ``Did John Poindexter ever tell you ... he planned on destroying any documents?'' the prosecutor asked. ``No,'' Reagan responded. ``Did John Poindexter ... tell you ... he had learned that Oliver North ... altered and destroyed records?'' Webb asked. ``No,'' Reagan said. Several jurors laughed when Greene put a halt to a heated exchange between defense lawyer Richard Beckler and Webb by saying, ``let's not make a federal case out of this.'' Copies of the Reagan tapes were released Wednesday to the media. Transcripts were released last month and the tapes were shown several times in the courthouse.

DOC.HEAD: Romania Says Hungary Incites Ethnic Tensions
LaserPhoto NY98
DOC.TEXT: The provisional government accused Hungary on Wednesday of inciting tensions between Romanians and ethnic Hungarians that led to bloody street battles this week in Transylvania. In a strongly worded statement released to news media, it charged Hungarian officialdom with ``propagandistic actions ... that present Transylvania as a Hungarian component.'' Clashes between the Romanian majority and Hungarian minority left several people injured Wednesday in the Transylvanian town of Tirgu Mures, scene of Tuesday night's bloodletting that killed at least six people and injured about 300. Tanks cordoned off all highways into the city of 165,000 northwest of Bucharest and patrolled downtown, where the pitched battles Tuesday featured men swinging scythes surging into crowds to beat other men. Tirgu Mures was reported quiet Wednesday night. However, Romanians and Hungarians were entering the city on foot late Wednesday afternoon armed with clubs and iron bars, witnesses said. The army had orders to arrest anyone carrying a weapon on the streets. The government accused interim Hungarian President Matyas Szueroes of issuing a March 18 call through the press to ethnic Hungarians in Romania, urging them ``to intensify their activity, and to organize themselves according to the idea that Transylvania would be `native Hungarian land.''' But the provisional leadership that has run Romania since the December revolution that overthrew Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu also put some of the blame for the violence on right-wing elements inciting ethnic Romanians. Interim Vice President Cazimir Ionescu blamed the clashes on a resurgence of the fascist Iron Guard. A special commission of inquiry flown to Tirgu Mures on Wednesday agreed to meet Thursday with representatives of both the Romanian and Hungarian communities. At United Nations headquarters in New York, a Hungarian diplomat said Wednesday that Hungary has appealed for U.N. help to protect the rights of Hungarians in Romania and is pressing for Security Council action to halt ethnic violence in Transylvania. He demanded anonymity. In a letter to Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar, Hungarian Foreign Minister Gyula Horn asked the international community and the United Nations ``to take effective measures ... to protect the individual and collective rights of the largest minority in Europe.'' Horn said ``legal Romanian organizations'' have fueled ethnic tensions and prompted violence against Hungarian minorities in Transylvanian cities. The State Department in Washington appealed to Romanians to reject extremist groups and end the ethnic violence. Spokesman Richard Boucher said, ``Romanian citizens of all ethnic backgrounds should remember their recent monumental sacrifices in ousting the brutal Ceaucescu dictatorship in the hope of establishing a democracy based on respect for human rights and tolerance of political and cultural diversity.'' The Romanian statement Wednesday accused Hungary of using the cover of cultural aid to send school books and posters that represent Transylvania as a part of Hungary. ``The Romanian government demands an immediate halt to incitements and opposes the way Hungarian officialdom manipulates the news and presents the situation in Romania,'' it said. Tirgu Mures is considered a cradle of ethnic Hungarian culture in Transylvania, which was ruled by Hungarians for centuries before being granted to Romania under a 1920 treaty. Since the December uprising, the Hungarian minority has been demanding greater cultural and social autonomy, including more Hungarian-language schools and other social institutions. Ceausescu suppressed all ethnic minorities in his drive for social, cultural and political uniformity. The 2.2 million ethnic Hungarians _ nearly all of them living in mountainous Transylvania _ make up almost 10 percent of Romania's 23 million population. Ethnic Romanians complain that concessions granted to the Hungarians by the new government discriminate against them by minimizing the use of the Romanian language in cities and towns where Hungarians predominate. Ionescu told The Associated Press on Wednesday, in singling out the Iron Guard as a provocateur, ``They scared the Romanians with the idea that the Hungarians want to take over Transylvania, and they are tellling the Hungarians that some requests they have made (to the government) will not be granted.'' Since the revolution, anti-minority letters and posters have been circulating in Romania signed by the Iron Guard, an anti-Semitic, xenophobic organization that flourished here in the late 1930s and early 1940s. The group called for ethnic purity and expulsion of all non-Romanians, especially Jews. At a Wednesday night news conference, interim Prime Minister Petre Roman said three Romanian-born Canadian ctizens were expelled Wednesday for Iron Guard activities. He did not identify them, but said they were found in possession of Iron Guard promotional literature. The state Rompres news agency identified the three as Nicolae Doru Popescu, 47, Gheorghe Balasu, 66, and Mihaela Moisin, 49, but gave no hometowns in Canada.

DOC.HEAD: Panel Says up to 5,000 Epilepsy Patients a Year Are Surgery Candidates
DOC.TEXT: An estimated 2,000 to 5,000 epilepsy patients a year are candidates for brain surgery using sophisticated new imaging techniques to provide surgeons a road map for the removal of abnormal brain cells. In a report released at a news conference Wednesday, a National Institutes of Health committee of experts said that 150,000 Americans annually have a first epiletic attack and many go on to develop a persistent pattern of seizures, some with up to 20 attacks a week. Anti-convulsant drugs will control seizures in about 70 percent of epilepsy patients, but 10 percent to 20 percent are not helped by such medication. ``Many of these patients and their families have to deal with a chronic disorder that impairs the quality of life for all concerned,'' the committee reported. For those with ``intractable'' epilepsy, the panel said, surgery offers the only hope of relief. The NIH convened the panel of 13 experts to study epilepsy surgery and to make treatment recommendations for use by the nation's medical community. About 500 operations to control epilepsy are performed annually in the United States, and the panel said the procedure is considered successful in 50 percent to 70 percent of the patients. Dr. Lewis P. Rowland, director of neurological service at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center in New York, said epilepsy surgery consists of locating and removing the group of brain cells responsible for the seizures. Rowland, chairman of the panel, said surgeons remove a portion of the skull, cut into the brain to remove the problem cells and restore the skull bone. Locating the problem cells, he said, now can be done using imaging techniques that use sophisticated, computer-driven X-rays or magnetic resonance imaging. ``We can do a a very precise operation now,'' said Dr. Edward R. Laws, professor of neurosurgery at George Washington University Medical Center in Washington. ``We can map the brain and know exactly the location of centers that cause the seizures.'' Death or injury to healthy parts of the brain are very uncommon from such operations, Laws said. ``It's practical now to do this type of surgery,'' he said. Laws said that most common epileptic surgery targets the temporal lobe, the portion of the brain at the temple. About 70 percent of those operations are successful, with the patients recovering either with no seizures or with seizures that can be controlled by drugs. A more complicated procedure is in the frontal lobe of the brain, that portion beneath the forehead. ``Results here fall to about 50 percent,'' Laws said. Such operations have been performed on children under the age of 2, but Rowland said the average age of epileptic surgery patients is 27. Cost of the operations average about $40,000, but can run as high as $100,000. Much of the expense comes from the use of sophisticated equipment to map the brain and to plan the surgery. The surgery is covered by some insurance companies and partially covered by Medicaid in some states. In their committee report, the experts recommended that epileptic surgery be limited to those hospitals with the equipment and staff to attempt such a complicated procedure. The committee also said a diagnosis of the epilepsy should be confirmed through tests, that all patients receive a careful trial of drug therapy and that a full range of tests be conducted to precisely locate the flawed brain cells that cause the seizures.

DOC.HEAD: Text of Lithuanian President's Statement
With AM-Lithuania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a text of Lithuanian President Vytautus Landsbergis' statement late Wednesday. It was issued in Lithuanian and translated for The Associated Press by Lithuanian officials.

This order, like any other adopted by a foreign state that pretends to claim sovereignty over Lithuania, has no legal power. It could be enforced only by brutal military force, and if the Soviet Union is willing to prolong the aggression of 1940 against Lithuania. It's a pity that it continues the mistake of the Third Congress of People's Deputies. It amounts to the claiming of non-existent and unjustified sovereignty of a powerful country over a small and unarmed neighbor. The Soviet Union has recognized as null and void the secret protocol to the agreement between Stalin and Hitler, condemned the policy of ultimatums and violation of international law including the annexation of Lithuania, but now once again is not able to give up the prize and restore justice. The ghost of Stalinism is walking in the Kremlin and the shadow of it lies far to the west (over Lithuania). Tomorrow will show if the world, which greets Lithuania and her desire for freedom, will approve. We'll meet tomorrow, serene and united as we were before facing previous threats.

DOC.HEAD: Museum Announces Acquisition of van Gogh's `Irises'
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: The J. Paul Getty Museum said Wednesday it has bought Vincent van Gogh's ``Irises'' from a debt-plagued entrepreneur who had bid a record $53.9 million for the masterpiece in 1987. ``The chance to acquire the painting was a great moment in the history of the museum and the trust,'' said Harold M. Williams, president and chief executive officer of the J. Paul Getty Trust. ``Irises'' already is on display in the museum's second-floor galleries alongside other 19th-century paintings by Pierre-Auguste Renoir, Edouard Manet and Edvard Munch. Painted in 1889 in van Gogh's bold style, it depicts a patch of garden in a French asylum at Saint-Remy de Provence, where the Dutch artist committed himself after a mental breakdown in Arles. Purple and midnight-blue blooms dominate, offset by a single white iris to the left and balanced below by salmon-pink soil. The painting was sold privately to the museum by Australian entrepreneur Alan Bond, who is reported to be $5 billion in debt. He bought it at a Sotheby's auction in New York on Nov. 11, 1987. In keeping with its policy of not discussing details of private acquisitions, the museum declined to disclose the price. The museum also did not discuss security arrangements. Early Sunday, thieves in Boston stole 12 artworks from the Gardner Museum. The loss was estimated in the hundreds of millions of dollars. John Paul Getty, the late oil baron, endowed the museum with $2.1 billion, making it the world's richest art institution. ``Until the sale of 1987, the painting was a well-known work. But it didn't achieve anything like the fame it achieved when it was sold here,'' said David Nash, Sotheby's director of fine arts in New York. The latest sale was arranged by Sotheby's, which had loaned Bond $27 million to buy ``Irises'' in an unusual deal that was widely criticized for inflating prices in the international art market. Bond's subsequent financial trouble further fueled intense speculation among art curators, dealers and collectors about the fate of the painting. While acknowledging the controversy, Diana D. Brooks, president of Sotheby's North America, said, ``We're comfortable with the way we handled it, and we're delighted that it's going to such a prestigous institution.'' She declined to describe any of the behind-the-scenes negotiations involving the painting. But when asked if Sotheby's had steered ``Irises'' to the Getty, Brooks said, ``If you had asked us of our dream, we would have said we would've wanted it to go to the Getty Museum.'' Nash, of Sotheby's, said ``the thing that's remarkable about the painting is its intensity and the energy that it conveys.'' ``This is among the most original and dynamic of all van Gogh's compositions, in which the spear-like, slashing representation of the flowers is echoed by the vibrancy of color,'' said a statement from George Goldner, the Getty's curator of paintings and drawings. ``At the same time it is a picture of great poetry, as expressed in the one white iris on the left side which, in its isolation, has a special poignancy.'' The painting was in private European collections until 1947, when it was purchased for $80,000 by New York philanthropist Joan Whitney Payson. After van Gogh's ``Sunflowers'' sold for $39.9 million in 1987, Payson's family decided to sell ``Irises'' and use the proceeds to endow a charitable foundation. Brooks said she had informed the Paysons that the Getty had acquired ``Irises.'' The family was ``absolutely thrilled'' the public would be able to view the painting as part of a museum's permanent collection, she said. In a statement released by Sotheby's, Bond said, ``I am very pleased with this sale, particularly because this great masterpiece will be on exhibition at such a pre-eminent museum.'' The Getty, designed in the style of a first-century Roman villa, overlooks the Pacific Ocean on the Los Angeles County coast. It is one of seven programs operated by the Getty Trust. Admission is free.

DOC.HEAD: Three Indicted For Selling Pentagon Bidding Information
DOC.TEXT: A former Navy procurement officer and two private consultants were indicted Wednesday on charges of peddling confidential bid information about lucrative Pentagon contacts to defense firms. George G. Stone, a former division director at the Navy's Space and Naval Warfare Systems Command, and consultants Thomas E. Muldoon and Mark C. Saunders were named in the eight-count indictment returned by a federal grand jury in suburban Alexandria, Va. The indictment was returned as part of the Justice Department's continuing investigation of Defense Department procurement fraud nicknamed ``Operation Ill Wind'' that has netted more than 30 convictions. The three were charged with participating in an illegal scheme to sell bid information about a contract to build a battlefield air traffic control system for the Marine Corps to two defense contractors. The indictment charges that the defendants relayed the confidential bid data to Norden Systems, a division of United Technologies Corp., and a subsidiary of Litton Industries Inc. The indictment also charges that Muldoon tried peddling similar information to Grumman Corp. and LTV Corp., which were also competing for the contract. The indictment charged that Muldoon gave Saunders $32,000 of the $96,000 he was paid by Litton and $13,750 of the $27,500 he received from Norden. Three former Norden executives have already pleaded guilty to participating in a scheme to pay Muldoon for inside information on the award of the $150 million contract. No charges have been brought against Litton or any of its employees. According to the indictment, Muldoon gave information to the contractors that he had received from Saunders, who in turn, obtained it from Stone. The indictment also charges that Stone used his influence during the contract compettition on behalf of Norden. Although Stone was not accused of receiving any money from the scheme, the indictment suggests that he was paid to help keep Norden in the competition. Recounting a wiretapped conversation, the indictment quotes Stone as telling Saunders that Norden had ``made the cut'' and was among the final competitors. Keeping Norden in competition was not a waste of time ``if it puts, you know, bread on the table,'' the indictment quotes Stone as telling Saunders. The indictment quotes Stone as saying his efforts had been ``a piece of cake'' and that he and Saunders were ``due.'' The three are also accused of relaying information to Unisys Corp. about a Navy contract to develop computer data base for submarine detection. The indictment is the second against Muldoon, who was sentenced in February to 27 months in prison for participating in a six-year scheme to bribe another Pentagon procurement official. The three defendants were each charged with conspiracy, wire fraud and conversion of government property. The charges aganst each of the three carry a maximum sentence upon conviction of 45 years in prison. In a separate investigation of contractors, two men were indicted Wednesday on charges of conspiring to acquire classified Pentagon budget and planning documents, the U.S. Attorney's Office in Alexandria said. John R. Kiely, 65, of Acton, Mass., and Frank J. Caso, 63, of Thousand Oaks, Calif., each were indicted as part of an investigation code-named ``Operation Uncover'' in which five companies and three individuals have already been convicted. Kiely worked for Raytheon Co., which on Tuesday pleaded guilty to related charges and agreed to pay $1 million in fines and penalties. Caso worked for Hughes Aircraft Co., which pleaded guilty on March 9 and was ordered to pay $3.57 in fines and penalties.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Up Ante on Eastern Europe With $2 Billion Aid Plan
DOC.TEXT: Senate Democrats plan a $2 billion package of additional aid for emerging democracies in Eastern Europe, six times what President Bush has proposed, according to a copy of the package obtained Wednesday. The draft bill by Sens. Claiborne Pell, D-R.I., and Joseph R. Biden, D-Del., calls for the new aid _ four times more than even the Democrats proposed just two months ago _ to be distributed to seven former Soviet bloc nations through 1992. Pell is chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Commttee and Biden is chairman of the panel's economic policy and trade subcommittee. The draft includes $1.2 billion for U.S. participation in a European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, which has been proposed by France to finance public works and new private enterprises in former communist economies. Bush administration officials have said the United States will not participate if the Soviet Union is allowed to be a net borrower from the bank. But Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady acknowledges the bank, which has already received commitments from most West European countries and Japan, is going forward with or without U.S. participation. ``Our economic competitors are racing to establish strong footings in Eastern Europe,'' Biden said Wednesday. ``We seem to be hesitating .... The United States could well be left out.'' The administration has proposed spending $300 million in additional aid in fiscal 1991 for Eastern Europe beyond the $738 million Congress set aside to help Poland and Hungary through 1992. Democrats have accused Bush of responding timidly to the overthrow of communist regimes as West Germany, Italy, France and Japan are investing heavily in Eastern Europe. ``Businesses are waiting for the government to go first and cover risks in the region and the government is waiting for business leaders to go in on their own,'' said Biden. ``What we're lacking is the vision to develop programs that transform our military presence in Europe to a political and economic presence.'' Biden said the $2 billion package could be introduced separately or could be tied to the $800 million in new aid Bush has requested for Nicaragua and Panama. Pell and Biden in late January proposed augmenting the Poland-Hungary package with another $511 million to include Czechoslovakia, East Germany, Romania, Bulgaria and Yugoslavia. Their new package would result in $2.75 billion going to the region by 1992. Included in their package is $200 million to create business centers in the seven countries to give technical and other assistance to American companies seeking a foothold in the markets. But the bulk of the new money would be for the new European Bank. In addition to the $400 million U.S. share for the $12 billion bank, the bill would establish an $800 million trust fund to finance East European purchases from U.S. companies to improve the nations' infrastructures. It would provide no direct assistance to the Soviet government, but would authorize the president to extend aspects of the program to the Soviet Union if they promote U.S. values there. For example, it would authorize the AFL-CIO to use $40 million in increased funds for the National Endowment for Democracy to help foster effective trade unions in the Soviet Union, as it did with the Solidarity movement in Poland. Biden said he and Pell wanted to avoid the furor that erupted earlier this month when House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., proposed sending direct aid to Moscow. ``This is a penetration program not an aid program, to the extent that the president wishes to engage in it at all,'' Biden said. ``The goal is to penetrate the Soviet Union with American values.''

DOC.HEAD: Sec't of State Baker Meets with Nelson Mandela
With AM-Namibia, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III met black nationalist leader Nelson Mandela on Wednesday amid growing superpower diplomacy for more reform in white minority-led South Africa. Baker arrived to see the African National Congress leader moments after Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze departed. Delegations from more than 100 nations were in Namibia to celebrate its independence from South Africa and the occasion provided a prime opportunity for officials to confer. Shevardnadze visited earlier in the day with South African President F.W. de Klerk. It was the first meeting between a South African president and a member of the Soviet government since the Soviet Union broke relations with South Africa 34 years ago because of apartheid. Baker was to meet with de Klerk on Thursday to press for further reforms in the apartheid system. A senior U.S. official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Baker urged Mandela to reconsider his support for nationalization of financial institutions and the mining industry in South Africa. The source said Baker ``was pleased with the way Mandela received that.'' Baker, in turn, assured Mandela that sanctions imposed by the U.S. Congress to protest apartheid would be observed by the Bush administration, the source said. In greeting Mandela, Baker said the U.S.-brokered negotiations that led to independence for Namibia were an example of how superpower cooperation could benefit the world. ``I fully agree,'' Mandela replied. ``One of the things we deeply appreciate is the effort made by the world powers to relax world tensions ... I think that we are turning a new chapter,'' he said. Baker, Mandela, several ANC leaders and South African Communist Party leader Joe Slovo met for 30 minutes. ``Mr. Baker and I have had a very fruitful discussion,'' Mandela said afterward. ``As you would expect, there are several issues on which our views are not so identical, but that has to be expected.'' Mandela reiterated the ANC's opposition to Baker's meeting with de Klerk in Cape Town, South Africa, on Thursday. He said it could create ``a great deal of confusion'' by suggesting that de Klerk's government ``has done something which requires a change of attitude on the part of the international community. We regard that as regrettable.'' However, Mandela also said there were areas of agreement between the Bush administration and the ANC. ``I regard Mr. Baker, the Congress, and the American people as true friends, and that characterized our discussions today.'' Baker said of Mandela: ``I think his courageousness is something that the world has taken note of and ... has sustained many, even in the U.S., in their position that apartheid must be abolished.'' Relations between the U.S. government and the ANC have improved during the last 12 months. The ANC, the main black group fighting minority white rule in South Africa, condemned former President Reagan's policy of ``constructive engagement'' toward South Africa, which involved maintaining ties in order to exert influence, and opposition to economic sanctions. The United States has imposed the toughest sanctions against South Africa of any Western country outside Scandinavia, but Congress did it over Reagan's veto. ANC leaders have said they can communicate better with the Bush administration, although they call for even stricter sanctions and cutting all diplomatic ties to the South African government, a move no Western government has taken. Shevardnadze, who was to fly to Mozambique on Thursday, characterized his talks with de Klerk as useful. De Klerk said the talks were ``promising and constructive.'' Soviet sources, who also spoke on condition of anonymity, said Shevardnadze would like to visit South Africa but further reforms are required there before such a trip can be considered.

DOC.HEAD: Revelations Could Undo French-U.S. Agreement
DOC.TEXT: A doctor involved in a dispute over the discovery of the AIDS virus said Wednesday a French-American agreement on the AIDS test could be called into question if disclosures in a reportedly hushed-up U.S. inquiry prove true. Dr. Luc Montagnier, who led the French team that discovered the AIDS virus, also called on his American collegue Robert C. Gallo to admit that his own discovery was the result of accidental laboratory contamination. Montagnier, of the Pasteur Institute in Paris, says his team discovered the deadly virus first, a claim disputed by Gallo, of the National Cancer Institute. ``I think ... Gallo should finally admit the obvious,'' Montagnier said in an interview with Le Monde newspaper. ``I again make a public call for him to do so, and I would be prepared to salute his courage if he did so.'' The Chicago Tribune reported this week on a secret U.S. government inquiry that allegedly uncovered evidence that Gallo was not the first to discover the AIDS virus. The inquiry, conducted by the National Institutes of Health, concluded that instead of discovering the AIDS virus, Gallo may have discovered the offspring of a sample virus sent to him by French scientists, the newspaper reported. He said the report referred to by The Chicago Tribune had never been made available to French lawyers, ``which is in absolute contradiction with American legislation under the Freedom of Information (Act).'' An out-of-court settlement between the U.S. government and the French in March 1987 gave the Pasteur Institute the right to sell its AIDS test in the United States and allowed the two sides to share royalties from the U.S. AIDS test. The agreement did not touch on the issue of who discovered the virus first. ``We do not exclude the possibility of bringing into question the terms of the French-American agreement in the light of new elements which could turn up,'' Montagnier told Le Monde. AIDS, or acquired immune deficiency syndrome, destroys the body's ability to fight disease. There is no known cure. Montagnier, whose team had shared its AIDS research with the Americans, contended the virus Gallo discovered was the result of an error of manipulation in the laboratory. ``This hypothesis is not only for me, but for the entire scientific community, completely obvious,'' he said. Montagnier said that by contamination he meant the virus in one test tube could contaminate other viral cultures in the laboratory and then be identified as a new virus. He said he is not accusing Gallo of fraud but of a laboratory accident that carried no ``dishonor.'' The French were first to publish information about their virus, in May 1983, but the finding, from one isolated case, was largely ignored. The Gallo group maintained it was the first to isolate, study in detail, classify and link a similar virus with AIDS. The work was published in the May 4, 1984, issue of the journal Science.

DOC.HEAD: Vermont Digs Out From Early Spring Snow
DOC.TEXT: A storm that dumped up to 2{ feet of snow on Vermont and cut electrical service to thousands moved out to sea Wednesday, and frost and freeze warnings were posted over parts of the Southeast for the second night of spring. Snowfall totals in the central and eastern Green Mountains of Vermont ranged up to 30 inches at Braintree, with 28 inches at Williamstown and 23 inches at Randolph. Most of the snow fell Tuesday and only flurries remained over eastern New England at midday as the storm moved out to sea, the National Weather Service said. The heavy wet snow downed many tree limbs and power lines, causing numerous power outages. Vermont had 30,000 customers still without power Wednesday, utilities said. Green Mountain Power Corp. sent out helicopters to help locate the hundreds of toppled trees responsible for many of the outages. The state Department of Public Service said some residences would be without power for at least 48 hours before all systems were restored. Crews fixing power lines, many of whom were out all night, were still having problems Wednesday with the wet snow, and some of their trucks were stuck in mud and snowbanks, said Central Vermont Public Service Corp. spokesman Charles Satterfield. But the storm was a lifesaver for the state's ski areas, which had been forced to curtail skiing to one or two trails because of 70-degree weather. ``Let's be very honest here, things were getting pretty grim,'' said Laura Witten, a spokesman at Killington Ski Area. On either side of Vermont, northeastern New York state got up to 7 inches and New Hampshire only got 3 to 9 inches. Elsewhere, a few light showers dampened Wisconsin on Wednesday afternoon and light snow was reported near Lake Superior. South-central Montana also had a few light showers. Flooding continued in Georgia, the Florida Panhandle and Alabama as a result of last week's heavy rain. River levels had begun dropping in Alabama, where the water forced thousands to evacuate, including 2,000 in the town of Elba. Temperatures dipped below freezing across much of the nation east of the Mississippi River from Tuesday night into Wednesday morning, with lows in the teens reported in West Virginia. Tallahassee, Fla., dipped to 28 degrees. Morning lows above freezing were primarily confined to the Florida Peninsula, with lows in the 50s and lower 60s in extreme southern Florida. A frost warning was posted into Thursday morning for the mountains, foothills, piedmont, midlands and western sections of South Carolina. Frost and freezing warnings were issued for the southern and central mountains of North Carolina, and for southwestern sections of the state. Frost warnings were issued for the foothills, piedmont and northern coastal plains of that state. Temperatures also dipped below freezing in the north-central states early Wednesday and in the Great Basin covering Nevada and western Utah. Midday temperatures Wednesday were only in the 30s in New England and from northern Montana to northern Minnesota. Wednesday's low for the Lower 48 states was 16 degrees at Elkins, W.Va., which had a record high one week earlier of of 82.

DOC.HEAD: CBO Studies Effects of Defense Cuts
DOC.TEXT: Cuts in military spending eventually will mean a higher standard of living for many Americans but will disrupt some areas of the country, a congressional study said. The Congressional Budget Office said in a report released this week that money trimmed from defense would likely be directed to non-defense programs or used to reduce taxes, allowing Americans to spend or save more money. ``Alternatively, a reduction in spending could be used to cut the federal deficit, which would lead to higher standards of living,'' CBO said in a memorandum assessing the effects of a reduced defense budget. ``Lower deficits would increase national saving, resulting both in higher domestic investment and lower indebtedness to the rest of the world.'' The short-term effects of a cut in defense spending would slow economic expansion and increase unemployment, but by a small amount. The study said, however, that it was unlikely the slow economic growth would trigger a recession. The CBO considered three possible reductions in the defense budget _ 4 percent, 7 percent and 10 percent a year in the 1991-1995 period. The cuts would result in a reduction in defense spending ranging from $8 billion to $17 billion in fiscal 1991 and $62 billion to about $139 billion by fiscal 1995. President Bush's current defense budget calls for $303 billion in defense spending. Although CBO found financial benefits from reductions in defense, the agency concluded that three of nine census regions would feel the greatest effect. If cuts are made in employment levels, the Pacific and South Atlantic regions would suffer the most because they boast the largest concentration of people employed by the Defense Department. If reductions are made in purchases, the New England area and the Pacific would be hardest hit. States that would suffer are Virginia, Alaska, Washington and Hawaii; 9 percent of their output is connected to defense spending. Specific metropolitan areas affected would be Los Angeles-Long Beach, Nassau-Suffolk on Long Island, Boston and Washington, D.C. In addition, communities around military bases slated for closing would suffer disruptions. ``Local impacts could be offset if other uses for defense bases are found or if companies diversify into non-defense work or are replaced by companies in non-defense markets,'' the CBO said. The study was done at the request of the House Budget Committee.

DOC.HEAD: Two Anti-Abortion Candidates Lose in Illinois Primary Election
With AM-Illinois Primary
DOC.TEXT: Illinois' anti-abortion lobby suffered a double blow at the polls with the defeat of a seven-term state representative and a longshot gubernatorial candidate. Rep. Penny Pullen, a leading sponsor of anti-abortion measures, blamed her razor-thin loss in Tuesday's primary on ``dirty politics'' by abortion rights candidate Rosemary Mulligan, and said she may challenge the results. Republican gubernatorial candidate Steven Baer, who appealed to opponents of abortion and higher taxes, lost by a 2-to-1 margin to Jim Edgar, two-term secretary of state and near-unanimous choice of the state GOP hierarchy. With all precincts reporting, Pullen, an assistant House minority leader, received 7,400 votes to 7,431 for Mulligan. ``I blame the closeness of this election on dirty politics ... the total distortion of my voting record,'' she said. In Washington, the National Abortion Rights Action League said Mulligan's ``outstanding victory over a 14-year, anti-choice leader is proof that since we can no longer depend on the courts, Americans are committed to protecting their right to choose with their votes.'' Mulligan, a paralegal from Des Plaines, denied her campaign had distorted her opponent's record. Both candidates received some of their campaign money from advocacy groups. In the last six months, about 67 percent of Mulligan's $40,382 campaign fund came from Personal PAC, a political committee affiliated with the National Abortion Rights Action Group and other pro-choice groups, records show. Miss Pullen raised $87,168 in the same period, including $1,000 from the National Right to Life PAC and $4,100 from the conservative, anti-abortion United Republican Fund, records say. The Illinois Federation for Right to Life also provided workers to help Pullen contact voters who share her views on abortion. Those services have not yet been reported in pre-election campaign finance records. Edgar's victory set up a November election matchup with Neil Hartigan, the state's two-term attorney general, who was unopposed in the Democratic primary. Both candidates are pro-choice, which may move the abortion issue out of the spotlight it held in the GOP primary. With 99 percent of precincts reporting, Edgar received 481,532 votes, or 63 percent, to 256,466, or 33 percent, for Baer. In Harrisburg, Penn., a Republican candidate for the state Legislature, Rosemary McAvoy, said Wednesday she was suspended by her parish priest as president of the school board and as a lector at St. Catherine Laboure Church after announcing her candidacy late last year. She is an abortion rights advocate. Monsignor Leo Beierschmitt said he could not comment on his actions because, ``I'm dealing with her in private.''

DOC.HEAD: Ethnic Violence in Romania Latest Manifestation of Ancient Feud
With AM-Romania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Ethnic hatreds that have flared in the Romanian city of Tirgu Mures are as old as the squabble over Transylvania, now part of Romania but administered for centuries by neighboring Hungary. At least six people were reported dead Wednesday in the Transylvanian city about 250 miles north of Bucharest and the same distance east of Budapest. About 300 were wounded in pitched street battles between ethnic Hungarians and Romanians _ some armed with wooden staves, scythes and pitchforks. The violence followed weeks of increasing tension over demands of Transylvania's 2.2 million-strong Hungarian minority, about 10 percent of Romania's population. Among the rights sought by ethnic Hungarians were re-establishment of separate Hungarian-language schools and universities, initially supported by the post-World War II Romanian leadership but abolished under toppled dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, and proportional government representation on the local and national level. Weeks of peaceful demonstrations in Transylvania by both ethnic groups turned into open conflict on the weekend over an apparently minor incident _ a Hungarian-language sign in a Tirgu Mures store window identifying it as a pharmacy. A group of Romanians demolished the pharmacy and attacked the headquarters of the Democratic Federation of Hungarians, the main special interest group of the minority. Street battles followed, and the army moved in to try to restore order. The Tirgu Mures clashes represented the first documented case of open ethnic violence in Transylvania in more than 40 years and displayed the depth of emotions kept in check under the iron hand of Ceausescu and his predecessor Gheorghe Gheorghiu-Dej. While their Communist systems perpetuated and later encouraged the hatreds as a way of diffusing opposition to authoritarian rule, both leaders would have moved quickly to crush any open ethnic conflict that could have developed into a threat to their authority. Nationalist rivalries seemingly faded in December, as the two ethnic groups joined in anti-Ceausescu demonstrations in Timisoara, another Transylvanian city, starting what quickly turned into the revolution. But bickering along ethnic lines quickly resurfaced. Romanians and Hungarians have been in Transylvania more than 1,000 years, and Hungarian kings ruled the territory in the Middle ages. The modern history of the conflict dates to the 1830s, with awakening nationalist sentiment across Europe. In 1848, the Hungarians rose against Austrian rule. They demanded recognition of their own national aspirations without being willing to extend similar recognition to like-minded desires of national minorities in the region. Hungarian revolutionaries sought the annexation of Transylvania, then administered by Austria. The Hungarians lost their independence battle but subsequently gained control of Transylvania as junior partners in the Austro-Hungarian monarchy. One incident indirectly leading to the Tirgu Mures violence was Romanian displeasure with open ethnic Hungarian celebrations of March 15 _ the anniversary of the outbreak of the anti-Austrian revolution. Such dates could not be observed during the Communist era. After dissolution of the Austro-Hungarian empire in 1918, the victorious Allies of World War I ceded Transylvania to Romania under the Treaty of Trianon. Recurring Hungarian repression of Transylvanian Romanians was replaced by officially condoned Romanian persecution of the region's Hungarians. Hungary reclaimed part of Transylvania as a reward for temporarily siding with Nazi Germany during World War II, only to lose it again at the end of the war with the defeat of the Axis.

DOC.HEAD: U.S.-Soviet Trade Talks Open
DOC.TEXT: U.S.-Soviet talks on a trade agreement and separate negotiations on a new, long-term grains accord began Wednesday behind closed doors. The negotiators reportedly hope to reach agreement on an overall trade package in time for a summit meeting between presidents Bush and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, scheduled for June. ``I don't have any statement to make,'' Ambassador Julius Katz, the deputy U.S. trade representative, told The Associated Press as he emerged from his limousine to attend the second round of the day at the Soviet trade mission. ``I won't say anything before the scheduled news conference tomorrow.'' Katz heads the U.S. negotiating teams at the two sets of talks. The Soviet trade mission refused to comment on the talks. An opening round of talks were held last month and both sides expressed satisfaction with their progress. Another round was held later in February in London. The trade package would include granting most-favored nation trading status, qualifying the Soviet Union for the lowest tariffs available to U.S. trading partners. Soviet exports to the United States now bear duties as much as 10 times higher than imports from other nations. Most-favored nation trading status would be a first step toward making U.S. exports to the Soviet Union eligible for U.S. government loans and credits. Bush first must waive the so-called Jackson-Vanik Amendment barring such status, passed by Congress in 1974 because the Soviets refused free emigration. A waiver would require Bush to certify to Congress that free emigration was being allowed. The latest U.S.-Soviet grains accord, which officially expired Sept.30, 1988, was extended through Dec.31, 1990, to help negotiations and to allow a new five-year accord to run concurrently with the Soviet Union's five-year planning process, a U.S. statement distributed here said. Under this accord, the Soviet Union must buy at least 4 million metric tons of wheat and 4 million metric tons of corn annually, together with an additional 1 million metric tons of cumulative amounts of wheat, corn, soybean and soymeal. At the same time, the Soviets are allowed to buy up to 3 million tons of additional wheat and corn each year without further consultations with the United States. U.S. Department of Agriculture officials said the Soviet Union bought more than 12 million metric tons of U.S. grains during the last quarter of 1989.

DOC.HEAD: AIDS Program Gets Acting Head Following Resignation of Dr. Mann
DOC.TEXT: The World Health Organization on Wednesday put its battle against AIDS under the temporary leadership of a U.S. doctor following the resignation of Dr. Jonathan Mann over differences with WHO's director-general. Dr. Michael H. Merson was named to take charge as acting head of the Global Program on AIDS effective Monday, according to a statement issued by the organization. Mann, also an American public health expert, announced his resignation Friday. He will remain on the staff until June. Merson, 44, of Brooklyn, New York City, also is in charge of WHO programs for diarrheal diseases and respiratory infections. He joined the agency in 1978. Mann has headed the AIDS program since its inception in 1986. He has won wide acclaim for pushing a worldwide campaign to inform people of the deadly disease and how to protect against it. In his letter of resignation to WHO Director-General Dr. Hiroshi Nakajima, Mann cited ``a great variance between our positions on a series of issues'' he considered critical for the global strategy in the fight against AIDS. No other details of the disagreement were disclosed, and Mann and Nakajima have not replied to requests to meet with reporters to talk about the issue. In Washington Wednesday, Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan and Assistant Secretary for Health James Mason expressed pleasure that Merson agreed to take over for Mann. ``We would like to take this opportunity to thank Dr. Jonathan Mann for his years of distinguished service in this position and to again assure Dr. Nakajima of the continued support of this administration for the vital work of WHO's global AIDS program,'' their statement said. Kathleen Kay, Mann's executive assistant, also has announced she is leaving the agency. Ms. Kay, an Australian, had worked with Mann almost since the program was launched. WHO spokeswoman Therese Gastaut said there had been no further resignations.

DOC.HEAD: Osage Tribe Says Koch Didn't Steal Oil
DOC.TEXT: The nation's largest independent oil producer didn't steal millions of dollars worth of oil from wells on Indian land as a U.S. Senate subcommittee alleged last year, Osage tribe officials concluded. The Osage Tribal Council said it investigated Koch Industries Inc. purchases in Osage County, Okla., for 1987, 1988 and the first five months of 1989 and found that ``overpayment of royalties by Koch were made as well as underpayments.'' The net amount owed was about $22,000, plus $7,057 in late penalties, the council said. In Monday's edition of the Osage Nation News, the council said it found no evidence to substantiate accusations by a subcommittee of the Senate Select Committee on Indian Lands that Koch stole million of dollars worth of oil. Two former Koch employees told the subcommittee last May they were pressured to steal oil from wells on Indian land. The company expected them to mismeasure oil from the wells so that Koch did not have to pay for all it got, they testified. The company rebutted the allegations, saying the subcommittee's figures were inaccurate and that comparisons with other companies were based on nonapplicable statistics. Koch's executive vice president for corporate and legal affairs, Don Cordes, said that of the oil it bought from Indian-owned land, 85 percent came from land owned by the Osages in Oklahoma. Koch had control of more than 10 million barrels of Osage oil during the period under investigation and paid royalties of approximately $33 million for it, Cordes said. ``This report completely undermines the false allegations of the Senate subcommittee,'' he said Tuesday. Koch records indicated a net overpayment to the Osages, Cordes said. He added tht the $22,000 discrepancy alleged by the tribe is less than 0.1 percent of the total royalties paid during the period. ``However, the differences between the Osage and Koch numbers are so tiny in relation to the total volume of business done that the Senate allegations are demonstrably false under either conclusion,'' Cordes said. Both sets of figures demonstrate the inexactness and imprecision of measuring crude oil, Cordes said. Koch officials maintained from the start of the controversy that factors such as temperature, crude oil composition and holding tank conditions make precise measurement of crude impossible.

DOC.HEAD: FCC Narrows Field
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on financial circuits
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Communications Commission on Wednesday further narrowed the field of contestants locked in a high-stakes battle to win the right to market a high-definition television transmission system. Chairman Alfred Sikes said the commission, which plans to announce the winner of the HDTV sweepstakes in early 1993, voted to consider only HDTV systems that will not require use of an extra ``augmentation'' channel of scarce TV space in order to provide the crystal-clear pictures and compact disc-quality sound that the new system promises. At the moment, no augmentation system is expected, but some could emerge or be revived. Only so-called simulcast systems will be considered for testing at the Advanced Television Test Center this fall, Sikes said at a meeting of the FCC's Advisory Committee on Advanced Television Service. Japanese and European manufacturers are far ahead of the United States in developing the next generation of television, which promises many military, educational and medical uses besides giving viewers motion picture-quality views of ``Roseanne.'' The test center is to recommend the winning system to the FCC in the fall of 1992. In a simulcast system, a TV station would broadcast its regular TV signal on one channel and the same program on another channel in high-definition _ for instance, the regular signal on channel 9 and the high-definition signal on channel 12. Commission engineers believe there are enough unused channels so that most broadcasters would be able to adopt simulcast HDTV systems. Augmentation systems, on the other hand, also use two channels, but use the second channel to provide a signal that, when combined in the TV set with the regular signal on the first channel, yields the high-definition picture. Of the nine companies or groups planning to offer HDTV systems for testing, only one proposed an augmentation-type approach, and the proposal has been scrapped, said Peter Fannon, executive director of the test center. That proposal was the ACTV-2 system from the David Sarnoff Research Center, Thomson Consumer Electronics and NBC. The proposal was killed earlier this year when Sarnoff joined forces with another HDTV proponent, Philips Consumer Electronics Co. The New York Institute of Technology also has said it wanted to submit an augmentation system, but it had not come up with the money to do so, Fannon said. ``In making this determination, we are aware of the fact that augmentation-type systems could also provide a quality high-definition television service,'' Sikes said. ``However, we find that the substantial spectrum availability and utilization problems that selection of an augmentation-type system would entail indicates that further testing of such systems is not warranted. ... In our judgment the interests of the public will be better served by selecting a simulcast system.'' Sikes also said the commission was committed to first adopting a transmission standard for full high-definition television and then, if necessary, considering so-called enhanced-definition that would today's signals without achieving true HDTV. The commission has said previously that any HDTV system it selects for U.S. transmissions must be compatible with the existing TV system to avoid making every TV set in the nation obsolete. Fannon said Wednesday's decision leaves eight entrants in the testing program. Five have already been certified: Sarnoff-Philips; an analog simulcast system from Philips; Zenith Electronics Corp.; and the narrow MUSE and MUSE-6 systems from the Japan Broadcasting Corp. Three others need to complete the certification process by June or lose their test slots: Faroudja Laboratories of Sunnyvale, Calif.; Production Services Inc. of Tucson, Ariz.; and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. The Faroudja, ACTV and MUSE 6 systems provide an enhanced-definition signal that removes some of the ghosts and squiggles that mar today's systems. Entrants will be required to put up $175,000 toward actual test costs, which Fannon said would reach $12 million and $15 million. The test program is being financed by the television and electronics industries.

DOC.HEAD: USDA Defends Food Sent To Reservations ^With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Indians complain the canned meat sent to reservations swims in fat and smells like dog food, but government cooks on Wednesday whipped up a tasting party to show what wonders a little barbecue sauce could work. Government commodities are ``wholesome, nutritious and widely accepted,'' Betty Jo Nelsen, administrator of Agriculture Department's food and nutrition service, said at a tasting party for reporters, where USDA cooks laid out a spread of stews, barbecue and baked meats. The palatable if somewhat bland dishes in no way resembled some noxious-smelling USDA meat that House Hunger Committee members displayed at a news conference earlier in the day. Committee Chairman Tony Hall, D-Ohio, charged that the canned beef and pork is unappealing and high in fat and sodium even though Indians suffer from high rates of diabetes and heart disease. An odor similar to that of dog food pervaded a small House hearing room after Hall spooned fat-covered clumps of ready-to-eat meat from USDA cans that were distributed to the Standing Rock Reservation in North Dakota. ``People shouldn't have to eat second-class food. We shouldn't feed them scraps and poor-quality scraps at that,'' Hall said. Hall and Rep. Byron Dorgan, D-N.D., called for a General Accounting Office investigation into the quality of the meat. Some Indian leaders have complained about the quality of the canned meat during recent congressional hearings and a recent GAO study of hunger on reservations in North Dakota and South Dakota. USDA officials contend that the 60 types of food they distribute, including canned fruit, egg mix and peanut butter, provide a balanced diet and are similar in quality to food sold in supermarkets. The food is distributed through USDA programs to 143,000 Indians and 271,000 women, children and elderly people each month. The canned beef and pork is covered with fat when it's opened because it's cooked in the can so that it can be stored without refrigeration, Nelsen said. The meat, which is inspected during and after processing, cannot contain more than 18 percent fat and usually has about 15 percent, she said. Ground beef, by comparison usually contains 20 percent to 30 percent fat, said Pat Daniel, an Agriculture Department nutrionist. The meat may be eaten directly from the can, but it's meant to be used in recipes with other ingredients like the stews or casseroles served to reporters, Nelsen said. An Agriculture Department aide opened a can of pork for reporters Wednesday afternoon that had only a faint odor. The meat had little flavor and a texture similar to canned tuna. ``It looks about as appealing as a chicken does when I bring it home from the market,'' Nelsen said. USDA officials, who did not attend Hall's news conference, had no explanation for the strong odor from the cans he opened except to suggest that the meat may have been left in storage too long. The meat is supposed to be used within a year, they said. Neal Flieger, a spokesman for the Hunger Committee, said the meat had been recently delivered to the Standing Rock Reservation from USDA and had a similar odor to numerous other cans the committee's staff has inspected. Hall, who has eaten some of the meat, said: ``It's not the kind of taste that makes you gag. But it's not pleasing. It's not good.'' Dorgan said he had not tasted it. ``I can't get past the smell,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: President Says It's Broccoli, and President Still Says To Hell With It
DOC.NOTE: EDs: ADDS 6 grafs with details on food bank getting broccoli; CORRECTS ``foodbank'' to two words throughout; adds byline
DOC.TEXT: President Bush stood firm Wednesday on his refusal to eat broccoli but applauded California growers' shipping 10 tons of the vegetable to feed the hungry in the nation's capital. ``I am not going to rethink my position,'' he said, laughing, on his way to his private quarters from the Oval Office. ``But Barbara was delighted to get the news.'' Bush has banned broccoli from Air Force One. His wife has lamented publicly in the past how difficult a time she has getting her husband to eat his vegetables. Bush, accompanied by friends from Texas, produced a news clipping about the southern California growers who packed a truck Tuesday with 10 tons of broccoli and sent it on its way to a Washington food bank. When a reporter asked if there was anything else that Bush did not like, the president laughed and replied, ``Yeah, but I don't want to get 10 tons of it!'' Two cartons of broccoli are reportedly earmarked for the White House, along with recipes offering some novel ways to serve it. The rest is to be distributed to soup kitchens, shelters and other non-profit organizations that feed the homeless and hungry. The growers are shipping their produce to the Capital Area Community Food Bank. Bush broke into laughter at the end of a White House ceremony on Tuesday when he encountered a produce lobbyist wearing a stalk of broccoli on his lapel. He told the lobbyist other people should eat broccoli _ if they like it. Bush's own taste runs more to pork rinds, taco salads and almost anything smothered in hot pepper sauce. Peter Lassen, food solicitor for the Capital Area Community Foodbank, said he was contacted by the California growers Monday after a news magazine reported the presidential ukase against broccoli. ``I got a call asking if we'd accept a shipment of broccoli as a good-natured protest to the president. I said sure we're be glad to have it,'' he said. A White House official contacted Lassen Tuesday and discussed a possible welcoming ceremony on Monday for the broccoli. ``They wanted to make sure it wasn't a hoax,'' said Lassen. He added, ``I don't know if the White House is going to go along with that yet.'' Lassen said his food bank isn't looking for any more broccoli shipments right now. ``We can handle (10 tons), but not much more than that because of the shelf life,'' said Lassen, whose bank distributes 3,000 tons of food a year.

DOC.HEAD: Authorities Investigate Sale of Convent as Nuns Leave for France
DOC.TEXT: Eight nuns moved to a castle in southern France after their convent was sold for $1.4 million, and police were investigating the religious order's purchase of racehorses and other property, a court official said Wednesday. Roman Catholic Church officials said the sale occurred without the bishop of Bruges' permission.
