He has excommunicated the convent's mother superior and the youngest of the eight nuns for failing to submit the convent's books for examination to the diocese and for refusing to let a church official enter the convent. Investigators have arrested the convent's financial director, Ronny Crab, 35, and charged him with swindling, abuse of trust, extortion and forgery. Police have uncovered unusual practices for a religious order, including the purchases of a Mercedes-Benz auto equipped with a bar, a farmhouse, racehorses and the dilapidated castle in Tarbes, France, where they are living, the court official said. The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said investigators had traveled to Tarbes, near Lourdes, to determine if the Poor Sisters of Clare agreed to the $1.4 million sale of the convent to a building corporation. The nuns left the same day, March 6, for the south of France, and the court official said. Authorities have sequestered th losses in an economy already beset by inflation, recession and unemployment. The rally and march took place on a warm first day of fall in this Southern Hemisphere nation of 32 million. Menem, 59, tried to avoid the strike, and an open break with organized labor, by offering a modest increase in public wages and doubling retirement pensions to about $80 a month. However, he said on Tuesday: ``They can stage a thousand strikes, but the economic plan is totally irreversible.'' Government officials say they have no choice but to reduce the budget because the printing of money by the Central Bank to finance the deficit fuels inflation, which soared 12,000 percent the past year, including 61 percent in February. For years, Argentina financed the fiscal deficit by borrowing abroad, but it can no longer do that because it stopped repaying its debt. It also sold bonds to Argentines, who stopped buying them after the government confiscated savings accounts last January. Meanwhile, the embattled director of the state telephone company threatened to cut off service to Congress if overdue bills aren't paid. ``They are being informed about how much they owe and when they have to pay,'' Maria Julia Alsogaray told reporters. Ms. Alsogaray has been heavily criticized for raising rates by about 2,300 percent since January. When the bimonthly bills started arriving last week, stunned Argentines said they could not pay, and outraged members of Congress demanded Alsogaray's resignation.

DOC.HEAD: Labor in Daylong Meetings to Form Israeli Government
DOC.TEXT: Shimon Peres said Wednesday that agreement was possible with a key ultra-Orthodox party following daylong talks his center-left Labor Party held with four left-wing and religious factions on forming a new government. The right-wing Likud bloc worked to block Peres' efforts to muster a majority in the 120-member Parliament. The negotiations came after President Chaim Herzog chose the 66-year-old Peres Tuesday night to form a Cabinet to replace the Likud-Labor coalition that fell on a parliamentary vote of no-confidence March 15. Peres told Israel Radio after meeting with the Agudat Israel Party that ``an agreement was emerging'' with it. The party has five seats in Parliament. By law, if Peres fails to build a coalition in six weeks, Likud could be named to try. But political analysts believed the momentum was in Peres' hands. Differences over peace moves brought down Likud Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's 15-month-old coalition. Shamir refused to accept a U.S. plan for starting an Israeli-Palestinian dialogue. Peres has already pledged that as premier he will accept the plan.

DOC.HEAD: ABC To Show Fewer Commercials in Premiere of New Series
DOC.TEXT: ABC said Wednesday it plans to show 20 percent fewer commercials when its new ``Twin Peaks'' series premieres as a two-hour special on April 8. The decision could cost the network up to $650,000. Spokeswoman Janice Gretemeyer said ABC had considered airing the special without commercials to draw attention to the series created by filmmaker David Lynch. But it decided that would have been too expensive, and opted instead to cut back on commercials, she said. The premiere will have 11 minutes and 12 seconds of commercials instead of the usual 14 minutes for Sunday movies. Richard Kostrya, an executive vice president of the J. Walter Thompson advertising agency, estimated that ABC's decision could cost the network from $600,000 to $650,000. The network did not provide an estimate. The usual number of commercials will be in place when the series begins its regular Thursday night run on April 12. As much as seven minutes of commercials are screened during one-hour dramas. The series, set in the Pacific Northwest, is described by ABC as a ``sometimes darkly common vision'' of commonplace things and events. Lynch is known for such dark works as the movie ``Blue Velvet.''

DOC.HEAD: Scotsman Says He's Selling Sand to the Saudis
DOC.TEXT: A Scottish farmer said Wednesday he is selling sand to Saudi Arabia even though that arid country is mostly desert. ``The Saudis have a lot of sand but it is the wrong shape,'' said the farmer, John Keddie. The Saudis want tons of Keddie's sand to use in filtration systems for water supplies and swimming pools. ``Their sand is too round. Ours is cuboid with the corners rubbed off. Ours is also very hard so it doesn't break down in the filters,'' said the farmer. Keddie grows oilseed rape and wheat on 600 acres at Alloa near the Forth River in southeast Scotland. He said he investigated the potential of his local sand two years ago and made his first sale of sand for glass-making when he found he could no longer make a living only by farming.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Says Publicity Won't Affect Trial
DOC.TEXT: The judge in the fraud case against Imelda Marcos expressed skepticism Wednesday that publicity would affect the trial, noting that similar negative press didn't prevent one-time Miss America Bess Myerson's acquittal. U.S. District Judge John F. Keenan made the comment in the second day of jury selection at the trial of Mrs. Marcos and Saudi financier Adnan Khashoggi. Outside the presence of would-be jurors, Mrs. Marcos' lawyer, Gerry Spence, told Keenan he was concerned about publicity. He read from a Daily News column about Mrs. Marcos headlined ``Last of the Red-Hot Evil Women.'' Spence quoted a passage that mentioned Mrs. Marcos as one of three ``famous female defendants'' along with hotel queen Leona Helmsley, convicted of tax evasion, and Miss Myerson, acquitted in a divorce-fixing conspiracy. Keenan said he doubted that news coverage would affect the Marcos trial outcome. Recalling the Myerson case, over which he also presided, Keenan said: ``They got terrible publicity ... they were all acquitted.'' Mrs. Marcos, 60, is accused of participating in the illegal transfer of more than $160 million from the Philippines treasury to buy New York real estate, and of defrauding banking institutions of an additional $165 million to finance the deals. Khashoggi is accused of helping Mrs. Marcos and her late husband, ex-Philippines President Ferdinand E. Marcos, who died in exile in Hawaii, conceal their ownership of the real estate. In the Philippines, about 1,500 Marcos supporters spat on and burned an American flag and an effigy of Uncle Sam in front of the U.S. Embassy on Wednesday to protest Mrs. Marcos' trial. Marcos supporters carried placards demanding ``Justice for Imelda'' and ``We love the Marcos family'' during the generally peaceful protest. Police stood guard in front of the seaside embassy compound in Manila but did not interfere. As on Tuesday, most of the potential jurors interviewed by Keenan had heard of the more than 1,000 shoes Mrs. Marcos left behind in the Philippines when her husband was ousted from power, but none said the shoes would affect their ability to be fair. ``I think many people own many pairs of shoes,'' said Carol Cross, a bookkeeper from Rockland County. Prospective jurors chosen for the jury pool included a postal clerk who had heard of Mrs. Marcos' shoe collection but who owned many shoes herself and a sanitation worker who doesn't follow world politics. One woman was disqualified when she said she didn't think the trial should take place, and ``certainly not in New York.'' Mrs. Marcos has maintained she is a Filipino citizen and should be tried in her homeland. A final panel of 12 jurors and six alternates is expected to be chosen next week. When asked during the lunch break what he thought about jury selection, Khashoggi said, ``I think it is a good way to get to know the American people.''

DOC.HEAD: President Elected By Aging Lawmakers; Opposition Demands Reform
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead to CORRECT Lee was elected president, sted re-elected, and penultimate graf `Lee Teng-hui' to ADD that he automatically assumed presidency after predecessor's death. Picks up last graf, `Lee is...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto TPE8
DOC.TEXT: President Lee Teng-hui was elected Wednesday by aging lawmakers who have not faced voters in more than 40 years while thousands of students demanding direct presidential elections protested for a sixth day. Student representatives met with Lee at his office Wednesday evening and said he made vague promises of political reform. Lee said earlier in a statement that he would not propose any changes before he is sworn in for a six-year term May 20. ``We don't quite agree with his promises, but we can accept them,'' said student leader Fan Yun, one of more than 50 representatives who met with the 67-year-old chairman of the ruling Nationalist Party. Lee was the only presidential candidate before the National Assembly, which is dominated by elderly deputies have not faced elections since the Communists drove them from mainland China in 1949. Lee received support from 641 of 688 National Assembly members who cast ballots at a suburban meeting hall. The other delegates cast invalid ballots. About 2,000 police officers in full riot gear stood guard. Hundreds of protesters tried to stop deputies on their way to the vote. One assemblyman was pulled from his car but appeared unharmed. A police officer was injured in a scuffle with the demonstrators. The crowd smashed windows of at least two cars. The Nationalist deputies, many in their 80s and 90s and in poor health, were frozen in office in support of the Nationalist claim to be the legitimate government of all China. Several voted from wheelchairs or used canes to walk to the ballot box. The opposition Democratic Progressive Party, whose 11 assemblymen were barred from voting because they refused to swear allegiance to the Nationalist government, questioned the legality of the election and urged Lee to quickly set a timetable for democratic reform. In a statement read to about 5,000 supporters Wednesday night, opposition leaders demanded direct presidential elections and the release of all political prisoners. About 6,000 university students pressed pro-democracy demands during a sit-in at a downtown park. Several thousand more people looked on as the students sang and danced under a huge replica of a wild lily, their symbol of freedom. Lee had said in a statement issued earlier he would ``devote my utmost endeavors to garner all forces to strive for constitutional democracy, economic progress and social stability in the coming six years.'' On Tuesday, Lee agreed to an emergency conference among Nationalist and opposition politicians to discuss changing the political system. Public pressure to disband the National Assembly has increased sharply in recent days, particularly after some deputies proposed increasing the assembly's powers and the salaries of its members. The election Wednesday marked the first time the National Assembly has been asked to choose as president someone outside the family that ruled Taiwan for four decades after the Nationalist retreat from mainland China. The assembly elected Chiang Kai-shek president five times and his eldest son, Chiang Ching-kuo, twice. The younger Chiang died in office in January 1988 shortly after he began a political liberalization program that included scrapping martial law after 38 years and abolishing a ban on opposition parties. Lee Teng-hui was the handpicked vice president of Chiang Ching-kuo and automatically assumed his post, finishing Chiang's term as president. Lee is the first native Taiwanese to head the government and ruling party and is regarded with suspicion by many of the Nationalist Old Guard, who believe he is not sufficiently committed to their dream of one day returning victoriously to rule the Chinese mainland.

DOC.HEAD: Victorious Democratic Movement in Moscow Not Sure of Next Step
DOC.TEXT: The loosely organized reform movement Democratic Russia that won control of the Moscow City Council this week has emerged split and confused, lacking a firm idea of what to do with its new power. The group faces enormous challenges in the Soviet capital, home to about 9 million people. Moscow's shops are empty, its streets are dirty and deteriorating, its air is filthy, historic buildings stand unrepaired and public transportation is overloaded. The problems facing the Muscovites are representative of those facing reformers who scored big in local run-off elections this week in the three large Slavic republics of the Soviet Union _ Russia, the Ukraine and Byelorussia. Originally held together by vague reformist ideas, Democratic Russia is now finding it hard to consolidate and work out a joint program of action. The first question is whether to stick together or split up. ``We came to this bloc from various groups because we all shared some democratic views,'' a councilman who gave his name as Fadeyev told about 150 activists Tuesday at a meeting at Moscow State University. ``But now, this stage is over. ... We see that there are Communists, Socialists, Social Democrats and even Christian Socialists among us. We do not need this totality anymore.''. Others said the group must stay united at any cost because a split would strengthen hard-core Communist Party bureaucrats who still hold many government posts. ``We must be united. The only hope of the old party apparatus is to cause a split among us,'' pleaded Sergei Sukhorukov, a councilman. According to the Moscow electoral commission, the alliance won 55 of Moscow's 65 seats in Russia's parliament in election runoffs in republics and municipalities this week. Democratic Russia also gained control of 263 seats in the 465-seat Moscow city council, ensuring itself a 60-percent majority. But it is unclear exactly what many of those new council members stand for. ``We did not use serious screening when we choose Democratic Russia candidates,'' Vladimir Krylovsky, chairman of a Moscow reformist voters' club, said in an interview. ``When it seemed to us that a candidate shared some of our views, we had to throw our support behind him.'' ``There will be much discord and wavering, but still, I see this as a victory.'' Among the few concrete steps the group took Tuesday was asking Moscow's prosecutor to investigate anti-Semitic leaflets that appeared during the elections and called Democratic Russia a ``United Jewish Front,'', and demanding local newspapers include party affiliation when identifying election winners. ``We shall decide the question of appointing a city prosecutor in accordance with whether he would be able to emerge with results before our decision,'' said radical economist Gavriil Popov, who presided at the meeting. ``Same with editors of local newspapers and TV shows.'' He read a draft manifesto that included promises of freedom of political and religious activity in Moscow, of a large-scale development program, plots of land near the city to build country houses for all who want them, as well as far-reaching plans to give government-owned apartments free to the residents. The gathering moved to debate the upcoming session of the city council, or Mossoviet. One member accused its executive council of working on the agenda without consulting Democratic Russia. But council deputy chairman Yuri Vinogradov denied it. ``I'm ready to talk at any opportunity, and today I decided to come upon my own initiative. We don't entertain any secret plans,'' he told the group. Popov, a parliament member, asked the gathering to appoint committees to work out the movement's platform, recommendations for immediate reforms in the city, and a declaration of intentions. ``For the first time in the history of our country since 1917, city council of Moscow, in its majority, will not be controlled by local Communist Party apparatus,'' the document stated. It never answered the question of what would follow.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Assures Polish Premier on Support for Current Borders
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after 5th graf, bgng: Bush played xxx to UPDATE with Mazowiecki toasts; picks up 6th graf pvs: Bush was...
DOC.TEXT: President Bush told Polish Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki on Wednesday his country's borders must not be altered by the reunification of Germany. Bush delivered his assurance at a sun-splashed ceremony at the White House welcoming Poland's first non-communist prime minister since World War II. After the pageantry, the two leaders talked privately for a half hour, and Bush invited Mazowiecki back for an unscheduled discussion Thursday. Mazowiecki also was being honored Wednesday night at a State Dinner. At the top of the agenda are Poland's fears that a reunified Germany might try to claim territory ceded to Poland by Germany after World War II. Moreover, Poland wants a greater role than it has been granted in international discussions about German reunification. Bush played down any disagreement over Polish participation in unification talks. ``We're really not that far apart,'' he told a reporter. Later, at a state dinner in his honor, Mazowiecki said, ``a need is emerging for a new structure ... to gradually free Europe of military rivalry and bring the two separated parts closer together.'' ``Reconciliation between nations is possible only when they do not fear either for their present or their future. For this reason, an important component of the building must be the recognition of the Polish border along the Oder-Neisse Rivers in the form of a treaty,'' said the prime minister. He praised the allied agreement that has ``guaranteed'' Poland a direct role in the talks on German unification. Bush, in his toast, said, ``All Americans agree that Poland's time has come and ... all our prayers are with you at this time of poland's rebirth.'' Bush was applauded by hundreds of people attending the welcoming ceremony when he declared, ``In any decisions affecting the fate of Poland, Poland must have a voice.'' The president said the world was undergoing turbulent changes, but that ``We see a new Europe in which the security of all European states _ and their fundamental right to exist secure within their present borders _ is totally assured.'' Bush said, ``America wants to see Poland succeed. We want to welcome Poland as a full partner in the community of nations. We want to see your people enjoy the fruits of free enterprise.'' Bush had telephoned West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl on Tuesday to press the U.S. position that Poland's current borders must be maintained in the German unification process. To the dismay of the United States, Poland also has said that, unlike its Eastern European neighbors, it wants Soviet troops to remain inside its territory, apparently out of concern about Germany. ``We are hopeful that it will not be necessary to have Soviet troops in Poland and we find it hard to believe that they really want that,'' White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said shortly before Mazowiecki arrived. ``The presence of Soviet troops is something that is a little surprising to us,'' Fitzwater said. ``We frankly don't think that will be necessary in the long run.'' Bush and Mazowiecki capped Wednesday's meeting by signing a treaty designed to spur U.S. investment in Poland's ailing economy. The agreement, the first U.S. economic treaty with any of the emerging democracies in Eastern Europe, provides internationally recognized protections and procedures for business transactions. Mazowiecki said Poland had sparked ``the process of democratic revolution across Eastern Europe. The victory of that revolution will, in a large measure, depend upon our success. ``Therefore,'' Mazowiecki said, ``we must succeed and I do believe that we will.'' Poland has expressed unhappiness with its role in meetings of the six nations that are discussing German reunification. The conference, consisting of East and West Germany, the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union, has agreed to invite Polish representatives when Poland's western borders are discussed. Mazowiecki has said he wants the United States to support Poland's demand for a signed treaty guaranteeing its borders before the two Germanys unite. Standing alongside Bush, Mazowiecki said, ``We have come from a country building a new democratic order. We have come from a country which wants to and can play a significant role in the new emerging order in Europe.'' However, he noted there are strains in the relationship. ``The time of the present crucial acceleration of history is also one in which partnership is being put to test,'' the prime minister said. Affirming U.S. reluctance to expand Poland's role in the six-nation talks, Assistant Secretary of State Raymond Seitz said the conference had ``a fairly restricted mandate. ... There are a variety of ways in which Poland can express itself on a variety of concerns.'' He said that while there may be some differences over procedures, ``We know what the border is. We regard that as a permanent border and there is nothing that is going to change our view.'' Bush and Mazoweicki hailed the investment treaty they signed. Bush called it ``a milestone on the road to a properous Poland and a stronger U.S.-Polish partnership.'' Mazoweicki said, ``The treaty offers a certain framework, and what needs to be done now is to fill it with contents.''

DOC.HEAD: Gardner Museum Re-opens to Public; Tipsters Calling On Megatheft
LaserPhoto BX11
DOC.TEXT: The FBI released composite drawings Wednesday of the two thieves who committed the art theft of the century at the Gardner Museum when they stole 11 priceless paintings and prints. Even before a $1 million reward was posted, tipsters began calling the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum and the FBI, hinting they knew where the artworks could be found, officials said. The public was allowed inside the museum Wednesday for the first time since the crime, with two of its looted rooms now behind police barricades. Two men, wearing police uniforms, talked their way into the museum early Sunday and made off with 11 paintings and prints by such artists as Rembrandt and Degas. They also swiped an ancient Chinese vase and a gilded eagle from a Napoleonic flag pole. The FBI composite drawings showed two white men in policemen's hats. One was depicted with gold wire-rimmed glasses, a strong jaw and was described as being in his late 20s to early 30s, with dark hair and eyes, medium build and 5-foot-7 to 5-foot-10. The other, shown with pronounced cheekbones, was thought to be in his early to mid-30s, with dark hair and eyes, 180 pounds and 6-feet or 6-foot-1. The composites showed both with mustaches and without because authorities believe they might have worn fake mustaches during the robbery. The items taken from what was the late Mrs. Gardner's personal collection are considered too well-known to be sold on the open market, and have been estimated to be worth hundreds of millions of dollars. The international auction houses, Sotheby's and Christie's, underwrote the $1 million reward Tuesday for safe return of the works. The FBI and the museum were fielding tips around the clock and deciding which might be the real thing. ``You're generally talking about thieves that are going to be in contact with others in criminal circles and that's where it generally comes from,'' said FBI agent Dennis O'Callaghan. He declined to comment on whether staff at the museum had been given lie detector tests, but said former employees were being questioned, a standard practice in such cases. Museum Director Anne Hawley said the museum, while hoping to get the pictures back, was also worried about what kind of damage might have occurred when they were removed from their frames. ``There's always a question of what happens to a painting when you roll it up. There can be flaking and chipping,'' she said. ``Paintings are like human beings and they have to be taken care of.'' While experts have suggested the thieves were selective in what they took, possibly indicating it was a commissioned crime, Hawley disagreed. ``I frankly don't think they were as knowlegeable about art,'' she said. ``I think they were knowledgeable about crime.'' Hawley said mong tipsters calling the museum included a woman who reached her Tuesday, claiming to have received an anonymous call from someone who claims to know where the works are. Hawley said the caller was a woman in the art community, outside Boston, whose name was known to her. She declined to identify her. The woman called asking how large the reward was one hour before the reward was announced.

DOC.HEAD: Voters Denounce Shopping Center's Junkyard Art, But Owners Says It Stays
DOC.TEXT: Voters in this Chicago suburb have made it official: they've seen enough of a 50-foot steel needle impaling eight cars and a companion piece of sculpture at a local shopping plaza. They urged scrapping of the used-car kebab, called ``Spindle,'' by a 2-to-1 margin and voted 3-to-1 to get rid of ``Big Bil-Bored,'' a 40-ton, 40-foot amalgam of television sets, radios, hair dryers and concrete. The owner says he's leaving them in place for now despite the results of Tuesday's advisory referendum, though he believes that ``in a public space I think the public has some rights.'' ``It was a very interesting referendum,'' said developer-art collector David Bermant, 70, of Rye, N.Y., who owns the shopping center and contributed his 1975 BMW to ``Spindle.'' Bermant said he has placed ``a couple hundred'' sculptures in shopping centers around the country without any problems from local critics. The works express a common theme _ ``taking the technical discoveries and scientific theories and the products of a technological society and translating them into aesthetic objects,'' he said in a telephone interview from his second home in Santa Barbara, Calif. ``This art form will endure,'' said Bermant. But ``Spindle'' was rejected by a vote of 5,512 to 2,450, and ``Big Bil-Bored,'' was put down 6,379 to 1,662 in this community of about 53,000. The $100,000 ``Spindle,'' by Los Angeles artist Dustin Schuler, has been in place a few months. ``Big Bil-Bored'' cost $25,000 10 years ago when he commissioned it from Los Angeles artist Nancy Rubins.

DOC.HEAD: Airport Teamsters Charged in Civil Racketeering Suit
DOC.TEXT: Federal authorities filed a $10 million civil racketeering lawsuit Wednesday against two Teamsters locals, charging that the Mafia has dominated the air freight business at Kennedy Airport for two decades. The lawsuit against Locals 295 and 851 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters alleges a 20-year pattern of labor racketeering involving extortion, illegal payoffs, securities fraud and obstruction of justice. It also names current and past union officials and associates of the Gambino and Lucchese crime families. Many of the defendants are either in jail or awaiting trial for organized crime activities. The suit seeks to recover some $10 million in illegal gains from 18 defendants, remove the mob's influence from the unions and force the selection of a court-appointed trustee to assume control of the two locals. The 150-plus page complaint names the leadership of the two unions and a number of reputed mobsters, including Anthony Guerrieri. He and reputed Gambino boss John Gotti were recently acquitted of assault charges in a shooting attack on a carpenters' union leader. U.S. Attorney Andrew J. Maloney said the air-freight business ``is particularly vulnerable because of the nature of the business _ time is of the essence. Any kind of a slowdown or a strike effectively puts them out of business.'' James M. Fox, assistant director in charge of the FBI's New York office, said organized crime has ``owned the air-freight business at JFK'' for decades. ``They accomplished this through extortion, bribery, security fraud and obstruction of justice,'' said Fox, speaking at a news conference with Maloney at the federal courthouse in Brooklyn where the lawsuit was filed. Maloney said the mob-controlled unions extorted payoffs through a number of means, including threatened and actual strikes and work slowdowns. The air freight forwarders, many of them now out of business, often found it cheaper and quicker to make cash payments to the unions rather than oppose them, Maloney said. More than half of the air freight coming into the United States passes through John F. Kennedy International Airport and the illegal activities pushed up air freight costs to consumers, the authorities said. No union officials were available to respond to the charges, according to people who answered the telephones at the locals' offices. Five weeks ago, the federal government sued three organized crime groups and six dockworkers' union locals, accusing the mob of exercising a decades-long stranglehold on the New York and New Jersey waterfront. The civil racketeering lawsuit claims that organized crime, including the Gambino family, has controlled the International Longshoreman's Association locals through murder, extortion, embezzlement of union funds and illegal labor payoffs.

DOC.HEAD: Stay Granted in Reuters-UPI Suit
DOC.TEXT: United Press International won a stay in federal appeals court Tuesday preventing Reuters from breaking a picture exchange contract between the two news services. U.S. District Judge Peter K. Leisure last week denied UPI's request for a preliminary injunction that would have forced Reuters to honor the contract pending trial. Leisure extended an earlier order barring Reuters from canceling the contract until Monday to allow UPI to appeal his decision on the injunction. On Tuesday, a three-judge panel of the 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals granted UPI a further stay, which means the contract stays in effect at least until the appeal is heard. Judge John Newman scheduled oral arguments for the week of April 16. The request for the injunction stemmed from a counterclaim made by UPI to a lawsuit filed by Reuters in U.S. District Court. The 10-year contract, which began in 1985, calls for UPI to supply Reuters with pictures from the United States, while Reuters provided UPI with pictures from other countries. UPI had sold its international phot service to Reuters. ``The main issue is the volume and quality of UPI pictures to Reuters has significantly declined and Reuters is entitled to break the contract,'' Robert Sugarman, attorney for Reuters, told the appeals court.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Opts Against Restrictions on Art Content
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 11th graf, bgng: Anne G. xxx to CORRECT spelling of Frohnmayer.
DOC.TEXT: WASHINGTON _ The Bush administration told Congress Wednesday it would not seek to control the content of art supported with federal tax dollars. The decision seemed sure to anger right-wing Republicans. Controversy over whether to restrict content of federally financed art received extensive publicity last year because of two photographic exhibits supported by money from the National Endowment for the Arts. One, by Robert Mapplethorpe, included depictions of sadomasochism and homoerotic acts. Another, by Andres Serrano, depicted a crucifix in a jar of urine. As a result, this year's spending bill contained restrictions, inspired by Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., on financing obscene works and gave a definition of obscene within limits set by the Supreme Court. The restrictions were good only for one year. In submitting legislation Wednesday to extend the existence of the arts endowment for another five years, starting Oct. 1, the Bush administration chose not to include ``content restrictions'' similar to those that apply this year. John F. Frohnmayer, chairman of the arts endowment, spelled out the administration's reasoning in testimony before the House Education and Labor subcommittee on post-secondary education. He said the content restrictions in effect this year caused ``much concern and confusion'' within the arts community. ``After much careful thought and discussion, it is our conclusion that the legislation proposed here which contains no content restrictions, along with measures discussed earlier, will best serve the American public,'' Frohnmayer said. The other measures mentioned by Frohnmayer include ways to improve the system for evaluating grants. The NEA will develop a ``grid'' to assure that all geographic areas are represented and that as many cultures as possible are represented. The makeup of the evaluation panels also will be diversified. ``Will these modifications in the panel process eliminate controversy?'' he asked. ``Probably not. I do not see as a desirable goal that the art which the federal government supports be so bland that no one even notices it.'' Anne G. Murphy, executive director of the American Arts Alliance, which opposes content restrictions, said she was pleased by Frohnmayer's comments but cautious about whether the administration will succeed in keeping NEA free of such restrictions. ``I think it's a first step in what is going to be a prolonged debate over the next six weeks,'' she said. Helms, in Raleigh, said he had asked the independent General Accounting Office to investigate whether the NEA is financing pornographic art. In a letter to Charles Bowsher, head of the GAO, Helms said Frohnmayer may be sincere in saying no NEA funds are being used to support obscene art. ``But the evidence to the contrary is so compelling that it is imperative that there be an objective investigation by an agency independent of the NEA,'' Helms wrote. The restrictions that Helms helped put in this year's law expressly forbid spending tax money on ``depictions of sadomasochism, homoeroticism, the sexual exploitation of children or individuals engaged in sex acts'' and materials that lack serious artistic value. Frohnmayer, in his testimony, condemned obscenity but also gave a long defense of freedom of expression. He criticized the religious fundamentalist groups, such as the 700 Club and the American Family Association, for spreading misinformation about the arts endowment. Defenders of the NEA say only 25 of 80,000 grants in the endowment's history have been controversial. Frohnmayer, a lawyer from Portland, Ore., said in an interview after his testimony that Bush personally opposed content restrictions although the president ``is very troubled with some of the images and we are certainly aware of avoiding the excesses on both sides.'' Frohnmayer said he opposed content restrictions because ``the original legislation for the NEA, the original concept for the arts endowment, is that it be free from political and content restrictions, and that is really required for creativity to flourish.''

DOC.HEAD: Former Oregon State Senate Head Dead at 61
DOC.TEXT: Jason Boe, a former four-term Oregon Senate president who dominated the Legislature during the 1970s, died following a heart attack at the age of 61. Boe died late Tuesday during emergency bypass surgery at Good Samaritan Hospital in Portland, hospital spokesman Chuck Williams said Wednesday. He had collapsed at his home in Portland, Williams said. Boe, a Democrat, served in the Oregon Legislature from 1965 to 1981. He first served three terms in the House and in 1970 was elected to the Senate. He was president of the Senate for a record four terms. He ran unsuccessfully for the U.S. Senate in 1974, and gave up his state senate seat in 1980 to run without success for treasurer. He also was a former president of the National Conference of State Legislatures. ``My goal was to pull the Legislature into the 20th century, and I think we have done that,'' Boe said in a 1979 interview. ``I was deeply saddened to learn of the passing of one of Oregon's most powerful and influential leaders,'' Gov. Neil Goldschmidt said Wednesday. ``The guy was incredible,'' said state Treasurer Tony Meeker, a Republican senator during Boe's tenure. ``He knew how to make the process work.'' At the time of his death, Boe owned an international consulting firm on government affairs, Jason Boe & Associates Inc., with offices in Taiwan and Korea. Boe is survived by his wife, Kathryn; three sons, a brother and two grandsons.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Rejects Helms Effort Asking Bush To Recognize Lithuania
DOC.NOTE: EDs: ADDS two grafs on earlier letter from House members.
DOC.HEAD: With BC-Senate-Lithuania roll Call a0760
DOC.TEXT: The Senate rejected, 59-36, a resolution Wednesday night urging President Bush to grant immediate diplomatic recognition to the breakaway government of Lithuania. The sponsor, Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., attempted to attach the resolution to unrelated legislation. But he failed in his attempt, a symbolic criticism of the administration's caution over Lithuania's attempt to secede from the Soviet Union. Democrats helped Republican leaders in the opposition to the Helms proposal. Voting in favor of the resolution were 27 Republicans and just nine Democrats. Opposed were 44 Democrats and 15 Republicans. Senate Republican Leader Bob Dole of Kansas told colleagues the White House opposed the resolution yet predicted, wrongly, that it would pass. ``The matter should be left to the president,'' Sen. John Chafee, R-R.I., said in support of Dole. ``All it can do is create mischief,'' said Sen. Dale Bumpers, D-Ark. Lithuania's parliament declared independence from the Soviet Union on March 11 and its fledgling government has been seeking recognition from other nations. Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev, however, has declared the indepenence decree illegal. Though Gorbachev has said he would not use force, Soviet troops have been conducting exercises in the area, and Gorbachev on Wednesday issued a directive to Lithuanians to turn in their firearms. Lithuania was one of the provinces of the Russian Czar before the 1917 Bolshevik revolution. It was able to establish its independence, along with the neighbiring Baltic states of Estonia and Latvia, in the turmoil that followed the revolution, indepedence its maintained until the Soviet Army invaded the country in 1940 and attached it to the Soviet Union. The United States never withdrew diplomatic recognition from the 1940 government, and the Lithuanian community in the United States has maintained a legation, with full diplomatic standing, ever since. The White House has declined to recognize the current government although it has urged the Soviet Union to honor the will of the Lithuanian people and refrain from using force. The administration's refusal of recognition has widely been attributed to reluctance on the part of the White House to be seen opposing Gorbachev, whom it considers the best hope for progress in the Soviet Union and who is under pressure from several directions. The ``sense of the Senate'' resolution offered by Helms would not have been binding. Such symbolic resolutions are frequent. Helms congratulated Bush for urging Moscow to begin talks with the Lithuanian people but then called on the administration to recognize the breakaway governmenet and name a U.S. ambassador to Lithuania. More than 100 members of the House earlier sent Bush a letter urging that Lithuania be recognized as an independent nation. ``All the Lithuanians ask for is moral and political support,'' said the letter drafted by Reps. John Miller, R-Wa., and Richard Durbin, D-Ill.

DOC.HEAD: Ala. Town Caked In Mud Tries To Clean Up, Flooding Continues In Florida
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 2 grafs to UPDATE with presidential declaration; picks up at 2nd graf, `Some central ...' SUBS 7th graf, ``A building ...,'' with 3 grafs to UPDATE with Red Cross survey of Elba damage, repairs to levee.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto XEN1
DOC.TEXT: Flooding rivers receded Wednesday in most of Alabama and some evacuees returned to homes and businesses, while Florida officials worked to evacuate people remaining in the path of rising water. President Bush declared parts of southeast Alabama a major disaster area Wednesday night, making individuals and local governments in Coffee County, including hard-hit Elba, eligible for federal grants and low-interest loans. The White House said other areas may be designated for assistance later. Some central Georgia cities along swollen waterways began to recover from flooding Wednesday, but cities in the southern part of the state were told to prepare for their share of problems. Flooding in the Florida Panhandle had already forced evacuation of almost 2,200 people, and state officials predicted more than 1,700 of them might have to remain out of their homes for several days. Many of the 2,000 evacuees from hard-hit Elba, Ala., returned while emergency crews tried to restore clean water, power and telephone lines to the mud-caked city. For some, the return five days after up to 16 inches of rain fell was devastating. ``There's three generations of antiques and family heirlooms in there,'' Becky Hayes said as she stood outside a mud-covered warehouse her family owns near Elba's town square. ``Now it's all upside down like scrambled eggs.'' Gene Malfer, a spokesman for the American Red Cross, said the organization estimated that 239 homes in Elba were destroyed, 286 suffered major damage and about 70 had minor damage. A building sat in the middle of an intersection where it was left by high water from the Pea River that poured over a broken levee early Saturday. Vehicles at a used-car dealership were piled on top of each other. Allen Morse of the Army Corps of Engineers, who is overseeing the levee rebuilding process, said the first priority is temporarily filling four breaks in the Elba levee because of the likelihood of more rain. He said permanent repairs could take 30 days in ideal conditions. The flooding was blamed for 11 deaths in Alabama. Traffic was backed up as evacuees headed into Elba, slowed by National Guard soldiers who set up identification checkpoints to allow in only those with homes and businesses in the flood-ravaged area. However, numerous sightseers apparently got by the barriers, forcing officials to evacuate the town for a few hours to clear the streets. A gas leak at a high school also prompted a brief evacuation from the school. Most homes outside Elba's levee had power, but fresh water was being trucked in as health officials advised against drinking city water. The local high school and middle school, which were completely covered by water over the weekend, still had several inches of water inside Wednesday. But around the Coffee County Courthouse square nothing was left but gooey red mud. Water also had covered the first floor of the courthouse, where probate, child-support, criminal and civil records are stored. ``We don't know to what extent the records are salvagable,'' said Allen Tapley of the state Administrative Office of the Courts. Tapley said records of about one-third of Alabama's court systems have been placed on microfilm, mostly in urban areas. Elba, though, still keeps most of its records on paper. The worst of Florida's flooding came along the Choctawhatchee River as water from last week's rain flowed downhill from Alabama and Georgia. Hardest hit was the farming community of Caryville, where emergency official Rod Westall said the Choctawhatchee was ``beginning to recede, but not by very much. Caryville will not be out from under water until probably Sunday.'' The Choctawhatchee crested near Caryville at 9.2 feet above flood stage late Tuesday but was still about 8.9 feet above flood stage Wednesday, said Westall. Caryville usually has a population of about 600. This week chickens roosted in trees and a swarm of fire ants floated through the middle of town. ``The Choctawhatchee River south of Caryville is still rising,'' said Westall. ``There's not much down there ... but there are some people, fish camps, weekend cabins ... there's not a lot of people.'' Some residents refused to leave their homes, including Willard Bailey, 56, a semi-retired mechanic from Caryville. He was living in a houseboat that was tied to his house, sitting in 5 feet of water. ``I built it a couple of years ago ... never put it in the river,'' Bailey said as he maneuvered another, smaller, boat through city streets. ``The river came to it. The river floated it off the trailer.'' In Macon, Ga., the Ocmulgee River began to recede and officials said preliminary tests showed no contamination of the city-county water supply from flooding. However, residents were asked to boil water or drink bottled water as a precaution. The Oconee River at Dublin, Ga., was expected to crest during the night at 27 feet, 6 feet above flood stage. ``Flooding of a low-lying trailer park and much farm and pastureland, as well as river access roads, can be expected in Laurens County and Dublin with this crest,'' the National Weather Service said.

DOC.HEAD: 10 Contras Reported Killed in Nicaragua Fighting
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 14 grafs to UPDATE with fighting, talks, U.S. delegation to arrive. Picks up 8th, `The rhetoric ...
DOC.TEXT: The Defense Ministry said Wednesday about 200 Contras attacked Sandinista troops in northern Nicaragua and 10 of the rebels were killed in the fighting. A ministry news release said the fighting took place Tuesday near Ubu Norte, 110 miles north of Managua in Matagalpa province. It gave no details other than to accuse another Contra group of rustling 400 head of cattle in central Chontales province. Three regional Contra commanders meanwhile were reported meeting with army officers in the Chontales capital of Juigalpa to discuss rebel demobilization in that area before President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro's government is inaugurated April 25. Rebel commanders Tirso Moreno, Cesar Chavarria and Diogenes Hernandez met for the second day with an army group headed by Lt. Col. Cesar Delgadillo, a local commander, ``to plan demobilization of the rebels in the 5th Military Region,'' a military source said, speaking on condition of anonymity. The source refused to give details of the talks. About 5,000 Contra fighters, out of a total of 12,000, are believed to be in the 5th Military Region area. The rest are in base camps in neighboring Honduras. On Thursday, a U.S. delegation is due in Managua to discuss U.S. assistance with Chamorro advisers to jump-start Nicaragua's economy, almost paralyzed by U.S. sanctions, 10 years of leftist Sandinista rule and the Contra war. A Foreign Ministry announcement said the delegation is led by Joseph Sullivan, undersecretary of state for inter-American affairs. Senior officials of President Daniel Ortega's outgoing administration will receive immunity from prosecution for official acts while in office under a new law passed by the National Assembly. Ortega proposed the law and it was approved Tuesday, designed to protect Sandinista party members from legal action by the new Chamorro administration. The measure also provides a lifetime pension for Ortega and Vice President Sergio Ramirez. Mrs. Chamorro, running on the United National Opposition coalition ticket, beat Ortega in Feb. 25 general elections. The two sides are negotiating a transfer of power, with the Sandinistas swearing to defend ``the gains of the revolution'' that brought them to power in 1979. ``If the peaceful transfer of power and national reconciliation are not achieved, it's legitimate to protect those who have propelled the social, economic and judicial transformations that now benefit most of the people,'' National Assembly President Carlos Nunez said. During the campaign, both UNO and Sandinista candidates promised to make their opponents ``pay the bill'' for past misdeeds. The Sandinistas accused UNO of being in league with U.S.-backed Contras who brought civil war to Nicaragua; UNO said the Sandinistas brought repression and economic misery. The rhetoric largely disappeared after Mrs. Chamorro won, but both sides still fear vengeance or resistance by the other. The Sandinista-controlled legislature approved the measure, 83-4. The law spells out that ``none of the highest members of state can be subject to any judicial action'' in Nicaraguan courts. ``The law is necessary to calm the waters and so that we can direct all our efforts to national reconstruction and getting the country out of crisis,'' Nunez said. The law guarantees officials immunity from prosecution for official actions in the six years since the outgoing administration's election in 1984. Those provided with permanent immunity are the president, vice president, ministers and deputy ministers, Supreme Court judges, the Supreme Electoral Council, appeals court judges, the army commander-in-chief and chief of staff, and ``presidents or directors of autonomous or government entities.'' Former National Assembly members receive one year of immunity under the law.

DOC.HEAD: Singer Needs Surgery For Crash Injury
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to RECAST lead, UPDATE that two vertebrae broken, sted one, edit; picks up 8th graf, `She's not ...' Estefan pronounced es-teh'-fahn.
DOC.HEAD: Laserphotos WX24,NY57
DOC.TEXT: Singer Gloria Estefan faces surgery Thursday and will need three to six months of recovery for two broken vertebrae suffered when her bus was rammed by a truck, doctors said Wednesday. The 32-year-old star of the Latin-pop Miami Sound Machine, known for her energetic dancing on stage, had some numbness and weakness in her legs, and a slim possibility of paralysis remained, surgeons said. Two vertebrae just above the waist were fractured and dislocated, a serious spinal injury, said Dr. Michael Neuwirth, the orthopedic surgeon who is to perform the operation at the Orthopedic Institute Hospital for Joint Diseases. The operation is needed to realign the vertebrae, two of the 33 bones of the spinal column, and fuse the spine so it won't move and damage the spinal cord, according to Dr. Harry Schmaltz of the Community Medical Center in Scranton, Pa. Miss Estefan was taken by helicopter Wednesday afternoon from the medical center to the Orthopedic Institute. Doctors at the Orthopedic Institute said at a news conference that two metal rods would be inserted into the fractured vertebrae in the operation. ``Her prognosis is excellent for a return to normal function,'' Neuwirth said. ``She's not going to do much in the way of entertaining for three to six months,'' Schmaltz said in Scranton. ``It's a very serious injury and it's going to keep her out of commission for quite a while.'' Schmaltz said the singer will have to wear a device to restrict her movement during recovery. ``She's in a lot of pain, but her spirits are up,'' said Miss Estefan's sister, Becky Fajardo.``She's looking forward to the operation as soon as she's feeling better. It's been tough on the family. But we're doing pretty well.'' Miss Estefan and the group were headed to Syracuse, N.Y., for a Tuesday night concert. The accident occurred about noon on westbound Interstate 380 near Tobyhanna in the Pocono Mountains in eastern Pennsylvania. Estefan was thrown from a couch where she was sleeping when a truck hit the bus, which was stopped because of a jackknifed tractor-trailer. The driver of the truck that struck the bus was cited for driving at an unsafe speed. Estefan's husband, Emilio, 37, was treated for head and hand injuries and their 9-year-old son, Nayab, broke his collarbone. Both were released. Miss Estefan's personal assistant, Barbara Arencibia, 25, remained in the Scranton hospital Wednesday with a back injury, and was listed in stable condition. Before she was transferred to New York, fans flooded the hospital switchboard and sent flowers and notes to the Cuban-born singer. Elton John sent flowers, and the well-wishers who called included Madonna, Bruce Springsteen, Jon Bon Jovi, John Denver, Ryan O'Neal and Frankie Avalon, associates said. President Bush, who met the singer Monday to discuss her anti-drug work, had talked to the singer twice since she arrived at the hospital. Miss Estefan was nominated in February for best pop vocal performance by a female for the single ``Don't Wanna Lose You'' in the Grammy awards. Her new album, ``Cuts Both Ways,'' a collection of dance songs and ballads, was 26th on the Cashbox magazine pop chart last week. Miss Estefan and Miami Sound Machine have attracted listeners worldwide with the sounds of salsa, samba and conga for more than a decade. Their hits include ``Rhythm Is Gonna Get You'' and ``Anything for You.''

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Increases Pressure to Stop Lithuanian Independence
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS two grafs after 22nd pvs, `But Lithuanian' with 100 congressmen urging Bush to recognize Lithuania, minor editing to conform. Picks up 25th pvs, `A group...'
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev increased pressure on the breakaway Lithuanian republic Wednesday by ordering its citizens to turn in their guns and telling the KGB to strengthen controls on the republic's border. In a decree certain to heighten tension between Lithuania and the Kremlin, Gorbachev also temporarily banned the sale of firearms in Lithuania and said those citizens who do not surrender weapons within a week will have them confiscated. Lithuanian President Vytautus Landsbergis, in a statement distributed by aides at the Supreme Council legislature, said Gorbachev's directive ``amounts to claiming the non-existent and unjustified sovereignty of a powerful country over a small and unarmed neighbor.'' ``It could be enforced only by brutal military force,'' he said. ``The ghost of Stalinism is walking in the Kremlin, and the shadow of it lies far to the west (in Lithuania),'' Landsbergis said. But he predicted that Lithuania would remain ``serene and united.'' Premier Kazimira Prunskiene of Lithuania told reporters in Vilnius her government still was counting on negotiations with Moscow on the republic's declaration of independence March 11. ``We are not getting too worked up about this,'' she said. ``We hope common sense will prevail.'' Gorbachev has proclaimed the declaration of independence invalid, but Lithuania refuses to recognize his authority. In issuing the decree, Gorbachev used powers given him when he was elected to the new, more powerful presidency last week. ``The decree demands that citizens living in Lithuania turn all their firearms in to temporary police custody within the next seven days,'' the Tass news agency said. He directed the Interior Ministry ``in the event of citizens' refusal to turn in these weapons, to ensure their confiscation.'' Gorbachev said despite previous directives from the Kremlin, ``the Lithuanian parliament and government continue passing bills that violate the rights of Soviet citizens and the sovereignty of the U.S.S.R.'' Access to firearms is severely restricted in the Soviet Union, and it is unknown how many weapons might be in the hands of Lithuania residents. Lithuanians have begun signing up for voluntary defense service, and some Lithuanians serving in the Soviet armed forces have deserted. Gorbachev previously said he expected to talk with Lithuanian leaders about the declaration of independence, and senior officials have said the Kremlin does not intend to use force to bring the Baltic republic back into the Soviet fold. The White House reacted ``with concern'' to the latest developments. ``It's a matter that we are watching seriously,'' said presidential press secretary Marlin Fitzwater. Gorbachev demanded that national and local governments ensure that Soviet law and the rights of citizens be observed and called for KGB border troops to increase security on Lithuania's section of the Soviet border. It ordered the government to ``tighten control over issuance to foreigners of visas and permission to visit Lithuania.'' That move apparently was aimed at many ethnic Lithuanians, who have returned recently to help set up an independent government and market economy in the republic. Lithuania's parliament voted overwhelmingly March 11 to break away from the Soviet Union and regain the independence it had before being forcibly annexed by the Kremlin in 1940, along with the other Baltic republics of Estonia and Latvia. Those republics have since elected parliaments dominated by pro-independence legislators but have not declared independence. A draft law outling requirements for secession passed its first legislative hurdle in Moscow on Wednesday. Deputies said the secession procedure, which requires a republic-wide referendum and a transition period of up to five years, would have to be observed by Lithuania. But Lithuanian legislator Vaidotas Antanaitis said it did not affect his republic. ``The bill doesn't apply to us, we've already left,'' he said. On Capitol Hill in Washington, meanwhile, more than 100 congressmen sent President Bush a letter Wednesday urging that Lithuania be recognized as an independent nation. ``All the Lithuanians ask for is moral and political support,'' said the letter drafted by Reps. John Miller, R-Wa., and Richard Durbin, D-Ill. On Tuesday night, the republic sent a telegram to the Kremlin complaining about increased activity of Soviet soldiers stationed on its territory. ``The people of Lithuania are deeply disturbed about the actions of the Soviet armed forces: the intense mobilization of armored vehicles and tanks, the intensified flights of military air force planes, and unauthorized sorties into Lithuanian territory by paratroopers involved in intelligence activities,'' said Prunskiene, the Lithuanian premier, in the cable to Gorbachev. A group of Soviet deputies Wednesday complained that Lithuania was planning legislation that ``subjects to summary judgment Soviet citizens speaking out for preservation of the existing government structure and the governmental unity of our country,'' Tass reported. The Interfax news service of official Radio Moscow reported that the legislation would permit a sentence of up to three years for ``calls for the forcible violation of the sovereignty or territorial integrity of the Lithuanian republic, or for the overthrow of the lawful authorities.'' A senior Lithuanian legislator, Romualdas Ozolas, confirmed in an interview that such legislation exists, but suggested that the Lithuanian parliament will not approve it. ``Such stupidity will get us nowhere,'' he said of the proposal. The Soviet deputies, whose group is called Soyuz, appealed to Gorbachev to use the new powers of the presidency to impose direct rule on Lithuania, Tass said.

DOC.HEAD: Campbell on Hugo Recovery: Expensive and Slow, But Progressing
DOC.TEXT: Six months after Hurricane Hugo, South Carolina's timber industry faces major fire threats and a long recovery, but tourism and other state industries are rebounding, Gov. Carroll Campbell said Wednesday. ``South Carolinians and South Carolina deserve the comeback of the year award,'' Campbell said in releasing a report on relief efforts since the storm. Though much of the state has returned to normal, 10,000 people still are displaced, and economic impacts on most state industries will be felt for at least another year, Campbell said. The report was released in the same conference room where Campbell and other top aides coordinated emergency efforts as the storm roared ashore near Charleston on Sept. 21 with 135-mph winds and storm surges reaching 15 feet. The storm left 29 dead and $5.9 billion in damage in South Carolina. ``This thing was a monster,'' Campbell said. Since the storm, about $200 million in state and federal funds have been set aside for local and state governments to rebuild public structures and pay such costs as overtime for cleanup workers. About another $200 million has been or will be distributed through private and public agencies in affected areas. An eight-member Economic Recovery Commission appointed by the governor is scheduled to present recommendations next week. Campbell said tourism has come back strongly, with inquiries running at a record pace and traffic at state travel information centers up 12 percent from a year ago. But the timber industry will take much longer to recuperate, Campbell said, though he offered no timetable. According to the report, 23 weeks of harvesting have brought timber salvage efforts to 41 percent of their goal of 625 million cubic feet. The danger of fire, though, has prompted the state Forestry Commission to hire an additional 100 firefighters and to arrange for seven more firefighting aircraft. ``The forest fire problem may well be the greatest danger that we still have to face,'' Campbell said. He gave no indication when a 13-member panel reviewing emergency management would present its report. But he suggested local officials needed more training, federal officials could offer more support, and coastal buildings need to follow strict building codes. ``The biggest problem we had ... was some local officials that didn't know what to do, or didn't know what the government's role was and what their role was,'' he said. ``I guess you can call it apathy,'' he added. ``Nothing happens for a long time, so you sort of sit there.'' He said neither state officials nor federal officials were prepared for a disaster as large as Hugo, which resulted in disaster assistance to 24 of the state's 46 counties.

DOC.HEAD: Sulfur Odor Closes Delco Elementary School
DOC.TEXT: A sulfur odor permeating an elementary school and learning center sickened hundreds of pupils and teachers Wednesday, forcing officials to cancel classes and to close the buildings through the weekend. ``It was bad. I had watery eyes ... a headache,'' said Paul Blanford, principal of the Marcus Hook Elementary School and Chichester Learning Center southwest of Philadelphia. He said investigators will spend the next several days trying to determine the source of the odor that forced out 420 children, 28 teachers and 15 support staff members. The school buildings have been plagued by recurring odors for more than two years. The school was closed for a short period in 1988, but an investigation by an industrial hygiene firm could not determine the source of that odor. An investigative task force appointed by the Chichester school board includes representatives from Sun Co. Inc. and British Petroleum Co. Ltd., which have refineries in the area. Oil companies in the area have agreed to finance 85 percent of an environmental study, Blanford said. The exact cost of the study has not been determined, he said. The task force was to begin taking air samples Thursday, Blanford said. ``It comes and goes,'' Blanford said. ``This time I think it was worse.'' Parents attended a school board meeting Tuesday night to complain about the smell. ``My son John ... has been experiencing severe headaches and chest pains ... the severity of them combined with the headaches has me most concerned,'' Grace Taylor told the board.

DOC.HEAD: Navigation Satellite Launch Scrubbed
DOC.TEXT: The Air Force late Wednesday scrubbed the launch of a Delta 2 rocket carrying a $65 million navigation satellite because of strong upper-atmosphere winds, a spokeswoman said. It was the second time in as many days the launch from Cape Canaveral Air Force Station was postponed. The decision not to launch came about 15 minutes before the scheduled liftoff around 10 p.m. EST, said Sgt. Ivey Paige. The McDonnell Douglas Corp. rocket had been scheduled for liftoff Tuesday night, but was postponed a day for data analysis and testing of the launch vehicle, said Air Force spokeswoman Terri Brasher. The payload is the seventh in a series of advanced Navstar satellites launched in the past year from Cape Canaveral. By 1992, the Air Force plans to have 21 of the spacecraft orbiting the Earth to form a global network.

DOC.HEAD: Earthquake Measuring 6.7 Rocks New Zealand's North Island
DOC.TEXT: An earthquake measuring 6.7 on the Richter scale and centered 800 miles northeast of here rocked parts of New Zealand's North Island before dawn Thursday, scientists said. The earthquake, which struck just before 5 a.m. in the Kermadec Islands, was felt in Wellington and several North Island cities, but caused no damage or injuries. A spokesman for New Zealand's Department of Scientific and Industrial Research said the Kermadecs, which run along the edge of a fault line in the South Pacific, are inhabited only by a small group of New Zealand scientists, none of whom were injured. ``It woke us up but didn't shake things off shelves,'' said scientiest Stephen Mann. He said the quake lasted about 30 seconds. The Richter scale is a gauge of the energy released by an earthquake, as measured by the ground motion recorded on a seismograph. A quake of magnitude 7 is considered a major earthquake, capable of widespread, heavy damage in a populated area.

DOC.HEAD: White House `Watching Seriously' After Moscow Orders Arms Confiscation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 4th graf, bgng: He called xxx to UPDATE with president's response to questions on Lithuania; SUBS 5th graf pvs, bgng: But, after xxx and 9th graf pvs, bgng: In another xxx to conform.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Lithuania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The White House, citing a Soviet promise not to use force in Lithuania, reacted ``with concern'' Wednesday to reports that Mikhail S. Gorbachev had ordered all arms confiscated in the rebellious republic. ``It's a matter that we are watching seriously,'' said presidential press secretary Marlin Fitzwater. Fitzwater earlier Wednesday welcomed assurances by Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze that Moscow would not intervene with force to block independence in Lithuania. He called Shevardnadze's statements ``very, very helpful'' and said the United States would take the Soviets ``at their word.'' On Wednesday night, President Bush, speaking to reporters at a state dinner at the White House, was asked if he felt reassured about how the Soviets were handling the Lithuanian situation. ``I am _ only because they restated their views on peaceful resolution'' of the impasse, the president said ``It is highly complicated. I'm not suggesting it's easy, but I see no reason to question what they've said.'' But, after news of the arms crackdown, the president's spokesman said, ``We hope that the statements of the foreign secretary yesterday are the course they intend tomorrow.'' Asked if the administration viewed an edict to turn in arms as tantamount to the use of Soviet force, Fitzwater said, ``I don't want to give it that kind of definition.'' ``We don't have enough information'' to react to the development more specifically, he said. A directive from Gorbachev read on the evening television program ``Vremya'' said the Soviet Interior Ministry should confiscate guns from anyone who refused to turn them in to Soviet authorities. In another development, the Senate rejected, 59-36, a resolution that would have urged Bush to grant immediate diplomatic recognition to the new government of Lithuania. The Soviet president's edict gave Lithuanians seven days to comply. ``We view these press reports with concern. We continue to urge dialogue between both sides,'' Fitzwater said. ``We note that as late as yesterday, Foreign Minister Shevardnadze reaffirmed the Soviet commitment to resolve the issue through peaceful means.'' Shevardnadze gave the no-force assurance to Secretary of State James A. Baker III in Africa on Tuesday. Lithuania declared independence on March 11. Gorbachev and the Soviet Congress have declared the move illegal. On Capitol Hill, meanwhile, more than 100 congressmen sent Bush a letter urging that Lithuania be recognized as an independent nation. ``All the Lithuanians ask for is moral and political support,'' said the letter drafted by Reps. John Miller, R-Wa., and Richard Durbin, D-Ill.

DOC.HEAD: Company Pleads Guilty, Agrees to Fine
DOC.TEXT: Raytheon Co. said it has pleaded guilty to a charge of illegally using classified Defense Department budget and planning documents and has agreed to pay a $1 million fine. Raytheon became the fifth defense contractor to plead guilty to trafficking in classified Pentagon documents. The documents may have given companies an advantage over competitors in bidding for government contracts. ``This matter involved conduct more than five years ago,'' Larry McCracken, a Raytheon spokesman, said Tuesday. ``It was contrary to company policy then, and it is contrary to company policy now, and it was done without the knowledge of any company director or officer,'' he said. The other companies that pleaded guilty were Boeing, the Hughes Aircraft unit of GM Corp., Grumman Corp., and the RCA unit of the General Electric Co. Their fines ranged from $2.5 million to $5.5 million. ``We believe the lower amount of the fines we had reflects our somewhat secondary involvement in the matter,'' McCracken said.

DOC.HEAD: Dutch Government Parties Lose in Municipal Elections
DOC.TEXT: Both parties in Premier Ruud Lubbers' center-left government lost in municipal elections Wednesday in the coalition's first electoral test since coming to power in November. The vote in 607 towns and cities brought big gains for the opposition D'66 party and the Green Left, members of a left-wing, three-party alliance that includes the Communist Party of the Netherlands. The results, and an unusually low turnout, reflected voter dissatifaction with the slow-paced beginning to Lubbers' third term. The biggest loser was the Labor Party of Deputy Premier Wim Kok, who said on Dutch Television the result showed ``voter impatience'' with the lack of left-wing policies initiated by the new government. With 98.5 percent of the votes counted, Labor had 24.9 percent of the vote, down 7 points from its 31.9 percent result in last September's parliamentary elections. Lubbers' centrist Christian Democrats, who have held the fulcrum of power in every Dutch government since World War II, rose from 31.6 percent of the vote in the last municipal elections in 1986 to 32.7 percent on Wednesday. But last September, the Christian Democrats won 35.33 percent of the vote. Although local issues blurred the picture in some spots, the overall vote was seen in national terms. If parliamentary elections were held today, both the Christian Democrats and Labor would apparently lose seats, but together would still have a majority in the 150-seat parliament. The D'66 party soared from 7.9 percent in September to 12.5 percent Wednesday. The party's leader in Parliament, Hans van Mierlo, said on TV the gain showed voters agreed with its strong environmentalist platform. Green Left took 6.8 percent of the vote, up 2.8 percent from September. Turnout on a blustery spring day was just above 50 percent in most places, an unusually low figure in the Netherlands. Lubbers, referring to the sweeping changes in Eastern Europe, said in a television interview, ``People who followed the news on radio and television in the past half year saw so many important events that what was happening here looked a little insignificant.'' The right-wing Liberals scored 14.7 percent of the vote Wednesday, up from 14.6 last September but sharply down from their 17.6 in 1986 municipal voting.

DOC.HEAD: Author Pledges $1 Million to University of Miami
DOC.TEXT: Author James Michener and his wife have pledged $1 million to the University of Miami, where he spent three years working on his latest book, school officials announced Wednesday. Michener, who has written 36 books detailing world history and culture, has asked that the gift be used to endow a writing program for graduate students, particularly students from the Caribbean area. ``We are grateful for Mr. Michener's splendid generosity. His commitment will support and inspire aspiring young writers who share his sense of adventure and love of creative writing,'' said university president Edward T. Foote. Michener did much of his research for his latest novel, ``Caribbean,'' in the Caribbean collection of the university library. He also worked with students in the school's writing program as a visiting English professor. ``Miami is effectively the capital of the Caribbean and Latin America,'' the 83-year-old author told a university audience in November. ``The library has a fine collection of materials on those regions.'' ``Caribbean'' traces the history of the entire region from the days of the primitive Arawak Indians to the conflicts faced by Cuban exiles in Miami today. Michener's books also include ``Hawaii,'' ``The Covenant,'' ``Poland,'' ``Centennial,'' ``Chesapeake,'' ``Texas,'' ``Space'' and ``South Pacific,'' for which he won the Pulitzer Prize. His works have been translated into 52 languages and have resulted in nine movies, four TV miniseries and one musical, South Pacific, which won its own Pulitzer Prize. Michener and his wife, Mari, live in Austin, Texas, where he is a professor emeritus at the University of Texas.

DOC.HEAD: El Salvador Offers Renewed Peace Talks With Rebels
DOC.TEXT: The conservative government of President Alfredo Cristiani offered unconditionally Wednesday to renew talks with leftist rebels, possibly in April, to try to end El Salvador's 10{-year-old civil war. The offer came in a statement read by spokesman Mauricio Sandoval at a news conference. It said the government ``is ready to resume the process of dialogue without any prior conditions.'' Sandoval said in responding to questions that while government officials had no firm date in mind for meeting with leaders of the rebel Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front, such an initial meeting could be held in April. A monthly round of talks begun last June were broken off Nov. 11 when the guerrillas launched a three-week, all-out offensive against San Salvador in retaliation for the bombing of a leftist union hall. The rebels accused the military of responsibility for the bombing, which killed 10 union leaders and wounded 30 activists. The armed forces denied it. Since then, the government has been insisting the rebels publicly renounce all attacks against civilian targets as a condition for renewing the talks. Last week, the guerrillas promised not to attack non-military objectives and the government called that ``positive.'' More than 71,000 people have been killed since the civil war began in October 1979, most of them civilians, according to human rights groups.

DOC.HEAD: Liberace's Former Lover Takes Stand in Canyon Murders
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to describe leniency.
DOC.TEXT: A homosexual lover of the late Liberace testified Wednesday that he gave evidence about four bludgeoning murders in Laurel Canyon in exchange for leniency in his own robbery case. Scott Alan Thorson took the stand in the murder trial of Eddie Nash, and said the convicted drug dealer and former night club owner made incriminating statements about the slayings. Thorson received a probationary sentence, but claimed he did not get any leniency in exchange for his cooperation. Nash, 60, also known as Adel Nasrallah, and his bodyguard, Gregory DeWitt Diles, 41, are being tried in the 1981 bludgeoning slayings of four people in a Laurel Canyon drug den. Both man could face the death penalty if convicted. Prosecutors contend Nash ordered the killings in retaliation for a burglary at his posh Studio City home two days before the slayings. Money, drugs, jewelry and other items worth about $1 million were stolen. Defense attorney Edward Rucker has said Nash was not involved in the slayings and that the killings occurred when the thieves fought over how to divide the spoils. Prosecutors filed murder charges against Nash in 1988, based mostly on new evidence provided earlier that year by Thorson, who was in jail on a robbery charge. During a preliminary hearing in 1989, Thorson testified he first met Nash when buying drugs and later moved in with him after a falling out with Liberace. Thorson said Nash never directly admitted his involvement in the killings, but said he would force the robbers to beg for mercy and claimed the slayings got ``out of hand.'' Thorson, 32, a former Las Vegas dancer, sued Liberace claiming the late piano player promised him $70,000 a year in return for being his live-in lover and chauffeur. The case was settled out of court in 1984. Liberace died of AIDS in February 1987. The late porn film star John Holmes was tried and acquitted of the killings in 1982, after he was accused of planning the robbery and then, when cornered by Nash, helping to arrange the murders. Holmes reportedly confessed his role in the slayings shortly before dying of AIDS in 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Company: Miswiring Caused Satellite Deployment Failure
DOC.TEXT: Miscommunications between technicians and computer engineers were to blame for the failure of a Martin Marietta Corp. rocket to deploy a $150 million communications satellite, company officials said. The Commercial Titan was wired to carry two satellites when only one was aboard, company officials said Monday. The 5-ton Intelsat satellite was left stranded in space last Wednesday when it failed to separate from the rocket's upper stage, a clamshell-like device that can house up to two satellites. The satellite remains in an orbit closer to Earth than is useful, with little chance for recovery. The mistake may cost as much as $500 million, including lost revenue from transmitting telephone calls and television signals, space analysts say. The technicians in charge of the booster's electric system and the computer software engineers were working in the same building, Martin Marietta officials said. ``No one was goofing off or being secretive,'' said company spokesman Steve Frank. ``It was language that each group thought meant the same thing.'' Martin Marietta officials at Cape Canaveral, Fla., found the same wiring problem in an identical Commercial Titan rocket scheduled to be launched in June, carrying another Intelsat satellite. A board of inquiry has been formed to investigate the incident and recommend improvements, Frank said. Company investigators found that Martin Marietta electricians apparently wired the rocket in a configuration allowing it to release two satellites. The wires, in turn, were connected to a computer that was supposed to trigger the separation of the satellite from the rocket. When ground crews ordered the computer to send its signal, the faulty design prevented it from traveling past the satellite to the separation device. ``It was a case where the computer people said they would launch the first payload and the wiring people thought that meant the bottom payload compartment,'' Frank said. ``There was just nothing at the separation device to receive the signal.'' The Denver Post today quoted anonymous sources close to the investigation as saying the company is likely to adopt pre-launch checks including a mock satellite separation on the ground using the firing commands employed in space.

DOC.HEAD: Six U.S. Soldiers Reported Injured in Nightclub Brawl
