DOC.HEAD: Ski Club Open to Slow Skiers But Not Young Ones
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS editor's note at end to CORRECT to Ballston Lake, sted Boston Lake. A version moved on sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: The entry requirements are few. ``You have to be an active downhill skier. You must be 70 years of age,'' says Lloyd T. Lambert, founder of the 70-Plus Ski Club. ``You pay $5 for a lifetime membership.'' The claims more than 5,500 members across the country. ``I'm not that speedy any more, but we've got some really, really hot shots,'' said Lambert, 89, who heads the group from his home in Ballston Lake. Senior citizens are staying in shape on the slopes in droves these days, and the trend shows no signs of slowing. With older Americans keener than ever to stay active, skiing is an ideal way to exercise through the winter. ``It's caught on now to where it (membership) has grown 75 percent a year,'' said Bill Vandersluin, 59, spokesman for The Over The Hill Gang, an elderly skiers group based in Aurora, Colo. One member from Los Angeles is living proof ``there's never any shortage of energy'' in the group, said Vandersluin. ``She skis like a demon,'' he said. ``She's 86, and she has no grey hair.'' The Over The Hill Gang, which offers its 2,400 members white water rafting, deep sea fishing and hiking as well as skiing trips, has a minimum membership age of 50. About 6.8 percent of the 18 million to 20 million skiers in the United States are 55 or older, said Chris Stoddard, a spokesman for the United Ski Industries Association. The association is a national trade group for ski areas and ski equipment suppliers. The 70-Plus Ski Club and The Over The Hill Gang hold ski gatherings across the country and provide their members with information about where they can ski for free or at discount rates. Three hundred older skiers descended on the Catskills in New York earlier this month for the 70-Plus Ski Club's annual meeting and races at Hunter Mountain. Lambert got back from a 70-Plus trip to Switzerland last month, but he's off again for more skiing in July, this time to Argentina. Injuries among elderly skiers are few and the accidents they suffer often have little to do with their age, Lambert said. ``These guys on snow boards have run into a few of our members,'' said Lambert. ``One had a broken shoulder, another had broken ribs, and another one was bumped around.'' Injuries on the slopes have been reduced from 7.7 accidents per 1,000 ski visits in the 1950s to 2.5 injuries per 1,000 visits today, according to Stoddard. ``Skiing has an image that you're going to fall and break something,'' he said. ``That image is just not true.'' Stoddard said many older skiers avoid injury because they are usually experienced, and he attributed the overall drop in skiing injuries to improvements in boot bindings and snow making and grooming. Lambert recalls pine toe-strap skies he owned when he first hit the slopes in 1915. ``You couldn't turn or do anything that you could today, because you had nothing to hold your heel in place,'' Lambert said. ``If you wanted to stop you had to fall down or kick the skis off.''

The 70-Plus Ski Club can be reached at 104 East Side Drive, Ballston Lake, N.Y., 12019, 518-399-5458. The Over The Hill Gang can be reached at 13791 East Rice Place, Aurora, Colo., 80015, 303-699-6404.
DOC.NOTE: End advance for March 22

DOC.TEXT: The largest surge in clothing costs in 43 years helped retail prices rise a brisk 0.5 percent in February even as fuel oil bills plummeted, the government said. The increase reported Tuesday in the Labor Department's Consumer Price Index was about twice what had been anticipated and came on top of a weather-fueled 1.1 percent jump in January, the steepest in 7{ years. Taken together, the first two months of the year represent an annual inflation rate of 9.9 percent, compared with 4.6 percent for all of 1989.

The U.S. trade deficit widened sharply to $9.3 billion in January as record demand for foreign oil offset an all-time high in sales of American products overseas, the government reported Tuesday. The January gap between imports and exports was 20.5 percent larger than December's $7.7 billion deficit, which had been the best monthly showing in five years.

The Supreme Court ruled that workers who sue their unions for allegedly failing to represent them fairly may be entitled to jury trials to settle the issue. By a 6-3 vote, the court said Tuesday that union members must be given jury trials if their suits seek monetary compensation such as back pay. The decision is a victory for 27 truck drivers who sued a North Carolina local of the Teamsters union.

An adviser to prominent takeover specialists of the 1980s pleaded guilty to stealing $1 million from his clients and evading and falsifying state income taxes. Donald C. Carter, 41, chairman of The Carter Organization, Inc., waived indictment and pleaded guilty Tuesday in state Supreme Court in Manhattan to grand larceny and filing a false and fradulent personal income tax return. The firm, which had suspended Carter from his duties on Monday, announced later Tuesday that it had fired Carter.

A plan to create an international lending agency to aid the economic recovery of Eastern Europe may be completed by July, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said. ``There is a sense of urgency among our European colleagues ... to get this job done ... by the economic summit'' set for July 9-11 in Houston, Brady told a Senate Appropriations subcommittee on Tuesday.

Savings and loan regulators are considering a controversial program that would pump taxpayer dollars into ailing thrift institutions before they fail. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. on Tuesday chose eight states whose institutions would be eligible for open thrift assistance, but postponed until next week approval of the program itself. The states, picked because they are economically depressed, are: Alaska, Arizona, Arkansas, Colorado, Louisiana, New Mexico, Oklahoma and Texas.

Venezuela and its creditor banks announced they reached an agreement in principle on reducing the country's $20 billion debt to commercial banks. Under the preliminary pact announced Tuesday, Venezuela will offer the banks a range of options that include permanent debt and debt-service reduction, a cash buyback of debt, and new loans, according to Venezuelan Planning Minister Miguel Rodriguez.

Eleven years later than they hoped, operators of the Seabrook nuclear power plant turned on its reactor to begin running it up to full power. At 3:59 a.m. Tuesday, the 1,150-megawatt reactor achieved its first sustained chain reaction since low-power tests in 1989, spokesman Ron Sher said. He said the reactor operated at a fraction of 1 percent of full power shortly after engineers partially withdrew some of the 57 control rods.

The government's budget proposal would fight inflation by encouraging Britons to save and hiking taxes on tobacco, alcohol and gasoline. In his annual spring budget statement to the House of Commons, Chancellor of the Exchequer John Major said Tuesday the government would raise an additional 500 million pounds, or $805 million, from taxpayers in the year ended March 31, 1991. But he announced no drastic changes in the way the government raises its tax revenue, choosing instead to tinker with thresholds and allowances.

The U.S. stock market finished lower Tuesday, as the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials fell 16.89 points to 2,738.74. Bond prices climbed after falling broadly early in the day. The dollar rocketed higher in heavy trading. Gold futures prices skidded well below $400 an ounce; coffee futures surged; livestock and meat futures retreated; energy futures were mixed; and grains and soybeans were mostly higher.

DOC.HEAD: Even for the Oscars, Renting Is Cheaper Than Buying
LaserPhoto RM2
DOC.TEXT: Men can rent the tuxedo, cummerbund, bow tie and black patent leather shoes. But women have had to buy their formal wear. Not any more. Shops that rent evening, prom and even wedding dresses _ along with loads of accessories _ for a fraction of the price of buying are shattering sartorial sexism from coast to coast. Frill Seekers in Richmond; One Night Stand in New York, London and Philadelphia; Til Midnight in Washington, D.C.; and Dress To Kill in Los Angeles offer an alternative to the $12,000 store-bought evening gown. ``I couldn't understand why there were many places in town for men to rent tuxedos, but no place for women,'' said Frill Seekers owner Chris Melson, who got the idea after finding prom dresses for her daughter expensive. About 60 of 100 dresses from size 3 to 13 at Frill Seekers, which opened last April, have designer labels. Rentals range from $30 to $125 for dresses that retail for $150 to nearly $1,000, including the cost of dry cleaning. Also rentable are gloves, purses, jewelry and slips. And if the renter spills a drink or otherwise damages a dress, she and Ms. Melson negotiate the cost of the damage. Alan Millstein, author of Fashion Network Report, a monthly garment industry newsletter in New York, said renting formal wear for women may be new in some places, but the Japanese have been renting wedding dresses for years. ``They do serve a purpose _ wear it once and look great, and, of course, not make an investment,'' he said. ``It's like McDonald's is not for dining, but for feeding,'' Millstein said. ``These clothing emporiums take care of not dressing, but body covering with some kind of style.'' While Ms. Melson operates Frill Seekers out of a spare bedroom, the 1,800-square-foot One Night Stand on Madison Avenue in New York carries 700 dresses. Owner Joanna Doniger buys dresses new from designers. A dress that would retail for $3,000 rents for $250, she said. ``A lot of people are jumping on the bandwagon, and why not,'' she said in a telephone interview from New York. ``It will be an enormous business in the next few years.'' Ms. Doniger opened the shop in London in 1983 and expanded to New York in 1987. The idea for the store was born after Ms. Doniger experienced ``a moment of panic'' one night when she had nothing to wear. ``Men have been renting tuxes for years,'' she said. ``A woman wants to wear the thing just once. ... You can fantasize for a night and it's fun.'' Cathy Baker opened Til Midnight last September to hit an untapped market in Washington. Clients for her 300 evening dresses, wedding dresses and pageant gowns include politicians' wives and other capital party-goers. But many women still are reluctant to rent a dress, shop owners say. ``Rental conjures up all sorts of connotations, like polyester bridesmaid gowns,'' Ms. Baker said. ``And another misconception is people think they are renting old dresses, but we update every season with the latest styles.'' ``The problem is mainly just getting them in the store,'' said Joan Rokahr, part owner of Dress to Kill in Los Angeles. ``Once they get in they say, `This is great, this is wonderful. I'm never buying another dress.''' Rentals on dresses that would retail for $900 to $12,000 go for $100 to $350 at Dress to Kill. Ms. Rokahr said her dresses have been worn to glitzy Hollywood charity balls and entertainment industry events, even the Academy Awards.

DOC.HEAD: Eastern Europe Opening Market for OPEC Oil
DOC.TEXT: OPEC members are looking to Eastern Europe as a promising crude oil market as the region loosens economic ties with the Soviet Union, its dominant supplier to date. Experts predict oil demand will increase as the emerging democracies change the centrally planned economies of their former Communist rulers into free-market models of the West. ``They are going to depend less and less on the Soviet Union,'' Iraqi Oil Minister Issam Abdul Raheem al-Chalabi said in an interview. ``They must improve their economy ... and that means they have to consume more energy,'' he said. ``The only way to get that is from oil, and the only way to get that is from OPEC countries.'' Experts say more emphasis may be placed on producing consumer goods. The auto industry, often ignored in the past, may be targeted for improvement, and more cars would lead to greater demand for gasoline. ``These countries have no other way. They must improve their consumption,'' said Iran's oil minister, Gholamreza Aqazadeh. Kuwait plans to set up offices in Eastern European capitals. Soviet production shortfalls already have led some nations to turn to members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. ``They are certainly starting to become interested,'' said Joseph Stanislaw, managing director of Cambridge Energy Research Associates in Paris. ``It is a natural market for OPEC to go into.'' The Soviet Union, the world's biggest oil producer, long has been the dominant crude supplier to its East-bloc allies. But analysts expect its tight grip to ease with the expiration next year of multi-year contracts with several nations. In negotiating new accords, Moscow is likely to raise prices and demand payment in dollars or other ``hard'' currency, analysts said. The East European countries now pay in Soviet rubles, worthless outside the East bloc, or by bartering equipment and other goods for oil. ``Once they're paying in hard currency, it's a whole new ball game,'' said Jan Vanous, research director at PlanEcon, a Washington consulting firm. ``They'll start shopping around.'' ``OPEC for the first time has a real shot at competing for the delivery of oil for domestic consumption,'' he said. OPEC Secretary-General Subroto said in a recent interview that a hard-currency requirement would prompt the countries to ``look for convenience _ which side can supply them at the best price and quality.'' East European countries also may want to line up other oil suppliers in case of disruptions or shortages in the Soviet Union, which is undergoing its own political and economic upheavals. For example, the southern Azerbaijan region, a recent target of ethnic strife, is a key producer of service equipment for the Soviet oil and gas industry. Even so, analysts said the backward economies of Eastern Europe will not present an enormous market for OPEC oil any time soon. Stanislaw estimated total oil consumption by Poland, Hungary, Czechoslovakia, East Germany, Romania, Yugoslavia and Bulgaria at a modest 1.5 million to 1.7 million barrels a day. The 13 OPEC countries produce more than 23 million barrels of oil a day. The Soviet Union pumped 12.5 million barrels a day last year, about 350,000 barrels less than in 1988, said Pierre Terzian, editor of the Paris newsletter Petrostrategies. Soviet oil exports amounted to 3.5 million barrels a day last year, down from 3.7 million barrels in 1988 and 4.2 million barrels in 1987, he said. To make up for shortfalls in Soviet supplies, Romania, Hungary and Bulgaria have turned to OPEC oil, mostly from Iran and Iraq, said Peter Gignoux, director of international energy at Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. in London. Iraq has supplied crude to Eastern Europe for some time, while Iran wants to increase business there, their oil ministers said. Both countries badly need money from crude sales to repair economies damaged by the eight-year Gulf war. Kuwait has a reputation for pursuing overseas investments aggressively. Oil Minister Ali Khalifa al-Sabah recently visited Hungary and said Kuwait was watching changes in the region closely. Al-Sabah told the Middle East Economic Survey that the state-owned Kuwait Petroleum Corp. planned to set up small offices in each of Eastern Europe's capitals to monitor developments.

DOC.HEAD: New Government Looks To U.S. for Help Amid Fear of Unrest
DOC.TEXT: Panama's new civilian government is turning to the United States for help in recharging an economy wracked by high unemployment, sagging productivity and the threat of widespread unrest. ``We cannot sit and wait,'' national comptroller Ruben Dario Carles said. ``Every unemployed person has a reason to protest and it will be bad if 200,000 protest.'' An estimated one-third of Panama's workers are out of work. Gross domestic product has plummeted. The government, scrimping to keep itself afloat, is relying on the United States for aid. Carlos Rodriguez, a Panamanian who is vice president of the American Chamber of Commerce, said Panama risks strikes, unrest and a backlash against the new government and the United States if the economy does not improve. For now, the government of President Guillermo Endara enjoys wide popularity. The U.S. invasion in December ousted Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, and Washington shortly afterward lifted economic sanctions. But the sanctions and the siphoning of money under Noriega had left Panama's economy in tatters. The invasion also prompted widespread looting and vandalism that temporarily closed about 90 percent of the country's businesses. During a 13-day fast that began March 1, Endara criticized the slowness of promised U.S. aid and the release of government funds frozen during the Noriega regime. ``People cannot eat democracy,'' Endara said. ``There could be popular unrest unless there are some quick solutions. The congressional delay of approval endangers our democracy.'' The Bush administration has proposed a $1 billion aid package. Congress has approved $43 million to rebuild the Chorrillo neighborhood, destroyed in the invasion, and the start of credit valued by the administration at $500 million. But a Bush administration call for $500 million in cash aid is expected to encounter difficulties in Congress. Panamanians argue that the country is equipped to use the money effectively, more so than reforming countries of East European that may be competing for assistance. ``Panama is not a basket case like some other countries. It has good infrastructure, a good entrepreneurial class,'' Rodriguez said. With a dollar-based economy, Panama was a thriving international banking and trade center. But it came to a near-halt amid political turmoil following indictments of Noriega on drug trafficking charges, a nine-week bank closure in 1988 and the sanctions. Assets in the cluster of gleaming, modern banking towers plummeted from $40 billion in June 1987 to less than $15 million two years later. Business has slowed to a trickle on streets that once teemed with visitors buying cameras, electronic equipment, watches and tailor-made suits. Panama's gross domestic poduct fell 20 percent in 1988 and another 7.5 percent in 1989. Much of what flowed into government coffers gushed out in corruption, officials said. ``If you stop the corruption, that by itself is income. It was that bad,'' said Second Vice President Guillermo Ford, who also is the planning minister. The city's kindergartens, for example, have $3,000 more a month since a department head was jailed for stealing from tuition. Unemployment _ about 20 percent before the invasion and under 10 percent before the U.S. sanctions were enacted in 1987 _ is estimated at above 30 percent now. Jorge Heraza, 21, finished high school three years ago with a specialty in commercial accounting, a seemingly practical career in a more than 70 percent service economy. He still doesn't have a job, despite repeated applications. Ousting Noriega and installing Endara seemed like a good idea, ``but they must follow through,'' Heraza said. ``They say they're going to give jobs, but unemployment, with what has happened, there is more.'' The government has been getting by on tax revenue, still slow but improving, and partial release of $390 million in frozen funds. Government officials slashed their own salaries, saving $2.1 million a year. Endara cut his pay to $7,000 a month from $10,000 a month. Until it catches up on $540 million in arrears on a $5.2 billion foreign debt, Panama will be ineligible for new multilateral and commercial bank loans. The government's strategy is to strengthen the private sector, Ford said. It plans to privatize state-owned Air Panama, sugar mills and cement and citrus processing plants. Some businessmen even suggest that the Panama Canal, to be turned over to Panama on Dec. 31, 1999, could be operated as a concession or its services privatized.

DOC.HEAD: UAL Unions Offer Five-Year, No-Strike Pacts In Buyout Concessions
DOC.TEXT: Five-year contracts with wage reductions and no-strike clauses are among the concessions United Airlines' unions are offering in their quest to buy parent UAL Corp. for more than $3.8 billion. Nonunion employees, who would share in the proposed 75 percent workers' stake, also would give up wages and benefits in the event of an employee buyout, according to documents made public Tuesday. The filings were made by the buyout group with the Securities and Exchange Commission in Washington. The group said annual payroll costs for non-contract employees would be reduced by $55 million from a 1990 base, and reductions would remain in effect during the term of labor agreements. The proposed contracts included in the filings appeared to indicate that United's three union groups would take wage-and-benefit cuts of about 10 percent, but union spokesmen would not confirm the amount of the reduction. The labor agreements would depend on approval of the buyout by UAL stockholders, the ability of the unions to secure financing and ratification of the contracts by the union rank-and-file, who comprise about two-thirds of UAL's work force. United's pilots, machinists and flight attendants unions Monday announced a bid that values UAL at more than $3.8 billion. The offer is composed of $150 per share in cash, $25 per share in debt securities and non-voting common stock in the new company with an undetermined value. Analysts have calculated the offer's value at $175 to $190 per share, or as much as $4.1 billion. Coniston Partners, a New York investment group and UAL's largest stockholder with an 11.8 percent stake, is backing the unions with the threat of a proxy fight aimed at replacing UAL's board with directors, who would favor an employee buyout. UAL's stock fell $2.50 Tuesday on the New York Stock Exchange, closing at $152 a share. The buyout of the nation's second-largest airline would create the country's biggest employee-owned company. UAL Chairman Stephen Wolf has said the board will consider the offer at an upcoming meeting expected to be held this week. UAL spokesman Joe Hopkins would not confirm a date. In January, the unions said they and the non-contract employees would help defray the cost of a takeover with wage and benefit concessions worth about $2 billion over five years, including about $300 million in the first year of the takeover. In a $6.8 billion pilot-management buyout bid that failed last October, leaders of United's pilots union had agreed tentatively to a seven-year, no-strike contract with 10 percent pay cuts for most pilots. The pilots also had planned to use retirement funds to buy $200 million worth of stock in the company. Nonunion UAL employees also would have taken 10 percent pay cuts as part of the $300-a-share plan, which collapsed Oct. 13, triggering a plunge in the stock market, after banks refused to finance it. The documents filed with the SEC state that the Coniston proxy slate would include four employee representatives, the three Coniston principals and eight candidates from the business community. Paul Tierney Jr., one of Coniston's three principal partners, said the unions would be allowed to pick a new UAL chairman if Coniston wins the proxy fight. The unions have been negotiating with Richard Ravitch, formerly chairman of New York's Metropolitan Transportation Authority, to replace Wolf, but say they have made no decision.

DOC.HEAD: Chevy Hoping Cops and Cabs Boost Caprice Sales
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. is looking to police departments and taxi companies to help support sales figures for its newly redesigned Chevrolet Caprice full-size car. The new 1991 Caprice, which went on sale to the public earlier this month, is the preferred car of law enforcement agencies nationwide. GM needs to maintain or increase those sales to hold its share of the full-size car market. Chevrolet sold about 50,000 1990-model Caprices to police agencies and taxi fleets, Chevrolet General Manager Jim Perkins said Tuesday. ``We expect (sales of 1991 Caprice) police and taxis to remain about the same,'' he said. Chevrolet expects to sell about 200,000 Caprices during the 1991 model year, the first full year of production of the new models. The new Caprice, shown off Tuesday at GM's newly refurbished Willow Run assembly plant west of Detroit, is much more rounded than previous Caprice models and from some angles appears similar to Ford's Mercury Sable. GM spent $85 million for changes at Willow Run as part of a plant modernization program that United Auto Workers union Vice President Stephen Yokich noted on Tuesday. The UAW and the nation's Big Three automakers begin negotiations in July to agree on a contract replacing one that expires Sept. 14. ``The capital investment in this plant and the equipment needed to start up a new product like this was very substantial,'' Yokich said. ``We have to remember, however, no auto company has ever invested so much in capital equipment and still managed to lose so much in market share.'' During the 1980s, GM spent about $77 billion, mainly for capital improvements in upgrading assembly and component plants. Between the end of 1982 and the end of last year, GM's share of the U.S.-made car market dropped 4 percentage points to 48 percent. One way to boost market share as the industry shrinks in 1990 is to hold or increase fleet sales. Perkins said he expected up to 30,000 police versions of Caprice and up to 25,000 taxi versions to be sold during the 1991 model year. More than half of all the police cars sold last year were Caprices, followed by Ford's Crown Victoria, also a rear-wheel-drive, full-size car. But other players are coming into the police car market, and they'll make it tougher for the full-size GM and Ford cars to hold their own. Ford is offering a Mustang outfitted for police use and later this year, GM will offer a police option package on its Chevrolet Camaro. When automakers make police cars, they swap out some standard equipment and replace it with components more suited to rugged driving. In the Caprice, Chevrolet offers an optional 5.7-liter engine in place of the standard 5-liter engine and larger tires for high-speed driving. A variety of options also is available so law enforcement agencies can customize a car to their needs. The local agency equips the vehicles with, among other things, radios, cages separating the front and rear seats and sirens. The Mustang and the Camaro, which can reach 100 mph much quicker than their larger cousins, are expected to attract state highway patrols, which might use them to prowl freeways for speeders. Because of their size, full-size Caprice and Crown Victoria cars are expected to remain popular with taxi companies and police departments, which require four-doors and door space for occupants who frequently must get in and out of the vehicle.

DOC.HEAD: CEO Pleads Guilty to Stealing $1 Million From Clients
DOC.TEXT: An adviser to some of corporate America's most powerful takeover artists became another symbol of Wall Street's decline when he pleaded quilty to stealing $1 million from clients. Donald C. Carter, 41, chairman of The Carter Organization, Inc., waived indictment and pleaded guilty Tuesday in state Supreme Court in Manhattan to grand larceny and filing a false and fradulent personal income tax return. He then was fired by the firm he founded. The Carter Organization said it was unaware about the plead guilty until Carter revealed it in Monday's Wall Street Journal. In fact, the company said that until that time, ``Mr. Carter denied that he stole from some of the clients of The Carter Organization.'' ``The Carter Organization, as Mr. Carter's former employer, said it is committed to cooperating with those clients to remedy any damage caused by Mr. Carter's criminality,'' the statement read. ``The company is also committed to ensuring that this kind of conduct can never reoccur.'' Among those Carter worked for as a proxy solictor were T. Boone Pickens, Saul Steinberg, Irwin Jacobs and Sir James Goldsmith. James W. Wetzler, commissioner of the state Taxation and Finance department, called Carter's plea a ``symbol of the greed that motivated so much of the '80s coming a cropper.'' Officials made the announcement at a news conference here. Ronald Goldstock, director of the New York State Organized Crime Task Force, which headed the Carter investigation, said business records seized at Carter's Manhattan office and at a Brooklyn warehouse showed a ``systematic pattern of greed and fraud.'' He said that between 1984 and 1989 Carter routinely billed his clients for non-existent or inflated expenses and when questioned about the expenses, he supplied fraudulent documentation to justify them. The corporate clients he was said to have defrauded included Union Carbide Corp., Shell Oil, Caesars World Inc., UNUM, an insurance company, and MacAndrews & Forbes Group Inc., which owns the Revlon cosmetics company. Goldstock said the Carter investigation was sparked by an unrelated probe, which he refused to discuss. Carter had faced up to 11 years in prison, but Justice George F. Roberts promised him a prison term of 16 months to four years and a fine of up to $2 million when he is sentenced May 2. Carter also agreed to establish a $1 million escrow fund to make restitution to the victims of the theft, said Goldstock. In addition to the grand larceny charge, Carter admitted falsifying his 1986 state income tax return by charging up to $10 million in personal expenses as business expenses. Goldstock said the personal expenses included hundreds of thousands of dollars in renovations to his East End Avenue home in Manhattan. The state estimates that Carter owes more than $1 million in taxes, penalties and interest for 1985 and 1986, said Wetzler. He added that at a time when the state may have to raise taxes for ``ordinary citizens ... it is inexcusable that welathy people not pay their fair share of the tax burden.'' Carter founded his company 16 years ago and sold it in 1987 to British-owned VPI Group PLC for $75 million. He continued to work for the company until Tuesday when officials announced he had been suspended. A Columbia Business School dropout, the brash and flamboyant Carter worked as an analyst for Carl Icahn before going out on his own. He spearheaded Frank Sinatra's successful drive to gain a representative on the board of the Del Webb casino company in 1977.

DOC.HEAD: Citicorp, Chase Bosses Expect Real Estate Loan Problems to Grow
DOC.TEXT: The heads of the nation's two largest banking companies, Citicorp and Chase Manhattan Corp., say they expect an increase in problem real estate loans this year. Citicorp Chairman John Reed told securities analysts Tuesday that the commercial real estate market ``will be difficult for awhile'' and force the nation's largest banking company to write off more loans than expected. He said the write-offs would be higher than the $53 million in commercial real estate write-offs taken in 1989, but declined to be more specific. Factors contributing to the poor market, he said, are deterioration in the economy, reduced market liquidity that is making it harder for investors to find buyers for buildings they had hoped to sell and increased regulatory attention to the possibility of problem real estate loans. Nonetheless, Reed said despite the higher write-offs, Citicorp's commercial real estate business would continue to be profitable in 1990. Citicorp reported it had $17.3 billion in outstanding commercial real estate loans as of Dec. 31, 1989. In a separate presentation to another group of securities analysts earlier in the day, Chase Manhattan President Thomas Labrecque said he expects to see a steady increase in problem real estate loans over the next several months as sluggishness in many commercial and residential markets continues. ``We had expected a cyclical market downswing for two years,'' Labrecque said. ``We took steps to limit our growth and tighten our underwriting and appraisal standards.'' Chase placed $783 million in domestic real estate loans on a nonaccrual basis at the end of 1989, a 49 percent jump from the $527 million the previous year. When loans are placed on nonaccrual status, banks no longer include on their statements the interest and other charges due on the loans until the money is actually received. As the current sluggish real estate environment persists, Labrecque said, the number of these non-performing loans is expected to increase moderately in the first quarter and ``somewhat more over the next quarters.'' Despite the sharp rise in problem loans, Labrecque told analysts overall credit quality in the bank's real estate lending business was relatively good and should remain profitable. Chase's domestic real estate loan portfolio totaled $9 billion at the end of 1989. Citicorp is the nation's largest banking company with assets of $230.6 billion at the end of 1989. Chase is the second largest with assets of $107.37 billion on Dec. 31, 1989. Looking at the longer-term finacial outlook for Citicorp, Reed told the analysts he expected that by the mid- to late-1990s, Citicorp would earn $5 billion a year and derive 65 percent of its earnings from consumer banking. In 1989, Citicorp earned $498 million, or $1.16 a share, when its results were depressed by a $1 billion addition to its loan loss reserve for potentially bad loans to Third World countries. In 1988, it earned $1.86 billion, or $5.36 a share. The company now gets about 40 percent of its operating earnings from consumer banking. In a separate announcement, Citicorp said it has changed the names of its 252 Citicorp Savings branches in California, Florida, Illinois and the District of Columbia to Citibank, Federal Savings Bank. The savings and loans had recently been given permission to change their charters from savings and loans to federal savings banks. William J. Heron Jr., group head for U.S. consumer banking at Citicorp, said the change ``reflects our increasing commitment to a unified approach to banking activities throughout the country.'' He said recent changes in federal laws removed limitations that had restricted Citicorp from using the name of its flagship New York bank, Citibank, in connection with the institutions it had acquired in the 1980s.

DOC.HEAD: Securities Firms Halt Underwriting Until Stock Market Stabilizes
DOC.TEXT: Japanese securities firms are halting equity-linked financing of Japanese companies at home and abroad until the collapsing Tokyo Stock Exchange recovers, officials said today. In an attempt to minimize damage and risks to stock and bond holders, the firms agreed Tuesday to suspend stock and bond underwriting for at least one month, said Nobuo Kurakazu, director of securities at Daiwa Securities Co. The first-time maneuver also is designed to stop the flow of additional shares and not dilute the market's current value. The moratorium involves new convertible bonds, warrants and common stocks. Kurakazu said companies will halt underwriting until the stock market starts showing signs of stability, in order not to harm investors. Japan's financial markets were closed today for the vernal equinox day, a national holiday. ``We can no longer continue normal sales activities under the current market situation, where prices of stocks and bonds have kept sinking,'' said Hiroshi Tanaka, chief of the underwriting division at Yamaichi Securities Co. ``It is best to halt the sales rather than keep selling those bonds when nobody is interested,'' he said, adding that demands for company bonds are especially affected. The Tokyo Stock Exchange's 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average has lost almost 21 percent of its value since the beginning of the year. The index has fallen by 8,100 points. The Nikkei, which plunged 1,353.20 points, or 4.15 percent, on Monday in its third-largest single-day fall, tumbled another 456.05 points, or 1.48 percent, on Tuesday. Its Tuesday close of 30,807.19 was the lowest since 30,678.39 on Jan. 9, 1989. As a result, the exchange's total value lost almost 91 trillion yen, or $600 billion, by mid-March. The market's total value, which was 590.9 trillion yen, $3.9 trillion, at the end of last year, fell to 499.6 trillion yen, $3.3 trillion, by last Friday. Kurakazu said the underwriting decision also involved uncertainty over Tuesday's discount rate increase. The Bank of Japan raised its official discount rate, a key lending rate to commercial banks, by one percentage point to 5.25 percent, effective immediately, to stem inflation and restabilize the financial markets. Analysts have blamed the delayed rate increase for contributing to the plunge of the yen and stock and bond prices, causing many companies to abandon plans to raise capital. Mitsukoshi, Yasuda Trust and Banking Co. and the Bank of Miyazaki have canceled plans to raise capital by issuing new common stock. Also, Sumitomo Metal and Jujo Paper have decided to postpone plans for raising capital by issuing convertible bonds, according to local news reports. Company officials were not available for comment due to a national holiday. The price of Sumitomo Metal's convertible bonds plunged 21 yen in the last month to 78 yen Tuesday from 99.00 yen Feb. 20. Japan Broadcasting Corp. estimated the number of convertible bonds issued last year at 2.48 trillion issues. Tanaka said the number of companies that postponed or canceled plans for issuing new common stocks and bonds has increased since the begining of March. Cancellation came especially from subsidiaries overseas, he added.

DOC.HEAD: Venezuela, Creditor Banks Announce Debt Agreement
DOC.TEXT: Venezuela and its creditor banks have agreed to a plan to reduce about $20 billion of the country's debt to commercial banks. The agreement in principle provides a boost to the Bush administration's debt-reduction policy _ the so-called Brady Plan, named for Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady _ which emphasizes reducing existing Third World debt rather than making new loans. Venezuela, whose $37 billion overall foreign debt is the fourth-largest in Latin America, has fallen behind on its interest and capital payments in recent years. The preliminary pact, announced on Tuesday, covers about $20 billion of medium- and long-term commercial bank debt. The plan follows a similar agreement signed by creditor banks and Mexico last month in which banks agreed to cut that country's $48.5 billion debt by some $7 billion. The banks were given three options: reduce debt capital by 35 percent, cut interest rates to a fixed 6.25 percent or offer new loans equivalent to 25 percent of their oustanding loans to Mexico. Under the agreement with Venezuela, banks have been offered a range of options that include permanent debt and debt-service reduction, a cash buyback of debt, and new loans, according to Venezuelan Planning Minister Miguel Rodriguez. Negotiations with a representative committee of 16 creditor banks are expected to continue until a final package is approved. Rodriguez said he expects to have an agreement with all 300 creditor banks finalized by July. Robert Murphy, chairman of the bank committee and a vice president at Chase Manhattan Bank, said the agreement would be attractive to the international financial community. However, neither he nor Rodriguez would predict which options would prove most popular with the banks. They said that until the results are in, it would be difficult to calculate how much debt reduction Venezuela would achieve with the package. The tentative agreement included the following options for creditor banks: _Buying back their debt at a reduced, not-yet-determined price. Venezuelan debt is currently selling at around 40 percent of face value. _Exchanging existing debt for new capital-reduced bonds at a 30 percent discount, or interest-reduced bonds yielding 6.75 percent. _Providing new money. Those choosing this option would get two series of bonds yielding the London interbank offered rate, which stands at around 8.5 percent, plus up to 1 percent. Rodriguez said he was hoping for about $1 billion in new money.

DOC.HEAD: De Beers To Raise Rough Gem Diamond Prices 5.5 Percent
DOC.TEXT: De Beers Consolidated Mines Ltd. said Wednesday it will raise the prices of rough gem diamonds sold through its Central Selling Organization by an average 5.5 percent effective Monday. Vigorous consumer demand and a need to keep prices in line with global inflation prompted the rise, said De Beers spokesman Andrew Lamont. De Beers pushed prices up 15.5 percent in its last increase in March 1989. The organization's sales were down 2 percent at $4.09 billion last year and are expected to be flat this year. Rough diamonds yielding polished diamonds of one carat and less have been selling at a premium in the open diamond bourses not run by the Central Selling Organization for the last several months, reflecting the strong demand, De Beers said. Polished diamonds currently fetching between $400 and $3,500 a carat, are experiencing particularly strong demand, and will bear the brunt of the price increase, Lamont said. De Beers doesn't disclose its prices, which vary considerably. The wholesale price of the highest grade one-carat gem is about $16,000. The organization sorts and values about 80 percent of the world's rough diamonds before selling them to wholesalers at regular sales called ``sights.''

DOC.HEAD: BAT Posts 34 Percent Profit Gain
DOC.TEXT: BAT Industries PLC, the British conglomerate fighting a takeover bid from Sir James Goldsmith's Hoylake Investments Ltd., on Wednesday reported a 38 percent jump in profit during 1989. The results were helped by record earnings from the group's tobacco interests and a near doubling of profits at its financial services division. BAT said last year's net income totaled $2.07 billion, compared with $1.5 billion in 1988. The latest results included a $197 million one-time gain from restructurings. Annual sales increased 25 percent to $35 billion from $28 billion. The company did not break out full quarterly results. It isn't required to under British law. BAT Chairman Patrick Sheehy described the results as excellent in light of the ``distractions forced on us by Hoylake.'' The $21 billion Hoylake bid has been suspended while U.S. state insurance regulators review the effect a change of ownership would have on BAT's Farmers Insurance Group Inc. of Los Angeles. ``The performance from financial services and tobacco is particularly significant because they are the businesses which will dominate the continuing group in the future,'' Sheehy said. Under a restructuring designed to fight off the Hoylake bid, BAT is selling or spinning off its retailing and paper interests. The companies to be sold include the U.S. retail stores Saks Fifth Avenue and Marshall Field's.

DOC.HEAD: Mobil Announces $300 Million Refinery Expansion
DOC.TEXT: Mobil Corp. said Wednesday it was expanding its largest U.S. refinery located in Beaumont, Texas, at a cost of $300 million. The expansion, which is scheduled to begin in the third quarter of this year, will increase the plant's capacity to 325,000 barrels a day of crude oil, from the current 285,000 barrels. The bigger refinery will enable Mobil, the nation's second-largest oil company after Exxon Corp., to substantially increase production of super unleaded gasoline and distillate fuels, such as home heating oil. The refinery processes various grades of crude oil into fuels and other products. The project, which is expected to be completed by the third quarter of 1992, also will include the closure of older processing units and the use of new technology in existing units. Mobil spokesman John Lord said the upgraded plant also will incorporate more modern equipment that will reduce emissions of sulfur and nitrogen dioxides. ``Its new processing equipment will help eliminate or substantially reduce pollutants normally emitted in the refining process,'' Lord said. Mobil has four other U.S. refineries in Torrance, Calif., Joliet, Ill., Paulsboro, N.J., and Chalmette, La. Mobil owns or has interests in 22 other refineries around the world. Its second-largest refinery located in Singapore has a capacity of 200,000 barrels a day.

DOC.HEAD: Manischewitz Fixed Matzo Prices, Justice Department Says
DOC.TEXT: The government is accusing the country's best known matzo maker, The B. Manischewitz Co., of arranging with competitors to fix the price of $25 million of Passover matzo from 1981 to 1986. Customers who were charged the allegedly fixed prices included kosher food distributors who sold to supermarket chains and grocery stores. An indictment filed in federal court here accused the Jersey City-based company of conspiracy to restrain trade. No other company was named, nor were any individuals charged. The 101-year-old maker of kosher products issued a statement denying the charge and said its prices have been ``independently and fairly determined.'' ``Manischewitz will vigorously defend against the charges,'' the company said. Questions were referred to Vice President Robert A. Mann, who said today that he would have no other comment beyond the company statement. Kosher for Passover matzo is unleavened bread made specially for the Jewish holiday that celebrates the exodus of Hebrew slaves led by Moses from ancient Egypt. The complaint, filed by the Justice Department's antitrust division, alleged that Manischewitz and co-conspirators discussed price increases and published ``price lists'' incorporating the agreed-on increases. The maximum penalty for the charge is a $1 million fine. Manischewitz earned $286,861 on $32.5 million in sales in the fiscal year ending July 31, 1989. The annual report said an 8.1 percent increase in sales resulted from higher average selling prices, plus ``modest'' volume increases. The company has about 225 employees.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Markets Open Mixed, Seeking News
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices opened mixed today on the Chicago Board of Trade as a variety of bullish factors offset profit-taking after two days of strong gains. Soybean futures were narrowly mixed, then turned higher with support stemming from indications that Brazil's soybean crop, which is now being harvested, will be smaller than previously expected. The Brazilian market newsletter Safras E Mercados lowered its maximum crop estimate to 20.2 million metric tons from 20.6 million, citing dry weather and tight farm credit policies. Private analysts in the United States also have been lowering their forecasts for the Brazilian crop. Corn futures were slightly lower amid fading hopes for confirmation of a rumored sale of U.S. corn to the Soviet Union. The wheat market was slightly higher, reflecting forecasts for cold weather this weekend in U.S. winter wheat country and news that the United States had donated 200,000 metric tons of wheat to Poland. In early trading, wheat futures were 1{ cents to 2} cents higher with the contract for delivery in March at $4.03 a bushel; corn futures were unchanged to 1 cent lower with March at $2.53 a bushel; oats were unchanged to { cent lower with March at $1.46 a bushel; soybeans were 1{ cents to 4{ cents higher with March at $5.95 a bushel. All March grain and soybean contracts are due to expire today at noon Central time. Cattle futures were slightly higher in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Pork futures were mixed. Live cattle were .15 cent to .17 cent higher with April at 76.97 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .17 cent .35 cent higher with March at 82.55 cents a pound; live hogs were .07 cent to .37 cent lower with April at 52.87 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .52 cent to .67 cent higher with May at 51.87 cents a pound. DOC.HEAD: Nineteen Women Claim Diet Caused Gall Bladder Damage
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf pvs, Those plaintiffs ..., with one graf to ADD that all 19 lawsuits filed by two lawyers. A version moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The popular Nutri-System diet program has come under fire from 19 south Florida women who say in separate lawsuits that they have suffered gall bladder damage from the rapid weight-loss plan. The company defends its program as safe and suggests the gall bladder problems are coincidental. All but two of the women, ages 17 to 60, have had gall bladder operations since 1988, according to the suits filed against the Pennsylvania company and several Florida franchises in Dade Circuit Court on Monday. Those plaintiffs who did not undergo surgery are suffering from gallstones, and may need to be hospitalized, attorney Robert Fiore said Tuesday. The 19 suits have been filed by either Fiore or a second lawyer, Herman Russomanno. The suits charge negligence, arguing that Nutri-System Inc., based in Willow Grove, Pa., failed to supervise customers. ``The conduct on the part of the defendants is tantamount to the unauthorized practice of medicine without a license,'' the suits charge. Nutri-System has weight-loss centers in all 50 states, Canada, the United Kingdom and Australia. It costs $530 to sign up, and the system provides some of the food to start the plan at a cost of $46 to $70. Rapid weight loss is known to be linked to a variety of physical ailments, according to the documents filed. ``In particular, rapid weight loss increases the saturation of bile with cholesterol, directly contributing to the formation of symptomatic gallstones and gall bladder disease,'' the suits said. Nutri-System spokesman James Millard said the company's attorneys had reviewed one of the suits, and found it without merit. ``The allegations seem to be coincidental to the state of obesity,'' Millard said. ``We feel our program is an excellent program, and we stand by its quality, its safety and its effectiveness.'' He described the Nutri-System program as a comprehensive program that includes a nutritionally balanced, calorie-controlled meal plan that includes behavior education, nutritional instruction, exercise and weight maintenance. One of the suits, by Rita Kronstat and her husband, Selig, said that Mrs. Kronstat lost 25{ of her 193 pounds in several weeks, but then began suffering abdominal pain. ``She was diagnosed as suffering from symptomatic gallstones and advised to have her gall bladder removed as soon as possible,'' her lawsuit said. The surgery was performed Dec. 7. Before signing up for Nutri-System, she never had any gallstone or gall bladder problems, according to the suit.

DOC.HEAD: Top Aesa Brown Officer Quits
DOC.TEXT: George Kimmel has resigned as president and chief executive officer of Asea Brown Boveri Ltd.'s U.S. subsidiary. Kimmel's announcement on Tuesday comes only four months after assuming the posts at Asea Brown Boveri Inc. He will be replaced by Gerhard Schulmeyer, an executive vice president of the Swiss-based parent, the company said. Kimmel, 55, said he was leaving the company because ``after working through the organization and other issues, I believed my skills and experience wouldn't be fully utilized.'' Kimmel was president and chief operating officer of Combustion Engineering Inc. before the Stamford-based company was bought by ABB Asea Brown Boveri Ltd. last December for $1.6 billion. ABB renamed the company and located headquarters at Combustion Engineering's building in Stamford. The parent is one of the world's largest electrical engineering companies, with about $25 billion in sales. The U.S. unit provides systems and services for power generation, factory automation, transportation and environmental cleanup. It has about $7 billion in annual sales.

DOC.HEAD: GATT: World Trade Value Hit $3 Trillion In 1989
DOC.TEXT: International trade volume could slow slightly this year, with inflation and rising interest rates in industrialized nations hampering trade expansion, the world's main trade forum reported Thursday. Experts at the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade also reported that the value of international merchandise trade topped $3 trillion for the first time in 1989 as the United States regained its position from West Germany as the world's top exporter. GATT experts predicted the volume of goods traded internationally would grow by 5 percent to 6 percent in 1990, the eighth straight year of expansion. The value of goods traded on world markets last year rose by 7.5 percent from 1988, to $3.1 trillion, the report stated. The report warned of continuing problems faced by heavily indebted countries. It also said persistent inflation and rising interest rates in industrialized countries threatened to dampen business investment, an important factor in trade expansion. In 1989 the United States regained its position as the world's leading exporter after three years in second place behind West Germany, the report said. U.S. exports were worth some $364.4 billion, ahead of West Germany's $341.4 billion and Japan's $275.2 billion. U.S. imports totalled $492.0 billion, compared to West Germany's $269.8 billion and Japan's $210.8 billion. The report said the value of U.S. exports rose 95 percent during the decade while imports shot up 120 percent. This compared with a world average increase of 86 percent for both imports and exports. Canada had the most significant growth among the biggest trading nations, moving from 10th to seventh place in the rankings. Canadian exports and imports in 1989 each totaled about $120 billion, respective increases of 107 percent and 112 percent over 1979. In contrast to growth in most other areas of the world, East Europe and the Soviet Union witnessed stagnation and even decline in trade last year, according to initial estimates cited by GATT. It said the combined value of imports and exports rose only 1 percent in the Soviet Union. Hungary's merchandise trade contracted by 3 percent and Bulgaria's by 4 percent. The value of Poland's trade rose 7 percent because of a surge in imports. Czechoslovakia's imports and exports increased by 4 percent, East Germany's by 2.5 percent and Romania's by 0.5 percent, the report said. Even though growth in the overall volume of world trade was expected to slow down in 1990, it would still exceed forecast output growth of about 3 percent, the report said. Looking ahead, it said the level and pattern of world trade would be affected as East Europe and the Soviet Union increased trade with countries outside the region. Necessary plant and infrastructure investments as part of the process of economic reform would call for higher imports of capital equipment and business services. Traditionally, about 60 percent of Soviet and East European exports and imports have been traded within the region, the report said. Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia and East Germany have relied most heavily on Soviet bloc trading partners, while Poland, Hungary, the Soviet Union and Romania sent close to half their merchandise exports to countries outside the region. Citing figures for 1988, the report said West European sales to the Soviet bloc totalled $42.9 billion, while imports from the Soviet bloc amounted to $46.1 billion. It said U.S. trade with East Europe and the Soviet Union remained small. In 1988 U.S. exports to the region totalled less than $5 billion and purchases from these countries less than $3 billion. GATT is a market-oriented trade forum that draws up agreements to liberalize world trade. Its 96 members account for more than four-fifths of global commerce.

DOC.HEAD: Hazelwood: Prudent Mariner or Reckless Drunk?
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to UPDATE with with jury beginning deliberations. Picks up 4th graf pvs, `Assistant District ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto AG1
DOC.TEXT: Jurors began deliberating today on whether Joseph Hazelwood was a reckless drunk or a prudent tanker captain _ conflicting portrayals by the prosecution and defense in a full day of intense summations. Superior Court Judge Karl Johnstone turned the 7-week-old criminal case in the nation's worst oil spill over to the jury late Tuesday. Jurors met briefly behind closed doors to elect a foreman, and returned today to begin reaching a verdict. Assistant District Attorney Brent Cole accused Exxon Corp. of maneuvering behind the scenes to win Hazelwood's acquittal; defense attorney Dick Madson said the oil company might be more interested in transferring its own share of the blame to Hazelwood, skipper at the time of the Exxon Valdez. Cole responded angrily when Madson called Hazelwood a scapegoat. ``A scapegoat?'' exclaimed Cole. ``The state of Alaska didn't put a glass of vodka in Captain Hazelwood's hand and force him to drink it.'' The bearded, balding Hazelwood listened without expression as Cole called him a gambler and a risk-taker who imbibed before boarding his ship. Cole said Hazelwood risked his tanker and the lives of his crew. ``He gambled that drinking would not affect his judgment,'' said Cole. ``He was wrong ... because alcohol never improves judgment.'' Madson pointed out that 21 witnesses testified Hazelwood appeared sober when he boarded the ship and said many of them vouched for his competent seamanship on the night the tanker ran aground on a jagged reef, spilling nearly 11 million gallons of Alaska North Slope crude oil. ``Twenty-one witnesses said he was not impaired,'' Madson said. ``What does that mean? That means Captain Hazelwood wasn't impaired by consumption of alcohol. There has to be proof of impairment.'' Cole countered that Hazelwood's appearance didn't matter and told jurors to remember witnesses saw the skipper drinking in a Valdez bar before boarding the ship. The accident occurred a year ago Saturday. The tanker's hull was ripped open, blackening hundreds of miles of shoreline and killing fish, birds and other wildlife. Hazelwood, 43, a veteran mariner from Huntington, N.Y., is charged with one felony, criminal mischief, and three misdemeanors: reckless endangerment, operating a vessel while intoxicated and negligent discharge of oil. If convicted, he could receive 7\ years in prison and $61,000 in fines. His wife and father recently arrived at the trial and listened to final arguments from a back row of the courtroom. Madson said Alaska has chosen Hazelwood as its scapegoat. ``There's a reason we're here today,'' he said. ``Politics and money.'' Cole claimed Exxon pressured witnesses to support the skipper. ``It doesn't take a brain surgeon to see Exxon's interest in this matter,'' Cole said. ``It's seeing Captain Hazelwood get acquitted.'' But Madson said Exxon had a different agenda. ``Maybe they're afraid the state might charge them with something,'' he said. Exxon spokesman Joe Tucker in Anchorage said Tuesday he was not authorized to comment on Cole's remarks and that Exxon officials in Houston were unavailable.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Fall in Dull London Trading
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with close.
DOC.TEXT: Prices fell in a lackluster session on London's Stock Exchange Wednesday with investors uncertain about the implications of Britain's new budget. There were few features in the dull dealings, and little leadership from Wall Street, dealers said. Investors also were feeling cautious ahead of several British economic reports due later in the week, including trade and inflation figures, dealers said. Others said the market performed reasonably well Wednesday, considering that the budget announced Tuesday was poorly received by British industry and the investment community. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was down 9.4 points, or 0.4 percent, at 2,250.3 at the close. That was the session's peak and was well above the minimum of 2,230.1. Volume amounted to 444.4 million shares, compared with 377.3 million shares Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Greyhound Credit Rating Drops as Drivers' Strike Continues
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 1st graf and INSERTS one graf after 10th graf, `George Gravley...' to UPDATE with Greyhound figures on service restoration. A version is moving on financial wire.
DOC.TEXT: The credit rating of Greyhound Lines Inc. dropped a notch as contract talks remained stalled and strike violence continued. But no one was injured in the latest round, and the company said it had enough replacement drivers to run 46 percent of it pre-strike schedule starting today. Shots from a small-caliber weapon damaged the driver's windshield of a Greyhound bus carrying 50 passengers Tuesday night southwest on Interstate 81 between Roanoke and Christiansburg in Virginia, police said. Standard & Poor's Corp., Wall Street's premier bond rating company, cited the walkout and a $380 million debt from a 1987 leveraged buyout when it downgraded Greyhound's rating Tuesday from B to B-. Contract talks in Arizona broke off over the weekend and had not been rescheduled. ``We wish they would be. The company walked away from the table about 10 a.m. Sunday, but the union stayed at the table,'' Nick Nichols, spokesman for the Amalgamated Council of Greyhound Local Unions, said Tuesday. ``As far as we are concerned, we are still at the table, waiting for them to come back,'' he said. Unions representing 6,300 drivers and an estimated 3,000 other Greyhound workers walked out March 2 over wages, job security and grievance procedures. Standard & Poor's Corp. said the strike ``initially halted most bus operations and has caused substantial losses.'' George Gravley, a spokesman for Dallas-based Greyhound, had little comment. ``We don't have anything to say about that. We have a good financial condition and we're not at all concerned,'' he said. ``I don't know why they did it. It doesn't change our plans at all.'' Replacement drivers allowed Greyhound to restore service today to 70 locations, mostly on the Boston-Washington corridor, or 46 percent of pre-strike schedule miles, the company said. ``Today, we're up to 1,514 (drivers),'' Gravley said. ``The first day we had around 300.'' Greyhound's new management has improved revenue generation and operating efficiency, but interest on the debt and rentals on leased buses ``remain a heavy burden,'' said Standard & Poor's. Virginia state Trooper E.R. Adams said he was not sure what type of gun was used in the latest shooting, but that it appeared the holes in the windshield were made by rounds from a small-caliber rifle. The bus, which left Roanoke about 10:15 p.m., was en route to the Christiansburg bus terminal at the time of the shooting, said Steve Mead, a spokesman for Greyhound in Dallas. ``This is carrying it just a little too far,'' said passenger Mark Lawson, who was riding the bus to Knoxville, Tenn. ``Why take it out on the passengers?'' Meanwhile, a replacement driver hired by the company and arrested by California police as a military deserter was turned over to Army authorities Tuesday, said a Del Norte County, Calif., sheriff's dispatcher. Martin Arthur Shaw, 28, of Portland, Ore., was arrested Saturday in Crescent City, Calif., after a California Highway Patrol officer pulled over the bus and discovered that Shaw was charged with deserting the Army, said police Sgt. Robert Munz. Greyhound hired Shaw on March 2 but had not completed his background review, company spokesman Steve Scarpino said.. Elsewhere, Superior Court Judge B.C. Ellis in Fayetteville, N.C., issued a temporary restraining order Tuesday against the union and Local 1493, prohibiting them from any illegal activity in the state. The company has obtained a total of 16 restraining orders against the union, said David Jones, vice president of Local 1493 in North Carolina. At least 14 other shooting attacks on Greyhound buses, 46 bomb threats and numerous other incidents of vandalism or threats have occurred during the walkout, company officials maintain.

DOC.HEAD: FDA Penalizes Abbott Labs for Quality Standards Violations
DOC.TEXT: The Food and Drug Administration has barred government agencies from buying certain drugs from Abbott Laboratories, charging the company failed to correct violations of quality standards at a suburban Chicago plant. The FDA also said it would not approve any new drug applications by the North Chicago-based pharmaceutical giant that involve certain products made in the plant. In a letter to Abbott dated March 14 but not released until Tuesday, the FDA said some of the company's products are adulterated because of improper manufacturing practices. The agency's district director in Chicago, Raymond Mlecko, said FDA investigators did not find unsterile products at the plant, but did see violations of federal manufacturing requirements. The letter warned that the FDA was prepared to take more severe measures, including seizing products and shutting down manufacturing operations, if Abbott did not quickly correct the alleged problems. Donald Wright, Abbott's corporate vice president of quality assurance, said the FDA action resulted from a misunderstanding about the extent to which the firm has worked to correct the problems. Wright said the problems should be remedied soon and would have no material effect on Abbott. A health industry analyst, Michael Harshbarger of Chicago Corp., said the FDA letter had ominous implications. ``This is not a slap on the wrist,'' he said. An FDA report in November cited the Abbott plant for failure to maintain proper sterilty, failure to follow up on quality problems and in at least one case, making improper changes in records designed to show that a drug was made in an approved manner. The drugs involved are an antibiotic called erythrocin lactobionate and a batch of an anti-inflammatory steroid sold under the brand name A-MethaPred that is given to patients in hospitals to treat severe arthritis and lupus _ a chronic inflammation of the tissue around the joints. Mlecko said there was no evidence that the problems pose any immediate public health risk.

DOC.HEAD: Investment Houses Halt New Underwriting To Help Support Market
DOC.TEXT: Japanese investment houses said Wednesday they temporarily had stopped underwriting new issues of stocks, bonds and warrants in an attempt to limit risks to investors until the sinking Tokyo stock market stabilizes. The unprecedented move, which affects capital-raising efforts by Japanese companies at home and overseas, follows a nearly 21 percent drop so far this year in the Tokyo Stock Exchange's 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average. Securities companies agreed Tuesday to halt underwriting of new convertible bonds, warrants and common stocks for at least one month, Nobuo Kurakazu, director of the securities division at Daiwa Securities Co., told The Associated Press. ``Many issues have already fallen below 100 yen (65 U.S. cents), which is abnormal,'' he said. Hiroshi Tanaka, chief of the underwriting division at Yamaichi Securities Co., said: ``We can no longer continue normal sales activities under the current market situation, where prices of stocks and bonds have kept sinking. ``It is best to halt the sales rather than keep selling those bonds when nobody is interested,'' he said, adding that demand for company bonds had been affected especially hard. By stopping the flow of additional shares into the market, the halt also could help prevent further weakening of prices caused by dilution. Japan's financial markets were closed Wednesday for the spring equinox holiday. On Monday, the Nikkei plunged 1,353.20 points, or 4.15 percent, its third-largest daily fall ever. It tumbled another 456.05 points, or 1.48 percent, on Tuesday to 30,807.19, the lowest since it closed at 30,678.39 on Jan. 9, 1989. The total value of securities listed on the Tokyo exchange has diminished by almost $600 billion this year, to $3.3 trillion by last Friday. Kurakazu said the decision to halt underwriting followed the Tokyo market's continuing plunges and uncertainty surrounding Tuesday's discount rate increase. The Bank of Japan raised its official discount rate, the key lending rate to commercial banks, by 1 percentage point to 5.25 percent in an effort to stem inflation and restabilize financial markets. Analysts said the bank was slow in raising the rate. They said the delay contributed to the plunge of the yen and stock and bond prices, prompting many companies to give up plans for raising capital. Mitsukoshi, Yasuda Trust and Banking Co. and the Bank of Miyazaki recently have canceled plans to raise capital by issuing new common stock. Also, Sumitomo Metal and Jujo Paper have decided to postpone plans for raising capital by issuing convertible bonds, local news reports said. Company officials were not available for comment on Wednesday. The price of Sumitomo Metal's convertibles plunged 21 yen in the last month, from 99.00 yen on Feb. 20 to 78.00 yen Tuesday. Japan Broadcasting Corp. estimated some 2.48 trillion convertible bonds were issued last year. Tanaka said the number of companies that postponed or canceled their plans for issuing new common stocks and bonds had increased since the beginning of March. Cancellations were especially heavy from overseas subsidiaries, he said.

The stock market was mixed today in light trading, buoyed by steadiness in blue-chip issues but restrained by profit-takers and an uncertain earnings outlook for a broad range of U.S. companies. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks was unchanged from Tuesday's close at 2,738.74 as of 3 p.m. EST. The broader market was lower. The broader markets are sluggish,'' said Paul Kronlokken, a technical stock analyst at Piper Jaffray & Hopwood, a Minneapolis investment firm. ``We're still holding to the view that the market's rise is intact, but the momentum may be in for some type of correction.'' DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Seizure of Illinois S&L Barred
DOC.TEXT: A judge today barred federal regulators from seizing an ailing Illinois thrift institution on the grounds the chief regulator had been unconstitutionally appointed. The decision could derail the government's massive savings and loan bailout. U.S. District Judge Royce C. Lamberth ordered the Treasury Department's Office of Thrift Supervision not to take over Olympic Federal Savings and Loan Association, Berwyn, Ill. until a new chief regulator is constitutionally installed in office. Royce ruled that both Salvatore R. Martoche, director of the office, and his immediate predecessor, M. Danny Wall, were unconstitutionally appointed. Under the bailout law, Wall inherited his office automatically when the predecessor agency he headed was abolished. Olympic argued this inheritance of office violated the constitutional provision that the president shall appoint, with the advice and consent of the Senate, ``all officers'' of the United States. Michael Robinson, a spokesman for the Justice Department, said the government asked the judge to stay his order and would appeal the ruling. Regulators had not moved to take over Olympic, but the thrift believed it was in imminent danger of seizure. Lamberth's decision could dramatically delay the seizure of some 200 other thrifts believed close to failure. Though the ruling applies only to Olympic, it also calls into question the legality of the takeover of 137 thrifts, with $97 billion in assets, since last Aug. 9, when President Bush signed the bailout law. The ruling likely would not affect the 265 S&Ls seized before Aug. 9, when Wall was the constitutionally appointed chairman of the now defunct Federal Home Loan Bank Board.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Rejects Tougher Smog Control Requirement
DOC.TEXT: The Senate today narrowly defeated an attempt to toughen controls on urban smog as part of a compromise clean air bill. It was the third major defeat for environmentalists seeking to strengthen the nation's main air pollution law. The vote was 53 to 46. Opponents of the smog-control measure, including Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, argued the overall bill under consideration already is a big improvement over current federal law and that stronger provisions could block passage this year. Sen. John Kerry, D-Mass., a key sponsor of the proposal, argued the amendment was needed to assure clean air in many of the cities that today suffer from the worst smog problems. The amendment would have preserved the federal government's authority to impose an air pollution reduction plan if states and local officials fail to act. It also would eliminate exemptions for some industrial polluters and broaden the smog-controlling curbs to include smaller polluters. The vote was the third major setback for environmentalists in the clean air debate. By a 52-46 vote Tuesday night, the Senate defeated a proposal to require tougher tailpipe-emission controls on automobiles, greater use of clean fuels by fleet operators and production of 1 million cars capable of burning alternative fuels. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, called the defeated amendment a ``prescription for deadlock'' on the clean air bill. ``Do we want 13 more years of speeches or do we want a bill? Do we want to make statements or do we want to make law?'' Mitchell said. Still unresolved was a proposal to give federal aid to coal miners who would lose their jobs as a result of the clean air measure _ a plan described by Senate leaders as a ``deal breaker.'' Sen. Robert C. Byrd, D-W.Va., is seeking $700 million in aid for the miners over four years if they lose their jobs because of tougher acid rain controls at coal-burning powerplants in the Midwest. The White House contends the assistance is too expensive. Sen. Timothy Wirth, D-Colo., said Tuesday that Byrd ``appears to have a majority of the votes'' for his proposal. However, an aide to Mitchell said it was uncertain whether the amendment would pass if it came to a vote. White House officials and Senate leaders were trying to work out a compromise with Byrd. Byrd for more than a decade has fought additional controls on sulfur dioxide from utility plants because such curbs would threaten the jobs of thousands of coal miners, including many in West Virginia where high-sulfur coal predominates. The clean air bill would set tough new pollution controls on industry and automobiles to reduce urban smog, cut toxic chemical emissions from industry and require electric utilities to reduce sulfur dioxide emissions by 10 million tons by the end of the decade. The auto pollution control amendment was sponsored by Wirth and Sen. Pete Wilson, R-Calif. Wirth argued his amendment was needed because autos ``are the biggest source of pollution in our cities.'' But senators backing the compromise bill insisted that passage of the tougher controls would threaten the legislation. ``It will bust the deal'' with the White House, said Sen. Max Baucus, D-Mont. The vote on the Wirth amendment revealed some of the maneuvering on the bill. Sen. Steven Symms, R-Idaho, was among some senators who voted for the tougher controls after arguing vigorously against the legislation for weeks. Senate sources suggested that Symms and other senators hoped to cripple the compromise bill by adding an amendment the White House would not accept. Environmentalists, meanwhile, said that while a number of votes are expected on other amendments intended to strengthen the clean air bill, the tougher auto pollution curbs were a top priority. Daniel Weiss of the Sierra Club accused the administration of ``ramming down the throats of the Senate'' a bill that does not go far enough to control urban smog. The vote was ``a good deal for General Motors and a terrible deal for the general public,'' said Gene Karpinski of the U.S. Public Interest Research Group. The automakers strongly opposed the tougher pollution controls, saying they would be required to manufacture alternative-fuel cars that customers might not want to buy. The measure also would require automakers to meet new tailpipe standards by the year 2003, although they say the technology to accomplish that does not exist.
