DOC.HEAD: Awaiting the Next Fad
DOC.TEXT: Somewhere out in the dim future a new stock market fad is developing, waiting to be discovered and exploited. You may be sure it will be, too, because the stock market needs stories _ call it excitement _ to generate in-out trading, the kind that produces the commissions that support the industry. Like astronomers scanning the heavens, the investment researchers are seeking a star, something to generate as much activity as the old takeover and junk bond crazes that seem to have burned out. Whatever they find will be seized upon by opportunists. New money-making geniuses will be presented to the investing public. New faces will grace the magazine covers. Drama will be pumped into a dull market. Sudden wealth will parade again, and the new stars will shine bright. They'll offer ways of doing things that'll make 1980s stars look like coal. They'll offer new concepts and visions; they'll scorn the old way. Nothing is certain about the future, of course, but if history means very much, the expectation just described has a very good chance of becoming the reality. It has happened over and over, so why not again? So many fads have come and gone they could fill a garbage truck: Fast food, conglomerates, real estate, construction, natural resources, South African mining, gold, energy, recession-proof stocks and inflation-proof stocks. There was a time when any company with a hard-sounding name _ with a K or an X or a Z in it _ was examined as a high-tech, high-flyer possibility. There was a time when cash-rich companies were simply takeover possibilities. Every month or so throughout the past 20 years there has been a new mutual fund created to seize upon fads within fads. Someone right now, for instance, is probably hatching a peace dividend fund. Most of the fads just faded. The rage over fast food stocks diminished after, so it seems, every hamlet in America was inhabited by a hamburger or fried chicken outlet and growth thereafter was based on such things as service and profits. The frantic search for companies with high-tech names lost its appeal when it was discovered that the names had to be accompanied by high-tech products or the stocks were worth hardly a dime. Some weren't. But, as many people recall, a lot of the fads went out with a blast. The rush to conglomerate stocks was one of the strongest of all movements, and it was supported by an outpouring of scholarly research, much of which concluded that one and one equaled three. The word synergy came into popular usage. Otherwise intelligent chief executive officers explained to shareholders that the acquisition of another company wouldn't just add new revenues but would enhance existing ones. Wall Street bought the idea and, in turn, so did the public, and conglomerates assumed some of the biggest price-earnings ratios ever seen in this century. The public fed them money and they bought even more companies. Then the public discovered that synergism wasn't always there, that one and one didn't make three, that earnings weren't enhanced and that, in some cases, the company had no reason for existence except to buy other companies. A couple of conglomerate bankruptcies then caught their attention, and sadly and probably not wiser they they returned to the old mathematics. The biggest blast of all, of course, may be the most recent, the collapse of the junk bond market and the slowing of the takeover frenzy. In dollar terms, it most certainly is the biggest collapse of any of the fads. Based on recent history, however, this collapse is no reason for an end to fads. The short-term mentality, the greed, the urgency of the kill still pervade the market. Nobody can say what the new fad will be, but you won't have to wait long. With the geography, economics and politics of the world rearranged in the last few years, the possibilities are many. How about Russian stocks?

DOC.HEAD: With BC-Diamonds
DOC.TEXT: Here are answers to commonly asked questions about diamonds. What are diamonds? Diamonds are crystallized carbon which has been subjected to prolonged, steady heat and pressure. They were formed up to 120 miles under the earth's crust billions of years ago. Where are diamonds usually found? Diamonds were brought to the earth's surface by volcankc eruptions, so they are found in volcanic rocks known as kimberlite and lamproite, as well as scattered in river beds, swamps and on beaches. Diamonds are mined in about 20 countries. Australia is the biggest producer in terms of volume, or 35 million carats in 1988. In terms of value however, Soviet Union, is considered No. 1, although the value of its production is a secret. How are diamonds mined? Diamonds are obtained largely through underground mining or via a dredging process. Diamond-embedded rocks are squeezed to allow the diamonds to roll free. Slurry is put in water and the heavier diamonds sink to the bottom. When were diamonds discovered? About 2,500 years ago, in India. They were thought to have special protective powers, worn in arm amulets and placed in sword hilts. Can diamonds be manufactured? Yes. General Electric Co. developed a method of synthesizing diamonds in the 1950s, but experts say natural ones are best. How are diamonds graded? By carat weight, clarity, color, and cut. A carat is 200 milligrams. There more than 5,000 categories of diamonds, and the colorless, clear diamonds are the most valued, although blues and pinks are highly prized. In what shapes are diamonds cut? The most popular cut is brilliant, a round-shape with 57 facets. Other classic cuts are pear, oval, marquise, and emerald. New cuts such as the heart shape have been introduced in recent years. How much do diamonds cost? Prices vary considerably, but the wholesale price of the highest grade one-carat gem is about $16,000. Does diamond jewelry appreciate in value? Sometimes, over a long period of time. But people don't tend to buy diamonds as a financial investment. What is the world's largest diamond? The Star of Africa, a 74-facet, 530.2-carat pear gem placed in Britain's Royal Sceptre. It was found in a mine in Pretoria, South Africa, cut in 1908 and presented to King Edward VII. Why do women wear diamond engagement rings? The diamond became a symbol of conjugal fidelity because of its resistance and endurance. It was introduced into European wedding ritual in the 15th century. Who sang ``Diamonds Are a Girl's Best Friend?'' Marilyn Monroe, in the title song of the 1949 movie ``Gentlemen Prefer Blondes.''

DOC.HEAD: Copper Futures Surge On Canadian Strike Fears
DOC.TEXT: Copper futures prices surged to new five-month highs Wednesday on New York's Commodity Exchange on speculation that union workers at a large Canadian smelter would reject a management contract offer, setting the stage for a strike. On other commodity markets, precious metals were mixed; petroleum futures advanced; grains and soybeans were mostly lower; and livestock and meat futures were mixed. Copper futures settled 1.05 cents to 4.6 cents higher in New York with the contract for delivery in March at $1.326 a pound, the highest near-month copper price since Oct. 13. About 700 workers at Noranda Inc.'s Horne copper smelter near Rouyn, Quebec began voting on management's final contract offer Wednesday afternoon, the company said. Results of the voting were not expected until Thursday. Analysts said the heavy buying in the futures market indicated traders expected the Canadian workers to reject the proposed pact, which would succeed a three-year contract that expired Feb. 22. Workers at the Horne smelter went on strike in November 1986 for almost four months in support of their contract demands. A Noranda strike at this time would exacerbate an already tight supply situation in the copper market, analysts said. Copper users already face the possibility of supply disruptions from a 10-day-old strike at Peru's largest copper company, the Southern Peru Copper Corp, where workers walked out on March 12. The Noranda smelter produces about 180,000 tons of copper a year. ``If you don't get that production, especially in a very tight market, it would be significant,'' said analyst Bette Raptopoulos of Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. Peter Cardillo, commodity trading adviser with Josephthal & Co., said heightened tensions within the Soviet Union also supported copper futures. Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev on Wednesday ordered citizens in the breakaway Lithuanian republic to hand over their weapons to Soviet authorities. Cardillo said copper typically attracts buying on political crises. The gold and silver futures markets registered little reaction to the Soviet developments. Gold extended Tuesday's steep decline while silver futures edged higher on the Commodity Exchange. Gold settled 40 cents to $1.40 lower with April at $392.50 a troy ounce; silver was 1 cent to 1.2 cents higher with March at $5.055 a troy ounce. Petroleum futures advanced on the New York Mercantile Exchange with refined products up sharply in light of Tuesday's weekly American Petroleum Institute inventory report, which showed large drawdowns in heating oil and gasoline stocks and only a slight rise in crude oil inventories. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 7 cents lower to 19 cents higher with May at $19.96 a barrel; heating oil was .24 cent to 1.19 cents higher with April at 55.54 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .60 cent to 1.24 cents higher with April at 57.94 cents a gallon. Some of the activity was tied to the noontime expiration of contracts for March deliveries of wheat, corn, oats, soybeans and soybean products as traders switched their positions to later contract months to avoid delivery obligations. DOC.HEAD: Senators Defeat Third Attempt to Toughen Clean Air Compromise
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS two grafs after 9th graf pvs, But Mitchell, with Sierra Club comment; SUBS 10th graf pvs to CORRECT Thursday to Tuesday; picks up 11th graf pvs, Earlier, a
DOC.TEXT: The Senate turned back a third attempt to strengthen the compromise clean air bill on Wednesday, defeating a proposal supporters said would close ``loopholes'' in the battle against urban smog. Opponents argued the amendement, which lost on a 53-46 vote, would burden too many small businesses with expensive pollution controls and require unnecessary federal involvement in urban air pollution plans. The vote marked the third unsuccessful attempt by a group of senators, mainly from urban areas with the dirtiest air, to add tougher environmental controls to a compromise bill worked out between Senate leaders and the White House. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, argued on each vote that the compromise bill already goes far beyond current federal pollution control laws and that compromises are needed to win approval in the Senate. But Sen. John Kerry, D-Mass., one of the key sponsors of the proposal, argued the amendment would only retain requirements in current pollution laws that are necessary to clean up the air in scores of cities so they meet federal health standards. The provisions were weakened during negotiations on the compromise legislation. Kerry's proposal would have preserved the federal government's authority to impose air pollution reduction plans if states and local officials failed to act. It also sought to eliminate waivers _ based on expense _ for some industrial polluters and broaden the smog-controlling curbs to include smaller polluters. Kerry said a clean air bill without the amendment ``would legalize new loopholes for delay'' in getting cities to meet air quality standards. But Mitchell said, ``This is a small business killer amendment.'' Senate leaders fought all three environmental amendments, arguing they threaten the agreement with the White House and could jeopardize passage of a clean air bill altogether. Environmentalists said they would now focus on the House, where a clean air bill is still in committee, in their attempt to strengthen curbs on smog-causing pollutants. In defeating the Kerry amendment, ``the Senate voted to shred the environmental safety net of the Clean Air Act,'' said Daniel Weiss of the Sierra Club. On Tuesday night, the Senate by 52-46 rejected a plan to tighten automobile emissions controls and require broader use of alternative fuels, including production of 1 million clean-fuel vehicles by the ed of the decade. Earlier, a proposal which would have required a reduction in toxic chemical emissions from automobiles fell by 65-33. Opponents of Kerry's smog amendment said the provisions were not needed. Sen. Max Baucus, D-Mont., said the Environmental Protection Agency has for nearly 20 years had authority to force federal smog-control plans on states and cities, but has never done so. But supporters argued the threat of federal intervention has prompted states and local officials to act. ``It was under pressure, under fear of the threat of federal (action)'' that authorities in southern California toughened pollution control, said Sen. Pete Wilson, R-Calif. And others said federal oversight may be the only way to deal with pollution that affects several states. A regional plan to curb smog in the Chicago area, which also affected air quality in Wisconsin, ``came about only by the EPA forcing the threat of a federal implementation plan,'' said Sen. Robert Kasten,R-Wis. Another provision of the amendment called for emission controls to apply to industrial polluters that emit more than 25 tons of pollution a year, instead of the 100 tons in the compromise agreement. Kerry argued the higher cutoff would allow polluters responsible for nearly half of the industrial smog-causing pollutants in cities to avoid the tougher controls. The amendment also would have eliminated a provision in the compromise bill to allow states to waive federal air quality standards if pollution controls would cost more than $5,000 a ton.

DOC.HEAD: If Everything Equal, BAT Would Favor Management Bids
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead and ADDS 1 new graf after 6th graf pvs, `Management of ...' to clarify BAT position on bids.
DOC.TEXT: British conglomerate BAT Industries PLC said Wednesday it might favor management bids for its U.S. retailers, including the Saks Fifth Avenue and Marshall Field chains, but not at stockholders' expense. Te company also posted a 38 percent jump in its 1989 net profit, boosted by record earnings from the group's tobacco interests and a near doubling of earnings at its financial services division. BAT has put its U.S. retail chains on the auction block as part of a defensive strategy against a $21 billion hostile bid from Hoylake Investments Ltd., an investor group led by British-French financier Sir James Goldsmith. BAT Chairman Patrick Sheehy said at a news conference that he had received a first round of offers for Saks Fifth Avenue, which operates 46 stores, and Marshall Field & Co., with 23 stores, and that he expects to announce the winning bids by the end of April. Sheehy said he also expects to announce the successful bidders for BAT's other U.S. retailers, Breuners and Ivey's, in the next couple of weeks. Breuners operates 61 furniture and home furnishings stores on the West Coast and Ivey's has 23 department stores in North and South Carolina and Florida. Management of all four chains have proposed buying their companies, and ``if all things were equal we would favor a management bid,'' Sheehy said. He cited continuity and concern for the retailers' communities as the reason. In a statement issued after the news conference, Sheehy said: ``BAT welcomes these management initiatives, but its primary obligation must be to shareholders.'' BAT said its net profit for the 12 months ended Dec. 31 came to the equivalent of $2.07 billion, up 38 percent from $1.5 billion in 1988. Last year's profit included a $197 million one-time gain from restructurings. Earnings per share came to $1.23 compared with $1.01 dollars. Annual sales increased 25 percent to $35 billion from $28 billion. The company didn't break out full quarterly results. It isn't required to under British law. Sheehy described the results as excellent in light of the ``distractions forced on us by Hoylake.'' ``The performance from financial services and tobacco is particularly significant because they are the businesses which will dominate the continuing group in the future,'' Sheehy said. Under BAT's restructuring designed to fight off the Hoylake bid, the company is shrinking itself in two areas: tobacco and financial services. In addition to selling the retailers, BAT will float its big paper interests as a new company later this year. The Hoylake bid has been suspended while U.S. state insurance regulators review the effect a change of ownership would have on BAT's Farmers Insurance Group Inc. of Los Angeles.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Futures Rise
DOC.TEXT: Energy futures prices jumped Wednesday, boosted by the latest industry statistics that showed a decline in oil product inventories. Heating oil for April delivery surged 1.19 cents to 55.54 cents a gallon on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The May heating oil contract advanced 0.74 cent to 53.51 cents while contracts for later delivery had smaller increases. Wholesale unleaded gasoline for delivery in April gained 0.63 cent to finish at 57.94 cents a gallon, May unleaded gasoline rose 1.24 cents to 62.45 cents and June added 1.02 cents to match at 62.45 cents. Crude oil, which got support from the product markets, posted smaller gains despite negative API statistics. The May contract for West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of crude oil, rose 19 cents to $19.96 a barrel. June rose 15 cents to $20.20 and July advanced 12 cents to $20.36 a 42-gallon barrel. Analysts said the American Petroleum Institute weekly inventory report showed a sharp decline in gasoline and heating oil stocks despite the seasonally weak demand period and strong crude oil production by OPEC. The report from API, the oil industry trade association that represents major oil refiners, showed that total gasoline stocks fell 2.6 million barrels in the week ended March 16 to 241 million barrels. Unleaded gasoline stocks fell 2.7 million barrels to 182.8 million barrels. Distillate fuel supplies dropped 4.2 million barrels to 105.9 million, while crude oil inventories rose 188,000 barrels to 350.9. ``The general trend in the market was up all day,'' said Richard Redoglio, energy analyst with Merrill Lynch Energy Futures. ``The APIs set the tone for the day.'' Analysts attributed the decline in inventories to refinery ``turnarounds,'' when oil companies selectively slow or shut down refineries for annual maintenance before the spring and summer travel rush. Demand for crude oil usually slows during this period because refiners don't need as much to make gasoline and other products.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: The stock market finished lower Wednesday in light trading, weakened by profit-takers and an uncertain earnings outlook for a broad range of U.S. companies. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials lost 10.81 points at 2,727.93. Declining issues outnumbered advancing ones by about 3 to 2 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 870 down, 582 up and 513 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board totaled a weak 130.99 million shares, down from 177.32 million in Tuesday's session. Stocks were mixed through most of the lackluster session, and the bulk of the loss occurred just before the closing bell. Brokers attributed the decline partly to profit-takers worried about the endurance of the market's recent strength, particularly in the face of stunning weakness in the other major world stock market, Japan. Last week, the Dow average gained a net 57.89 points to 2,741.22, its highest level since early January. The advance continued on Monday, as the blue-chip barometer picked up another 14.41 points. But it stalled in Tuesday's trading and the retreat was extended Wednesday. ``The market is even-keel,'' said Larry Wachtel, an analyst for Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. ``After a substantial runup, the overall market has quieted down.'' Analysts also said first-quarter earnings of many U.S. companies, due early next month, could show worse-than-expected results that would depress the value of American stocks. The Tokyo stock market, which plunged on Monday and Tuesday, had a respite Wednesday for a national holiday. New York traders have been closely watching the weakening yen, which has fueled inflation in Japan and forced the central bank to raise its key interest rate by 1 percentage point on Tuesday. Actively traded NYSE issues Wednesday included Citicorp, up \ to 24 on volume of more than 1 million shares. John Reed, chairman of the biggest U.S. bank, told securities analysts Tuesday he expected earnings to triple by the mid- to late 1990s. Among other briskly traded bank stocks, Chase Manhattan fell [ to 27[, Bank of New England tumbled [ to 5 and Shawmut National rose \ to 14~. General Electric was down \ at 64[, Philip Morris slipped [ to 38~ and Homestake was unchanged at 19}. Upjohn surged 1[ to 38}, AT&T was up [ at 41~ and American Express rose [ to 27}. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 161.00 million shares. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market lost $14.52 billion, or 0.44 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks declined 0.89 to 186.82. Standard & Poor's industrial index fell 2.22 to 394.23, and S&P's 500-stock composite index lost 1.83 at 339.74. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market slipped 0.78 to 439.30. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down 0.27 at 363.15.

DOC.HEAD: USX Says Pitfalls In USX Split
DOC.TEXT: Takeover strategist Carl Icahn's proposal to split USX Corp.'s energy and steel businesses would weaken the company's borrowing power and make it more vulnerable to business downturns, USX said Wednesday. Icahn, USX's largest shareholder, wants the company to incorporate its steel division into an independent, publicly traded compay to be known as U.S. Steel Corp. and spin off 80 percent of it. USX management opposes the proposal but has agreed to put it to a non-binding vote of shareholders at its May 7 annual meeting in Findlay, Ohio. Icahn's plan is ``a simplistic approach to a complicated issue,'' the company's directors said in a proxy statement mailed to USX's 144,000 shareholders Wednesday. The statement concerns issues to be voted on at the annual meeting. The directors recommended shareholders reject the proposal, saying it is unnecessary and unwise. About 65 percent of USX's revenue comes from its energy division, while about 31 percent comes from steel, said USX spokesman William Keslar. The company said a spin-off would involve ``complex tax, legal and business issues.'' USX Chairman Charles A. Corry told Wall Street analysts last week that splitting the company would result in tax difficulties. Icahn, who has a 13.26 percent stake in USX, has long been unhappy with USX management and believes the company's stock price is too low. He had argued in favor of selling Marathon. Icahn, chairman of Trans World Airlines Inc., has said he will spend $5 million to $10 million on an intensive campaign to persuade shareholders to approve the resolution. USX said in the past decade, USX acquired about $10 billion in assets _ mostly energy related _ disposed of $7 billion of assets and businesses and wrote off about $3.5 billion, mostly in steel. USX said it has emerged ``as a strong energy company while remaining the largest and among the most profitable domestic integrated steel companies.'' The company said approval of Icahn's proposal could limit USX's flexibility in considering other alternatives that may be in the best interest of shareholders.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mixed, Gold Off Slightly
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 13th graf, Other late... to CORRECT trend on French franc to up sted down. Picks up 14th graf, Selected rates...
DOC.TEXT: The dollar finished mixed against major currencies in slow trading Wednesday. Buying of dollars as a safe investment haven lent some strength to the U.S. currency. Gold prices posted minor declines in domestic dealings after much larger losses overseas. On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold for March delivery settled at $391.80 a troy ounce, 40 cents lower than Tuesday. Later Republic National Bank of New York quoted a bid of $391.90 for a troy ounce of gold, 50 cents lower than Tuesday's late bid. Foreign exchange dealers said the dollar drifted steadily higher against certain foreign currencies in part because of escalating tensions in Lithuania, which declared its independence from the Soviet Union on March 11. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Wednesday ordered Lithuanians to turn in their weapons, a day after the Baltic republic's government demanded an end to Soviet military maneuvers. Investors frequently buy dollars in times of political uncertainty outside the United States. The cloudy outlook for Britain's governing Conservatives and the failure of the Japanese yen to rise despite Monday's 1 percentage point hike in the country's key interest rates also spurred interest in the dollar. Confidence in Britain's business-oriented Conservative Party, in power for nearly 11 years, has been shaken by rising prices, high interest rates, the deterioration of the government-run health service and a new tax on every adult to finance municipal services. The annual budget statement by Chancellor of the Exchequer John Major on Tuesday was criticized by currency dealers as too soft on inflation. They said it threatened a possible further increase in the current 15 percent base interest rate. One British pound was quoted at $1.5955 late in New York, a weakening from late Tuesday's $1.6005. The pound closed in London on Wednesday at $1.5965, cheaper for buyers than Tuesday's late $1.6105. It stood at $1.7145 on Feb. 22. One dollar bought 154.365 Japanese yen late in New York, slightly more than 154.20 yen late Tuesday. In London, the dollar traded late at 154 Japanese yen, compared with 153.65 in Tokyo at Tuesday's close. Tokyo markets were closed for the Spring Equinox Day national holiday. Earl I. Johnson, a vice president at Harris Bank in Chicago, said activity in the dollar was subdued, lacking significant corporate or interbank trading. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late quotes Tuesday, included: 1.7100 West German marks, up from 1.7048; 1.5225 Swiss francs, unchanged; 5.768 French francs, up from 5.7575; 1,259.75 Italian lire, up from 1,258.00; and 1.17875 Canadian dollars, up from 1.17765. Selected rates for the dollar late in European compared with late Tuesday's levels were: 1.7070 West German marks, up from 1.6965; 1.5192 Swiss francs, up from 1.5157; 5.7575 French francs, up from 5.7340; 1.9230 Dutch guilders, up from 1.9107; 1,257.25 Italian lire, up from 1,253.50; and 1.1769 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1792. Gold bullion prices were on the slide again after creeping above $400 an ounce on Monday. Dealers said the metal's outlook was uncertain after a number of investors unloaded from their holdings on Tuesday when the dollar rallied. Gold closed in London, the major foreign market, at a bid of $391.75 a troy ounce, down from $398. The closing bid price in Zurich was $391.50, down from $399.25. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold closed at $393.65 bid, down from $401.15. Silver was mixed. In New York, silver bullion for March delivery closed at $5.055 a troy ounce, up from Tuesday's settlement of $5.043. Silver bullion traded late in London at $5.06, down from Tuesday's late bid of $5.09.

DOC.HEAD: Scotsman Sells Sand to Saudis
DOC.TEXT: Don't tell Scottish farmer John Keddie the last thing Saudi Arabia needs is sand. He's selling a pile of it to the desert kingdom. ``The Saudis have a lot of sand but it is the wrong shape,'' he said. The Saudis want tons of Keddie's sand to use in filtration systems for water supplies and in swimming pool filters. ``Their sand is too round. Ours is cuboid with the corners rubbed off. Ours is also very hard so it doesn't break down in the filters,'' said the farmer. Keddie grows oilseed rape and wheat on 600 acres at Alloa near the Forth river in southeast Scotland. He said he investigated the potential of his local sand two years ago and made his first sale for glass-making when he found he could no longer keep going by farming alone.

DOC.HEAD: Names New Chairman
DOC.TEXT: The Boston Co., which revealed last year it had overstated profits, announced Wednesday that George W. Phillips would resign as chairman, replaced by one of the company's executives. The action came in the aftermath of a top-level shakeup at Boston Co.'s parent firm, Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., which has named a new chairman and chief executive. Boston Co. said John Laird has been proposed as new chairman and chief executive officer, effective April 20. Laird, 47, joined the company last September after working as an executive at American Express, which acquired controlling interest in Shearson in 1981. ``John was very successful while at American Express and at all times was supportive of American Express' traditional values,'' Howard L. Clark Jr., Shearson Lehman's chief executive, said in a statement. Clark also served as an executive at American Express. The Boston Co., the parent of Boston Safe Deposit & Trust Co., reported in January 1989 that it had overstated profits for the first three quarters of 1988 by $30 million. At the time, Shearson officials said the overstatement involved no misuse of company or client funds. Nonetheless, Boston Co.'s parent firm apparently saw no need to make changes until Shearson's new leadership stepped in, said Perrin Long, who follows the financial industry for Lipper Analytical Services in New York. ``The former (Shearson) management might have been dragging their feet,'' he said. In the company statement, Phillips, 52, said he looked back at his 28 years with The Boston Co. ``with considerable pride.'' ``However, I look forward to new challenges and take great comfort in the strong management team which I leave behind at the company,'' he said. William J. Nutt will continue as president of The Boston Co. and chairman and chief executive officer of Boston Safe Deposit & Trust.

DOC.HEAD: Dodd Favors Giving Stock-Index Future Control to SEC
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of a Senate subcommittee that oversees the Securities and Exchange Commission said Wednesday he is willing to add a curb on program trading to pending legislation. Sen. Christopher Dodd, D-Conn., also said he favors giving the SEC authority to regulate stock-index futures. Legislation that would give the SEC new powers to halt trading in emergencies and keep tabs on the financial health of brokerage houses' parent companies is awaiting floor action in both the House and Senate. But the House version contains a provision allowing the SEC to restrain program trading, the computerized trading of large blocks of stocks based on price differences between the securities and stock-index futures markets. The Senate version does not. Dodd said that after talking with SEC Chairman Richard C. Breeden, who did not seek _ but says he can live with _ the program trading amendement, ``if that's the case, then we can either add something on the floor as a floor amendment or wait until conference'' with the House on a final verison of a bill. Dodd, chairman of the Senate Banking Committee's subcommittee on securities, said he doesn't want to ``dismember'' the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, which currently oversees stock-index futures. Rather, he told a news conference in his Senate office, ``My inclination is to be supportive of taking stock-index futures and moving them over under the jurisdiction of the SEC.'' Dodd conceded that such a move would meet opposition by congressional supporters of the CFTC, which is under the control of House and Senate agriculture committees. ``While from a theoretical standpoint, it has made some sense to me to move in that direction, our job now is that the committee must examine the practicalities of that,'' Dodd said. Stock-index futures are financial products that allow investors to speculate on stock indexes such as the Standard & Poors 500 without buying the underlying stocks. The Senate Banking Committee has scheduled a hearing next week on which federal agency should set minimum standards for margins _ the down payments investors must make to purchase securities or futures on credit. The Federal Reserve now sets margins for the stock markets while the futures exchanges themselves set margins in their industry. Critics argue that wide disparities between securities and futures margins have caused _ or least worsened _ heavy trading in stock-index futures. Some people believe the disparity causes sharp price fluctuations in the markets. Witnesses at the March 29 hearing are scheduled to include SEC Chairman Richard C. Breeden and CFTC Chairman Wendy Gramm, as well as Fed Chairman Alan Greenspan. Some House members are exploring possible legislation to merge both agencies into one super agency. Dodd called that plan ``an interesting discussion but I certainly haven't drawn any conclusion that it makes any sense at all.''

DOC.HEAD: Continental Taps Wells Rich Greene As its News Ad Agency
DOC.TEXT: Continental Airlines has selected Wells Rich Greene to handle its $40 million to $50 million advertising account. The selection, announced Tuesday, followed a review that involved five agencies in the wake of Continental's decision in January to end its three-year association with another New York-based ad agency, N.W. Ayer. The other agencies considered for the assignment were J. Walter Thompson, Lintas:New York, TBWA Advertising inc. and Hal Riney & Partners Inc. James V. O'Donnell, senior vice president for marketing programs at Houston-based Continental, said Wells Rich Greene won the assignment because ``they seemed to offer us what we were looking for.'' He said the agency offered creative excellence as well as ``a level of enthusiasm and commitment'' needed for what normally is a demanding and time-consuming job. In addition, he said the company felt the agency could help it shape its services to better satisfy customer demand. O'Donnell said the airline is working to increase its share of the business travel market and to expand international service. Wells Rich Greene previously worked for Continental Airlines in 1981 and 1982, and also has worked at various times for Braniff, Pan Am and TWA, O'Donnell said. But he said it was not that work as much as Wells Rich's recent work for MCI Communications Corp. telephone service, Hertz rental cars and International Business Machines Corp. that convinced Continental to hire the agency. He said the first advertising work from Continental's new agency should start showing up in May. O'Donnell declined to comment on reports that Thompson dropped out of the running for the account because it demanded that Continental pay in advance for media placement.

DOC.HEAD: Braniff Says Purchase Agreement with Holding Company Canceled
DOC.TEXT: Braniff Inc. said Wednesday it terminated an agreement to sell some of the airline's assets because the intended buyer did not meet a $1 million payment deadline. Coastal Maine Holdings Corp. had asked the U.S. Bankruptcy Court in Orlando for authorization to buy Braniff's flight certificates, operating manuals and trademarks. The agreement was announced last week. ``They didn't come up with $1 million'' by 5 p.m. last Friday, said Irma Ellis, a Braniff spokeswoman in Dallas. Braniff chief executive David Murchison said the Orlando-based airline will seek new buyers for the assets. Coastal Maine officials did not immediately return a call seeking comment. The Jacksonville-based company has operations from oil production to shoe sales. A Coastal Maine spokesman said last week the company wanted to operate commuter flights in Orlando, Kansas City, Mo., and Baltimore under the Braniff name. Coastal Maine was seeking to build on a small commuter carrier it recently bought, Cumberland, Md.-based Cumberland Airlines. Braniff filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection last September and has virtually stopped flying and laid off most of its 4,800 employees.

DOC.HEAD: Company Tells SEC It May Have To File for Bankruptcy Protection
DOC.TEXT: Western Union Co. told federal regulators Wednesday it may have to seek bankruptcy court protection if it cannot meet mounting debt interest payments. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Western Union said if it cannot raise additional funds, it probably will not be able to make $51 million in interest payments on $530 million in outstanding notes due June 15. The notes, which carry interest rates of 19.25 percent and 16 percent, are due to mature June 15, 1991. Failure to meet interest payments would result in default. Western Union also said in the filing that the SEC is conducting an inquiry into the timing of write-downs against company earnings in the first quarter of 1988. Western Union said it is cooperating with the inquiry. Company spokesman Warren Bechtel said the SEC has questioned actions leading up to the restructuring charge, which he said took place under previous management. Bechtel also said that as part of its agreement with U.S. Trust Co. of New York, the trustee overseeing the 19.25 percent notes, Western Union's consolidated capital must not fall below a certain level. If that requirement is not met for two consecutive quarters, Western Union must repurchase $100 million of worth of its outstanding notes, he said. Western Union told the SEC it could fall below the preordained level by March 31, the end of the first quarter. ``But it's just a possiblity down the road,'' Bechtel said. ``It's not something that exists.'' Bechtel said the company wants to restructure its debt before the June 15 deadline on the $51 million in interest payments _ $48 million on $500 million in 19.25 percent notes and $3 million on the 16 percent notes. The payments are due twice a year. Western Union said in the filing it may offer to exchange the notes for new securities with lower interest rates and longer repayment schedules. If it cannot restructure, Western Union may use the options of raising money through a public offering of stock or by selling its assets quickly, the company said in the filing. Without the restructuring, the company could default and that ``could force Western Union to seek protection under the U.S. bankruptcy code,'' the company said. Western Union took special charges of $603 million in the 1988 first quarter connected with the planned unloading of the company's microwave voice-switching facilities. Western Union has exited the business of providing communications facilities to focus on specialized business and consumer services, but the company has continued to struggle, reporting $32 million in losses in 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Bank Revises 1989 Earnings To Show Loss After Federal Examination
DOC.TEXT: Shawmut National Corp. revised its 1989 earnings to show a $128.9 million loss after federal regulators found the bank's reserves for losses from real estate loans were inadequate, according to a published report Thursday. Shawmut, one of New England's largest banking companies, in January reported a profit of $201.7 million for last year. More than 170 federal bank examiners spent six weeks studying the bank's records before the company decided that its reserves to protect against bad real estate loans were too small, The New York Times reported. The move was the latest sign that the government is being more critical than usual in judging bank real estate loans. Examinations of real estate lending led to a $1.1 billion loss at Bank of New England Corp. earlier this year. After the review, Shawmut, which is based in Boston and Hartford and has more than 400 branches, nearly doubled the size of its reserves for loan losses at the end of 1989 to $739 million from $383 million, the Times said. Increases in loan loss reserves are subtracted from earnings, or from capital in the case of a loss. The bank's nonperforming loans, which are not paying interest or face other troubles, rose to $1.045 billion from $535.6 million. The bank was surprised by the federal examiners' findings, the newspaper said. Shawmut had increased its reserves to cover losses on real estate loans for commercial projects, eliminating almost all of its fourth-quarter profits. Shawmut said it expects to earn about $40 million, or 54 cents a share, in the first quarter. It also warned that nonperforming loans would rise along with reserves for loan losses.
